HEADLINE: New York Restaurateur Plots A Resurrection in Budapest

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, May 13

 BODY:
George Lang, the Hungarian-born New York restaurateur, thinks of life in graphic terms. Some people, he says, have a life that goes up and down. With the purchase of Gundel's, a revered relic of Budapest's culinary belle epoque, his will have come full circle.
"Forgive me for such a horrifying cliche," Mr. Lang said one recent balmy evening as he sat out on the terrace behind the palatial restaurant, "but the whole story is like a fairy tale, complete with evil spirits and a magic wand." 
 In 1936, when Mr. Lang was 15 years old, he and his father came to Budapest from the provincial town of Szekesfehervar and stopped for a meal at Gundel's. It was his first time in a fashionable restaurant and his first taste of Gundel's famous palacsinta, pancakes stuffed with crushed walnuts and topped with hot chocolate and rum.
More than half a century later, the memory of the rum was so vivid that Mr. Lang paused while telling his story -- but only for a minute. The man who came to the United States in 1946 as a violinist, worked in a kitchen and went on to become a renowned restaurant designer, a caterer and the owner of Cafe des Artistes in Manhattan, is now consumed by a new dream: to recapture the spirit of the old Gundel's, once a centerpiece of Austro-Hungarian cuisine.
Karoly Gundel (pronounced GOON-del), son of a Budapest hotelier, opened Gundel's in 1910. Mr. Gundel turned the restaurant on the edge of City Park, next to the zoo, into an elaborate, elegant gathering spot -- big enough for banquets, balls and outdoor operas, but manageable enough to serve some of the best food east of Vienna.
When the Communists came to power after World War II, Gundel's became the property of the state and was incorporated into the Hungarhotel chain, a fate that eventually led to the virtual collapse of its old reputation. Now, on the eve of its transformation back into a privately owned restaurant, Gundel's is known as a tourist and catering restaurant, and not a very good one.
Last Thursday, touring the restaurant, with its partitioned "function rooms" and giant kitchens, Mr. Lang kept a running list of the damage done by 40 years of Communist management. "This, of course, had to be completely redone, rethought," he said of the cheap wood paneling and plastic fixtures in the Bagolyvar, an extension built to resemble an old-fashioned Transylvanian lodge.
"Of course, I will tear down all this garbage," he said, pointing to a flimsy second-floor addition done in a style he called "neo-brutalismo."
Though connected to the main restaurant, the Bagolyvar is around the corner from it, and on the street corner between the two stands a two-story building with brown-tinted windows. It was built in 1975 to house offices and the test kitchen for the Hungarhotel chain. Mr. Lang calls it a knife in his heart, and is pondering ways to disguise or, possibly, remove it.
He prefers to talk about his ideas: a crystal pavillion in the back of the garden, a Transylvanian menu for the Bagolyvar, an orchestra, an English club-style casino on the upper floor, a wine-tasting room in the cellar, a shop where Gundel products -- goose livers, wines and paprika -- will be sold.
"I can't say I can take Gundel's back to its old glory," Mr. Lang said. "But what I have to try to do is to do what Karoly Gundel would do if he were alive today."
How Mr. Lang came to take possession of Gundel's -- the formal signing ceremonies are still a few weeks away -- is a story that will no doubt become part of the restaurant's legend. It began 14 months ago, when Mr. Lang and Ronald Lauder, the cosmetics empire heir who has taken a keen interest in Eastern Europe, formed L & L Partners to bid for a half share in the restaurant. The other half was to belong to the Government.
Although Hungary, like the rest of Eastern Europe, is trying to privatize its economy with help from foreign investors, there are limits to what the state is willing to sell outright. Initially, one limit was Gundel's, a restaurant so closely linked to Budapest's glory years that as Mr. Lang put it, it had acquired status as a national treasure, ranking only behind the Crown of St. Stephen.
The first proposal by the State Property Agency, which is charged with the privatization of the Hungarian economy, called for an $8 million investment to pay for the restaurant's restoration, a sum that the American investors first thought would be split with the state. It turned out they were wrong: the entire $8 million was to come from the investors, with the state's share delivered in the form of the property itself.
"I cried, I laughed, and told them I would hang myself from the Chain Bridge," Mr. Lang said. "But they were absolutely firm. They desperately need the money, and they want to get it where they can."
Determined, Mr. Lang agreed and the final deal was all but sealed one day last February, when Mr. Lang was abruptly summoned to the telephone. "Suddenly, they were offering 100 percent ownership," he said. "I was absolutely speechless."
Mr. Lang, who had negotiated hard and unsuccessfully for at least 51 percent, immediately jumped at the offer. By the next morning, he had handed over a revised proposal, which was promptly approved by the State Property Agency.
Technically, Gundel's was open to other bids during the entire negotiations. But Mr. Lang said no other offers came in, apparently because word of his involvement had spread.
Typically, Mr. Lang works on 20 to 30 projects at one time. To bring Gundel's back to life, he dropped everything else for six months, leaving his wife, Jenifer, to run Cafe des Artists, the popular restaurant at 1 West 67th Street.
Toward the end of the final negotiations, he threw a party at Gundel's for Budapest's intelligentsia -- a group he dubbed the Gundel Regulars. The guests of honor included the Hungarian President, Arpad Goncz, Sir Georg Solti, the Chicago Symphony conductor, who had just made a triumphant return to his homeland, and the novelist George Konrad.
Dessert that night was a white-and-black chocolate crossword puzzle with the words "Gundel Regulars" in separate letters, which the guest could rearrange in sticky wordplays. The centerpieces were baskets of dough filled with grapes. The menu included goose liver in port wine aspic and miniature salmon in puff pastry. Budapest was impressed.
But for Mr. Lang, the evening was a "trial marriage" with the restaurant's 220 employees. If, perchance, he hired too many, he said, they would all be able to find jobs in his spreading Hungarian empire -- from his 58-acre vineyard in the Tokaj winegrowing region to the Gundel's delicatessen shop he hopes to open on Budapest's glamorous Vaci Street.
By the time the renovated Gundel's opens for business next year, Mr. Lang said he hopes to be able to catch part of the city's growing tourist trade, which is already stretching the hotels and restaurants to their limits. With 500 seats in the garden, 200 in the dining rooms and another 200 in the more informal Bagolyvar, the restaurant will be able to offer a range of prices, Mr. Lang said.
He is also pinning hopes on Expo 95, the world's fair that is to be held jointly in Budapest and Vienna. Mr. Lang has had experience at world fairs, doing catering for the 1964 New York World's Fair. So, too, did Karoly Gundel Jr., son of the founder, who ran the Hungarian pavillion at the 1939 New York World's Fair.
The idea of Gundel's being the showcase for another world's fair fits in nicely with Mr. Lang's schemes. "Again," he said, "the circle closes."

HEADLINE: REAL ESTATE;
A Big Swap Of Offices In Houston

BYLINE: By Lettice Stuart

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
NEARLY every weekend for the last year, a fleet of moving vans has shuttled furniture and equipment between two Houston office complexes five miles apart. Dresser Industries and its M. W. Kellogg subsidiary are swapping office buildings in one of the largest and most complex corporate relocations in this city's history.
The swap, which will be completed next month, involves more than 3,000 employees, a million square feet of office space and 90,000 pieces of equipment and furniture. 
 Kellogg, an international engineering and construction concern, has taken over 400,000 square feet of space on 16 floors formerly leased by its parent, Dallas-based Dresser. The 40-story building, part of the 3.5-million-square-foot Cullen Center complex downtown, has been renamed M. W. Kellogg Tower. Kellogg has leased an additional 250,000 square feet on 12 floors in a contiguous building in Cullen Center.
In turn, Dresser, an oilfield services company, took over part of Kellogg's lease of a 21-story building in the Greenway Plaza complex, and renamed the building Dresser Tower. Dresser is leasing eight floors with 163,000 square feet, and Kellogg, which has added 800 employees since the move began a year ago, will continue to lease six floors there.
The relocation has solved Kellogg's need for more space and Dresser's need for less, saving both companies millions of dollars in rent, said Richard T. Arnott, the Kellogg vice president who has supervised the year-long operation.
Kellogg has grown sharply since moving its headquarters to Houston from New York in 1970. The company began its operations here with fewer than 600 employees occupying half of 3 Greenway Plaza. As the energy industry boomed in the late 1970's, Kellogg, which specializes in building chemical and petrochemical plants, grew worldwide. The company eventually took over all of the building and four floors in an adjacent one.
Still in need of more space early last year, Kellogg hired Interstate Realty to study the problem. Kellogg's lease in Greenway Plaza was up for renewal on July 1, 1991, and would involve a rent increase.
Meanwhile, Dresser occupied only 8 of the 16 floors it was leasing in Cullen Center. The company's staff had been reduced by half by the oil patch downturn of the mid-1980's, but all 16 floors were leased until 2003. Dresser's rental rates are low, however, because the company owns a 50 percent interest in the building. A long-term lease at below-market rent is what made the move economically attractive for Kellogg, Mr. Arnott said. Dresser, on the other hand, is paying higher rent for its new quarters, but has less than half the space it previously had.
The logistics of the move was complicated because 36 floors in three buildings had to be renovated. What made it possible was Dresser's eight vacant floors downtown, Mr. Arnott said.
The decision to swap was made on March 1, 1990, and a construction team began renovating the vacant floors. Four months later several hundred Kellogg employees moved into Cullen Center.
Then the space they vacated in Greenway Plaza was renovated, and some Dresser employees moved in. That process has continued.
Patsy Lesley, a move consultant hired by Kellogg, said a key goal was to minimize disruptions to the companies' operations. Employees start packing belongings in boxes at 2:30 on a Friday afternoon. An hour later movers begin loading. A company moving team works through the weekend arranging the new offices and hooking up equipment. When employees arrive at their new offices the following Monday morning, they unpack and are back at work in an hour and a half.
During one weekend in the move, $20 million worth of Kellogg computer equipment was relocated. The entire computer system was disconnected and transported in special air suspension trucks accompanied by a police escort. Then it was reinstalled. The process took 22 hours.
Mr. Arnott said Kellogg had benefited from the opportunity to redesign its space for maximum efficiency. The company shuffles an average of 300 employees around each month to different work stations. To eliminate opening the ceiling to find wiring as each piece of equipment is moved, Kellogg designed a cable raceway system that runs along the baseboards so equipment can be plugged in anywhere. Mr. Arnott said the new system would save the company $800,000 a year previously spent on constant electrical modifications.
Kellogg also switched its entire filing system from four-drawer cabinets to a wall system that saves 16,000 square feet of floor space. In the process, 37 tons of paper were cleaned out, most of it recycled.

HEADLINE: ROMA JOURNAL;
A Town That's Addicted To Illegal Drug Money

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROMA, Tex.

 BODY:
Contrasts between wealth and poverty in this dilapidated outpost on the Mexican border stand out as sharply as the extravagant yellow blooms on a lowly prickly pear cactus.
A pillared mansion on a hill looms above unpainted slums with backyard outhouses and the occasional satellite dish. 
 At local high schools, children of migrant farm workers sit next to students wearing Rolex watches -- the children, officials say, of "mules," or lower-echelon drug runners.
Across Starr County's ranch and farmland the air is pungent with the scent of harvested onion. Any proud local resident will attest to the hard-working, churchgoing nature of the community. Most will also acknowledge how the drug trade distorts nearly every aspect of life here.
Much of Starr County, where smuggling of cattle, liquor and electronic equipment across the Rio Grande has been a way of life for generations, is entangled in a cocaine and marijuana industry that coils from Mexico to the hungry street markets of the United States, Federal agents say.
Remote, insulated and historically left to its own ways, Starr County more than a decade ago began attracting free-spending, privacy-hungry drug runners as well.
"You can't come any closer to cutting off the serpent's head than you do in Starr County and South Texas," says Fred Ball, chief of the Drug Enforcement Administration office in the city of McAllen, in neighboring Hidalgo County.
Federal agents say their increased attention here and along the whole Texas border in recent years is paying off. The United States Marshal's Office for this region is now managing some 160 properties seized from drug suspects, more than three times the number of a huge urban center like Houston.
But the increasing tonnage of narcotics seized at South Texas checkpoints only hints at the traffic across the border. And over the years, Starr County has become addicted -- not necessarily to drugs, but to their greenback high.
While few of the county's 40,500 residents are in the drug business, many are profiting from the money spent by those who are.
In a county with the lowest per capita income in the nation, where unemployment peaked at 52.8 percent in 1990 and clinics routinely treat diseases most often found in the third world, bank deposits have soared and land values along the main business route have bloated far beyond the reach of many legitimate developers.
Local government agencies benefit by collecting the higher property taxes. Businesses that might otherwise not survive flourish on the easy flow of drug money. Others go under, unable to match cut-rate prices offered by what Federal authorities describe as money-laundering fronts.
When the Federal authorities recently auctioned off the confiscated race horses of a convicted drug kingpin, they say the money literally reeked of marijuana, showing how deeply drugs have infiltrated the cash in circulation.
Angry Starr County leaders say most of the drug "Mafiosi" are recent arrivals from Mexico who are tarnishing the county's reputation. "We're not to blame because we're located on a drug stopover between Mexico and New York City," said Eleuterio Garza, Roma's Superintendent of Schools.
Here in Roma, a town of 8,059 people, a tender spot is the new 60-acre, $11.5 million high school campus, complete with indoor pool and tennis courts -- all paid for in cash. Humberto Vasquez, principal of the school, says the district diligently saved for the school over many years, but acknowledges that the inflated property taxes helped them reach their goal more quickly.
At the school, "we haven't had an overdose or a major bust or a drive-by shooting," said Mr. Vasquez. "Instead of being praised for our efforts, everyone is suspicious. That's what hurts."
But weaning this old-fashioned community of strong loyalties and extended families off its supply of drug money will not be easy.
"When people walk in with a paper bag and pay $27,000 cash for a pick-up," said Mr. Ball of the D.E.A., "the toughest thing in the world is telling that guy, 'Sorry, I don't take drug money.' "

HEADLINE: India Wary of U.S. Relief Force in Bangladesh

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CALCUTTA, India, May 15

 BODY:
As American forces move into Bangladesh to assist in cyclone relief and rehabilitation work, hackles began to rise today in India, where there is a tradition of criticizing any United States military presence in the region as a direct threat to New Delhi.
The "foreign hand," a phrase that became a code name for the United States during the Government of Indira Gandhi, sets off a particularly high level of anxiety here in West Bengal, a state that has had a Communist-led government for 14 years.Calcutta, where the street on which the American Consulate is situated was renamed after Ho Chi Minh and where leftist radicals once sacked the American Center, still harbors the potential for quick-fire protests against the United States. Leftist columnists in the local press have begun the attack in the last two days. 
 While there has been no official reaction from India, a country in the final days of a messy national election campaign, the first indication that the foreign-policy establishment was paying attention came from the Government-controlled news agency, the Press Trust of India.
 Quoting "official sources," the news agency said there was consternation in New Delhi over the arrival of thousands of American troops in South Asia. Disaster relief, those unidentified officials said, was normally left to international organizations.
The revival of the specter of American interference follows sharp criticism from many Indians over New Delhi's low-keyed, delayed-reaction response to the Bangladesh crisis. The Indian military could have provided considerable assistance in the early days of the disaster.
New Delhi's deliberation over how to respond to the cyclone has been variously attributed to serious economic problems at home and concern over negative reactions in Bangladesh, where the presence of the Indian military provokes outrage if not fear. In the years since Indian troops intervened in 1971 to win independence for Bangladesh, which was then part of Pakistan, Bangladeshis have become very wary of their huge neighbor, whose intelligence agencies have most recently supported a tribal revolt in the Chittagong Hills.
Indians keep their grievances alive, too. Today, the unidentified sources quoted by the Press Trust of India recalled what Indians still regard as a sinister appearance of an American fleet in the Indian Ocean during the Bangladesh war in 1971.
India's caretaker Prime Minister, Chandra Shekhar, who visited Bangladesh over the weekend, said he did not want to put a strain on Bangladesh's small air force by visiting the country earlier and causing officals to divert aircraft from relief work.
Mr. Shekhar, who jeopardized his short tenure as Prime Minister by allowing United States aircraft to refuel in India during the Persian Gulf war, has been the least critical of the United States of any recent Indian head of Government. He and his predecessor, V. P. Singh, made efforts to reassure the smaller nations of the region that New Delhi would not interfere in their affairs.
In 1987, under Rajiv Gandhi, India violated the air space of neighboring Sri Lanka to drop supplies to Tamils on the Jaffna peninsula, where an armed insurrection against the Colombo Government was based.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines in Trading Paced by Buying of Marks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly against major foreign currencies yesterday in trading dominated by active buying of German marks.
Gold prices fell in New York. At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold was quoted at $359.90 an ounce, down 20 cents from Tuesday. In New York the Republic Bank offered a late quote of $359.20, off 10 cents from Tuesday. 
 The mark showed continued strength despite newspaper reports that Karl Otto Pohl may resign as president of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank. Traders say that even if Mr. Pohl steps down, the Bundesbank probably will not change its tight monetary policy and loosen interest rates.
"If Pohl comes or goes, the fact is they won't change their policy," said Robert Ryan, senior currency trader at the Bank of New York. Mr. Ryan said other central banks, including the Federal Reserve in the United States, have lowered interest rates recently, and added that the Japanese faced pressures to cut rates as well.
Traders bought marks on the prospect of the continued high German interest rates, a move that depressed the dollar and other currencies, analysts said.
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.68445 German marks, down from 1.6965 on Tuesday; in European dealings, the dollar slipped to 1.6895 German marks, down from 1.7010 late Tuesday.
Robert Hatcher, corporate dealer for Barclays Bank P.L.C., said the trading session over all was dominated by technical factors in the absence of any fundamental economic news.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 137.89 Japanese yen, from 139.03 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 137.85 yen. In New York at closing, it was quoted at 137.15 yen, down from 138.00 late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7475, from $1.7380 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.7540 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.7460.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.4310 Swiss francs, down from 1.4305; 5.7385 French francs, down from 5.7705; 1.9040 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9165; 1,257.25 Italian lire, down from 1,261.25, and 1.1499 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1510.

HEADLINE: PANEL VOTES DOWN RULES ON MILEAGE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
In a victory for the Bush Administration, the Senate Energy Committee voted today against imposing higher fuel economy standards for automobiles.
Shortly before the vote, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins wrote the committee that "no feasible combination of conservation efforts, by itself, can substantially reduce U.S. oil imports." Just after the vote, Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore said, "We don't think there is any need for legislation." 
 First, the committee on a 15-to-5 vote killed a proposal that would have raised the required corporate fleet average to 40 miles per gallon by the year 2001 from the current 27.5 miles. Then it voted 13 to 7 to reject a measure proposed by Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who is chairman of the committee, that would have raised the standard to 34 miles per gallon by 2001.
The committee's nine Republicans opposed both proposals. The 11 Democrats were unable to agree on either proposal, with majorities of them opposing the 40 miles per gallon standard as too severe and the 34 mile per gallon rule as too weak.
 
First Major Tests on Energy Bill
 Mr. Johnston had urged passage of his measure on the ground that a bill without specific higher standards would not survive before the full Senate, where a 40-mile-per-gallon proposal by Senator Richard D. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, was beaten last year only by a filibuster.
Today's votes were the first major tests in what all sides say will be a long, arduous road toward adopting an energy bill. The committee next faces an equally contentious question, whether to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to exploratory oil drilling.
Instead of either mileage standard, the committee adopted a plan that would require the Department of Transportation to determine whether the current standard should be raised. The bill set out standards for the department to follow, although some Democrats argued that it would avoid them because of its opposition to any to raising mileage requirements.
But Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, insisted that the department would indeed set standards -- enforced on the average mileage of all cars sold by a particular company -- based on the assumption that industry would use the best technology.
Republican hostility to higher standards was epitomized by Senator Conrad Burns of Montana. He said they were acceptable only if people "want to drive itty-bitty cars." He insisted that higher fuel-efficiency standards were useless because fuel consumption went up despite them.
Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, conceded that gasoline use increased, but only because there are more cars on the road today.
Several Republicans argued that neither they nor the committee staff knew enough about what was technologically possible to set specific standards and that it was wiser to let experts in the Department of Transportation make the decisions.
Mr. Johnston argued that his proposal would have the committee rather than the Energy Department apply the standards Republicans said they favored.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Post Declining Yields in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's said short-term interest rates were still coming down weeks after the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate on April 30, while yields on longer maturities had begun inching up after the Government's quarterly refunding last week. 
 Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said that money market yields could still go lower, but that that was not a given as the Fed is more concerned with long-term interest rates, which are important to business investments and mortgage rates. He said he sensed that money market yields might be bottoming, or at least stablizing and that he did not believe investors would abandon the funds as there are so few investments that can match their liquidity and yield.
Tax-exempt money fund yields declined for the week, with the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios down a day, to 44. The assets of the tax-exempt funds increased by $96 million, to $88.2 billion.
For the week ended yesterday, the average tax-exempt compounded yield fell 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.23 percent, with the seven-day simple yield down a similar amount, to 4.14 percent. The 30-day compounded average yield increased by a basis point, to 4.31 percent, and the 30-day simple yields rose similarly, to 4.22 percent.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 5.87 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 6.13 percent.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Managment Inc. of Milwaukee, had the best return at 5.19 percent.
Assets of taxable funds decreased by $1 billion, to $457.4 billion, while assets of institutional funds were up $300 million, to $116.5 billion. Most of the outflow centered on the consumer funds, which were down by $1.3 billion, to $340.9 billion, an indication the small investor is searching for higher yields elsewhere.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell 7 basis points, to 5.74 percent, while the 30-day compounded yield fell 7 basis points, to 5.86 percent. The seven-day simple yield was down 7 basis points, to 5.58 percent, and the 30-day simple was down 6 basis points, to 5.70 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return on investment this week was the American Performance Cash Management fund distributed by the Winsbury Company of Columbus, Ohio, with a return of 6.86 percent.

HEADLINE: Senate Asks Bush to Back Loan Guarantees for Soviets

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
The Senate passed a resolution today asking President Bush to approve an additional $1.5 billion in loan guarantees for grain shipments to the Soviet Union.
A request by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in March for the additional guarantees received little attention in Washington at first. But Soviet officials have contended with increasing fervor in recent weeks that the provision of additional food assistance is critical to the preservation of civil order there and a test of Soviet-American relations. 
 President Bush said on April 29 that while he wanted to help the Soviet Union, his options were limited because farm legislation passed by Congress late last year included a provision banning agricultural loan guarantees for countries that were not creditworthy. The resolution passed 70 to 28 by the Senate today calls on the President to approve the loan guarantees anyway.
The debate over the resolution in the last two weeks brought out a deep division in Washington over how to conduct relations with the Soviet Union. On one side, led by the resolution's sponsor, Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, were agricultural interests and politicians who believe that the United States must help the Soviet Union to prevent its possible descent into civil disorder.
Senator Dole said that President Bush had expressed enthusiasm for the resolution at a lunch with Republican senators before the vote.
The resolution asks the President not to intrepret the provision on creditworthiness in the farm legislation as applicable to the Soviet Union and links most of the guarantees to progress on political reform and Soviet interest payments on previous guaranteed loans. The resolution provides political cover for the President now to authorize the loan guarantees, trade officials said.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, led opposition to the resolution. The Soviet Union is a bad credit risk, he said, guilty of ruthless political repression and still wed to a highly centralized system of economic management that results in waste of much of the annual harvest.
Soviet officials have expressed enthusiasm for several years for putting more of their economy on a free-market footing but have repeatedly shied away from doing so, Senator Bradley said in an interview after the vote. "This resolution said we'll send the money and they'll make promises," he added.
Subsidizing grain for the Soviet Union represents interference in that country's internal politics, he said, by helping President Gorbachev at the expense of the republics. In addition, he said, the Soviet Union will further postpone its overdue debt payments to American companies if it is allowed to pile up more agriculture loans for which the United States Government, a lender with more leverage than private companies, demands repayment.
M. Ann Tutwiler, the associate director of the International Policy Council on Agriculture and Trade, a Washington-based group that promotes free trade in farm products, said that the Soviet leadership's current problems in feeding its people were a combination of a poor harvest and an inefficient distribution system. Huge quantities of food are wasted through mismanagement or diverted out of official channels because of corruption, she said.
Additional credits for the Soviet Union would help farmers in the United States who are suffering because of low whet prices and large stockpiles.
The resolution also coincides with controversy on Capitol Hill over the cost of guaranteeing agricultural loans. A study issued on Tuesday by the General Accounting Office, the Congressional research arm, estimated that foreign governments would not repay $6.7 billion of the $11.2 billion in guaranteed loans that they now owe to banks, forcing the United States Government to make up the difference.
The G.A.O.'s loss estimate included $2 billion in guaranteed loans on which Iraq has defaulted.

HEADLINE: Where Car Makers Fear to Cut

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 15

 BODY:
Auto executives traditionally do not discuss future car and truck models for fear buyers might put off a purchase until the new ones arrive. But the Chrysler Corporation took that risk by recently allowing dealers, journalists and others onto its test track to give them a glimpse of the 1993 mid-size models on which Chrysler is pinning its hopes for a recovery.
The slump in car sales and the national recession, which coincide with yet another big push by the Japanese for American market share, is squeezing Detroit and causing a torrent of cash to flow out the door. All of the auto makers are cutting costs and conserving resources. What they are struggling to avoid, though, are any deep cuts that would delay or eliminate new products.
 
A Matter of Perceptions
 Chrysler, like the others in the Big Three, does not want investors, suppliers or lenders to get the idea that it is paring spending for new models, a perception that would only worsen its problems on the showroom floor.
The pressure to spend, even when money is scarce, is a matter of market share for the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, and a matter of survival for Chrysler. All three are striving to avoid having their need to save money force them into canceling or delaying important vehicle projects. G.M. on Monday announced plans to float an issue of preference stock to raise $600 million, partly to pay for future vehicle models, among them eight new-car and thee new-truck models in the next year.
"Spending for new products must go on in good times and bad," said James B. Fitzpatrick, a G.M. vice president for communications and marketing. "It is our lifeblood." Cash generated internally at G.M. has shrunk from $10.08 billion in 1987 to an estimated $5.27 billion this year, according to estimates by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Japanese auto makers can develop a new vehicle in far less time than Detroit can, and they are invading market niches in the United States where they have never been before. Today, for example, Nissan showed journalists its first mini-van, named the Quest. It was designed in California and will be built at a Ford plant near Cleveland starting next April. Last year, Nissan withdrew from the market its Axxess station wagon that was meant to attract mini-van buyers but was a flop.
American auto makers know they cannot compete unless they compress their normal five-year product-gestation period to three years, like the Japanese, and bring out more new cars more frequently. Indeed, the most scathing criticism that could be leveled at the American auto industry would be to say that it was mortgaging the future by scrimping on new-product development.
But new products take money. Depending on the extent of the redesign, the cost of bringing a new car to dealer lots ranges from $500 million to $1 billion.
While G.M. has been able to keep most models on schedule, it has acknowledged a few delays. Rumors among parts suppliers say G.M. has delayed its redesigned S-10 Blazer utility vehicle to 1995, from 1994.
 
Taking on More Debt
 As for Ford, it borrowed $800 million in the first quarter of the year, raising its debt to $8.2 billion; a year ago, debt stood at $4.4 billion. Ford's debt-to-equity ratio on March 31 was 38 percent, compared with 16 percent a year ago. Ford is trying to keep most future models on schedule, but analysts and suppliers say it has delayed the redesign of the Taurus and the Sable models for one year, to 1995.
After Ford announced a first-quarter loss of $884 million, David N. McCammon, vice president-finance, said projects "are basically intact, but we always are making timing adjustments" to cut costs and looking for ways "to get a dollar's worth of new products for every 80 cents we spend."
Chrysler, which has suffered critical losses and has little financial cushion, has the least borrowing power among the Big Three, the lowest relative stock price, and the least ability to put money into new products. But Chris Cedergren, an automotive analyst for J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive consulting firm in Agoura Hills, Calif., said Chrysler more than any other American auto maker might be trying to pull spending forward.
Perhaps because of its well-publicized financial weakness, the No. 3 auto maker must go to the greatest lengths to prove that its $3 billion in cost-cutting is not hampering development of new models. The company renegotiated a $1.5 billion line of credit after the lowering of its debt ratings made borrowing from the public too expensive.
"The fear is that Chrysler is cutting into muscle and bone," said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "But I hope not, because I love the way the L/H looks." He was referring to the code name for Chrysler's 1993 mid-size sedan, which will be sold by the Eagle, Dodge and Chrysler divisions; it will be built, starting next year, at a factory in Bramalea, Ontario.
Other Chrysler vehicles badly need replacement, too. The full-size pickup truck -- referred to by some Chrysler engineers as "Festus," the grizzled codger in the "Gunsmoke" television western -- has not been redesigned for more than 15 years. Chrysler is planning to replace it in 1993.
 
No Profits, No Cash
 In economically healthy times auto makers pay part of their new-product costs with cash from current sales. But with no profits, auto makers must increase borrowings or sell equity. In the last six months, the Big Three have been forced to trim dividends and drastically cut costs to strengthen balance sheets enough to finance new-product spending.
One-time expenses have also been a drain on cash. G.M., for example, was obligated on March 1 to buy $600 million worth of its class H stock from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute as part of the renegotiated terms of the sale of Hughes Aircraft to G.M. in 1985.
The three-year labor contract negotiated in the fall with the United Automobile Workers union has become a huge financial burden as well. Under its terms, the Big Three must pay most workers even if they are laid off, a situation that makes labor costs akin to a fixed expense. In previous recessions, labor expenses went down as sales and production dropped, allowing auto makers to keep losses in check.
In 1982, under an earlier labor agreement, the industry was operating at only 62 percent of capacity, yet auto makers were breaking even. But last year, utilization was at 78 percent and still the industry lost about $5 billion in North America, according to an analysis by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
 
The Cost of Competition
 Of course, foreign imports and transplants -- Japanese cars made in America -- were not as much of a factor during the last recession. Vicious competition is hurting the Big Three's ability to maintain prices. Even with much lower production, the auto makers have been forced to continue offering large rebates on most car and truck models -- another drain on cash.
Shorter development cycles for cars like Chrysler's L/H model should help to cut costs, analysts say. Chrysler will have brought the L/H out in 42 months, a 30 percent reduction in the typical development time, helping produce a 25 percent cut in development costs, according to an estimate by Sanford C. Bernstein.
Chrysler believes the length of the cycle will be about 39 months, said Glen Gardner, who heads the project; that compares with the Japanese average of about 36 months. "The trick is going to be to get the rest of our projects on this schedule," he said.

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
Congress Moves On Price-Fixing

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
CONGRESS is moving quickly to adopt significant antitrust legislation that its supporters assert will encourage price competition by making it more difficult for manufacturers and retailers to fix prices.
Last week the Senate approved legislation that would essentially codify some court rulings, making vertical price-fixing by manufacturers and retailers automatically illegal. The measure, approved on voice vote, would also roll back decisions by the United States Supreme Court and Federal appeals courts in the last decade that have made it increasingly more difficult for plaintiffs to bring such actions. 
 Proponents of the measure say it would make it easier for discounters like K Mart and Toys "R" Us to sue a rival that persuades a manufacturer to try to dictate price levels. Consumer groups estimate that the legislation could save customers up to $20 billion annually.
The bill is sponsored by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio. After years of unsuccessful attempts to change the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890, Mr. Metzenbaum broke a deadlock in the Senate by agreeing to amendments offered by Senator Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, that would make the legislation slightly less onerous on manufacturers. That move won the support of some Republicans whose opposition had blocked the measure.
Similar legislation sponsored last year by Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, was approved overwhelmingly in the House. Mr. Brooks is expected to reintroduce his legislation shortly. If, as expected, his measure is adopted, it would have to be reconciled with the Senate measure before proceeding to the White House.
But the Justice Department has expressed opposition to the measure, saying that it would create an inference of unlawful conspiracy in many cases where none existed. At this point, it is expected that the measure will be vetoed by the President, and both the measure's supporters and its critics say it is not clear whether there are sufficient votes to override a veto.
The measure was adopted largely in response to decisions by the Reagan and Bush Administrations not to bring any civil price-fixing cases between retailers and manufacturers. Justice Department officials have maintained that "price maintenance" agreements improve service to customers and are therefore not harmful to competition.
Nor has the Supreme Court felt the need to encourage such lawsuits.
In 1984, the justices decided that plaintiffs bringing such cases must provide evidence showing that the manufacturer and another party consciously intended to maintain resale price levels. And in 1988, the Supreme Court elaborated on the ruling by holding that there was no violation of antitrust laws unless the manufacturer and retailer actually agreed on a specific price. As a result of those decisions, retailers have been discouraged from filing lawsuits.
The legislation approved by the Senate would ease the standards of evidence for plaintiffs bringing such suits. The measure has drawn widespread support from an array of consumer groups and representatives of discounters and has provoked criticism from manufacturers and other business interests.
"It's happening for everything from tennis racquets to Passover products," said Kristen Rand, counsel to Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine. "The state attorneys general say it is endemic to the economy."
But the manufacturers, whose most vocal supporter on Capitol Hill is Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, are fighting to block the legislation.
James P. Carty, vice president for government affairs for the National Association of Manufacturers, said the measure would result in scores of new legal actions.
"Any time a retailer is terminated by a manufacturer, counsel will immediately threaten to file a treble damages antitrust lawsuit," he said. "The system right now is working well. You and I don't have a problem getting discounted products."

HEADLINE: Israel Rejects Baker's Plan for Mideast Peace Talks

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 15

 BODY:
Israel today rejected Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's proposals for bridging the differences between Israel and Syria on how a Middle East peace conference should be organized and on what role the United Nations should play in it, American and Israeli officials said.
President Hafez al-Assad of Syria had rejected virtually the same proposals from Mr. Baker when the two met in Damascus on Sunday. 
 Mr. Baker will meet again with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Thursday before returning to Washington, and some Israeli officials hinted that Mr. Shamir might show a little more flexibility at the 11th hour to give Mr. Baker something to go back to the Syrians with and to avoid any suggestion that Israel and Syria were equally to blame for holding up the conference. But American officials said Mr. Baker received no such proposals from Mr. Shamir today.
Mr. Baker is expected to return to Washington later Thursday and sit down with President Bush to decide what their next move should be in their effort to follow up the Persian Gulf war with some kind of Arab-Israeli peace negotiation.
 
Document on Peace Terms
 Since American officials believe that some of the other Arab states and the Palestinians are prepared to be more flexible than Syria, they are beginning to think more seriously about trying to convene a smaller Arab-Israeli conference in which the Syrians would not be involved, at least initially. But American officials say they still very much want to see the Syrians take part and have not given up yet.
After spending much of the day in talks with Mr. Shamir, Foreign Minister David Levy and Defense Minister Moshe Arens, Mr. Baker suggested that the two sides draw up an informal document spelling out the terms for a peace conference on which they had already agreed and spelling out those areas where they still disagreed.
Mr. Baker wanted to do that, officials said, for several reasons. To begin with, Mr. Shamir, Mr. Arens and Mr. Levy are all political rivals. Mr. Baker has often in the past had to negotiate with each one separately, and, officials said, he wanted to nail down what all three agreed on today, so that if the negotiations resume in a few days he will not find himself having to start all over again with three different ministers.
"This is just an informal understanding between Baker and the Israeli ministers," said an American diplomat. "It won't be used for anything other than to make sure that positions don't change. We don't consider it a formal Cabinet decision, but an informal understanding."
Both sides, though, intend to use the document for their own purposes. The Americans hope that it will highlight to the world how insignificant are the procedural issues on which Israel is refusing to compromise in order to make a peace conference possible.
The Israelis, for their part, are expected to point to the other part of the document -- all the areas they agree on with Washington -- in order to emphasize that they are being much more flexible than the Arabs.
As Mr. Levy said today: "I am optimistic about peace because that is the center of our political activities and Israel, in fact, was the one to float the peace initiative. It is the Arabs that are making it difficult."
Israeli and American officials said differences remain over what role the United Nations should play in any conference and whether the conference should be a one-day session or have a permanent status.
 
Length of Conference
 The Israelis believe the United Nations has a long record of bias against them and they refuse to have it play any role, even as an observer. The Syrians want the United Nations to play a major role, so that United Nations resolutions will be sure to apply during the negotiations.
Mr. Shamir also insisted that the conference be simply a one-day ceremonial opening to direct talks between Israel and the Palestinians and Israel and its Arab neighbors, while the Syrians demanded that the conference be an ongoing affair and that the cosponsors, the United States and the Soviet Union, be able to intervene to help the parties overcome obstacles.
Mr. Baker had proposed as a compromise that the Israelis and the Syrians agree that the United Nations be represented by an "observer" who would have no functional role in the talks, and that the conference reconvene periodically, provided both sides were amenable, to hear reports of progress but not to interfere in the talks in any way. It was that compromise that was rejected by Mr. Shamir and Mr. Assad.
The areas where the United States, Israel and the Arabs agree are that there should be a peace conference to promote direct bilateral negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians, and Israel and the surrounding Arab states.
The terms of reference for that conference will be United Nations Resolutions 242 and 338, but each side is free to interpret those resolutions as it sees fit. Those resolutions call on Israel to return territories occupied in the 1967 war in return for security and recognition from the Arab side. The Arabs interpret that as meaning that Israel must trade the West Bank, the Golan Heights and the Gaza Strip for peace, while Mr. Shamir insists that Israel, having already given back the Sinai desert to Egypt, has fulfilled all of its territorial obligations.
There also appears to be a general understanding among parties on how the Palestinians will be represented, most likely in a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation, but the details of that are not yet clear.
Assuming that Mr. Baker leaves here on Thursday with the two key differences still outstanding, the Bush Administration is understood to be considering other alternatives.
One is to give this approach a little more time, in hopes of bridging the differences between Israel and Syria. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is going to Damascus later this week in an effort to soften Mr. Assad's stand.
Another alternative is to try to convene a peace conference without the Syrians, but with just Israelis, Palestinians, Jordanians and Lebanese and with the Arab Gulf states taking part as observers in side negotiations on issues like water use, arms control and economic development.

HEADLINE: Weicker Income-Tax Plan Dying As Bipartisan Opposition Grows

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 15

 BODY:
Three months after Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. proposed that Connecticut resolve its fiscal crisis by adopting an income tax, his budget plan appears to be heading for defeat.
The income tax is dying in part because of Mr. Weicker's status as an independent governor without a single party member in the General Assembly, which increasingly seems not to need him very much nor care what he thinks. 
 But it is also the result of this state's deep antagonism to a tax on wages, and the determination of a growing majority in the legislature to patch together a budget and close a $2.7 billion revenue shortfall in a more traditional way for Connecticut: by expanding its 8 percent sales tax, already the highest statewide sales tax in the nation. Connecticut is one of only 10 states with no broad-based tax on wages.
 
Fate Linked to Tax
 In a budget address to legislators today, Mr. Weicker said, "I don't have the troops to ram the truth home, and I don't have the will to execute the duties of my office in a neck-saving way."
Mr. Weicker proposed an overhaul of the state's tax system in February, after only a month in office, linking the fate of his administration with that of the income tax, for decades the single thorniest issue in Connecticut politics.
Without legislators of his party behind him, Mr. Weicker said from the outset that he would have to sell his income-tax plan to the public, and so convince lawmakers that they could vote for the tax without fear of voter reprisals.
Politicians in both parties and on both sides of the income-tax question now say the campaign flopped, as far as allaying legislators' fears. At the same time, a coalition of newly aggressive Republicans and moderate Democrats opposed to an income tax has emerged, more than prepared to push Mr. Weicker to the margins.
The group is strongest in the Senate, which is expected to throw out the Weicker plan as early as next week, in favor of a "conventional" package relying on the sales tax, deeper cuts in state spending and more borrowing.
One result is that Mr. Weicker no longer seems able to arouse even hostility.
In his speech today before the House and Senate, he made another impassioned if familiar argument in favor of the income tax, promised to meet with lawmakers through the weekend to work out a budget compromise, and said he would accept the coalition's plan to impose controls on the growth of state spending. Lawmakers responded with indifference.
"It was a nice gesture, and we're certainly going to try to meet with him -- be happy to do that," said the Senate majority leader, Cornelius O'Leary, a Democrat from Windsor Locks. "But I'm not sure he contributed a great deal. We're very close to a conclusion that would solve the deficit problem along the traditional lines."
Coalition leaders say that with the 16 Republicans in the Senate largely united against an income tax, the 20 Democrats are deeply divided just about down the middle. That a majority exists ready to vote down the income tax is unchallenged. The only question is whether there is a two-thirds to override a veto.
 
Lawmakers Unmoved
 In the House, where the Democrats have a stronger majority of 88 votes, against 62 Republicans, the numbers are softer, but most lawmakers still cast the question as whether the sales-tax plan can be defeated, rather than whether an income-tax plan can pass.
"I don't think he moved two votes," said the Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., a representative from Oxford.
Income-tax advocates and administration officials, while conceding that the income-tax plan is threatened, denied that Mr. Weicker's role in the debate was over. They said that in these last few weeks before the legislature's mandated June 5 adjournment, and through the long weeks of summer, if there is a stalemate, almost anything can happen.
The co-chairman of the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford who supports an income tax, said he remained convinced that Connecticut would have an income tax in 1991.
Only when the full implications of a non-income-tax plan are brought to light, he said -- especially the effect of a huge sales-tax expansion on the state's already weak business climate -- will the true gravity of the choice emerge.
Connecticut faces a projected revenue shortfall of about $2.7 billion over the next 14 months in a preliminary budget of about $8.6 billion, caused primarily by declines in collections on the sales tax and corporate-profits tax -- the two largest tax sources -- and by rising expenses related to the recession, especially in medical assistance to the poor.
"There are enough people who are sufficiently spooked by the idea of voting for an income tax that they'll want to believe anything and will vote for anything other than an income tax," Mr. Mulready said.
But once those anxieties and energies are exhausted, he said, Mr. Weicker may yet emerge with a pivotal role, and his speech today was simply an effort to keep the door open and set the stage.
"He's trying to reinsert himself into the process: 'I'm here and you can't ignore me,' " Mr. Mulready said.
The tone of Mr. Weicker's speech was also markedly different from his last appearance before the jointly convened General Assembly -- when he proposed his budget -- and speeches elsewhere since. The gruff manner, and the suggestion that opponents to an income tax were somehow craven or lacking in spine, were absent.
But leaders of the bipartisan coalition said that short of abandoning the income tax, Mr. Weicker really has nothing to bargain with to get himself fully back into the debate. The spending controls he proposed, for example, have already been endorsed by every leader across the spectrum and would have been almost certain to be included in any budget plan, whether it included an income tax or not.
"His next decision is going to have to be whether to veto the conventional package," said Senator James H. Maloney, a Democrat from Danbury who has emerged as one of the bipartisan leaders. "I would hope he doesn't because I think that plunges the state into fiscal chaos, and I think as a result he won't make that decision."
Mr. Maloney said that as long as the income tax is still firmly on the Governor's agenda, Mr. Weicker and his views will largely be irrelevant.
"He doesn't have to be," Mr. Maloney said. "If he will drop his insistence to the income tax, I think the General Assembly would rally very quickly to a reopening of every consideration and every issue and would very much like to have his point of view on all of them."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Agencies Are Urged to Revitalize Industry

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

DATELINE: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va.

 BODY:
SOME people in advertising think their industry needs another David Ogilvy. Others think their industry needs another William Bernbach. But Keith Reinhard thinks the industry needs another Ted Turner.
"The Ted Turner of our industry has yet to identify himself," Mr. Reinhard, outgoing chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said in an interview before the group's 73th annual meeting opened here yesterday. "Yet we better get about reinvigorating our industry before someone else does it for us." 
The wake-up call from Mr. Reinhard, chairman and chief executive of DDB Needham Worldwide, echoed meaningfully as advertising industry leaders gathered for the meeting. As the industry struggles to cope with a plethora of internal and external problems, Mr. Reinhard offered some thoughts about the issues that concerned him during his 14 months as the 4 A's chairman. As planned, he was succeeded yesterday by Alex Kroll, chairman and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Inc.
"Can we as an industry transform ourselves quickly enough to convince our market that we are once again as relevant as we were in simpler times?" Mr. Reinhard asked last week during an interview at his New York office. Failure to do so, he said, could result in clients eliminating their agencies from any meaningful role in advertising decision-making, thus "relegating agencies to just filling in orders for the ads."
To avoid such a fate, the industry must intensify its efforts to rethink itself, Mr. Reinhard said, not just providing clients with advertising, but with "integrated, custom-made marketing communications programs." These would cover the spectrum from sales messages carried by traditional media like newspapers to "contact opportunities" with consumers, like shopping-mall displays. Within DDB Needham, staff members unofficially use other terms for the words "advertising agency," he said, to "get people to expand their horizons." Among them: "sales creation agency" and "marketing consultancy."
Mr. Reinhard's verbal exercises fit well with the theme of this year's 4 A's meeting: "Advertising must be redefined to comprise all marketing communications to the consumer." That expands on a topic examined during the 1990 meeting, "The New Advertising," which has become industry shorthand for agencies' involving themselves in the total marketing communications needs of their clients.
These days, with the national economy in recession and the industry's own financial woes dragging into a third year, many might consider the issue of whether advertising is "new" or "old" less important than whether clients are advertising at all. Mr. Reinhard acknowledged the dislocation caused by the economy but hoped neither that nor "other business problems, like the threat of taxation and the threat of regulation," would distract agencies from addressing their serious long-term problems.
Among the subjects to be discussed at the meeting, which continues at the Greenbrier resort through Saturday, are the results of research into what clients think of the new advertising, as well as a look at consumer behavior.
In the group's election, Robert L. James, chairman and president of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York, was elected vice chairman, putting him in line to succeed Mr. Kroll as chairman of the 4 A's in 1992.
In a brief speech accepting his new post as chairman, Mr. Kroll acknowledged that the industry was passing through "a very difficult year," but urged members of the 4 A's to redouble their efforts to sell clients on "what a valuable potion we brew" in creating advertising.
And, as usually happens when advertising executives gather, awards are on the agenda. One, the Advertiser Recognition Award, was presented to Carillon Importers Ltd. of Teaneck, N.J., for its Absolut vodka print advertising created by TBWA Advertising Inc., New York. A second prize, the A+ Creative Excellence Award, is to be presented tomorrow night to one of 15 agency finalists.

HEADLINE: Bush Backs China Trade Status, Reopening Conflict Over Rights

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
In a move that immediately reopened a conflict with Congress over relations with China, and surprised even his staff, President Bush said today that he wanted to extend China's favorable trading status for another year despite misgivings about its human rights record.
Within an hour, as members of Congress began attacking the President's remarks, the White House tried to back away from Mr. Bush's comments. Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the President had not yet made a formal decision to extend China's trading privileges, known as most-favored-nation status, for another year. 
 Mr. Bush's statement today highlighted not only the basic conflict between the White House and Congress over how to handle relations with China but also the highly secretive and personal way in which the President operates when it comes to relations with the authorities in Beijing.
 
Calls It a 'Big Pitch'
 Mr. Bush considers himself an expert on China after serving as envoy to Beijing in 1975 and generally makes all decisions on Chinese-American relations with one or two advisers in the Oval Office. He disclosed his intentions about China's trading status today without waiting for the normal option papers from Government agencies. His comments took his own staff and other departments by surprise.
Despite Mr. Fitzwater's efforts to mitigate the political impact of Mr. Bush's statement, the President's intentions seemed clear when he told reporters on the White House South Lawn that he had made a "big pitch" for renewing China's trade status during a Capitol Hill lunch with Republican lawmakers. Under Federal law, the President has until June 3 to recommend the extension formally; the trading privileges expire on July 3.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that "there are major problems in China" on human rights, arms exports and other issues, but added, "I want to see M.F.N. for China continue."
Most-favored-nation status fixes tariffs on imports at the lowest prevailing rates and is not normally granted to Communist countries, including the Soviet Union.
 
Reward for Support on Gulf
 The President said he did not want to isolate Beijing and indicated that he was trying in part to reward China for not blocking American actions at the United Nations during the Persian Gulf crisis. Mr. Bush said today that he was considering asking the Security Council, where China has veto power, for a new resolution that would send a United Nations police force to northern Iraq.
"I look at the big picture," he said. "I look at the support we got from China back in Desert Storm, the importance of China as a country. And I don't want to see us isolate them. I do want to see them come forward more on some of the things that we've been asking."
He argues that diplomatic pressure will be more effective with Chinese officials than economic pressure. But many lawmakers, who want to squeeze China financially, say the diplomatic efforts have failed so far.
"We've had far too many high-level contacts and not much result," said Representative Don J. Pease, Democrat of Ohio, who tried to tie China trade to human rights issues last year.
Other lawmakers zeroed in on the quid pro quo suggested by Mr. Bush in his comments today. "It's unfortunate that the President sees China in such a different light from any other country," said Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California. "He makes the argument about China's cooperation in the Persian Gulf war and yet we don't have most-favored nation with the Soviet Union, which was even more cooperative."
Ms. Pelosi is sponsoring a bill that would extend China's trading status for this year but make the 1992 extension contingent on human rights improvements and other conditions. Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, the majority leader, plans to introduce a similar bill on Thursday.
 
Limited Requirements Now
 Under current law, Mr. Bush need not consider human rights and other issues in deciding on trade with China. Under a provision of law known as the Jackson-Vanick Amendment, the granting of favored trade status is tied only to emigration.
China, which sold $15.2 billion in goods to American companies last year, is the eighth-largest exporter to the United States. But its purchases of $4.8 billion made it only the 18th-largest importer of American products.
Administration officials said the options papers on extending Chinese trade privileges had not even been completed, much less sent to the White House, when Mr. Bush spoke today. The President had received only a strategy memo from Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that did not discuss the pros and cons of extending the trading privileges but merely outlined ways to sell the idea to Congress, one official said.
It was not entirely clear why the President chose to reveal his position on China trade so precipitously in an unscheduled question-and-answer session on the White House South Lawn.
But some officials said the President felt the pressure of time because of two coming events that would make such an announcement particularly inappropriate. On May 23, China plans to unveil a monument to its absorption of Tibet, which is not recognized by the United States, and June 4, a day after the deadline for the trade decision, is the second anniversary of the violence on Tiananmen Square.
Congress has been pushing Mr. Bush to punish Beijing for that crackdown on political dissent, while the President has always sought to balance those pressures with economic pressures from American companies that do business with China and his strong personal penchant for maintaining relations with Beijing.
"I go back to the days when I was in China as the equivalent of Ambassador and though there are major problems in China, things we don't like about their system, things are an awful lot better than they were back in 1975," Mr. Bush said.
 
Envoy Dispatched
 Last month, Mr. Bush blocked the sale of satellite parts to China because of concern about its sale of missiles and other weapons to Pakistan and other nations. Earlier this month, Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, was sent to Beijing for what American officials called a candid discussion about human rights, trade and weapons sales.
But since the Tiananmen Square violence in 1989, Mr. Bush came under steady fire from Capitol Hill for not speaking out more strongly against Beijing or taking tough action, like cutting off China's favorable trade status.
The pressure dramatically increased when it was disclosed in December 1989 that Mr. Bush had sent his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and the Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, on a secret mission to Beijing that the President later admitted was a failure.

HEADLINE: ROHATYN DROPPING BID TO AID DINKINS

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In a setback for the Dinkins administration, Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, yesterday abruptly dropped his plan to give the city $1 billion after a bond rating agency said the plan could lead to an immediate downgrading of city bonds.
Mr. Rohatyn canceled a meeting of the M.A.C. board scheduled for today after learning that the Standard & Poor's rating agency had warned that his plan would probably hurt the city's credit rating. The corporation would have provided the city with $1 billion over four years by cashing in M.A.C. bonds, giving the city the proceeds and issuing new bonds that the city would have to pay off later. 
 He said the assistance corporation would reconsider the plan only if the city satisfied the bond-rating agency's worries over the plan's being simply a scheme to allow the city to continue living beyond its means.
 
Cornerstone of Strategy
 The bond-refinancing plan was a cornerstone of a negotiating strategy laid out by Mayor David N. Dinkins since January to avert the worst of thousands of layoffs and deep service cuts he proposed to close a $3.5 billion gap in the city's budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
Its rejection left the Mayor's strategy, at least temporarily, in shambles, with union leaders who had agreed in principle to make concessions now balking, making the imposition of the worst of the cuts ever more likley.
"Regardless of what they do, we will close our gap and control our destiny," a resolute Mayor Dinkins said in Washington yesterday, on a trip with other big-city mayors to lobby for more aid. The mayors, who met with Congressional leaders, asked for money for mass transit, kindergarten programs and other proposals they said would help shore up sliding revenues.
Both Mr. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo sought to discount the importance of Mr. Rohatyn's actions yesterday, suggesting that he would probably find a way to help the city after the City Council adopts the budget next month.
Other officials saw Mr. Rohatyn's decision to postpone any consideration of the plan as a warning that the city's bonds were likely to be downgraded anyway because of the city's fiscal troubles and that Mr. Rohatyn did not want to be associated with that.
Mr. Rohatyn's action upsets delicate behind-the-scenes maneuvering by the Mayor, the Governor, union leaders and Mr. Rohatyn, all trying to find some way out of the city's fiscal problems, which have raised concerns in financial markets and could eventually lead to a takeover of the city's finances by the State Financial Control Board.
 
A Reluctant Participant
 Mr. Rohatyn, who has been deeply skeptical of the city's efforts to close its budget gap since last October, when the Mayor granted a substantial pay raise to teachers, was a reluctant participant in the process, but agreed to help out after he was lobbied heavily by officials in Albany and from City Hall.
Union leaders then insisted that Mr. Rohatyn provide cash to the city before they would consider making cost-cutting concessions sought by the Dinkins administration.
"We prepared a plan that we believe is a good plan that is fully justified by the economic problems in the city right now," Mr. Rohatyn said.
Earlier this month, Mr. Dinkins offered a vision of a city devastated by cuts, with libraries and swimming pools closed, thousands of workers laid off and services slashed. He offered hope that the worst of the cuts could be forestalled through union concessions, increased state aid and surplus cash from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up in the 1970's to borrow money on the city's behalf.
But yesterday municipal union leaders said they too would hold off making concessions unless others shared the scarfice too. "This has been a terrible shock to us," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the teamsters union. "We have said all along that all of the players have to share the pain. In this process there is no pain except to the workers."
Under the plan, the M.A.C. would refinance bonds so as to postpone principal payments until after 1995, in effect shifting the cost to future taxpayers. To assure that the administration spent the funds wisely, Mr. Rohatyn proposed that the payments be made only if the control board certified that the administration's plans would bring the city into a permanent balance betweeen spending and revenue.
Mr. Dinkins has steadfastly resisted suggestions that he cede any powers to the control board. "I'm looking for M.A.C. assistance, but that does not mean I'm willing to say I'll take M.A.C. assistance and yield control of the city to the control board," the Mayor said yesterday.
Richard P. Larkin, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, said the city's current bond rating of A- could be in jeopardy if it gets $300 million from the assistance corporation next year. Earlier this year, another rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, cut the city's credit rating to Baa1.
"An A- situation assumes that the city's budget challenges are manageable, within their means to accomplish," Mr. Larkin said. "We are talking about a different credit rating if their situation is managing them."
Some city officials are concerned that even without the corporation's funds, Standard & Poor's will lower the rating when the city sells $600 million in long-term bonds in June. But Mr. Larkin said that Mr. Dinkins's budget had "few surprises" in it and that it "should be a manageable situation."
Mr. Rohatyn, who acknowledged having "concerns" about some city policies, said he was still committed to helping the city out, but only after the city and the state adopt their budgets. "We tried to get ahead of the train," he said. "Now we will have to go back to our usual place at the caboose."
