HEADLINE: The Feature-Length Cartoon Returns

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 15

 BODY:
Inspired by the success of movies like "The Little Mermaid" and by a continuing baby boomlet, Hollywood studios are energetically plunging into the production of feature-length animated films, a realm both they and movie audiences have long regarded as a monopoly of the Walt Disney Company .
Warner Brothers' "Rover Dangerfield," starring a canine cartoon version of the comedian Rodney Dangerfield, is scheduled to arrive in theaters this summer. And later this year, in what studio executives say is a sign of things to come, Disney's "Beauty and the Beast," Universal's "An American Tail: Fievel Goes West" and 20th Century Fox's environmentalist fantasy "Ferngully: The Last Rain Forest" will all be competing for the approval of family audiences. 
 At the moment, in fact, all seven of Hollywood's major studios have at least one animated film scheduled for release this year or production next year, leading to intense competition for the services of top animators. "It's a very exciting time," said Charles Solomon, the author of "Enchanted Drawings: The History of Animation." "There are probably more features in production right now than there ever have been."
 
Money: Root of All Imitation
 Like so much else in Hollywood, the renewed interest in animated films after decades of general neglect stems largely from a hunger to duplicate some very impressive box-office numbers. The $154 million made by "Who Framed Roger Rabbit," the $84 million that "The Little Mermaid" earned, the $53 million taken in by "Oliver and Company" and the $47 million performance of "An American Tail" have awakened in movie makers a desire for a foothold in what is seen as an increasingly lucrative specialized market.
"It's very simple," said Roger Birnbaum, the head of production at 20th Century Fox, said when asked why his studio had plunged into animation. "We saw that animated films, when made well, were working in the marketplace, and felt that we also wanted to be in that ballgame."
The studio plans to follow "Ferngully" with another environmentalist cartoon feature, called "The Endangered"
Studio executives are further encouraged by what they see when they study demographic data. Baby boomers, who tend to have fond memories of childhood cartoon characters, are in their prime reproductive years and children ages 5 to 12 are emerging as an important market. Movie makers have visions of attracting both parents and children to theaters with a single product, a formula that worked to the amount of $267 million with 20th Century Fox's live-action comedy "Home Alone."
"We're in an era in which a lot of children are being born and will continue to be born for the next 10 to 15 years," said Gary Lucchesi, the head of production at Paramount Pictures, which recently signed a three-year agreement with Tom Wilhite, the maker of "Rover Dangerfield," in hopes of being able to release an animated feature annually starting in 1992. "Right now that market is dominated by one company, and we believe that doesn't make any sense."
The Disney model, however, is precisely what inspires other studios. They too hope to make animated movies whose popularity is such that they can be rereleased whenever a new generation of children comes along and that are not overexposed through repeated showings on cable or network television.
"There's a general feeling that animated product does tend to be evergreen," said Jean MacCurdy, the vice president for animation at Warner Brothers, which has revived production of its Bugs Bunny cartoons as well as moving into animated features. "You can not only rerelease them theatrically, but in video," where Disney has had tremendous success with such classic titles as "Bambi" and "The Jungle Book," which generated 6.4 million advance orders from video shops when it was offered last month.
 
New Ways to Profit
 Studios have also learned that the merchandising of cartoon characters in stores or at theme parks can be just as lucrative as a theatrical release. "The tail is not only wagging the dog, it's larger than the dog," Mr. Solomon, the film historian, complained. "A film is seen as a great big commercial for a character that has been created with merchandising and licensing rights in mind."
In a time of rapidly escalating film production costs, animated movies are also attractive because they are relatively cheap to make. Though the Motion Picture Association of America calculated the average movie production cost at $27.5 million last year, the director and producer Steven Spielberg said his company was able to make "Fievel Goes West" for about $16.5 million.
Mr. Spielberg said his company, which is also involved in production of the "Tiny Toon" cartoons for television, plans to follow "Fievel Goes West" with animated versions of "Cats" and Rudyard Kipling's "Just So" stories. His only concern is that the vogue for animated movies comes at a time when there is a limited pool of talent, which helps to drive up salaries and add to production costs.
"What we have already discovered, and what other studios will discover, is that there is not exactly an army of animators waiting for employment, but a complete shortage," Mr. Spielberg said. "Within their own little world, they are beginning to attain the status of Kevin Costner and Julia Roberts, and studios are starting to steal from studios."
To cut down on costs, Hollywood animation companies are farming out much of their less complicated work, such as the inking and painting of the thousands of cels that make up an animated movie, to Europe or Southeast Asia, where labor costs are less than half those in the United States. Movies like "Fern Gully" have also been quick to take advantage of recent advances in technology, especially computers.
"We never could have done this film without them," said Bill Kroyer, the former Disney animator who directed the movie. "We use our computer to animate reptiles, vehicles, trees and plants, to save our artists from having to draw them. Our computer has touched almost every phase of the project."
The current combination of market and technological forces makes it possible to imagine a time when studios will regard animated features as a genre that must be represented on their production schedules, several studio executives said. The people actually making the movies hope that forecast proves to be correct.
"In the golden era, every studio had an animation department," Mr. Spielberg said. "There's no limit to it, unless bad stories and bad animation resurface because of economic pressures."

HEADLINE: Baby Beckons. Why Is Daddy at Work?

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
"THIS is Gordon Rothman at 'CBS This Morning,' but you can call me Mr. Mom."
You can also call him an exception. Mr. Rothman, a field producer who left that message on his answering machine at work, is doing what a great many men in corporate America say they dream of, but dare not do for fear of wrecking their careers: he is on a leave of absence to take care of his infant daughter. 
 "I always wanted to share as much as I could in the raising of a child, and my wife and I want Hannah to spend as much time with her parents as possible in her first year," said Mr. Rothman, who began his nine-week leave when his wife, Faith Justice, finished a three-month maternity leave from her job at Pitney Bowes .
Mr. Rothman's employer, CBS , is one of a growing number of companies that allow fathers to take leaves to care for babies. But Mr. Rothman, who lives in New York City, is one of the relatively few men who have taken advantage of that dramatic change in corporate policy. Indeed, he said he knew of no other new father at CBS who had gone on leave.
"The few fathers who take a couple of months off from work tend to end up on the covers of magazines," said Fran Rodgers, the president of Work/Family Directions , a consulting firm in Boston. "So it looks like a trend, but it isn't. There is no company where very many men are taking months off."
The numbers are low even at companies that are leaders in this area. "There is something in the corporate culture that says to men, 'Don't do it,' " said Allen W. Bergerson, the director of personnel policy development at Eastman Kodak , one such employer. Kodak says that since its family leave policy began in 1987, offering employees up to 17 weeks of unpaid time off, 42 men and 624 women have used it to care for infants. Seventy-five percent of Kodak's employees are men.
Researchers also say men usually take off less time than women because they think they look more serious about their jobs if they do not take a full leave.
Besides the worry that time off from work with a baby could shift a man's career off the fast track and onto the "daddy track," financial considerations discourage fathers who might consider taking a leave, especially those who are primary breadwinners. Such leave is unpaid at most companies that offer it.
But as Ms. Rodgers said, "This is more than just an economic issue."
Mr. Rothman agreed: "Five years from now I'm not going to look back and say I wish I had the money instead."
To Richard J. Salls, who lives in Cranford, N.J., the need to spend time with his children outweighed the need for a paycheck when his second son was born in January 1990. He resigned as a finance manager at Ciba-Geigy , the drug manufacturer, to spend at least a year with his children. His wife, Nansie, who took a three-month leave from her job as an accounting manager at Centercore , a maker of office furniture, has been supporting the family.
Mr. Salls's company offered a three-month leave following childbirth, but he did not consider it an option. "There was nothing in the policy that said men could not take the leave," he said, "but there was an unwritten rule that men do not do it."
Parental leave for fathers has been a subject of much public discussion in this era of equal-opportunity parenthood. But it has failed to take hold, say researchers who study the behavior of men in corporations, because men generally fear that it would make them appear soft in their commitment to work and prevent advancement. For some new fathers who have temporarily traded desks for diapers, they add, that is exactly what has happened. Women note that taking time off to care for babies does not advance their careers either, but that does not stop them from doing it.
Advocates of parental leave say that if a family and medical leave bill sponsored by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, becomes law, it would do a great deal to legitimize the concept of time off for new fathers. The bill, which Congress is expected to vote on this summer, would require companies with 50 or more employees to provide up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for various important family situations, including the birth or adoption of a child.
Similar legislation was passed last year and vetoed by President Bush, who said the Government should not order companies to provide certain benefits. The White House has threatened to veto the bill again.
"The bill would legally open opportunities for men, but it would also have a psychological effect," said James A. Levine, director of the Fatherhood Project at the Families and Work Institute in New York, which does research for companies. "It would help to normalize the notion of parental leave."
Although the number of employers offering leaves for new fathers has risen in recent years, a majority of American men are not covered. A survey of 521 large companies conducted in 1988 for the Conference Board found that 60 percent offered a leave beyond routine disability following childbirth for mothers; 44 percent offered a leave for fathers.
The survey asked the maximum length of the leaves. The averages: 56 days for mothers; 18 days for fathers.
While few men make use of formal leave policies, researchers say it has become common for new fathers to arrange short unofficial leaves. Men take an average of six days off when a child is born by using vacation days or calling in sick, said Joseph H. Pleck, the Luce Professor of the Family at Wheaton College. "Men are very careful not to have this labeled as time off with a child," Dr. Pleck said. "It is a quiet revolution."
Proponents of extended leave for men say that research shows that babies benefit greatly from time spent with fathers, and that the experience helps strengthen families. Moreover, they argue, the opportunity should be available equally to mothers and fathers. But those ideals tend to dissipate in the face of corporate and family realities.
Mr. Levine said he recently met a man at a large company "who had been regarded as a high-potential candidate, but after he took parental leave his career stalled." A man at another company, he said, was advised by his boss not to go on leave because "it would be a bad sign of his commitment and would be held against him."
At a time of recession and widespread layoffs, parental leave without pay is unthinkable for many fathers who worry that taking time off could increase their vulnerability. In addition, at many companies that offer parental leave, men are unaware of it. Researchers say that some companies have parental leave policies for both men and women, to protect themselves against charges of sex discrimination, but that they make no effort to tell men about the policies.
Mark Moreland, a senior engineer at Corning who took a month's leave this year, said he knew nothing of his company's policy for new fathers before his wife, Nancy, became pregnant. Mr. Moreland, who lives in Elmira, N.Y., said his supervisor, whose approval was required, did not know about the 13-year-old policy either.
For some men, the changing nature of family life has given the issue of parental leave a new urgency. For example, if the mother's income is larger than the father's, a couple might decide that it makes economic sense for the father to stay home with a baby. And some couples find that the father's employer is more generous with parental leave than the mother's. For men who are single parents, the issue is especially acute.
Some working parents look to parental leave as a child-care solution for an infant. Raymond St. Francis, an architect on the corporate real estate staff at International Business Machines, and his wife, Susan Peterson, an architect with GTE , took back-to-back leaves to take care of their son. Mr. St. Francis began a six-month leave in February, when his wife's three-month leave ended.
"We felt that at 3 months, Adrian was much too young for day care," said Mr. St. Francis, who lives in Stamford, Conn.
Mr. Salls, who is looking for a job, described his 16 months as a full-time father as "a great experience and an unbelievable risk."
"You worry that the person interviewing you for a job might not fully understand what you did," he said. "I wish corporations would realize that some parents don't want better day-care centers. They want time with their kids."

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL: TV SPORTS;
Parcells Courted By TV

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Despite Bill Parcells's protestations yesterday that he has no plans for his post-Giants future, he has laid the groundwork for at least two possible career moves -- to NBC and the Madison Square Garden Network.
In March, Robert Fraley, Parcells's agent, initiated talks with NBC that led to an audition for an analyst's job and with MSG about being host for a weekly program about the National Football League. 
 NBC Sports's executive producer, Terry O'Neil, said: "Fraley called and asked, 'If Bill were to leave coaching, would you be interested in him?' I said, 'Yes we would,' and then, 'To help answer the question, would Bill audition?' "
O'Neil brought Parcells together with play-by-play announcer Don Criqui on March 23 to make a tape of last season's American Football Conference between the Raiders and Bengals divisional playoff game. Bill Walsh tested in the same studio before he was hired by NBC.
O'Neil said there have been no formal negotiations with Parcells and no offer has been tendered. "The talks have been informal," he said. "We'll give him a week and get in touch after that. There's no deadline except the start of the preseason."
O'Neil said unequivocally that there is room in the crowded NBC football booth for Parcells if he wants the job -- despite the presence of Walsh, Todd Christensen, Paul Maguire, Bob Trumpy, Ahmad Rashad and Joe Namath. "You can't have enough good analysts," O'Neil said.
A prime consideration in having room for Parcells is the arrival of Notre Dame football on NBC. Walsh will leave the N.F.L. booth for six Irish games this fall, and Rashad will also draw Notre Dame duty in the booth and studio.
NBC's economics makes it possible to pay Parcells upwards of $500,000 because it doesn't have analysts earning more than Walsh (about $575,000), the way that CBS's high-priced booth does, with John Madden leading the way at more than $1 million. In essence, money is a more important consideration to NBC than adding to the analyst head count.
Walsh's contract locks him into being the undisputed top football analyst for the next two years. Asked about the possibility of being joined by Parcells, Walsh said: "I look forward to having him at NBC. Neither of us have the kind of ego where we'll feel we're in competition with each other."
Parcells's talks with the MSG Network have gone considerably further than those at NBC. He has been speaking to the cable network since March -- and as recently as a week ago -- about a weekly N.F.L. show. MSG is speaking to the Prime Sports Network about making the program a national venture.
"This show would have no bearing on going to NBC," said Bob Gutkowski, president of the Madison Square Garden Communication Groups, parent company of the cable network. "I think he wants the MSG thing to be the first piece in his puzzle and then he'd make other decisions."
Gutkowski said that Parcells has qualities that make a show on MSG viable. "I've liked his ability to handle the media, his candor and his honesty," he said. "He's got a lot of credibility."
Parcells could probably earn about $200,000 from the MSG program and will probably have to decide soon whether to sign on to allow the network to plan its fall programming without him.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
T.W.A. Acts To Buy Debt Below Value

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines yesterday offered to buy back debt securities from creditors far below face value, arguing that the creditors faced even larger losses if the airline was forced to file for bankruptcy protection.
The airline also threatened a Chapter 11 filing if its three unions did not agree to major concessions and if creditors did not resolve lawsuits that could result in the courts allowing them to repossess aircraft and spare parts. 
 The airline said the offer to creditors was a "first step in a restructuring designed to enable T.W.A. to survive."
The various steps signaled that Carl C. Icahn, the chairman, was preparing for a long and difficult attempt to cut the carrier's costs and make it viable or attractive enough to be bought by another airline.
The airline said it would use the proceeds of the $445 million sale of London routes to American Airlines to buy back the bonds.
 
Impact of the War
 Mr. Icahn this week sold his 13.5 percent interest in USX Corporation for $1.02 billion, but in the annoucement yesterday there was no mention of the sale or indication that any of the proceeds would be used to buy back T.W.A. debt.
T.W.A. also issued earnings yesterday, reporting a loss of $88.2 million for first quarter compared with a loss of $143 million in the first quarter of 1990. Much of the loss came from a decline of traffic as a result of the war in the Persian Gulf and the recession in the United States.
The airline's revenues in the first quarter totaled $820.2 million, down 19.2 percent from revenues of $1 billion in the first quarter of last year.
Several analysts said that the offers for the various debt securities would prove attractive to creditors even though they would be asked to swallow considerable losses.
"It's an interesting offer that is definitely worth considering," said Ray Neidl, an airline industry analyst for Dillon, Read & Company.
 
Opening Move Is Seen
 However, one bondholder, Mel Ehrlich, the vice president of corporate bond trading at Halpert & Company, said he saw Mr. Icahn's offer as an opening move and would hold on.
He said that the mood was similar among other bondholders he had talked to and that they all expected Mr. Icahn to sweeten his offer. He said that his firm held the subordinated notes for which Mr. Icahn was offering 17.5 cents on the dollar. He added that he had bought more of the notes yesterday at 15 cents on the dollar.
Mr. Neidl also said that the airline's argument that creditors would get much less if T.W.A. was forced into bankruptcy carried weight since it would be difficult to get good prices for assets when other carriers were also seeking to sell assets.
 
Concessions Offered to Outsider
 Still, Mr. Icahn would save more than $700 million in debt if creditors accept his offer. Mr. Neidl estmated that it would cost Mr. Icahn about $500 million to buy back $1.236 billion worth of debt.
The T.W.A. creditors who choose not to accept the cash tender offer would get equity and new debt.
 The airline said that Mr. Icahn owned a total of $188.6 million in subordinated notes and about 90 percent of the common stock of T.W.A. Mr. Icahn has estimated that he will lose more than $40 million in the buyback of debt securities.
If the debt is retired, T.W.A. would save more than $150 million a year in interest costs.
Even if most of the creditors go along, T.W.A. would face a major battle with its unions, which have backed an effort to buy the airline by Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast investor. The unions have agreed to a package of concessions that they would offer to Mr. Kerkorian who has promised to inject $250 million into the airline if he can aquire it. Mr. Icahn has spurned the buyout effort so far.
The airline has also resorted to withholding payment on debt and equipment leases to conserve cash. It has defaulted on about $200 million in principal and interest payments.
Some creditors have been able to get a court decision that they could seize aircraft and spare parts if payments were not made.
In the tender offer, T.W.A. said it was offering 73 cents on the dollar on its equipment trust certificates; 65 cents on the dollar for its 15 percent senior notes; 35 cents on the dollar for its unsecured notes, and 17.5 cents on the dollar for its subordinated notes.
 
Less Debt, Less Cash
 William Compton, the chairman of the negotiating committee of the pilots' union at T.W.A., said that there was concern that Mr. Icahn was depleting the airline of cash in retiring the debt.
"You've got less debt, but there is a lot of cash leaving the company," he said. "How do you make this thing work afterward?"
He added that the holders of the subordinated notes should get equity instead of cash since the notes were issued when Mr. Icahn took the carrier private and withdrew $469 million in cash for himself.
He said that Mr. Icahn was a major holder of the subordinated notes, which had traded as low as 9 cents on the dollar. By offering 17.5 cents on the dollar, he said, Mr. Icahn increased the value of the notes on the open market.

LENGTH: 492 words

HEADLINE: Malpractice Victims: Ignored

 BODY:
Medical liability insurance premiums are rising by more than 20 percent a year, forcing some physicians to practice defensive, and therefore costly, medicine and to withdraw from risky service altogether. What can government, which pays some of the bills, do about it? Yesterday the Bush Administration issued its answer.
Make that half an answer. The Administration plan addresses cost, finding ways to insulate doctors and hospitals against outlandish settlements. But it virtually ignores the pain of thousands of victims of malpractice, people who don't sue and don't collect a dime.
 
 According to the American Medical Association, malpractice insurance premiums add $5.6 billion to patient bills and about $15 billion to defensive practices. Because fees are high and physicians have been forced to withdraw from high-risk services like obstetrics, the Administration contends that an attack on malpractice awards will improve access to quality care.
The Bush proposal would encourage states to adopt the reforms by reallocating a small percentage of Federal medical reimbursements. It would place a $250,000 cap on non-economic damages like pain and suffering. States would be required to set up dispute-resolution mechanisms and strengthen medical boards to establish treatment guidelines.
The Administration is right: Many doctors are sued inappropriately. And many states lack guidelines to help juries make awards reasonable and consistent. The system often looks more like a crapshoot than reasonable recompense.
But there's another dimension: Thousands of malpractice victims get no compensation at all. Paul Weiler, a Harvard law professor, cites a study of New York hospitals in 1984 of which he was co-author. It found that only one in eight victims ever sued -- and only half of them received compensation. Correcting this problem would add billions to medical insurance premiums, perhaps explaining the Administration's silence.
Another, more recent study of which Mr. Weiler was co-author, for the American Law Institute, offers evidence challenging different points in the Administration plan. Fixed caps on non-economic damages would only affect the most extreme and expensive injuries. A better way to handle arbitrary rewards would be for states to create guidelines for all types of injuries.
This report also recommends that attorney's fees be included among recoverable damages -- essential if jury awards are scaled back as the Administration recommends. The Bush plan is silent on this point, just as it is silent, and surprisingly so, on a larger philosophical point of presumably strong interest to conservatives especially: On what ground does the Federal Government intrude into what heretofore has been a matter for the states?
Medical malpractice needs serious reform. President Bush offers half a plan. Congress could wisely turn to the well-crafted Law Institute report for the rest.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Small-Business Agency Gives Award to Woman

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Joann R. Schulz has been named the National Small Business Person of the Year by the Small Business Administration. She is the first woman so honored in the 27 years that the Federal agency has presented the award.
Mrs. Schulz, who is 45, was cited for her work as president of DGR Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., a maker of ophthalmic products for eye surgeons. Mrs. Schulz took over the company in 1986 after the death of her husband, Richard, who had been president. His death came only a year after the company was founded and it was struggling. 
 "The company could not afford to put all founders on the payroll," she said. "My husband was president, heading operations; another founder headed manufacturing. We also hired an assembler."
When her husband died of a heart attack at 44, Mrs. Schulz thought her new position was temporary. She already headed a consulting firm, Regtech, which helped companies to obtain Food and Drug Administration approvals.
"I planned to stay for three months, which became six months and then five years," she said.
In 1990, sales totaled $4 million and pretax profit was $1 million. "This year, sales will be about $6 million and pretax profit about $1.5 million," Mrs. Shultz estimated. She said the company now had 75 employees.
In March, Mrs. Schulz resigned as head of DGR to become president of a larger company, Phoenix Laser Systems Inc., a San Francisco optical products concern. She said she hoped to merge Phoenix with DGR, where she still owns 17 percent of the stock.
Mrs. Schulz, who majored in chemistry and biological science, received her undergraduate degree from the University of California in 1973. She added a master's degree in biochemistry in 1977.
Her first professional job was with an ophthalmic unit of American Hospital Supply. "I left in 1979 to work in the technical area, for Coburn Optical, then a division of Revlon and based in Florida," she said, adding that she took the job even though she did not like the general manager. "A year and a half later, in 1980, I married him," she said.

HEADLINE: Nomination To Fed Seat Is Expected

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
President Bush is expected to name Susan M. Phillips, a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, to a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board.
Administration officials said this week that Ms. Phillips's nomination had been tentatively approved by President Bush on the basis of a recommendation from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, but would not be announced until the Federal Bureau of Investigation had completed its background check. 
 The background investigations required of top Presidential appointees often take months. Because Ms. Phillips has been out of the Government for only four years, hers could take less time.
Meantime, the assumption throughout the Administration is that Alan Greenspan will be given another four-year term as chairman of the Fed when his term expires in August, but officials said no high-level discussions had yet been held on the chairmanship.
Ms. Phillips, who is 46 years old, is now vice president of finance and university services at the University of Iowa. She was a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission from 1981 to 1983 and its chairman from 1983 until 1987. Her office in Iowa City said she was traveling today and could not be reached.
Her academic speciality is finance and financial markets. Her views on monetary policy, the main responsibility of the Federal Reserve Board, are not widely known.
That is characteristic of Mr. Bush's other nominations to the seven-member board of the central bank. The first person he put on the board, David W. Mullins Jr., was an Assistant Treasury Secretary who specialized in banking matters. Mr. Bush's next nominee, Lawrence B. Lindsey, was a White House economist whose academic expertise is tax policy. Mr. Lindsey's confirmation is pending before the Senate.
Ms. Phillips would replace Martha R. Seger, who resigned in March, in what seems to have become the woman's seat on the Federal Reserve Board. Ms. Seger succeeded Nancy H. Teeters, who in 1978 became the first woman to sit on the board.
Mr. Greenspan's renomination, said one Administration official who works on economic policy, "is a foregone conclusion." Reconfirmation by the Senate would be required, but he would face little opposition, if any. Officials said a final decision on the chairmanship would be made in a month or two.
 
Viewed as a Loyalist
 Although Mr. Brady, and to a lesser extent President Bush himself, have been critical of Mr. Greenspan, accusing him of retarding economic growth by keeping interest rates unnecessarily high, the Fed chairman is generally viewed as an Administration loyalist.
Mr. Brady and Mr. Boskin are especially fond of him and are expected to vigorously advocate his renomination. The only question is the opinion of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. Some officials suggested that Mr. Sununu might favor replacing Mr. Greenspan, but they said they did not know Mr. Sununu's position with certainty.
In the one publicly known instance when Mr. Brady and Mr. Sununu disagreed over an appointment, the President sided with the Treasury Secretary. That was late last year when Mr. Brady wanted to keep Robert L. Clarke as Comptroller of the Currency and Mr. Sununu wanted to remove him.
According to several middle-level officials, two important factors make Mr. Greenspan's renomination likely. The first is that there is no obvious candidate to replace him. When the Reagan Administration decided in 1987 that it did not want to keep Paul A. Volcker as Fed chairman, Mr. Greenspan was widely seen as waiting in the wings.
The other factor is the potentially adverse reaction in Congress and in the financial markets if Mr. Greenspan is not retained. He is unusually popular among both parties in Congress and is widely respected on Wall Street, where he spent most of his professional career as an economist.

HEADLINE: Let's Borrow More Money

BYLINE: By John Kenneth Galbraith; John Kenneth Galbraith is emeritus professor of economics at Harvard.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
One cannot but marvel on encountering an issue of major popular concern on which, as now, there is a broad unity as to response. That issue is the recession and what to do about it. The truly complete agreement by all levels of government is on measures designed to make it worse.
Everywhere across the country governments are tightening budgets, curtailing services, reducing payrolls, furloughing workers -- or promising to do so. Individuals immediately affected, needless to say, have their spending -- and resulting support to the economy -- promptly reduced. Many under threat of unemployment are impelled to retrench. So also those in receipt of welfare and other payments now being curtailed or threatened with curtailment. 
 The depressive effect goes on -- to those people from whom all these formerly purchased goods and services and to their employees. It is what my technically more elegant professional colleagues call a multiplier effect, this one being in reverse.
President Bush and numerous official and volunteer spokesmen have advised that the recession will be shallow and brief. The third or fourth or some slightly later quarter will see the automatic recovery. Better home sales and the small improvement in retail sales announced this week surely point the way. All those who so speak should be regarded with restraint. They divide as between those who do not know and those who do not know they do not know.
Similarly suspect are those who speak confidently of the magic of monetary action, the therapeutic marvel of a modest reduction in interest rates. On all this, there are warnings from the past. So many optimistic predictions were made in the early months of the Great Depression that Simeon D. Fess, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was led to suspect an exceptionally devious plot to discredit Herbert Hoover's Administration. "Every time an Administration official gives out an optimistic statement about business conditions, the market immediately drops," he said.
It is better and safer that all levels of government reverse course and unite in making things better. Accepting the conservative conviction that recessions are soon over, let us have short-run borrowing to sustain services and thus to cover the recession-induced shortfall in revenues. Then if automatic recovery is not assumed, this becomes even more important.
If there are constitutional barriers to borrowing, let there be steps to have them relaxed temporarily. More important, let the Federal Government, from its far greater fiscal resources, now establish a special fund, a latter-day Reconstruction Finance Corporation, with borrowing power on a scale in keeping with the savings and loan bailout. This would provide grants and low-interest loans to states and localities in the months ahead. Thus would the deflationary effects (and human costs) of the present course of events be arrested or reversed.
There is something bizarre in an Education President urging educational reform when school districts are curtailing the school term, freezing or cutting teachers' pay and, in some extreme cases, threatening to close schools for lack of money, and students in state colleges and universities are reacting in despair to higher tuition, curtailed scholarship funds and reduced course offerings.
The financing corporation should invest in repair and improvement of roads and bridges, urban transport facilities, airports and other, as it is called, infrastructure. We are now seeking through lower interest rates to encourage private investment; why not proceed with greatly needed public investment?
As a bow to fiscal conservatism, perhaps we should have a higher- bracket tax increase to cover interest and amortization on the borrowing by this corporation. The expansive effect of the large immediate expenditure would far offset the small restraining effect of the more enduring tax.
The important thing is to get all levels of government off their present deflationary track. They are supposed to be the guardians of the public well-being. Presently, they are united in making it worse.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Tribune Co.'s Bleak News

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 16

 BODY:
The Tribune Company's 1991 earnings will fall far short of last year's earnings, even excluding losses at The Daily News in New York, according to Charles T. Brumback, the president.
The Chicago-based media company had taken a one-time charge against earnings of $295 million in the fourth quarter last year related to the sale of The Daily News to the British publisher Robert Maxwell on March 20. The company lost $63.5 million in 1990, but would have shown income of $191.5 million, or $2.64 a share, without the New York paper. 
 Earnings likely will be "well below" that in 1991, Mr. Brumback said at the company's annual meeting Wednesday. He blamed declines in advertising and a sluggish economy.
"But assuming modest improvement in the economy, the trends should be in the right direction and we are looking for better results in 1992," Mr. Brumback said in a statement.
At the meeting, outside directors defended the company's handling of a long strike at The Daily News.
"All Mr. Brumback and management were trying to do was run the business for the shareholders in the most efficient way," said Frank W. Considine, a director who is honorary chairman of American National Can Company.

HEADLINE: HOUSING IN MASSACHUSETTS;
Brokers and Lenders Join To Push Cape Cod Sales

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HYANNIS, Mass., May 16

 BODY:
Anyone interested in buying property on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard this summer can get a quick one-stop look at what's available on Sunday when 22 real estate brokers, two mortgage loan companies and a Cape Cod bank will display their wares in a Hyannis hotel showroom.
The showcase has been organized by Premier Productions, a small promotions firm based in Brookline, Mass. Andrea Dale, a partner, said each broker and lending company would have a booth with pictures and fact sheets on the properties they are handling in a large meeting room at the Tara Hyannis from 10 A.M. until 5 P.M. Admission is $2.50 for adults; children will be admitted without charge. 
 "With New England real estate prices at their lowest levels in nearly four years and with the usual great interest in property on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard, we thought this would be a great time to give possible buyers a chance to get an introductory look at what's available right now in the two areas," she said.
The azaleas, forsythia and beach plums are not the only source of great swatches of yellow, red and white this week. There are also the myriad for-sale signs stretching like ceremonial flags along all the major roads and streets.
It is truly a buyer's market: Near-record numbers of residential property and condominium units are listed for sale, average prices are at or near the bottom of the trough, interest rates have been slowly slipping down for six weeks and the Cape and Martha's Vineyard have just come through one of the worst winters of sales on record.
As of April 12, the latest counting period of the Cape Cod Board of Realtors, there were 4,340 residential units and 861 condominium units listed for sale on the Cape and Martha's Vineyard, one of the highest totals on record.
According to the figures released last week by the Massachusetts Association of Realtors, the average selling price for detached, single-family homes on the Cape fell by 14.3 percent, to $153,099, in the first quarter of 1991 from the period a year earlier. The Cape's average was well below the state's, which was $172,122, a decline of 10.3 percent.
According to the Banker & Tradesman, an independent publication that charts each sale recorded at local registries of deeds, residential sales on the Cape in the first quarter of this year fell to 689 from 936 last year, a drop of 26 percent. Condo unit sales fell to 75 from 142, a decline of 47 percent.
As of last Sunday, 15-year fixed-rate mortgages ranged from 8.87 percent to 9.25 percent, while 30-year fixed-rates ranged from 9.12 to 9.62 percent.
Some real estate brokers say they are certain prices have hit bottom and are turning up.
Charles F. Lockhart, executive vice president of the Board of Realtors, said that in the last two months there had been a clear rise in the number of houses under contract but not yet closed.
There has also been an increase in buyer interest, he said, and most of this was in asking prices of $150,000 to $160,000.
"One reason for this," he said, "is that our brokers are handling an unusually large number of properties taken over by the banks. Many of these are on the market at excellent prices for a buyer."
Egerton Homes Massachusetts is another believer in the upturn theory. For the last year, this development company managed to keep its large Stratford Pond condominium development in Mashpee alive by selling units through an equity sharing plan. Under this plan, a buyer borrows half of the purchase price and occupies a unit (average full price about $180,000). The other half of the price would be dormant for five years, after which the buyer would borrow the remainder.
Egerton no longer uses this plan, said Carl A. Grassetti, its president, because sales are beginning to pick up. "All of last year, only 15 to 18 units were sold and built at Stratford Pond," he said. "But now, with regular financing, we're averaging a sale a week."

HEADLINE: More Economic Pain Seen for Soviets

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The economy of the Soviet Union faces a decline in output of 10 percent, an inflation rate exceeding 100 percent and the likelihood of a "radically worse" year, American intelligence agencies said today.
Those forecasts were included in the annual report to Congress on the state of the Soviet economy by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency. 
 In an appendix, the C.I.A. notes that over the years it has been much more conservative than the official Moscow analysis of Soviet economic conditions, but it adds that lately Soviet and Western estimates seemed to be converging in several categories as a result of sharp, downward revisions by Soviet statisticians.
In an accompanying presentation to the Technology and National Security Subcommittee of the Joint Economic Committee, C. Patrick Duecy of the Defense Intelligence Agency said that "despite much fanfare," the Soviet Government had made little progress in converting military industries to civilian production.
 
Best Case: 10% Decline in Output
 The analyst said that while the Pentagon expects the Soviet Union to continue modernizing its forces and weapons systems, "military programs will likely have to be cut further."
The intelligence agencies envisioned various scenarios in which the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev either succeeded in mediating the worst differences between the central Government and restive Soviet republics or failed and turned to more repressive measures. Even in the best case -- with improvement in relations between the central Government and the republics and a renewal of reform efforts -- the study says Soviet output would "probably still fall some 10 percent."
In the worst case, repressive steps "to control the republics, to enforce state orders and to stabilize the economy" would speed "the downward spiral," it says.
In that case, the study says, "the decline would eventually equal or exceed the 30 percent drop in G.N.P. and the 25 percent unemployment rate experienced in the United States during the Great Depression of 1930-1933."
That mirrors the view of the general trend of the Soviet economy voiced by some Soviet analysts, among them Vladimir M. Mashchits, one of the young economists who helped draft a "500-day plan" of drastic revisions commissioned and then rejected by President Gorbachev last year. "We are in a classic slide, which nothing can stop," Mr. Mashchits said a month ago. "It may take another year to reach bottom."
Describing various elements of "an economy in turmoil," the study speaks of "a breakdown in the distribution system" and "the twin threats of rising unemployment and accelerating consumer inflation." It notes that republic authorities have deliberately held back deliveries of such commodities as grain, fruit and livestock products -- preferring to barter them. Republics producing oil, coal and cotton have similarly ignored central delivery orders in favor of barter deals.
It attributes the current economic problems in part to "a progressive loss of control over financial flows, a mismanaged shift of resources from invstment and defense to consumption and rising political and social tensions."
Productivity declined in 1990 in considerable part because of a loss of 10 million worker days due to strikes.
 
Foreign Trade Suffers
 While it is still the world's leading producer of oil, output continues to decline after a 6 percent decrease last year, cutting into the Soviet Union's vitally needed hard-currency earnings.
Soviet foreign trade is also suffering, the study says, with record deficits arising from a surge in the import of consumer goods to meet ballooning domestic shortages. Despite the imports, the situation of the ordinary Soviet citizen "has worsened since the beginning of the year," the study says -- partly a result of a decrease in the domestic manufacture of consumer goods.
The C.I.A.'s chief Soviet analyst, George Kolt, acknowledging past criticism of his agency's estimates of Soviet economic performance in comparison with that of the United States, said that the Soviet gross national product was probably overstated because, for example, it was impossible to adjust completely for inferior goods and services.
The agency said, for instance, that the Soviets concluded there was a 3 percent growth in the economy in 1989, while the C.I.A. concluded the percentage change was only half that.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Activity In Advance of Trade Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose slightly against most major currencies yesterday in light trading as the market awaited a report on the nation's balance of trade.
The market all but ignored the news that Karl Otto Pohl resigned as president of Germany's Bundesbank. Traders said they were reassured by comments from Mr. Pohl and other German officials that the central bank would not change its policy of controlling inflation through tight money. 
 In addition, Mr. Pohl's departure had been rumored for several days and so was not a surprise, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange trading at Paine Webber.
"The market believes the Bundesbank policy will not change with or without Mr. Pohl," Mr. Troni said.
The currency market also had little reaction to comments by a Treasury official that the dollar's value was about right. The Under Secretary of the Treasury, David C. Mulford, told a Senate subcommittee that the upward move of the dollar since the end of the gulf war had not adversely affected United States exports.
Mr. Troni said similar comments had been made earlier by other Bush Administration officials. He said the market was marking time ahead of today's release of merchandise trade figures for March.
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6968 German marks, up from 1.68445 marks on Wednesday. In European trading the dollar rose to 1.6965 German marks, up from 1.6895.
In Tokyo, the dollar ended the day at 137.30 Japanese yen, down from 137.89 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 137.50 yen. The dollar was quoted at 137.45 yen in late New York trading, up from 137.15 late on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7465, from $1.7475 late on Wednesday. In New York, the pound cost $1.7595, up from $1.7540.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4374 Swiss francs, up from 1.4240; 5.7460 French francs, up from 5.7145; 1,261 Italian lire, up from 1,252, and 1.1500 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1490.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Bonn's Contrasts With Washington

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
A COALITION of top Administration officials and business executives has been pushing the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates, and thus far Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, and a majority of the Fed's policy makers have been cautiously going along. The Economist last week read the riot act to both the Administration and the Fed: "Not only has the Bush Administration shown itself incapable of exercising wise economic leadership but, much more disturbing, it seems that the Federal Reserve stands ready to do its bidding."
In Germany, however, the Bundesbank has been acting like Horatio at the bridge, defending its strong anti-inflationary policy and interest-rate structure against any and all threats from the Eastern provinces of Germany, Brussels, Bonn or Washington.
Does this contrast in German and American central-bank style simply reflect a difference in the personalities of the fiery Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank who announced his resignation yesterday for personal reasons, and the mild Mr. Greenspan? Or does it represent a difference in politics? (Mr. Pohl is a Social Democrat, unlike the Christian Democratic Chancellor, Helmut Kohl; Mr. Greenspan a Republican, like President Bush.) But the Bonn Government proclaims its own anti-inflationary fervor, and the mark has risen on the market's expectations that when Mr. Pohl leaves he will be replaced by an equally orthodox keeper of the Bundesbank's faith and integrity.
The difference in German and American monetary policies may represent contrasting national cultures, with Germans giving their highest priority to avoiding inflation and Americans to avoiding depression. The greatest economic trauma of Germany was the hyperinflation of the early 1920's, which wiped out the value of money, undermined the middle class and prepared the soil for Nazism. The worst economic trauma of the United States was the Great Depression and mass unemployment of the 1930's, which transformed capitalism and gave the state the responsibility of insuring high employment.
Yet there is still another way of interpreting recent Federal Reserve vs. Bundesbank behavior: as a reflection of their different reactions to the respective political and economic dangers facing both countries. In the United States, both the Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index rose in April by a modest two-tenths of 1 percent. Since December, under the impact of the recession, producer prices have declined at an annual rate of about 3.5 percent. And since February, consumer prices have risen at an annual rate of only about 1 percent. In 1990, consumer prices rose by 6.1 percent and producer prices by 5.6 percent.
As a result of the sharp decline in inflation, there has been little or no decline in real interest rates, measured as nominal interest rates minus the current or prospective rate of inflation. Since the recession began last July, the Treasury bill rate has come down to 5.57 percent from 7.66 percent.
Without a cut in real, rather than just nominal, rates, the economic recovery is likely to get no help from monetary policy. How much should real rates come down to help the economy overcome its sluggishness? At a recent conference at the Jerome Levy Economic Institute of Bard College, Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard said, "I don't know and I don't pretend to know exactly how much real interest rates would have to come down, but I do know they haven't come down that much."
He calculated that the one-year Treasury bill rate has come down "visibly less" than the decline in the average inflation rate in seven of the last eight recessions. "What recovery we have in the next year," Professor Friedman said, "will be recovery not because of monetary policy but despite monetary policy.
But as inflation eases in the United States, inflationary expectations are rising in Germany. Though the Consumer Price Index for the whole of Germany has been rising at an annual rate of about 3 percent, up only slightly from the 1990 rate of 2.7 percent, inflation has soared at an annual rate of 20 percent to 30 percent in what was formerly East Germany, said Adolphe J. Warner, chairman of Global Assets Management Associates and the retired senior adviser to the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation.
The East Germans have been unable thus far to rid themselves of the incubus of their Communist past, with its inculcated habits of high but concealed inflation, low or negative productivity growth, widespread underemployment and (often concealed) unemployment, a lack of initiative and subservience to political masters.
The threat to inflation in the Federal Republic of Germany stems not just from the Eastern provinces but from the Government's huge expenditures on the East, big budget deficits and potential membership on the Bundesbank board of political hacks from the East.
Thus, the contrasts between German and American monetary policy stem not just from cultural or theoretical differences but from real differences in the political and economic problems confronting each country. This may be becoming a global economy, but nation-states and national currencies still matter.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Backs Expanded I.R.A.'s

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Legislation that would make tax-deductible individual retirement accounts available again to all Americans won a lukewarm endorsement today from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
But despite Mr. Greenspan's support, the popularity of I.R.A.'s among taxpayers and the sponsorship of more than three-quarters of the Senate, the measure is not likely to be enacted this year because of budget constraints. 
 In testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Greenspan called the low rate of savings "the key domestic economic policy problem of this country." After studying the matter carefully, Mr. Greenspan said, he found the evidence inconclusive that expanded retirement accounts would increase savings, but he added, "It's probably worth a chance, because even if it doesn't turn out to have any major net addition to national savings, there's probably very little damage that is done."Restrictions Put in Place
From 1981 through 1986, taxpayers could put up to $2,000 a year into retirement accounts and deduct the amount on their Federal tax returns. Since then, such deductions have been disallowed for taxpayers covered by other pension arrangements who have incomes above $25,000 for single people and $40,000 for couples.
In March, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, a senior Republican on the committee, introduced legislation that would make the I.R.A. rules even more generous than those in the early 1980's. Seventy-five Senators joined them as co-sponsors.
Under the Bentsen-Roth plan, taxpayers would have the option of taking the deduction when they put money into their retirement account and paying taxes when it is withdrawn or of forgoing the immediate deduction and enjoying tax-free income on all money left in the account for more than five years. In addition, money could be withdrawn without penalty to buy homes, pay tuition or meet large medical bills.
In times past, when the budget rules were more lax, such a measure would have sailed through Congress. But the budget law enacted last year requires any tax cuts to be offset dollar for dollar by a tax increase elsewhere or by reduced spending.
 
Cost of Legislation
 The Congressional tax staff has estimated that the Bentsen-Roth legislation would cost about $4.5 billion in lost revenue in the first year and more than $25 billion over five years.
Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Roth have not said how they would raise that, and whatever they propose is likely to generate significant opposition. "The co-sponsors are going to start dropping like flies as soon as the talk about the offset starts," said a Congressional staff expert.
The Bush Administration opposes the measure on budget grounds, as do key figures in the House. A spokesman for Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, characterized Mr. Rostenkowski's view this way: "I love I.R.A.'s, but where does Lloyd think the money's going to come from?"
Meanwhile, Mr. Rostenkowski said today in a speech to the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants that he would introduce a tax "simplification" bill next month. The chairman's spokesman said the bill would not change tax policy or the amount of revenue raised but would simplify arcane parts of the tax code, mostly involving corporations, that accountants find especially complicated and burdensome.
 
Called as First Witness
 Mr. Greenspan is the Government's most important economic policy maker, but he has no direct influence over tax policy. He was called nonetheless as the first witness on the I.R.A. bill in part because of the Bush Administration's opposition to the measure and in part because the Fed chairman is so widely admired in Congress as an economist that the measure's sponsors thought his endorsement, even a weak one, would add impetus to their drive.
Mr. Greenspan said that increasing the amount Americans save was cru cial to the country's long-term economic prospects. That is the only way to expand private investment and guarantee an increasing standard of living for Americans, he told the lawmakers.
Even reviewing the experience of the 1980's in hindsight, economists differ over whether I.R.A.'s increase private savings significantly or merely result in a tax break for people who shift money from a taxable account to a deductible one. They agree, however, that the wealthier the taxpayers, the more likely they are to save in a retirement account.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Japanese Parent to Aid Bridgestone/Firestone

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 16

 BODY:
The Japanese parent of Bridgestone/ Firestone Inc. said today that it would inject $1.4 billion into the debt-ridden United States tire maker.
The Bridgestone Corporation, Japan's biggest tire company, said the infusion, which it will make by the end of the month, would be used as a capital reserve and to cut the subsidiary's heavy debt. The wholly owned United States unit, based in Akron, Ohio, owes $3 billion. 
 "Bridgestone/Firestone has been investing to upgrade its facilities and everyone has been working to improve quality," said Akira Yeiri, president of the Bridgestone Corporation. Because of these capital expenditures, he said, the company has taken on a large amount of debt. But he said Bridgestone wanted to "revitalize" its American operations in order to become "the world's leading tire company."
The added debt, coupled with a severe downturn in the industry, has left Bridgestone/Firestone hard-pressed to pay its bills.
The tire maker is also struggling with lower sales as a result of the recession. Bridgestone/Firestone lost $350 million in 1990 and dismissed 500 managers last month. More cutbacks in facilities and personnel are expected.
Bridgestone, which controls about half the Japanese market, bought the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company three years ago. The merged company is the world's No. 2 tire maker after France's Groupe Michelin.
But foreign competition is intensifying, as the world's top companies consolidate. Earlier this week, Continental A.G. of Germany and Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy announced that they had opened friendly discussions to form an alliance.
On top of tougher competition, the pool of customers is shrinking. Tire prices are plunging as auto makers cut back production, reducing the need for original equipment tires.

HEADLINE: New York Workers Accept a Film Pact, Ending a Shutdown

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Reversing an earlier vote, members of a film-crafts union local accepted an accord yesterday with leading Hollywood producers to end a bitter stalemate that had virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City since November.
The acceptance came at a crucial time of year for New York's film industry, a vital part of the city's economy that is estimated to generate from $500 million to $2.3 billion in business as well as an abundance of ancillary jobs. Commitments can still be made to bring some big-budget productions to the city for summer filming, and one production that had left New York is coming back next week.
 
Terms Make City Attractive
 The settlement is viewed as a breakthrough that will bring substantial savings to producers for night and weekend shooting in New York, which had previously entailed substantial overtime penalties. The agreement will make New York more competitive since it will bring the city's film workers' rates into line with rates in Los Angeles, Chicago and other locations. 
 "The new contract terms are going to be a magnet for producers, and make New York an extremely attractive location," said Joel Grossman, vice president for labor relations at Columbia Pictures, who was the producers' chief negotiator with the film union local.
"On behalf of all New Yorkers I welcome the return of movie makers and movie making to the city where they belong," Mayor David N. Dinkins said at a news conference yesterday afternoon. He added that the city would "move forward with an aggressive marketing strategy that will win back this multibillion-dollar industry."
In mail ballots counted yesterday, the rank and file of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators voted 801 to 449 to accept the tentative settlement, which was reached on March 18. The 2,000-member union had stunned New York's film community by rejecting the same settlement on April 15 by a vote of 606 to 393.
The union decided to put the proposal to a second vote on April 25 after Local 52 came under intense pressure from members of other film unions and from the president of the union's international, Alfred W. DiTolla.
Walter Stocklin, president of Local 52, said the agreement was accepted "because a lot of our people must have had second thoughts, because if there is no work in the city, it doesn't matter what kind of contract you have."
The April 15 vote had caused a further exodus of feature films from New York, which was shunned by producers who had been planning to shoot movies in the city. In the last month, at least 10 films were steered away from New York City, including "Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune" and "The Babe Ruth Story."
Thanks to yesterday's vote, "Frankie and Johnny," a film starring Al Pacino and Michelle Pfeiffer that spurned New York for California in April, will start shooting in New York next week, said the Mayor's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcast.
"We hope that this vote means that some films will be here in July, and more by late summer," said Amy O. Sultan, an assistant director of the Mayor's film office. "We know a lot of people are anxious to start filming here, but have been holding off until the vote."
She estimated that, as a result of the boycott, the city had lost $100 million worth of film business so far this year.
The agreement offered the film producers money-saving changes in overtime and weekend pay in return for greater health and pension benefits. At the time of last month's rejection of the settlement, many union members had been out of work for as long as five months. But they were opposed to provisions that would have reduced their wages about 30 percent, Mr. Stocklin said.
Local 52 provides behind-the-scenes workers for movies in New York, including sound people, electricians, shop crafts workers, prop people, camera grips and set dressers.
The March agreement was reached in Sherman Oaks, Calif., between the producers and the bargaining committees of Local 52 and another film union, Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries. Members of Local 644, film cinematographers and camera crews, had, like members of Local 52, been working without a contract. Local 644 accepted the tentative agreement on May 3 by a vote of 478 to 30.
The major producers involved in the negotiations are five Hollywood studios: Columbia Pictures, the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Paramount Pictures and Warner Brothers, MGM-United Artists. A sixth, Orion Pictures, participated as a distributor.
 
Local Pressed to Settle
 "I'm delighted that the Local 52 membership has ratified the agreement, and I hope we can put the rancor behind us, and so what we do best -- make movies," said Mr. Grossman of Columbia.
Before the tentative settlement in March, the 19-week stalemate had halted major-studio movie making in New York City. Mayor Dinkins had pressed for a settlement along with the city's film office, the state's film office and the New York Commissioner of Labor, Thomas F. Hartnett, who met with the unions' executive boards.
In 1989, 110 films were shot partly or totally in New York City, the film office reported. In 1990, 139 films were shot in New York City. Since January, 48 feature-film permits, primarily for low-budget movies, have been granted by the film office, compared with 59 by this time last year, many of which were big-budget studio projects.
After Local 52's contract expired on Oct. 31 -- a month after Local 644's contract expired -- the producers promised to steer films away from New York City until an agreement was reached, amounting to a boycott of New York movie making other than independent productions, which have continued.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Service Is Dropped By Prodigy

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Prodigy, which provides computerized services to nearly a million subscribers, dropped its grocery shopping service on Wednesday in a cost-cutting move that is part of its continuing attempt to become profitable after three years of operation.
One analyst said the cutback of the service, which allowed people to order groceries using their home computer, illustrates Prodigy's problems in creating compelling services for its membership. Several analysts said the company must make further changes in its offerings and rein in costs in order to become profitable. 
 "They are going to have a major cutback," predicted Joshua Harris, president of Jupiter Communications Company, a research firm.
Using home computers and telephone lines, Prodigy Services Company, a joint venture between the International Business Machines Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company, connects nearly a million subscribers to games, electronic banking and shopping services. Analysts said I.B.M. and Sears have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in Prodigy, buying mainframe computers and hiring 1,200 employees to run the service.
 
Prodigy's Response
 Prodigy charges a flat fee of $12.95 a month to belong to the service, but the bulk of its revenue comes from charging companies to display electronic advertisements along the bottom portion of subscribers' computer screens.
A Prodigy spokesman, Brian Ek, played down the demise of the grocery shopping service. He said the grocery service was halted because it was available in only a limited number of cities and was used by just a fraction of Prodigy's members.
Mr. Ek said the company had spent a "significant amount of money" trying to make the grocery service work, but he declined to be more specific.
D'Agostino Supermarkets in New York had tried the service but dropped out last year, citing delivery problems and a lack of response.
Mr. Ek said Prodigy was on target for achieving profitability in the early 1990's. He said Prodigy's home banking, travel and discount brokerage services are enjoying steady growth.
He added that no other major cutbacks were planned, but said that, "in the current economic environment, everybody is looking for ways to cut costs."
Richard Adler, a long-time Prodigy watcher in San Francisco, said Prodigy needed to make substantial changes in order to become viable. "They have not found the secret of making people buy things through the service."

HEADLINE: With the Royal Visit, Britain Signals a New Reality

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The appearance of Queen Elizabeth II on Capitol Hill this morning, like her participation in the Bicentennial celebrations in 1976, had the unmistakable whiff of history about it. But it also had a practical, modern purpose: to symbolize and shore up the enduring 20th-century alliance between the two countries, by emphasizing the values, traditions and experiences they share, the latter most recently in the Persian Gulf.
The very setting for the speech was a reminder that Congress, like so many other deliberative bodies, is the offspring of the mother of parliaments in Westminster. The Queen was introduced by Representative Thomas S. Foley, who is called the Speaker of the House, just like the presiding officer in London; she gazed out at legislators who sit in party blocs, also as in London. 
 In case anybody missed the point, she called the two bodies "the twin pillars of our civilizations and the chief among the many treasures we have inherited from our ancestors."
Through all the long history of the American republic, no British sovereign had ever appeared before a joint Congressional session until today. For many and many a year, senators and representatives would hardly have welcomed a speech by a descendant of and successor to George III, the 18th-century king whom Thomas Paine once called "the Royal Brute of Great Britain."
 
'Our Common Enterprise'
 Few if any Americans hold the sins of George III against modern British rulers. Few even recall that most of the Declaration of Independence is directed against him personally ("He has plundered our seas, ravaged our coasts, burnt our towns and destroyed the lives of our people," it states.)
The Queen spoke of "our common enterprise throughout this turbulent century," making it sound as if the United States and Britain are permanent allies, always on the same side -- as they often are but were not, for example, in the Suez crisis of 1956.
Her words were those of an anonymous draftsman in the British Embassy here, officials said, approved by the Government of Prime Minister John Major, which has every reason to seek to strengthen the ties between London and Washington. They seemed to be loosening quite a lot only a few months ago, with Germany, reunified, assuming an ever more powerful role in an integrated Europe in which Margaret Thatcher's Britain appeared reluctant to play a leading role.
Now Mr. Major, less reluctant about Europe, is in power, central Europe is in some disarray and the German economy looks slightly less awe-inspiring. President Bush, who had described Germany as America's partner in European leadership, has now dispatched Ambassador Raymond Seitz to London. He said in his first interview there that it was "silly" to suggest, as many had, that the special relationship between Britain and the United States was waning.
Obviously Britain would like to keep the new trend going. It has many weapons in its arsenal as it tries to influence American policy and attitudes, and most of them were in use this week -- shared memories of World War II, which the Queen mentioned today, and the grandest ambassadorial residence in Washington, the great brick pile on Massachusetts Avenue designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens, where she entertained 1,500 people for tea on Wednesday, and the common language, celebrated at a luncheon at the Library of Congress.
The most potent is the Queen herself. France may have Lafayette, and Germany may have the crucial geopolitical position, but she is arguably the most famous person in the world -- a woman famous not for Andy Warhol's 15 minutes or for 15 years but for almost five decades. She is incalculably wealthy, a living link with the Britain of Chaucer and Shakespeare and Wellington and Churchill, who has herself been privy to the deepest secrets of the West since 1952, when Harry S. Truman lived in the White House and Joseph Stalin lived in the Kremlin.
She created a fuss in Washington this week that no other national leader could match, not even Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the height of Gorbamania, though there is a minority, here as in Britain, that views the whole institution of monarchy as anti-democratic or anachronistic or boring or all three.
 
Building Good Will
 Much of what she did was simple good-will-building, like her visit to a ball game and her trip to Mount Vernon. She deftly managed such unscripted moments as a most irregular hug from a woman whose house she visited and a podium on the White House lawn that made her seem to be wearing a talking hat.
But her celebrity also assures her words a wide audience, so this morning she talked substance. She sent a signal of the new reality, as London sees it, by making two main points about the Atlantic alliance. She asserted, "Britain is at the heart of a growing movement toward greater cohesion in Europe" -- not something she would have said during the Thatcher era -- and argued, "The best progress is made when Europeans and Americans act in concert." Not long ago, she might have said "Britons and Americans."
Finally, she mentioned three points that find their way onto every Western agenda, hoping, evidently, to move them just a little closer to the top of the list: the environment, the importance of the United Nations and the need for greater tolerance among ethnic and cultural groups.
The capital, which prides itself on its world-weariness the way New York prides itself on its aggression, seemed to enjoy it all. Not for the first time: after Elizabeth's first visit in 1951, while she was still a Princess, President Truman wrote to her father that she "went to the hearts of all the citizens of the United States."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Clears Way for Indian Casino

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 16

 BODY:
The last barrier to an Indian tribe opening Connecticut's first gambling casino fell tonight when the state House of Representatives rejected Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s emergency request to repeal the legal basis for the casino, a law allowing nonprofit groups to run "Las Vegas night" fund-raisers.
The 84-to-62 vote preserves the right of schools and church groups to conduct occasional casino nights for fund raising. But it also removes the state's last possible legal avenue to stop the tribe, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, from building their own profit-making casino on their reservation in Ledyard, in eastern Connecticut.The Pequots have used Federal Indian gaming laws to argue that the state's Las Vegas night statute opened the door to a profit-making casino, and the Federal Court system has agreed.
 
Social Ills Argument
 The United States Supreme Court refused to take the case last month, and Mr. Weicker, arguing that the advent of casino gambling would bring organized crime, prostitution and other social ills to the state, asked shortly afterward that the underlying law be revoked, despite the pain that might be felt by the nonprofit organizations. 
 Repeal, he said, would allow the state at least to try and persuade the Federal Department of the Interior not to issue the final casino approval. Mr. Weicker, an independent governor with no members of his own Connecticut Party in the General Assembly, said in a terse statement after the vote that the House had "decided the appropriateness of casino gambling in the state of Connecticut," and that he would cooperate with the tribe in carrying out operating guidelines from the Federal Government.
The Senate approved the repeal measure last week in an 18-to-17 vote, but the House's reversal today was unquestionably the final step.
Friday marks the last day of a public comment period under which objections to the casino could be forwarded to the Secretary of the Interior, Manuel Lujan Jr.
Even if the repeal had passed, the legislature would have had to suspend its rules to get the legislation to Mr. Weicker's desk in time to make the Federal deadline.
For many lawmakers, it was clearly a painful issue. On questions of economics, morality and the state's quality of life, the vote divided conservatives and liberals alike. There was also an emotionally articulated issue of race and justice: that repealing the law and blocking the casino at the last second would be a slap at Indians everywhere.
"One of the things that will never be rectified is what we have done to the Indians," said Representative Edna Negron, a Democrat from Hartford who opposed the repeal bill. "It's an issue of justice. They went through the process. They went through the courts. They did it right, they won."
Some of those seeking repeal tried to evoke the issue of Connecticut's quality of life, describing in detail the sordid characters and practices that surround gambling centers in Las Vegas and Atlantic City. Others portrayed the vote as an opportunity for the state to reassert its autonomy in the face of a Federal court system that they argued had overreached itself in clearing the path for the Indians.
Some lawmakers said they would vote for repeal even if they felt it would make no difference, simply to make their voice heard against the idea of casino gambling.
"I would prefer to go down kicking and screaming all the way," said Representative Sally Bolster, a Republican from Rowayton who voted for the bill.
The tribe, which has about 200 members, has already broken ground for the casino complex on its 1,800-acre reservation in Ledyard about an hour from the capital. Tribal officials said the casino plus the hotels and restaurants to be built in conjunction, would employ almost 2,000 people, and could open as early as this fall.
They also projected that it could bring as many as 500,000 tourists to a part of the state that is heavily dependent on defense spending and battered by the recession and by recent cutbacks in defense contracts. Local business groups in southeastern Connecticut have also endorsed the casino specifically in part because it will help diversify the economy.
