HEADLINE: Debt Issue By Chrysler

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation yesterday priced $400 million in floating-rate certificates backed by loans of its auto dealers, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
The certificates, which were priced at 99.75, pay interest monthly at 25 basis points above the one-month London interbank offered rate. The Libor rate, as it is known, is the basic short-term rate of interest in the Eurodollar market and the rate to which many Eurodollar loans and deposits are tied. Eurodollars are United States dollars held in banks outside the United States. 
 Traders had speculated that the certificates would probably float at 23 basis points over the one-month Libor. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The certificates are being sold as Carco Auto Loan 1991-1 by the Chrysler Auto Receivables Company and have an average life of 3.3 years and an expected maturity of Dec. 15, 1994, and a legal maturity of June 15, 1996.
Part of the financing includes some subordinated class B certificates that are backing the class A issue, as a cushion against losses.
Underwriters said the issue had been rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, Duff & Phelps and Fitch Investors Service.

HEADLINE: New Unemployment Claims Up Slightly in Early May

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The number of people filing their first claims for unemployment benefits rose a slight 4,000 in the week ended May 4, to 459,000, the Labor Department said today.
While the small increase was a sign the job market may be stabilizing, economists said the report also showed a recovery that was far from robust.
The only states that showed a significant deterioration in the job market were California, where the recession has arrived more recently, and Iowa.
 
Layoffs at Deere
 The department said California processed 3,660 new claims for jobless benefits in the week ended May 4 because of retrenchment in the retail, entertainment, aerospace and manufacturing sectors.
Layoffs at a Deere & Company subsidiary in Dubuque, Iowa, pushed up that state's new claims by 2,900, the department said.
The increases were offset by fewer first-time claims in some of the Middle Atlantic States and the Midwest, which had contributed to the sharp rises in unemployment claims in recent months.
The number of people receiving unemployment benefits expanded more sharply, showing that those already claiming benefits are staying on the lists longer.
The department said 3.5 million people were receiving state unemployment benefits in the week ended April 27, the latest period for which the figure was available, a 38,000 increase from the previous week.
"The claims data tell us that the rate of layoffs has slowed, but people are still getting laid off," said Matthew Alexy, an economist at Deutsche Bank.
But Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said there was some cause for optimism because the small increase in initial claims came after a big decline in the previous week. Initial claims fell 45,000 for the week ended April 27.
Cindy Ambler, an analyst at the Employment and Training Administration, said a decline in continued claims for unemployment benefits usually lagged behind any drop in first-time claims as a recovery began.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The Industry Tries to Laugh in the Face of Hard Times

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

DATELINE: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS , W.Va.

 BODY:
THE leaders of the country's advertising industry might not be smiling through the apocalypse, but as their annual meeting continues here they are trying at least to chuckle their way through their two recessions.
Loud laughter greeted John O'Toole, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, when at yesterday's general session he quoted from a spoof of graduation speeches by Woody Allen. "More than any other time in history mankind faces a crossroads. One path leads to despair and utter hopelessness. The other to total extinction. Let us pray we have the wisdom to choose correctly." 
 Despite that good humor, association members interviewed at the meeting are still expressing concern over the recessions -- the nation's, in its 10th month, and their industry's, in its third year.
"Over all, you couldn't say you see any improvement coming," said Richard (Bink) Garrison, chairman and chief executive of Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, in Boston. While "a lot of our national business is up minimally," he said, citing clients like the clothing retailer T. J. Maxx and the CVS drugstore chain, what are missing are new opportunities that would stimulate increases in ad spending the way computer and other high-technology companies did in the 1980's.
In New England, "we're still looking for our next engine of growth," Mr. Garrison added.
"I see a lot of folks continuing to hang back," said Robert Kroyer, president of Ketchum Advertising USA, Pittsburgh. "Instead of looking forward, they're looking over their shoulders." Even so, Mr. Kroyer said he was now starting to glimpse "glimmers of light on the horizon . . . glimmers that weren't there before." Among them are campaigns Ketchum has created for two large clients' product introductions: a personal computer from the Digital Equipment Corporation and the Vigor luxury car from Honda's Acura division.
The Vigor campaign in particular heartens Mr. Kroyer because it is being rolled out "full steam ahead, no cuts, in spite of the down auto market and the down economy," he said.
Also sounding optimistic was Sam Chisholm, president and chief executive of the Mingo Group, New ork. "I'm hoping this will begin to remedy itself in six or eight months," he said. "If we have the year we are anticipating, we will end the year on a good note." While Mr. Chisholm's agency's clients, like the General Motors Corporation and the Miller Brewing Company, are maintaining their advertising budgets, he said, "it's an interesting thing to see how clients are spending." He went on: "Normally, a client comes in and says, 'Here's your budget for the year.' Now, they're parceling out the budget on a quarter-by-quarter basis."
One of the most cheerful executives was Pat McGrath, president of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York, perhaps because on Wednesday his agency was selected as one of the six finalists on Subaru of America's review of the company's $60 million account.
"My feeling is that the economy has reached bottom and is about to turn around," Mr. McGrath said. "All of the excesses that characterized the incredible 80's, all of the fat, have been squeezed out. I see slow but steady growth, so I'm optimistic right now."
Also squeezed out has been a sizable chunk of the attendance at the group's 73d annual meeting. Registrations, usually a reliable barometer of the industry's economic outlook, plunged to around 420, from 627 last year and 670 in 1989.
If misery loves company, those attending will be reassured to learn that the annual meetings of many other trade associations are suffering through a similar slump. For example, attendance at the American Newspaper Publishers Association's annual convention last week in Vancouver, British Columbia, was reported to have dropped to fewer than 1,500 from 2,176 in 1990.
Also reassuring were some unscripted remarks in Mr. O'Toole's address yesterday. While there are "unique and frightening aspects" to the current economic uncertainties, "this is not the end of the world," he said, adding, "This, too, shall pass."

HEADLINE: SOVIET REPUBLICS ARE SAID TO AGREE ON CRISIS PROGRAM

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 16

 BODY:
The Soviet Government announced today that 13 of the nation's 15 republics had agreed on the details of an emergency plan to steer the nation out of economic crisis. The plan includes a new effort to ban strikes, budget cuts and fresh assurances for skeptical foreign investors.
"We let down many of our partners and punished ourselves most of all," said Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov, who resolved to revive the tattered economy now that greater agreement had been reached with most of the balky, sovereignty-minded republics. 
 He said only Georgia and Estonia did not take part in this week's negotiations. Even independence-minded Lithuania found the talks inviting enough to retain "observer" status, he said.
 
Wage Increases Planned
 Details are not expected to be published until next week, and while Soviet officials at a news conference conceded that past plans had gone awry, they insisted that this one was different for the level of input from the republics.
[The Soviet economy faces a decline in output of 10 percent, an inflation rate exceeding 100 percent and a "radically worse" year, American intelligence agencies say. Page A6.]
Soviet officials promised fast steps toward building economic credibility. Among those are an executive order with a strong strike ban counterbalanced by a plan for wage increases tied to higher worker productivity in some industries, including energy, chemical and metals. Manufacturers would have greater freedom to sell a minor part of their products on the open market.
 
Sensitive Issue of Strikes
 The banning of strikes is especially sensitive. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has already sought to outlaw them by decree, only to find his wishes ignored. Siberian coal miners recently ended a two-month stoppage that left equipment badly damaged, along with the President's prestige.
As described by Mr. Pavlov, the present state of the consensus plan does not answer critical questions like how the nation might deal with the privatization of property as the underpinning of a move to a market economy. He said the parties had agreed to begin in some fashion with properties at the republic level.
But the negotiations at least signaled progress, if only in terms of basic planning and common resolve, on the heels of the "dacha summit" compromise of last month, when President Gorbachev reached a surprise agreement with most of the republic leaders over an outline for economic planning and power sharing. Mr. Pavlov conceded that the past year had seen a cascade of economic disasters, including the mine strike and the Government's failure to meet international trade payments.
"Our left hand reached further than our right one," he said, vowing fast repairs, including accelerated parliamentary approval next week of a multinational measure to reassure foreign investors by guaranteeing protection of their investments here and repatriation of their profits.
Economic officials also said the new plan, whose precise timetable was not announced, would demonstrate fresh resolve by aiming for a 30 percent cut in the central Government's administrative budget and by speeding plans to convert the defense industry to civilian uses and permit share-holding and outside investment.
"The defense complex cannot exist as an oasis when the entire country is moving in another direction," said Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Scherbakov. He referred to the military-industrial complex, long tied to Communist Party hard-liners, that is fighting to maintain its cold-war-era dominance.
 
A More Flexible Attitude
 Prime Minister Pavlov, considered something of an alumnus of that hard-line school, clearly sought to display a more flexible attitude than he showed a few months ago on taking office. Then, he alarmed international investors by talking of a capitalist plot to destroy the ruble.
Today, he talked much more of free-market hope, saying the Government's more ambitious plans envisioned an elaborate swap of Soviet energy resources for farm technology within a pan-European plan. He also repeated the Kremlin's ambition to have a role at the annual summit meeting of economic powers.
Mr. Scherbakov said other features of the plan included strengthening the battered ruble internally by backing it with state buildings, land and other properties, as well as shrinking the Kremlin ministries that long have ruled the nation's life.
Elsewhere, Kremlin officials were repeating today the goal of making the ruble strong enough to be floated within two years on the world market. But Prime Minister Pavlov eschewed such timetables as guaranteeing "the free market by next Christmas," saying the task was too complex.
Mr. Pavlov insisted that the negotiations contradicted skeptics' doubts that Mr. Gorbachev's Government changes were strong enough to produce an effective plan for economic resurrection.
"Today, the joint agreement of the Union and the republic governments is a reality," he declared, saying that after rounds of negotiations by deputy ministers, the final basic decisions had been settled by the national Government's Council of Ministers.
The council is the new advisory panel created by Mr. Gorbachev to allow the republics a greater voice in Kremlin decisions. The council's final few issues, Mr. Scherbakov said, included determining that there should be financial and credit policy for the nation at large, rather than a principle to be specified differently by each republic.
Also agreed to, he said, was that there should be a federal system of taxation and that the privatization issue was to focus initally on industries "that should be under the republics."
It was noted of this latter question that the republics include a crosscurrent of views on this most sensitive area of Communist hegemony and that some republic representatives are outright opposed to denationalization of properties.
Speaking of bolstering the invitation for foreign investment, Mr. Pavlov said: "We are not naive people. Of course investors need some profits." He added, however, that this "should be a mutually beneficial action."
President Gorbachev made the same point on Wednesday in declaring that the nation would not be a "Klondike" waiting to be stripped by foreign investors. Once the plan is finally set, presumably with the publication next week and a final blessing from Mr. Gorbachev, it faces consideration in the Parliament, where the concern will be over possible pain to the Soviet public.

Soviet Emigration Bill Fails Again
 MOSCOW, May 16 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Parliament failed today for the third time in a week to approve a key emigration bill giving most citizens a right to travel abroad.
Approval of the law -- viewed as important in insuring Soviet compliance with international human rights agreements -- has been made a condition for United States granting of most-favored-nation trade benefits and credit guarantees to the Soviet Union.
The bill fell two votes short of what was required in one of the two chambers of the Supreme Soviet. The vote was to approve the law in principle and have details of putting it into effect worked out by the Government.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Rose by 6.2 Percent in April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The Government said today that builders increased construction of new homes and apartments by 6.2 percent in April, a report seen by analysts as evidence that the housing industry is making an erratic, rather than brisk, recovery from the recession.
"It's kind of staggering along," said David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. "Hopefully, it will smooth out, but it will be a gradual affair." 
 Martin Regalia, an economist with the National Council of Savings Institutions, concurred. "There may be some months where it doesn't improve or actually declines a little bit," he said. "But, in general, we'll see a gradual improvement throughout the year."
The Commerce Department said housing starts totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 957,000, up from 901,000 in March.
Most analysts believe the housing recession bottomed in January, when starts plunged 12.8 percent, to an 847,000 annual rate. That was the lowest level since construction plummeted to an 843,000 rate in the previous recession in January 1982.
While construction rebounded 17.1 percent in February, it fell 9.2 percent in March.
"We're convinced that January was the low, but we're off to an erratic start to the recovery," Mr. Seiders said.
Applications for building permits, an indicator of future activity, fell 3 percent in April, to an annual rate of 865,000, after rising the previous two months. But applications for single-family homes, which represent 75 percent of the housing industry, edged up seven-tenths of a percent.
Sales of new homes also rose in both February and March, the department reported earlier, and Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said that should stimulate more starts.
 
Weakness in Multifamily Sector
 But applications for multifamily buildings fell 15.8 percent, reflecting high vacancy rates in some parts of the country as well as an inability by builders to obtain financing, analysts said.
Construction of single-family houses shot up 5.7 percent in April, to a 778,000 rate, nearly erasing a 6.6 percent loss a month earlier.
Multifamily housing starts were up 8.5 percent, to a 41,000 rate. But starts of buildings with five or more units slipped seven-tenths of a percent, to 138,000 -- the lowest level since the department began keeping records in 1963. Apartment construction plummeted 19.1 percent in March.
 
25.3% Gain in West
 In the West, starts increased 25.3 percent, to a rate of 238,000, wiping out a 12 percent loss in March. In the Midwest, starts were up 3.1 percent, to 231,000 units. In the South, starts rose eight-tenths of a percent, to 392,000 units.
But in the Northeast, construction fell 2 percent, to a 96,000 rate. The Northeast has been the weakest region for some time.

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs 28.63 Points, To 2,894.01

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Buyers moved back into the stock market yesterday to pick up a few bargains, with Wall Street apparently concluding that it had overreacted the day before to the bad news from Compaq Computer.
Trading, though, was slow, and some technology stocks gave further ground. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which slid 21.47 points on Wednesday, rebounded 28.63 yesterday, to 2,894.01.
 
Volume Posts a Decline
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to a weak 154.5 million shares, from 193.1 million the previous day. But advances led declines by almost 2 to 1.
More important, the Nasdaq composite, which sank the equivalent of more than 60 Dow points on Wednesday, recovered a third of the loss yesterday.
The selloff started when Compaq, the big producer of personal computers, said its second-quarter profits would drop to less than a fourth of the year before.
Compaq had plunged 13 1/4 in heavy trading on Wednesday and dragged the rest of the market down with it. By yesterday, though, investors thought better of the entire technology group and began nibbling again.
 
Compaq Stock Most Active
 Compaq, the most active Big Board stock again yesterday, fell 1/4, to 35 3/4, with 7.2 million shares changing hands. During the day it traded between 37 7/8 and 34 3/8.
The Compaq news, said Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist for County NatWest Securities in New Work, "created a panic in Intel, Sun Microsystems, Microsoft, Borland and others that went down more than they should have."
Unlike Compaq or Apple, which previously forecast weak profits, these stocks, he said, were "not likely to be hurt as much."
Moreover, Mr. Canelo said, "investors have sold down these stocks to where they have more than adequately discounted the foreseeable earnings risk."
Even so, Intel, which dropped 4 on Wednesday, fell 3/4 in heavy trading yesterday, to 48 1/2. Sun Microsystems, which fell 2, slid 7/8 more, to 34. Borland, which fell 3, declined 2 1/2 more, to 44 1/2, and Microsoft, which fell 3 1/4, actually recovered 1 3/8, to 99 3/8.
While other technology stocks continued to weaken, the overall tone of the technology market was upbeat. The Pacific Stock Exchange's high-tech index of the top 100 technology stocks in the country rose nearly 1 percent.
Among them, I.B.M. rose 1 3/8, to 104 1/8, after losing 3 1/4 on Wednesday. Hewlett-Packard, which had lost 1 3/4, rose 2, to 48. Trading in both was heavy.
Commenting on Hewlett-Packard, which reported a 25 percent jump in profits for the April quarter, Laszlo Birinyi Jr., president of Birinyi Associates, said it was "a good piece of news and showed that the technology weakness is not consistent, that it's not a one-way street for technology stocks."
As for I.B.M., he called the recovery "another piece of good news," representing "real buying, rather than sellers stepping away."
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said program buying continued strong and lifted the Dow 20 points.
County NatWest's Mr. Canelo said the selloff in technology stocks reflected "a stall in the economy -- it isn't going down but it isn't recovering as fast as people hoped."
He noted that several economic indicators had started "a nice recovery into the first days of this quarter," but had subsequently fallen.
He speculated, though, that the "technology slaughter," as he put it, might not cut prices more than an additional 5 percent, which, he felt, might bring the Dow industrials down to around 2,850, below which the index has not fallen since early March.
Drug and biotechnology stocks also advanced. Amgen rose 3 1/2, to 119 1/2; Centocor 2, to 61 3/4; Chiron 1 1/2, to 50.

HEADLINE: Sea Turtles Put New Friction In U.S.-Japan Trade Quarrels

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
With its hooked beak, scaly neck and stubby legs, the yard-long hawksbill sea turtle will win no beauty contests. But this homely creature, an endangered vestige of the dinosaur age, is suddenly at the center of a squall in United States-Japanese relations.
It does not have the grace of a dolphin, the majesty of a whale or the mournful appeal of a baby harp seal. But the hawksbill may well prompt the first use of an American law authorizing curbs on imports of fish and other wildlife products from countries that contribute to the disappearance of an endangered species.
 
Sanctions Seem Near
 Barring a last-minute breakthrough in negotiations, President Bush is likely to inform Congress by Sunday that the United States will impose trade sanctions on Japan for the sake of this rare turtle, senior Administration officials said today. It would be the first time the United States has used trade sanctions to help protect an endangered species. 
 About 2,000 people in Japan are employed in a $125 million-a-year cottage industry that fashions expensive eyeglass frames, combs and jewelry from imported hawksbill shell, inaccurately known as tortoise shell. The raw material for these products is often gathered by ripping the shells from living turtles that are being slowly barbecued alive.
The dispute over trying to persuade these people to abandon their livelihood has highlighted the difficulties of accommodating environmental concerns in international trade.
Imposing sanctions on Japan to help large green reptiles with lustrous shells is a relatively easy political move for the Bush Administration. It wins friends in the environmental movement, costs no money, shows toughness on trade and cannot be labeled protectionist because the United States does not have a tortoise-shell industry.
It is illegal in the United States to sell tortoise-shell products made from hawksbill turtles. Plastic substitutes are commonly used.
Members of the Economic Policy Council, a Cabinet-level panel composed of President Bush's inner circle on economic issues, have already reviewed the question of the turtle, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said. "They've decided absolutely that these sanctions will go into place" unless Japan agrees to close the industry quickly, he said.
A Japanese official in Washington said that no negotiations were under way, but that ways to avoid the sanctions were being explored informally.
Mr. Mosbacher said in a brief interview this morning that progress had been made, particularly this week, but not enough yet to avoid sanctions. Regardless of the Economic Policy Council's recommendation, the final decision would be up to President Bush, who has expressed no opinion.
The sanctions would impose duties on or ban imports of some or all fish and other wildlife products from Japan. There has been speculation in Washington that high duties might be placed on Japanese products that use wild pearls. Administration officials today declined to discuss what form any sanctions might take.
American imports of Japanese fish totaled $353.8 million last year, the Commerce Department says, and imports of other wildlife products were far smaller.
 
Centered in Nagasaki
 Most of the hawksbill-shell workers are in Nagasaki prefecture, and they have passionately opposed all attempts by the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry to shrink or eliminate their industry, said a Japanese official who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
"Some people told the MITI people that this was a second atomic bomb that the Americans are dropping" on Nagasaki, the official added.
But in the United States, turtles are becoming popular, and that has limited the Administration's room to maneuver. A recently published comic book depicts the Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles traveling back in time to confront a "Cap'n Mossback," who uses the good ship Sir Commerce to net many sea turtles.
Populations of hawksbill sea turtles are found in the Pacific and Indian Oceans and in warm parts of the Atlantic. Michael J. Bean, a senior attorney in the Washington office of the New York-based Environmental Defense Fund, said the species would face extinction early in the next century if no action was taken.
Japanese negotiators have already made a significant concession by agreeing that the tortoise-shell industry in Japan must be closed instead of simply made smaller, the Japanese official said. But while Japan wants to phase out imports over four or five years, the United States wants them eliminated by early next year.
The harvesting of hawksbill turtles is often cruel, said Dr. Michael W. Klemens, a specialist in turtles at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. People in developing countries commonly net or spear the turtles, or gather them on land.
Turtles caught in nets are dumped on their backs on ships' decks to keep them from crawling away. "Sea turtles in general, when they're put on their backs, tend to gasp and sigh because they are heavy and have trouble breathing," Dr. Klemens said.
The turtles also appear to be weeping. Special glands near the eyes secrete liquid to protect the eyeball from salt water. These glands continue working when the turtle is out of water.
The live turtles are placed on burning coals and heated until their top and bottom shells become malleable enough to rip off. The naked living turtle is then thrown back into the water in the belief that it will regrow its shell and can be harvested again.
But turtle shells do not regenerate, and turtles that have lost their shells typically die in a few weeks from infections, Dr. Klemens said.
In dealing with products from endangered species, environmental policy makers constantly face the choice of whether to attack the demand or the supply. Much of the hawksbill hunting now is the direct result of merchants seeking shells in poor countries for shipment to Japan, so American officials have focused their attention on Japan.
 
Some Restrictions in Place
 The Japanese Government is already restricting imports of the shells. The Government authorized the importation of 20 tons of hawksbill turtle shells for a 12-month period ending in July, but is not issuing enough import quotas to allow even this amount to enter Japan, the Japanese official said.
For the next 12-month period, beginning on Aug. 1, Japan will allow imports of only five tons.
American officials have expressed impatience with the Japanese Government's reluctance to take actions that would put 2,000 people out of work. Imports of Japanese goods to the United States have caused the closing of entire American factories with many more employees, said a Commerce Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"They say, 'We can't just displace these people,' " he said. "We say, 'Yes, you can.' "
On March 20, Mr. Mosbacher and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. certified that Japan was contributing to the disappearance of an endangered species. Under the law authorizing import restrictions on such countries, if President Bush decides to impose sanctions he must inform Congress of that within 60 days of the certification. This time limit expires on Sunday.
The United States has certified six countries on five occasions under the terms of the law, which was enacted in 1974, Mr. Bean of the Environmental Defense Fund said. All of the instances involved whaling, and in each case the nation involved made concessions rather than face sanctions.

HEADLINE: Bank Loans Still Tight But Less So

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The ability of business borrowers to get loans from banks worsened in the latest three months but the credit-tightening was "considerably less" than in the preceding quarters, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Financing of commercial and residential real estate showed a similar pattern. And banks said they had stopped making it harder to obtain consumer loans. 
 The findings of the Fed's quarterly survey of senior lending officers suggested that the worst of the so-called credit crunch was over and that loans might soon start to become more freely available and less costly than they had been for the last year or so.
 
'Softening' Is Seen
 "We are beginning to see signs," Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Finance Committee today, "that while the crunch is not easing, it's reached its maximum and there is some evidence that we may not be too far from a basic softening in it."
He added, however, that until this occurred a lack of adequate credit availability remained "our major problem."
The Fed has moved repeatedly this year to inject more money into the financial system, pushing down interest rates, but banks have been generally reluctant to lend the money because of heavy losses on earlier bad loans and because of a need to rebuild capital. At the same time, the recession that began in July has thinned the ranks of creditworthy borrowers.
As the credit tightening wanes, however, Mr. Greenspan predicted that even rates on consumer loans, like auto loans, which are costly for banks to administer, will come down and help stimulate economic recovery.
The Fed's quarterly survey of lending officers, released shortly after Mr. Greenspan spoke, showed that only 9, or 15 percent, of the 60 domestic banks surveyed had tightened standards or loan terms for large borrowers during the three months ended in early May. The other 51 banks reported that their lending policies were unchanged, and no banks were listed as either easing somewhat or easing considerably.
 
A Steady Decline
 The 15 percent listed as tightening was down from 35 percent in the three months ended in January and from 50 percent in the period that ended in Octber.
The pattern was similar for medium-sized business borrowers, but for small ones, those with annual sales of less than $50 million, only 9 percent of banks were making credit harder to get in the latest period.
The slowing pace of tightening was even more evident at branches of foreign banks, with only 28 percent of them reporting stricter lending standards, compared with 89 percent in the January survey. Still, relatively more foreign banks reported tightening than did domestic banks.
The Fed said the diminished amount of credit restriction at American banks might be related to the recent improvement in the banks' ability to raise both debt and equity capital. Of those banks that did tighten credit availability in the current survey, "virtually none mentioned pressures on capital positions or deteriorating loan portfolios as a reason."
Earlier, these had been a factor, along with the primary reasons still being cited of "concerns about the economic outlook" in general and problems with specific industries.
Looking only at tightened loan terms -- as opposed to the turning away of borrowers considered overly risky -- the change from previous periods was not as pronounced, the Fed reported.
 
Other Sources of Loans
 The Fed survey also found that as previously potential borrowers who felt the brunt of tightening moves commonly ended up obtaining money either from another bank or, depending on the borrower's size, in the credit markets or from finance companies. Only when these other sources failed did companies cut back, postpone or cancel their spending plans.
For commercial real estate, a fourth of domestic banks tightened standards for construction and land-development loans in the latest three months, down from half in the January period and two-thirds in October, the survey showed. On residential mortgages, a fifth of the banks reported tightening compared with a third in January, even as demand for mortgages climbed.
The willingness to make consumer loans was about unchanged in the latest period, compared with banks being "somewhat less willing" in January.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 942 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins and the 'Invader';
His Fear of State Control Prompts Debate: Would Fiscal Intervention Be Good or Bad?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
For months, Mayor David N. Dinkins has said New York City must keep its budget balanced at all costs -- including cuts in city services that he calls unthinkable -- to avoid sharing control of its spending with a little- understood state board that he describes as if it were an alien invader.
 The villain Mr. Dinkins despises is the Financial Control Board, which was created to oversee the city's finances in the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's and which has now receded to an advisory role. But the board would reimpose binding, sometimes sweeping, powers to approve spending if the city ended the year with a deficit of $100 million or more; or if it could no longer borrow money in the bond markets; or if the board decided that such things were about to happen. 
 As the city's fiscal problems have deepened and Mr. Dinkins has had trouble persuading a panoply of players to cooperate, a debate has developed over whether a return to power by the control board would be good or bad -- and for whom. At the heart of the issue is a not too subtle argument over whether the city's problems are so severe that Mr. Dinkins simply cannot solve them alone but should share the burdens and the blame.
Mr. Dinkins fiercely resists the idea. He explained why last week: "We give up on the dreams we hold so dear, effectively permitting others we do not elect -- individuals who are not accountable to us -- to do our dreaming for us. To me, that is simply unacceptable."
But if some see the control board as the enemy, its advocates say the enemy is "us." Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is the chairman of the board, but Mr. Dinkins sits on it, along with the city and state comptrollers and three private citizens appointed by the Governor.
 
Some Pros, Some Cons
 In general, the board could not make Mr. Dinkins do anything that he would not have to do to avoid its intervention (which is why its supporters say intervention would not be so bad). Nor could the board let the Mayor do much that he could not do by himself (which is why he says it is unnecessary).
The board could hold the city's spending within fixed limits, but it would not tell Mr. Dinkins what to cut or where. It would have power to approve future labor settlements, but not to undo those already reached. It could not allow the city to have a budget that is out of balance.
As it is, the city has flexibility to take extraordinary actions, though if it took them, it might wind up inviting control by the board.
 
'It Is Not Saddam Hussein'
 For example, the city could argue in the middle of a year that balancing a budget would cause a "material adverse impact on the delivery of essential services." But if it failed to balance the budget by the end of the year, it could fall under the board's control.
The city could float short-term notes to spread a deficit from year to year, but if it sought to finance an operating deficit of $100 million or more, it would invite control by the board.
"It is not Saddam Hussein," Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and an architect of the city's recovery from the last fiscal crisis, said of the Financial Control Board. "I think the F.C.B. could be a very useful tool on the Mayor as leverage on the state to get more committed to the city."
On the other hand, Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by business, said: "The control board can't produce money, and the control board does not replace the Mayor as chief executive of the city. The existence of the control board simply means that the governor and the two comptrollers become implicated in the major spending and borrowing decisions that the city makes. It's a political issue. I don't think it changes the economics one iota."
Precisely because it is a political issue, it is explosive, laden with everything from Mr. Dinkins's racial sensibilities to Mr. Cuomo's Presidential prospects.
The mere suggestion that the board reimpose control implies a skepticism about Mr. Dinkins's abilities that he understandably resists, his aides say, seeing it as usurpation of his stewardship and a profound blow to his position as the city's first black Mayor.
Mr. Cuomo, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan -- while sniping at Mr. Dinkins's management of the city from the sidelines -- are just as reluctant to be drawn further into its troubles. Mr. Cuomo repeatedly says he favors "cooperation, not control," thereby reminding the world that control is always a possibility.
"My opinion, as strong as I can make it to you, you cannot have a control period without first admitting failure," Mr. Cuomo said yesterday.
 
State No Paragon
 With the state having practiced for years the sort of sloppy fiscal management that it bars the city from indulging in, Mr. Dinkins resents the idea that the Governor and state are in any position to tell him how to behave.
"One can be very sympathetic with the Mayor's view that the state's fiscal behavior has been much worse than the city's," Mr. Rohatyn said. "And I can understand that the symbolism is very distasteful to the Mayor, and I can understand his political concern about it."
At the same time some of the Governor's aides and advisers muse privately on the merits of a period of control, though not over the Mayor's objections.
"Unless the Mayor takes the lead, everyone else has to stand back," one person close to the Governor said. "I think what everybody's doing is trying to see if they can help the Mayor do it without control. He's hellbent on avoiding it."

HEADLINE: REVIEW/ART;
How Jewish Artists Found Their Place in New York

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
To a considerable degree, "Painting a Place in America" is a recapitulation of the history of early 20th-century art in New York City. In this sense, it tells a remarkable story.
The show, at the Jewish Museum in its temporary quarters at the New-York Historical Society, celebrates the work of Jewish artists from the turn of the century to the end of the Second World War. Having arrived, many of them, as part of the huge waves of Eastern European emigrants who settled here between 1881 and 1924, these Jewish artists did not take long to secure places in the city's fledgling modernist art scene. Among them were Max Weber, Abraham Walkowitz, Louise Nevelson, Ben Shahn and Mark Rothko. 
 Almost 150 paintings, sculptures, prints and drawings by these and 45 other artists, encompassing almost every major style of the period, are brought together for this ambitious, flawed, but ultimately inspiring exhibition. The works have been arranged by Norman L. Kleeblatt, curator of collections at the museum, and Susan Chevlowe, curatorial assistant, to highlight the activities of five Jewish art organizations in which these artists participated -- the Educational Alliance, the People's Art Guild, the Jewish Art Center, the Yiddisher Kultur Farband and the Ten.
This has made for a confusing and rambling display, not least because the artistic distinctions between these organizations are sometimes difficult to fathom. Many of the artists are represented by minor achievements and early works completed while studying at places like the Educational Alliance.
Yet in one important regard the meandering quality of "Painting a Place in America" serves the show's central theme by making evident the diversity and open-mindedness of Jewish culture in New York. When the Educational Alliance was founded in 1889 to "Americanize" the Jewish population on the city's Lower East Side, its progressive agenda promoted accessible realism of the Ash Can School variety yet was willing to embrace not only Walkowitz's French-inspired abstractions that were among the earliest modernist works by an American artist, but also Nevelson's Picasso-like abstractions.
And when the People's Art Guild was founded in 1915 to disseminate art to the masses and promote Jewish culture, it did not prescribe any particular style. Everything from William Meyerowitz's self-portrait, with its strange Expressionistic coloration, to William Zorach's Cubistic "Roof Playground" was promoted by the guild.
Only with the Yiddisher Kultur Farband, a branch of the Popular Front that was created by the Communist Party, did the works tend to toe the particular artistic line of Social Realism while still tolerating a plurality of styles. Indeed, if anything can be said to characterize the nature of Jewish art in the early part of the century, it is the liberalism and political involvement that became most fervent with the Yiddisher Kultur Farband during the 1930's.
The section devoted to that organization and a related section on wartime Jewish art provide several of the exhibition's memorable works. These include Arnold Friedman's "Unemployable," whose crisp realism recalls Northern Renaissance portraiture, and Aaron J. Goodelman's carved wood abstraction called "Kultur," which elegantly links the oppression of blacks and the plight of Jews in Germany.
The show is also a reminder of the accomplishments of artists like Morton Schamberg and Joseph Solman, and of less familiar aspects in the careers of better-known painters and sculptors. How many viewers would guess that the depiction of a bespectacled man in the show's final gallery is a Rothko self-portrait of 1936? Yet, once identified, it is tempting to see intimations of the artist's mature abstractions in the washes of paint and the broad areas of color that suffice to define his figure.
Rothko's encounters with anti-Semitism played a role in his work. But when he and several other artists banded together in 1935 to form the Ten, and to advocate modern art, the coincidence of their Jewishness went largely unremarked, even among themselves. Such was the measure of how rapidly Jewish artists had become assimilated.
Whether, and to what extent, assimilation was desirable remained a subject of debate in Jewish cultural groups, and this is one of the topics that makes "Painting a Place in America" timely. The show comes at a time when the issue of multi-culturalism has refueled discussions about ethnic and racial distinctions in art.
Throughout the early years of this century there were disagreements about what, if anything, was "Jewish" about Jewish art, about whether describing an artist in terms of his Jewishness ghettoized that artist, about the responsibility of Jewish artists to their community and about how to respond to racism. The same kind of issues occupy discussions of work by minority artists today. And to be put in mind of artists during the 1930's and 40's making political art and railing against what they considered to be the commercialism of the galleries is, in particular, to sense that history travels in circles.
Raphael Soyer provides the exhibition's most endearing work, a rendition from 1926 of his immigrant parents watching two of their children awkwardly learning to dance Western style. As an expression of the acculturation process that within so few decades turned Eastern European Jews into quintessential New Yorkers, "The Dancing Lesson" is also the show's emblematic painting.
"Painting a Place in America: Jewish Artists in New York, 1900-1945" remains at the Jewish Museum at the New-York Historical Society, 77th Street and Central Park West, through Sept. 29.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A detail from "Dancing Lesson" by Raphael Soyer in 1926 on exhibit at the Jewish Museum. (Jonathan Morris-Ebbs/Jewish Musuem)

LENGTH: 243 words

HEADLINE: Prejudice Is Still a Fact of Life for Blacks;
Marketers Miss

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In 1986 I wrote a marketing research presentation, "Black Power: Color It Green," which documented the economic clout blacks had attained in the marketplace. "When Blacks Shop, Bias Often Accompanies Sale" (front page, April 30) demonstrates that the presentation is still required reading.
Economically, the private sector has remained largely closed to blacks as an avenue for economic upward mobility. However, the public sector has provided a financial ladder for blacks to climb with staff positions in assistance, job training and educational programs. Renewed financing rests on continuing the public's perception that a high percentage of blacks are poor. 
 The unfortunate consequence of this is that America's marketers have discounted the black market. The Asian and Cuban stereotypes of industriousness and wealth have produced carefully crafted, precisely targeted advertising campaigns for upscale goods and services directed at these niches; in stark contrast the reinforced perception of blanket black poverty has resulted in product managers' turning a cold shoulder to the community, with the notorious exceptions of cheap wine, tobacco and "we'll tote the note" car dealerships.
I congratulate The Times for exposing racist attitudes against blacks; but the community must ask its leadership, "Why do you persist in presenting our lacks instead of our luster?"
 
KENNETH E. LAMB
Birmingham, Ala., May 6, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: In Retail, It's Perilous at the Top

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Frank Doroff, the chairman of Bonwit Teller stores, yesterday became one more merchant without a store. After spending more than half his life in retailing, he will be on the outside looking in, probably wondering which fork in the road proved the wrong one.
After five years of takeovers, shake-ups, slow sales and now recession, retail chains have set adrift hundreds of Frank Doroffs. And continuing consolidation and store failures guarantee that more will follow. 
 Consider the latest victims:
When rivals took too big a bite out of his market, Frank Arnone, the Marshalls chairman, lost his job. After the Dayton Hudson Corporation bought Marshall Field & Company of Chicago, Burnett W. Donoho, the president of Fields, was told he was no longer needed. Bankruptcies claimed the jobs of Peter Hollis, chairman of Ames Department Stores, and Steven Goldberger, president of Hills Department Stores. Richard Van Pelt, chairman of the Jordan Marsh Company of Boston, resigned when Federated Stores Inc., now attempting to emerge from voluntary bankruptcy, decided to change course.
 
The Pressure Builds
 Mr. Doroff is leaving Bonwit on his own after just a year because the chain's parent, the Pyramid Companies, could not raise the money from banks for the expansion he wanted. He also refused to leave his New York offices for Syracuse, where Pyramid is based.
The long list of resignations and dismissals reflects the pressure in the executive offices brought on by weak sales, ill-fated takeover attempts and strategic blunders. Some bosses were fall guys for costly mistakes. Others were victims of consolidations. But many others, especially those trained as merchants, found themselves ill equipped to grapple with the swirl of financial, operational, strategic and merchandising problems that now confront retail chains.
"Just being a merchant today isn't enough to keep a chief executive in his or her job," said Joseph J. Carideo, a partner at Thorndike Deland Associates, New York executive recruiters. "Today, with all the problems in retailing, the C.E.O. also needs skills in marketing, finance and operations as well as merchandising. There are a lot of good merchants on the beach. That says something."
Mr. Doroff jumped at the Bonwit job because it gave him a chance to run the store, not just be the chief merchant. But he concedes it was one of his most serious career mistakes. But "I still love it," he added, heartily, referring to the retail business. "In relocating to another job, I want to take my time to avoid any unpleasant surprises such as the unexpectedness of my change at Bonwit. I think there are opportunities out there for me." Like the airlines and the entertainment and advertising fields, he said, "retailing is going through some tough times and significant restructuring; but I don't think it is a bad career."
There is no need to shed a tear, though, for Mr. Doroff. He won't talk about it, but trade reports indicate that he will walk away with about $4 million in a separation agreement with Bonwit Teller that was part of his contract.
 
Widely Respected
 Mr. Doroff stands out, say retailers and industry analysts who know him well. While only 42 years old, he has spent 24 years in the business and is widely respected as a savvy, instinctive merchant.
He made his strongest marks at Macy's New York and Bullock's department stores in Los Angeles, where he gained a reputation for taking risks to try to turn stores around, and achieving gains. He also held important positions at Federated Stores, where he was once considered a possible candidate to run its crown jewel, Bloomingdale's, when Marvin S. Traub, Bloomingdale's near-legendary chairman, chief executive and merchandising guru retires.
"Frank Doroff is the quintessential merchant, very astute about the business, yet he conducts himself in a very human way that makes his staff and his suppliers respect him," said Bernard Chaus, chairman and chief executive of Bernard Chaus Inc., a New York sportswear producer, who has done business with Mr. Doroff.
 
Excited by the Challenge
 But being a fine merchant may not be enough today, and Mr. Doroff may face some difficulties in finding another good position.
For one thing, recruiters say, in the tight retailing job market today there are plenty of ex-chairmen and ex-presidents of retail chains. And for another, Mr. Doroff's youthful appearance may complicate his receiving a top post with a major company.
Attracted by the new owners of the Bonwit Teller name and three remaining stores, he took the chairman's job. He was excited by the challenge of reviving Bonwit, and it did not hurt that he was offered a 45 percent equity share in the reborn chain.
Two years ago he left the presidency of Bullock's department stores to become chairman of Federated/ Allied Merchandising Services, the New York buying office. But he said he took the job only because Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who acquired Federated, promised him a top operating post at a store.
The promise, according to persistent trade reports was the presidency of Bloomingdale's.
Mr. Doroff will not comment on that, twisting in his seat with the question because he explains that he still has many friends at "Bloomie's" and at Federated. He did not get the job, which probably would have put him in a key position to succeed Mr. Traub. Beleaguered by Federated's 1990 voluntary bankruptcy and his own debts, Mr. Campeau withdrew last year from any further connection with Federated. Along with his departure went the job Mr. Campeau had reportedly promised.
"I grew up in a retailing family," Mr. Doroff said. His father is Ben Doroff, now a consultant in Syracuse after serving as executive vice president of John Wanamaker Inc., the big Philadelphia retailer.
 
Started With Macy's
 After graduating from Washington and Jefferson College with an economics degree, and getting a master's degree from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Doroff went into Macy's executive training squad in 1972. He spent a year each in several jobs as a buyer.
Then, in 1977, Edward S. Finkelstein, who was Macy New York's chief executive at the time, tapped Mr. Doroff to be one of several senior vice presidents -- all in their early 30's -- to be groomed for major store management posts.
By 1982, he had received telephone calls from Howard Goldfeder, then chairman of Federated Department Stores, who kept telling Mr. Doroff in effect that he had nine store divisions while Macy's had only four. He talked about opportunities at Bullock's in Los Angeles and Sanger-Harris in Dallas.
In 1983, Mr. Doroff succumbed and left Macy's to join Bullock's. Four years later he was president of the chain.
 
'We Were All Tense'
 But on Jan. 25, 1988, Robert Campeau, who had already acquired the Allied Stores Corporation, made an unexpected, hostile bid for Federated. "We were all sick at Bullock's when Campeau made his bid," Mr. Doroff recalls. "We were all tense. We had had a good run. I consoled the store staff with the fact that our performance had been so good that we could be confident nothing would happen to us."
That prediction proved wrong. After Macy's tried to help Federated repel the Campeau attack, Mr. Campeau and Mr. Finkelstein, who by then was Macy's corporate chairman, agreed that Macy's would walk away from the fray if it could buy two of Federated's divisions, Bullock's and I. Magnin, for $1.1 billion.
A month later, when Mr. Finkelstein and Mark Handler, Macy's corporate president, visited Bullock's to meet the staff, Mr. Doroff learned that his stores would be run from Macy's in Atlanta instead of Los Angeles and that Macy's wanted him to remain as Bullock's president without retaining his merchandising responsibilities.
 
'The Most Exciting Business'
 "It meant that our merchandise would be bought in Atlanta and they were taking away the thing I loved most," Mr. Doroff said. "How could I go for that? I loved buying and selling clothes. Even as an assistant buyer, I loved it. It was like going to school in a school that you enjoyed. Someone hands you an order pad and tells you you have a $4 million budget. It's like having your own business. And you have almost instant feedback when the customers show up. It's the most exciting business in the world."
He left Bullock's and rejoined Federated as head of its New York buying office. But after two years, he decided he missed running stores and he opted for the Bonwit Teller job.
Just where Mr. Doroff might fit into a particular industry slot is uncertain. Robert Nesbit, managing partner of Korn/Ferry International, New York executive recruiters, thinks there are suitable opportunities for him. "But I think he would have to revert to his real forte, merchandising, rather than administration," he said. "I think he is still unproven as a president with its multifarious disciplines."

The positions Frank Doroff has held in his 24-year retailing career and what has happened to his employers.
 
R.H. Macy & Company: Frank Doroff rose from trainee to senior vice president in his 11 years with the New York department store. He quit in 1983. Macy's went private in a leveraged buyout in 1986.
 
Bullock's: Joined the Los Angeles store as a senior vice president in 1983. He quit as the company's president after it was acquired by Macy's in May 1988.
 
Federated/Allied Merchandising Services: Served as chairman and chief executive from July 1988 to May 1990. The New York buying office continues to advise the nine store divisions although it has scaled back operations.
 
Bonwit Teller: Became chairman and chief executive in May 1990, four months after the New York store was closed. The chain recently moved its headquarters to Syracuse and its expansion plans remain on hold. Yesterday was Mr. Doroff's last day on the job. (Pg. D4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Busch Theme Park Unit Names 3 to Top Posts

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Anheuser-Busch Companies, whose theme park business has been hurt by the recession, yesterday named the No. 2 executive at its theme park unit as president and made two other executives officers of the subsidiary.
John B. Roberts, formerly executive vice president and general manager of the Busch Entertainment Corporation, was named its president, effective immediately. Busch is the nation's second-largest operator of theme parks after the Walt Disney Company. Its nine parks include Sea World parks in Florida, Texas, California and Ohio, as well as Busch Gardens in Tampa, Fla., and Williamsburg, Va. 
 Mr. Roberts, 46, replaces W. Randolph Baker, who was reassigned in January to oversee a Spanish theme-park project, scheduled for completion for the mid-1990's. Mr. Roberts had since been acting president. He was unavailable for comment yesterday.
A 20-year Busch employee, Mr. Roberts is a graduate of Southwest Texas University, majoring in management. He joined the company as operations manager for Busch Gardens in Houston in 1970 and then became general manager of the Williamsburg park. He was named vice president for operations at the entertainment company in 1978 and, 10 years later, executive vice president. He is married and has two sons.
In its first-quarter results announced last month, Busch said its theme park business continued to be hurt by the recession and the resulting lower attendance at its parks.
In 1990, the entertainment division posted operating earnings of $58.3 million, or less than 4 percent of the total operating profit. It posted sales of $625.3 million, or less than 6 percent of total sales.
Busch also named Robert K. Gault, Jr., 47, president of the company's Sea World of California marine-life park, as vice president of operations of Busch Entertainment. Melvin L. Bilbo, 41, general manager of Busch Gardens in Williamsburg, was named vice president for marketing and product development.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Day Up Sharply on Improved Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed sharply higher yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit narrowed impressively to $4.05 billion in March, the lowest level in nearly eight years.
The Government said the recession reduced demand for imports while hefty increases in aircraft and computer sales kept exports at near-record levels. 
 The dollar's surge was also given impetus by the Swedish central bank's announcement that it was linking the value of the krona to the European Currency Unit, said Mike Faust, a foreign exchange analyst with MMS International in Chicago.
Effective immediately, the Swedish currency will be allowed to fluctuate 1.5 percent beyond the basic rate of 7.4 kronor for each ECU, the Riksbank said. Sweden made the move as a step toward membership in the European Community.
 
 Swedish Demand for Dollar
 Analysts said the move would require Swedish banks to adjust their foreign exchange holdings, increasing demand for the dollar by as much as $20 billion.
The dollar's sharp climb yesterday came despite sales of dollars by the Federal Reserve and the German Bundesbank, traders said. The dollar soared more than 4 pfennigs against the German mark in New York, closing at 1.7360 marks, up from 1.69475 late Thursday. Mr. Faust said the dollar traded as high as 1.7420 marks.
In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.7355 German marks from 1.6965.
The British pound tumbled against the dollar, falling to $1.7125 in New York, from $1.7495 late Thursday. In London, sterling slumped to $1.7165 from late Thursday's $1.7465.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.4700 Swiss francs, up from 1.43735; 5.8855 French francs, up from 5.7460; 1,291.00 Italian lire, up from 1,261.00, and 1.14945 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14995.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4670 Swiss francs, up from 1.4395; 5.8818 French francs, up from 5.7560; 1.9548 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9110; 1,293.25 Italian lire, up from 1,262.75, and 1.1506 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1488.
The dollar also gained against the Japanese yen, rising to 138.20 yen in New York from late Thursday's 137.45. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to a closing 137.72 Japanese yen from 137.30 yen at Thursday's close, and in London, it rose to 138.45 yen.
Gold prices fell in New York, with a troy ounce dropping 80 cents on the Commodity Exchange to $355.20 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $354.75, off $1.15.Gold also fell in London to a late bid price of $355.50 a troy ounce, down from $355.95 late Thursday.
Silver fell half a cent on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.003 a troy ounce. In London, silver was unchanged at a late bid price of $4.04.

HEADLINE: Iraq Accepts U.N. System for Weapons Inspections

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 17

 BODY:
After an initial show of resistance, Iraq agreed today to a rigorous system of inspections of its military and scientific installations by an international commission charged with locating and destroying its most dangerous weapons.
Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, the executive chairman of the commission created by the Security Council to oversee the destruction of the Iraqi weapons, said Baghdad had now accepted all his demands. 
 That will allow the commission's inspectors nearly total freedom to investigate President Saddam Hussein's weapons programs and to fulfill the mandate to destroy or render harmless Iraq's chemical and biological weapons as well as ballistic missiles and nuclear-weapons-grade material.
 
Access Is Guaranteed
 Iraq has in effect guaranteed the commission's inspectors immediate access to any site or factory they want to check. It has also said they may take chemical and other samples out of the country for analysis, conduct aerial surveys inside Iraq and question Iraqi officials about their work on demand.
After Iraq had at first balked at these terms, the commission threatened to suspend operations at midnight tonight, Baghdad time, unless the Government changed its mind. Suspension of the commission's work would have placed Iraq in violation of Security Council Resolution 678, which sets out the allied coalition's terms for lifting economic sanctions and which Baghdad had accepted in exchange for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.
A suspension would also have ended any prospect of the Council's relaxing the trade sanctions when they come up for review on June 3.
Today the United States and the four other permanent Security Council members -- Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China -- discussed the dispute at a closed meeting.
Baghdad's acceptance of the terms today followed the failure of a team of nuclear inspectors to persuade Iraq to agree to them when the inspectors arrived in Baghdad this week.
The 34 inspectors, experts from the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency as well as from the Security Council commission, were the first such group to reach Iraq since it agreed to give up its weapons of mass destruction.
The operating procedures that Iraq agreed to today will create a precedent for subsequent inspection teams.
The United States and its allies have already accused Iraq of failing to comply properly with other parts of the procedure that the Security Council has laid down for locating and destroying Iraqi weapons of mass destruction.
In letters sent to the United Nations on April 19, Iraq disclosed that it retains a substantial arsenal of chemical weapons but said it had no biological weapons or nuclear-weapons-grade material.
 
More Uranium Fuel Disclosed
 But in another letter dated April 27, Iraq acknowledged that it had nearly twice as much highly enriched weapons-grade uranium as American and atomic agency officials had indicated.
Baghdad disclosed that in addition to some 25 pounds of highly enriched uranium of French manufacture, it also had 66 pounds of enriched Soviet uranium fuel. Most previous estimates had put the amount at about 20 pounds.
In a study commissioned by the Nuclear Control Institute, a Washington group that studies nuclear proliferation, J. Carlson Mark, former head of weapons design at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, said the total amount would be enough to build two atomic bombs of power equivalent to the bomb dropped on Nagasaki.
The disclosure has prompted criticism of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which had previously said Iraq did not have "a significant quantity" of enriched uranium, a phrase that means more than the 50 pounds usually considered necessary for a bomb.
The atomic agency appears to have justified this position by the fact that the highly enriched fuel was at four sites. As a result it inspected the fuel only at six-month intervals to try to insure that it was not diverted for military ends.
Iraq also acknowledged moving all this highly enriched uranium from its nuclear center at Al Tuwaitha, near Baghdad, to an undisclosed location before the United States-led coalition started air attacks on Iraq in January, raising the possibility that it may have removed and hidden equipment designed for weapons production as well.
 
Allies Question Claim
 The United States and its allies have also questioned Iraq's claim that it has not experimented with biological weapons. The Security Council has already forced Iraq to ratify the Geneva Convention banning biological weapons by making it one of the conditions imposed by Resolution 678 for lifting sanctions.
As a result, Iraq must now reveal the location of all "high-risk laboratories" equipped with advanced safety devices for handling dangerous biological substances. The commission will then inspect these sites in an effort to determine what kind of experiments were conducted there.
 
Kurd Reports Gains in Talks

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 17 (AP) -- Massoud Barzani, the Kurdish rebel and political leader, said today that he and the Iraqi Government had agreed to major points in a peace proposal, but he declined to disclose them.
The rebel leader said he would provide details of the proposal at a news conference on Saturday. He indicated that the Kurds had dropped their demand for international guarantees to any accord with the Government, and he urged refugees to return to northern Iraq.

HEADLINE: Moscow to Ask Help From West On Reform Plan

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 17

 BODY:
The Kremlin has begun an initiative to get major Western countries to join directly in drafting and financing a far-reaching plan for economic and political reform, including creation of a market economy, political decentralization and privatization.
The initiative, details of which were made public in the weekly Moscow News, has not been formally endorsed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev or by the Group of Seven industrialized powers. 
 But extensive private contacts have produced an appeal to the West signed by Yevgeny M. Primakov, a senior adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, and Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a widely respected economist.
 
Young Aide's Second Initiative
 Mr. Yavlinsky, the 39-year-old economist who was the primary architect of the "500 day plan" of radical economic reform rejected by Mr. Gorbachev last summer, was said to be the major mover behind the new initiative.
His aides say he and Mr. Primakov are to fly to Boston on Sunday to discuss refinements for the plan with economists at Harvard University. The idea began taking shape last month when Mr. Yavlinsky was invited to a meeting of experts on the Soviet economy from the Group of Seven.
The initiative that emerged is still taking shape, and Mr. Gorbachev is said to be awaiting the reception in the West before he publicly endorses the plan. The Kremlin reportedly hopes to reach sufficient agreement for Mr. Gorbachev to be invited to the summit meeting of the Seven -- the United States, Canada, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Japan -- in London in July.
In Moscow, the initiative is thought to come at a propitious time. On the Soviet side, Mr. Gorbachev has struck a promising truce with Boris N. Yeltsin, the head of the Russian republic and the primary champion of radical economic reform, in which the President finally recognized the sovereignty of the republics and their right to secede.
 
Growing Sense on Need for Aid
 There is also a growing sense in the Soviet Union that the "crisis program" produced by the government of Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov can only be a stopgap measure without extensive Western assistance. Mr. Pavlov himself in a recent interview appealed to the West not to be bystanders to the Soviet crisis.
On the Western side, President Bush has lately demonstrated a renewed interest in assisting Mr. Gorbachev, prompting a flurry of new contacts, including a telephone conversation between the leaders on May 11.
In addition, many Western experts have come to say that the West cannot sit on the sidelines if it is interested in genuine reforms in the Soviet Union. One of these, Graham Allison, former dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, helped Mr. Yavlinsky shape the proposals.
Mr. Yavlinsky is considered by many Western experts to be the most competent of Soviet economists. He has remained active as an adviser to Mr. Yeltsin and other republican leaders. Mr. Gorbachev's willingness to listen to him again was in itself viewed as further evidence that the President is retreating from the alliance with hard-line forces that he formed last fall.
 
Basic Principles Outlined
 The basic principles of the new initiative are included in an "Appeal to the Group of Seven" signed by Mr. Yavlinsky and Mr. Primakov. It calls on the Soviet Union to draft a comprehensive reform plan and asks the Group of Seven to prepare a parallel plan of economic cooperation.
The letter outlines these basic objectives:
*"A concrete distribution of powers between the center and the republics, especially in economic matters."
*Strict financial and monetary policies and liberalized prices.
*A "broad program of privatization and demonopolization."
*"The creation of conditions for the formation of an open economic system in the Soviet Union and its integration into the world economy."
*The development of legislative bases for a market economy.
These elements have been cited in most previous reform plans. The difference is that this is the first to propose an active role for the West. The financial package, the Soviets say, could include new terms for repaying Moscow's foreign debt, the lifting of trade restrictions, Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, long-term credits and diverse technical assistance.
 
No Cost Mentioned
 Drafters of the letter did not include a cost for the proposal. But Aleksei Mikhailov, a member of Mr. Yavlinsky's economic think-tank, "Epicenter," pointed to a recent article by Prof. Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard University -- currently an economic advisor to the Polish government -- in which he said Western assistance to Moscow should be on the order of $30 billion per year for five years.
Mr. Mikhailov said the proposal resolved the needs of both the Soviet Union and the West. The West would help Moscow achieve the political and economic stability without which it cannot introduce reforms, and the Soviet Union in turn would launch the reforms that the West demands as necessary for any assistance.
In an interview with Moscow News, Mr. Yavlinsky said he was prodded to seek new solutions after Mr. Gorbachev ordered troops into the Moscow streets in March in an unsuccessful attempt to block a pro-Yeltsin rally. The stalemate, he said, proved "that nobody can win," and that the only path was through compromise and negotiation.
Then last month he was invited to attend a meeting of experts preparing the Group of Seven summit talks. Before going he consulted with Mr. Primakov and other Government officials. Mr. Yavlinsky's departure coincided with Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with the presidents of nine Soviet republics, at which they called off their destructive feuding and agreed to cooperate.
Mr. Yavlinsky said he argued his case for cooperation in Washington. The experts wanted a sign that the Kremlin shared his interest, and from this arose the idea of a joint appeal from him and Mr. Primakov.

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT DROPPED IN MARCH TO AN 8-YEAR LOW

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
A jump in exports and sinking demand for imports narrowed the nation's trade deficit in March to $4.05 billion, the smallest monthly imbalance in almost eight years, the Commerce Department said today.
By comparison, the deficit totaled $5.50 billion in February and $8.62 billion in March of last year. 
 The improvement in the March trade data was another indication that strong exports may be blunting the effects of the recession. Aircraft and computer exports rose while auto and oil imports were flat. Exports hit a record level last October and have stayed strong since then.
 
 In Different Directions
 Altogether, exports rose 1.2 percent from February, to $33.99 billion, while imports fell 2.7 percent, to $38.04 billion.
Economists said the fall in imports was not surprising in a recession because domestic demand for goods and services has weakened.
But they said the growth in exports showed that many other economies were still healthy enough to buy American goods and that the dollar remained at a competitive rate against other currencies despite its appreciation early this year.
"That is a really important silver lining of this recession that many people have been too quick to dismiss," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "There still is a real cushion from export demand in this recession."
 
Effect on Foreign Capital
 Just as important, the shrinking United States trade deficit reduces the need for foreign capital at a time when some experts on international finance warn of a global shortage of investment funds. The need for additional money from foreign investors is diminished as the increased sales of American goods abroad bring in enough foreign currency to cover most purchases of imports.
Such a reduced dependence on foreign capital translates into less pressure on the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates high enough to stay attractive to foreign investors.
Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said he found the new statistics encouraging in demonstrating that the slow shrinkage of the trade deficit continued. "It confirms a trend that has been going on for some time, and that's reassuring," he said.
The annual trade deficit peaked at $152.13 billion in 1987 and has fallen steadily since then, to $101.72 billion last year. The last month in which the United States had a trade surplus was in the middle of the last recession, a $291 million surplus in April 1982, said Stephen L. Cooney, the director of international investment and finance at the National Association of Manufacturers.
The deficit reported today for March was the smallest since a $3.96 billion gap recorded in June 1983, when the economy was in the early stages of an expansion that continued until the middle of last year.
 
 Strong Showing in Europe
 The biggest gain in exports for March came in trade with the European Community, helping lift the surplus in that sector to $2.82 billion from a surplus of $1.42 billion in February and $990 million a year before. By contrast, the United States deficit with Japan showed further deterioration in March, moving to $3.58 billion from $3.16 billion in February. It was about even with the year before, at $3.57 billion.
The deficit with Japan has proved stubborn for five reasons, Mr. Hormats said. High Japanese investment in new factories, American consumer loyalty to Japanese brands and the depreciation of the yen all give Japanese companies an advantage, he said. In addition, the growing number of Japanese-owned factories on American soil and Japanese-made cars on American roads have created a strong, consistent demand for imported components and spare parts.
The ever-more controversial United States trade deficit with China, meanwhile, narrowed sharply in March, to $501.4 million, from $773.2 million in February and $554.9 million in March 1990. President Bush said on Wednesday that he would like to renew China's preferential access to the United States market, which is set to expire on July 3.
The annual renewal of the "most favored nation" status, which allows Chinese goods to enter the United States at the lowest tariffs available for each category of products, was almost rejected in Congress last summer because of concerns about China's human rights record. Since then the trade deficit with China has generally deteriorated; it totaled $10.3 billion last year as tons of textiles and apparel were shipped to the United States, mostly by way of Hong Kong.
As a result, protectionists have joined human rights advocates in criticizing a renewal of the most-favored status.
 
 A Small Gap With Mexico
 Another politically touchy trade relationship showed a small deterioration. The United States posted a $65 million deficit with Mexico, compared with a $119 million surplus in February.
Many members of Congress have opposed the negotiation of a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico, raising fears that American companies will move factories and send back a flood of cheap imports while taking advantage of the cheap labor and less-strict environmental laws in Mexico.
The long-term trend in Mexican trade has been for the United States' deficit to shrink slowly. The deficit in March 1990 was $341.3 million.
Both houses of Congress are expected to vote early next week on resolutions that would cancel the automatic renewal of the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements that are then submitted for a single vote in Congress with no amendments permitted. The resolutions are not expected to pass.
Overall imports of oil and oil products, meanwhile, totaled $3.76 billion in March, little changed from $3.70 billion in February.
The total trade figure reported today was seasonally adjusted. In unadjusted terms, trade was nearly in balance, posting a deficit of only $1.84 billion. But the March deficit is usually one of the smaller ones each year, as winter demand for heating oil fades and summer demand for gasoline imports still lies ahead. So in the seasonal adjustment process, the $1.84 billion deficit was recalculated using a formula that increased it to $4.05 billion.
