HEADLINE: New I.B.M. Price Cuts Expected

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. will reduce prices by 6 to 24 percent on Monday on some of its most popular desktop systems, according to industry executives familiar with the action. The cuts are in response to continued deep price cuts by other makers of personal computers.
The new round of price cuts -- the second such move by the International Business Machines Corporation in the last month -- follows similar actions by its principal competitors, including the Compaq Computer Corporation, Apple Computer Inc., Dell Computer, the Toshiba Corportion, the AST Research Corporation and others. On Thursday, Zenith Data Systems announced price cuts across its product line ranging from 12 to 31 percent. 
 On April 23, just a week after Compaq had cut prices as much as 34 percent, I.B.M. reduced prices on 20 models from 3 percent to 38 percent. At the same time, it introduced a number of models based on a new chip made by the Intel Corporation, the 486sx microprocessor.
 
 Surge in Apple Sales
 I.B.M. and Compaq are responding not only to the inroads made by clone makers, but also to a sales surge at Apple after price cuts in March, which have driven its market share up to nearly 20 percent in recent months.
The industrywide price-cutting epidemic may be grim news for computer makers facing new pressure on profitability, but it could be a big plus for computer buyers, analysts said.
"All these price cuts represent the best news for buyers in some time," said Dan Ness Jr., a microcomputer analyst at Computer Intelligence, a La Jolla, Calif., market research firm. "The message has now gotten to anyone who has a few dollars. It will bring people out of the woodwork and be good for software sellers as well."
 
 Price-Tracking Service
 Mr. Ness said that price cuts had come so rapidly in recent months that his company had set up a special price-tracking service for its corporate customers.
The I.B.M. price cuts, according to the industry executives, will affect 13 models, including 4 model 30's, 4 model 55's and 5 deskside model 80's. The base price for one of the model 80 systems will be reduced from $11,495 to $8,695, they said.
In announcing its first-quarter results, I.B.M. executives said that personal computer sales had fallen by 17 percent during the period and showed no immediate sign of improvement because of domestic and international economic weakness.
Industry analysts attribute the personal-computer price cuts to fundamental changes in the business, mostly the sudden broader acceptance of products from small computer makers that once were off-limits to large corporate buyers, which puchased name brands like Compaq and I.B.M. at premium prices.
"The problem facing Compaq in particular is that their distribution channel is exploding in their face," said John McCarthy, an analyst at Forrester Research, a market research firm based in Boston. "Fortune 500 companies are not buying because of the recession, and smaller buyers are shifting to mail order vendors and superstores."
The industry price war has had its nasty side. Last month, Compaq filed suit in Federal District Court in Houston, contending that magazine ads place by a mail-order reseller, Dell Computer, had improperly quoted Compaq's published list prices as actual prices, and had unfairly compared the performance of the two companies' products.

HEADLINE: Fed to Consult More Closely About Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve confirmed yesterday that its top policy makers had agreed to consult more closely about changing interest rates to influence economic growth.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, appears, however, to have retained the power to change a key short-term lending rate, minutes of the March 26 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee show. 
 The Fed was reported to have had an internal disagreement over altering the Federal funds rate -- the rate at which commercial banks lend one another short-term funds -- with some members feeling Mr. Greenspan had not consulted them sufficiently.
"Members agreed that in general the existing practice" should be continued, the minutes reported, but added that "consultation among members" would be appropriate when sizable rate changes were contemplated.
 
 Governors and Presidents
 The policy-making Open Market Committee is made up of the seven members of the Fed's board of governors and five regional bank presidents. There are two vacancies on the board of governors.
The presidents -- who have traditionally been more fearful that lower interest rates will fuel inflation -- were reportedly upset over not having been more closely consulted about a cut in the funds rate.
The group, which deliberates behind closed doors, meets every six to eight weeks to discuss economic growth and set interest rates. It releases the minutes of its proceedings on the Friday after the next meeting.
The market committee last met on Tuesday, and economists said the group appeared to have left its credit policies unchanged. It voted 10 to 0 at the March 26 meeting to keep its credit stance unchanged, although some members expressed the need to "be alert" to the possibility of raising interest rates to curb inflation pressures.
 
Rates Lowered on April 30
 In an apparent reversal, however, the Fed lowered interest rates on April 30, when it cut its benchmark discount rate -- the rate it charges commercial banks for loans -- by a half-point, to 5 1/2 percent. The central bank also nudged down the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point, to 5 3/4 percent.
The minutes of the March meeting said committee members discussed to what extent changes in the discount rate should be passed through to the Federal funds rate. Some of the Fed presidents are reported to have balked at Mr. Greenspan's decision on Feb. 1 to push down the funds rate by a half-point at the same time the board agreed to lower the discount rate by a half-point.
Referring to subsequent rate cuts, the minutes singled out the more rapid growth of the nation's money supply in February and March, which supported expectations of a near-term rebound in the economy.

HEADLINE: New York Ethics Law Leads Local Officials to Quit Posts

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 17

 BODY:
Scores of municipal officials across New York State are resigning their positions on public boards and authorities rather than filing extensive financial disclosure reports required by a new state ethics law.
The law has generated a backlash across the state, in which an effort to stop corruption is threatening to stop government instead. Officials in some municipalities fear that the resignations will paralyze local government by making it difficult to convene quorums on zoning boards, community college boards and development agencies. 
 The rebellion in New York has been particularly noticeable in smaller municipalities, where unpaid appointees to local boards have balked at meeting the deadline -- last Wednesday -- for filing 20-page disclosure forms that request information on everything from property holdings to investment income for officials, their spouses and their children.
 
New Jersey Faces Similar Law
 "My objection is that I'm a volunteer; I'm not elected and I'm not paid," said Christopher H. Brown, an accountant who resigned his seat on the Niagara Falls library board on Thursday. "I wasn't going to sacrifice my privacy for the so-called privilege of giving up my family time and my free time."
A similar storm is brewing in New Jersey, where a new state financial disclosure law approved in February has generated threats of mass resignations from local governments by August, when officials must file their first disclosure forms.
The revolts in both states reflect a political environment in which government officials at all levels are complaining that increased scrutiny is driving good people from government.
 
Finances and Real Estate
 The New York law, which was passed in 1987 in reaction to the New York City corruption scandals, applies to elected officials, department heads, policy-making employees and officials who approve contracts and leases in municipalities with more than 50,000 residents. The disclosure forms vary slightly by municipality. But at a minimum officials must report their income and most investments, with amounts indicated within a range of values. They must list the location of all real estate that they own within their jurisdiction or within five miles of it. And they must describe debts in excess of $5,000 and any interest in contracts involving their municipality.
Several officials who have resigned said they had no conflicts of interest to hide. But they said they feared that such information could be used to their disadvantage by competitors in their professions and businesses.
Even Henry G. Miller, the chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Local Government Ethics, which was established in 1989 to enforce the new law, said he believes "the forms are far too burdensome and intrusive." The commission has proposed a new law that would vastly simplify the financial disclosure requirements.
 
No Statistics Compiled
 Because the first deadline for filing financial disclosure reports just passed, statistics have yet to be compiled on how many officials have submitted resignations. But Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said his organization had received reports of more than 100 resignations from county governments.
Few problems have been reported by New York City and other large governments where many of the affected jobs are full-time paid positions. In those places, officials have often filled out the forms grudgingly rather than forsake their salaries.
Some municipal officials have received extensions for the filing date from state and local ethics boards and are expected to resign if the Legislature does not pass a less onerous law before the extensions expire. In Sullivan County, seven of the 10 members of the Private Industry Council and two of the three members of a prisoner release commission have submitted resignations, said David Kaufman, chairman of the Board of Supervisors.
 
Stalls Government Decisions
 In Genesee County, three of the nine trustees of the community college have resigned, said Charles W. Meyer, the County Manager. All the members of the county's board of the Industrial Development Agency and its Board of Health have vowed to quit if a new ethics law is not passed before their extensions expire.
New Jersey's law, which requires the disclosure of all sources of income of more than $2,000 earned by officials and their family members, has already brought threats of resignation from members of the Mount Olive zoning board, for example.
Many of the issues that come before local policy boards are matters that require little more than a rubber stamp of approval. But when the boards cannot meet, even simple decisions on contracts, appointments, purchases and real-estate matters must be suspended.
In New York State, for instance, the Industrial Development Agency of Sullivan County could not gather a quorum on May 9 because of the resignation of several members. The agency had to postpone a vote to increase the size of a bond issue needed to construct a major office building in the county, said Paula Osenni, the county's economic development director.
The Temporary State Commission on Local Government Ethics has proposed a new law that would require a two-page disclosure form. The form would request only a listing of real estate owned by the official or his family within one mile of the municipality and the name and nature of any business interests of the official and his spouse.
The proposal would establish a code of ethics for municipal officials that would bar conflicts of interest and prohibit former officials from appearing before their former employers for a year after leaving government.
The executive director of New York State Common Cause, Julian S. Palmer, said his group is not yet convinced that the current forms should be scrapped. "As we see it, holding public office is a matter of public trust, and unfortunately the public has been disappointed too many times and has become too cynical not to have significant financial disclosure," he said.

HEADLINE: F.T.C. Investigating Pricing of Appliances

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Government regulators are investigating possible price collusion among the nation's biggest makers of home appliances, officials from the companies and the Federal Trade Commission said today.
The F.T.C. apparently began its inquiry after the chairman of the Raytheon Company, manufacturer of Amana and Speed Queen appliances, called at a 1989 meeting of securities analysts for industry competitors to raise prices. 
 Kevin Arquit, chief of the F.T.C.'s antitrust division, said the agency had under way "several investigations in the area of invitations to collude."
 
 1989 Remark by Raytheon Chief
 During the 1989 meeting of securities analysts in New York, Thomas Phillips, then chairman of Raytheon, called on major manufacturers to raise prices by 6 percent to 7 percent. The remark was reported in a trade newspaper, HFD.
"I can't really characterize his statements other than as they were reported," Larry McCracken, a Raytheon spokesman, said. "He was responding to some questions that were directed toward him, and that's all I can say."
Mr. McCracken said Raytheon had supplied information to the F.T.C. in 1989 and 1990 and the company's last contact with the agency was "at least six months ago."
In addition to Raytheon, the F.T.C. asked the Whirlpool Corporation and the General Electric Company for information in conjunction with the investigation.
A Whirlpool spokesman, T. R. Reid, said his company responded to the F.T.C.'s request for information shortly after thye remark by Mr. Phillips and again last September. However, he added, "to the best of our knowledge, we're not a focus of any investigation that might be going on, nor have we been contacted by the F.T.C. again."
G.E. has supplied information to the F.T.C. "on an ongoing basis," a spokesman, Jack Batty, said. "I presume it's on pricing."
A person familiar with the situation, who asked not to be identified, said G.E. also was not a target of the investigation.
Mr. Arquit of the F.T.C. said a solicitation for higher prices could violate Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, which forbids unfair methods of competition. "There are some arguments that this could be labeled an unfair method," he added.
Shipments of household appliances fell 2.5 percent from 1989 to 1990. The Federal Government attributed the slowdown to decreased consumer confidence and to higher unemployment and inflation rates late in the year. A slowdown in housing construction also contributed, the Government said.
Mr. Batty of G.E. said the household appliance market was "highly competitive."

HEADLINE: Tilting at Taxes in Connecticut

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell Weicker's proposal that Connecticut tax personal income has produced a menacing coalition of Democratic and Republican legislators who (1) don't like the tax and (2) don't like Mr. Weicker. Their shortsighted scrambling for a no-income-tax alternative puts politics ahead of Connecticut's long-term interest.
Mr. Weicker's election as an independent gave him latitude to press tax reforms that Democrats and Republicans have ducked for decades. But it also bred bipartisan resentment. Democrats resent his breaking their lock on the governorship. Republicans doubly resent that he quit the G.O.P. to run alone, and then beat their strong candidate. 
 With no troops of his own in the General Assembly, Mr. Weicker's tax plan needs hefty outside support. He has it from major business groups and unions, but taxpayers appear largely unconvinced. The public's suspicion is misplaced; the no-income-tax option packs more pain than Mr. Weicker's.
The Weicker plan, fair and sound, would tax all income above $12,500 ($25,000 for couples) at 6 percent, end separate taxes on capital gains, dividends and interest, slash the sales tax but apply it more broadly, and cut taxes on corporate income.
Sales taxes are inherently unfair to the poor, because they pay the same tax as the rich on every purchase. Sales taxes are also unstable revenue; collections bounce up and down with the economy. Finally, cutting the state tax from 8 percent -- the nation's highest -- to 4.25 percent would make it the region's lowest, and thus attract business.
Sponsors of the coalition alternative, including most of both parties' leaders, have not yet showed their hand. News reports indicate they want to hold the sales tax at 8 percent and apply it far and wide, cut corporate taxes, raise cigarette and alcohol taxes, make more people pay taxes on dividends and interest, raise the capital gains tax, slap a tax on large gifts -- and more.
The plan is also said to involve more spending cuts, a stretchout in debt reduction and some dubious accounting. Yet, coming so close to adjournment, it will have no proper public airing.
If the advance word is correct, the coalition package seems calculated to drive out businesses and wealth, postpone grief for politicians who don't dare vote responsibly, and land a haymaker on Mr. Weicker. But if this mischievous package prevails, Connecticut will be the injured party.

HEADLINE: France, Where the Center Holds

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis ;Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
During the 1981 elections, which brought the Socialists to power, one of their stars, Lionel Jospin, said, "The political center in France is like the Bermuda Triangle. Whoever approaches it disappears."
Now, after Francois Mitterrand celebrated his 10th anniversary as President, the change is evident. In effect, France is governed from the center. 
 This will remain true despite the nomination this week of Edith Cresson as France's first female prime minister, replacing Michel Rocard. She is a Mitterrand loyalist and tough promoter of French industry against foreign competition. Mr. Rocard, who never got along with the President, was popular but his Socialist Party criticized him for lacking social sensitivity.
The Communists are marginalized. The far right, about equal to the far left, is more vigorous. But there is a wide consensus not so different from the one embracing most American Republicans and Democrats.
It came without fanfare, almost unnoticed until last week when the political class started adding up the results of the decade. This is a profound change for France, used to thinking of itself as clearly divided between right and left ever since the Revolution.
And it is provoking great outcries from politicians who feel they need the sharp, familiar definitions to advance their claims on an increasingly disinterested electorate.
Far from applauding the transformation to centrism of a Socialist Government that set out to "change society" and force a "rupture" with capitalism, the opposition bewails that Mr. Mitterrand has stolen their thunder. Some Socialists complain that their party has lost its soul, and settled for managing the society that exists instead of pursuing its vocation to "reinvent" it.
The major switch under President Mitterrand was imposed by necessity, after the first two frenetic years of nationalizations, expanded social welfare and Government-led enterprise brought huge deficits and threatened the franc. Austerity was proclaimed as an interlude, to restore balance before moving on again to classic Socialist goals from a sounder base.
That never happened. Some Socialist takeovers and regulations were abruptly reversed during the two years of "cohabitation" under conservative Prime Minister Jacques Chirac in 1986-88, while Mr. Mitterrand bided his time as the imperturbable "President of all the French," as he took to describing himself in place of his previous assertion of leading "the people of the left."
Europe has slowed the French pendulum. It has proved impossible for a major member of the European Community to go against the tide dominating its partners. In that sense, Margaret Thatcher was right that the community limits the choices of independent governments.
This constraint will increase with the single market and steps toward economic-monetary union and political union. It will affect the politics of all the members, perhaps not in terms of who wins and loses elections but in terms of how much difference it makes. A government change in Germany or Italy can no longer have the dramatic results it might have 10 years ago. The French experience will not be unique.
Nor is it contested. Except in the occasional reflex gesture and the increasingly empty but still sacrosanct Gaullist rhetoric, France is abandoning its insistence on singularity. From De Gaulle's limit on integration to a "Europe of states," France has moved to the forefront of encouraging emergence of a more consolidated European power.
It isn't only in the East that old habits and assumptions are abandoned. Quietly, it's happened in France, too.

HEADLINE: Separate Ethnic Worlds Grow on Campus

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
Sergio Perez lives in an off-campus apartment with other Chicano students at the University of California at Berkeley. A senior, he is majoring in Chicano studies, and participating in bilingual commencement exercises reserved for Chicano and Latino students.
Most of his friends are Mexican-American, like Jesus Covarrubias, who, one recent afternoon, was relaxing with Mr. Perez at Sproul Plaza on a section of wall marked as Chicano territory. 
 "You could say that this campus is segregated for some reasons," Mr. Perez said, looking to Mr. Covarrubias for support."But for me it was like family."
 
Separate Ethnic Worlds
 Family, yes, with the positive reassurance that implies for the members. But often a closed and exclusive family that demands loyalty and rejects outsiders.
As American campuses grow more racially and ethnically diverse, many students are creating ever more complete worlds of their own, in which they live, study and socialize only with others like themselves. Sociologists and educators warn that this phenomenon has already splintered Berkeley and many other universities around the country into ethnic encampments filled with dissonance and misunderstanding.
"Separatism and even tribalism in the old-fashioned sense are increasing," said Ernest L. Boyer, the former United States Education Commissioner who is president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.
The implications are frightening, Dr. Boyer said, because the college campus, in many ways, is a crucible for tomorrow's society. "If humanism and communal understanding can't happen on a college campus, how in the world can it happen on city streets?" he said.
Such separatism has existed for decades, gaining notice with the militancy and isolation of black students in the 1960's, who banded together for support in a hostile environment. Most educators agree that student self-segregation has intensified since then as the number of minority students has steadily increased on most campuses.
 
Ethnic Growth on Campuses
 About 16 percent of all college students belong to minority groups, as against 13.5 percent in 1978, but the percentage is much higher in California and the Southwest. Black, Asian and Hispanic students and, to a lesser extent, American Indians, now have enough members to form a substantial nucleus at universities like Berkeley. Many other universities also have substantial minority populations, including Stanford, Cornell, Rutgers and Penn State as well as smaller colleges like Vassar, where black students will hold their own graduation ceremony.
The rise over the last decade of ethnic studies departments, separate dormitories and activities based on race have all made it easier for students to function within the larger campus environment without really being a part of it.
Of course, nothing prevents college students from meeting and becoming friends with students of other races, as many do. On the other hand, there may be benefits to campus Balkanization. Studies have shown, for instance, that black students who live with black roommates and belong to African-American organizations graduate at a higher rate than those without such sources of support.
 
'Stresses and Strains'
 "To me it's not a bad thing for folks to affiliate with other people they have an interest in," said Michael L. Jackson, an associate dean of students at Stanford University, where 37 percent of undergraduate students come from minority groups as against 13 percent in 1980. "The great experiment we have is to bring people together at a community like Stanford and have them live near each other and learn from each other. That will not be without its stresses and strains."
Those strains are evident on almost every campus. Incidents of racial harassment are increasing, embittered debates rage over affirmative action policies, and students and professors say there is such a heightened sensitivity to remarks that could be perceived as biased that they cannot speak freely about race.
As minority enrollment has increased, many students have developed a heightened self-consciousness of their own racial identity, beginning almost from the moment they arrive on campus, sociologists say. Whites say they are made to feel like oppressers, with any affirmation of their culture seen as "racist behavior." Minority students say they are made to feel like they do not belong on campuses where affirmative action casts doubt on their qualifications.
"I didn't want a whole layer of challenges about whether I deserved to be here," said Akinwunmi McKenzie, a sophomore from Memphis who chose to live in a predominantly black dorm during his first year at Stanford. "I figured that if I lived in a black environment, it wouldn't come up."
Mr. McKenzie said that after his first year he felt confident enough to leave the security of the black dorm. "I had been self-affirmed," he said. He now lives in a dorm with many Hispanic students.
 
Harbinger of Social Changes
 Berkeley, where minority enrollment has gone to more than 55 percent from 34 percent a decade ago, is the most ethnically and racially diverse research university in the country and is often a harbinger of social changes.
Predominantly white in the 1960's, Berkeley is now so diverse that no group is a majority.
At lunchtime, Sproul Plaza becomes an international bazaar: members of the Filipino-American Alliance are there, as are members of the Vietnamese Students' Association, the Chinese Student Association, the Asian Student Union and Tonodach: The Japanese American Cultural Club.
Resisting such alliances, and the peer pressure to join them, can be difficult. "My first semester here I took an Asian studies class that turned into a total complaining session, and I swore I would never get into a class like that again," said Chak Gaude, a Berkeley sophomore of Indian descent. "Since then I've taken some heat for not associating with the Asians, but so what."
 
New Racial Awareness
 Troy Duster, director of the Institute for the Study of Social Change at Berkeley, is finishing a two-year study on the accelerated diversity of the campus. He has found that as minority enrollment rose, racial awareness intensified and left students struggling to deal with the racial realities they had never encountered.
Dr. Duster interviewed 230 Berkeley students and found that while many wanted to experience different cultures, they had trouble understanding the actions of other groups and often segregated themselves, either for self-defense or mutual support.
Dr. Duster has concluded that campus fragmentation, if it is balanced on as many different groups as it is at Berkeley, might lead to a social transformation -- a society without a dominant group, capable of working in the multi-cultural world economy that is now forming.
"Now we have to start talking not in the old tradition of, 'How you can be like me,' " Dr. Duster said, "but, 'How can I understand you?' "
Dr. Duster is recommending in his report that the Berkeley administration do more to unite students during their crucial first six months on campus and to encourage them to interact in class and in public areas without feeling they are violating racial and ethnic allegiances.
Other institutions are trying various sorts of experiments in social engineering. Cornell has a Ujaama House for African-American students and is building a small dorm with a American Indian theme. Oberlin College in Oberlin, Ohio, has set aside dorms for African-American, Hispanic and Jewish students.
 
Stanford Model Is Watched
 One model being watched by other universities is at Stanford, which has four special ethnic dorms, for black, Asian, American Indian and Hispanic students, but with a twist -- no more than about half of the students living in each dorm can belong to the theme group. The rest must be from other groups.
The house with the Hispanic theme is called Casa Zapata, named after the famous Mexican revolutionary Emiliano Zapata. Half its 98 residents are from Spanish-speaking cultures, primarily Mexican-American. The others either selected Casa Zapata or were assigned there in a housing lottery.
Except for boisterous murals of Latin heroes throughout the dormitory, Casa Zapata looks, smells and sounds like most other dorms. Spanish is often heard, but by no means is it used exclusively. Hispanic culture enlivens Casa Zapata's cafeteria menu and prompts some holiday observances like Cinco de Mayo. But the real tradition of the dorm is a feeling of family that embraces all cultures.
"Students of this generation talk about anything -- sex, gender, drugs -- but somehow the issue of ethnicity and race still is a foreign language," said Cecilia Preciado Burciaga, an associate dean of students and a resident fellow who lives at Casa Zapata. "Maybe now is the time to look for common ground rather than just celebrating differences."
 
Defining People's Differences
 For students, many from segregated backgrounds, such common ground usually starts with defining the differences between people.
Stacey Strong, a first-year student,with a give-away Boston accent, was randomly selected to live at Casa Zapata and at first found the transition difficult. She said she took twice as long as anyone else to remember names because they seemed so foreign to her.
"Sometimes I'd get confused because I didn't know if I was going to offend," she said. She said she finally appreciated the difference between herself and the Hispanic students when one of them asked her what it felt like to be an Anglo.
"I'd never heard anyone use the word Anglo for me before," said Miss Strong, whose home is Weymouth, Mass., a predominately white, middle-class community. "Where I came from no one was an Anglo; everyone was just Irish Catholic. But after being at Casa Zapata a while I realized that an Anglo can be an Anglo only if there's someone who's not."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 20, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about rising ethnic and racial separatism on American campuses misstated commencement plans at Vassar College. Black students will not hold their own graduation ceremony on May 26; they have organized special events that will be open to everyone.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops by 7.38; Loss for Week at 33.54

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late flurry of selling pushed the stock market into the minus column yesterday in a relatively active session.
As measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, the market closed down 7.38, at 2,886.63. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 largely blue-chip issues rose 0.20, to 372.39. For the week, the Dow lost 33.54, and the S.& P. index was off 3.35. 
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange climbed to 174.2 million shares, from 154.5 million the day before. Much of the increased volume was attributed to yesterday's "double witching hour," when the May stock options and index futures expired. Those exercising their options usually cause an increase in volume.
 
 Rumor on Discount Rate
 "The day's most important news wasn't news at all but a rumor that the Federal Reserve was about to cut its discount rate again," said William M. LeFevre, market strategist at Tucker Anthony Inc. "Until that rumor hit the street at midday, the market was on a downward bias."
After several feeble afternoon rallies, trading ended with a brief bout of pre-weekend profit taking. There were 684 issues that advanced and 813 that declined.
Compaq Computer was again the most actively traded issue, closing unchanged at 35 3/4 on a turnover of five million shares. Company projections of much lower future profits sent Compaq shares tumbling by 13 1/4 points on Wednesday. Because Compaq is a popular issue, its huge loss has depressed other computer stocks as well as the market generally.
Apple Computer, for example, was the second-most-active issue and fell 2, to 47, on a volume of 4.2 million shares. Among other actively traded issues, Philip Morris lost a point, at 64 3/4, as Congress and several European countries advanced proposals that would curb tobacco advertising.
 
Royal Dutch Down
 Environmental concerns contributed to a 2 1/4-point decline in the price of Royal Dutch shares, which closed at 80 3/8 in heavy trading. Some of the decline in Royal Dutch, one of the biggest oil companies, was laid to reports that petroleum companies with large European operations were planning to impose more stringent practices to prevent spills and other accidents that could damage the environment.
One of the day's best performers was the initial public offering of shares in Ann Taylor Stores, a chain of women's apparel shops that has done well during the recession. The offering of roughly six million shares was made at 27 and the stock closed at 27 7/8. Ann Taylor shares led the most-active list for much of the session.
Elsewhere, the American Stock Exchange's market value index slipped 0.24, to 358.01, while the Nasdaq composite index closed down by 0.39, at 481.38.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 22, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about Friday's stock trading misstated the reason for the price decline of Royal Dutch. It reflected a dividend that will be paid only to those who held Royal Dutch shares before Friday.

HEADLINE: Seville Journal;
Picture a U.S. Pavilion (Better Late Than Never)

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEVILLE, Spain, May 11

 BODY:
One year before the opening of Seville's universal exhibition, Expo '92, the large plot of land assigned to the United States is already a tourist attraction. While new pavilions are going up all around it, the American site is silent and deep in weeds.
 Beside it, New Zealand's pavilion is well advanced. The eventual shape of the British, Japanese and Soviet pavilions is already clear. Many buildings being put up by Spain are close to completion. But the first cement mixer has yet to arrive at the padlocked American site. 
Expo's organizers are perplexed. The most powerful nation on earth, the country that probably best symbolizes Expo's main theme, "Discoveries," has so far done less to prepare for the last universal exhibition of the 20th century than Monaco.
 But back in 1988, President Reagan was the only head of state who personally accepted King Juan Carlos's invitation to join this celebration of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's trip to the New World. And it was the United States that demanded the largest pavilion site after that of Spain.
 
Like a Dallas Country Fair
 So buses taking tourists around the 538-acre Expo site on La Cartuja island beside Seville often slow down near the American plot to give guides a chance to explain why it is empty. But they always reassure visitors that by inauguration day on April 20 next year, it will be filled.
 "I have faith in American ingenuity and America's capacity to recover," Emilio Cassinello, who heads the Expo state company, said. "But I cannot deny that the United States is running late, above all in terms of the expectations raised by the American presence."
In reality, work on the American pavilion should start soon. But it has been scaled back from its original striking design to something that a Spanish official said would resemble a country fair in Dallas. And the United States is still unsure what it will exhibit.
 What the United States has already demonstrated is the difficulty that government and private sector have in collaborating on a prestige project of this kind. While in most countries governments took the lead, the United States squabbled for three years over who should pay for its pavilion.
 For this same reason, in fact, Expo '92 is taking place in a southern Spanish city rather than a northern American city. As far back as 1982, private promoters in Chicago made the first bid for the fifth centenary exhibition, but the initiative collapsed after the city government withheld its support.
 
Recession Adds to Problems
 In the case of Seville, the Federal Government first proposed a $45 million budget for the American pavilion, including $15 million from the private sector. But the request for funds was delayed in a House subcommittee by legislators who argued that taxpayers should not foot the bill.
 And without a green light for official involvement, the American commissioner for Expo '92 at the time, Marvin Stone, had to struggle to find American companies, states and cities willing to take part with stands or contributions. When the recession began, his problems multiplied.
 Finally, last summer, Congress authorized the United States Information Agency to put $13 million toward Expo '92, and Spanish companies at last made bids to build the pavilion, designed by Barton Myers. But while American experts predicted bids of about $10 million, the lowest was for $26 million.
 One culprit was the inflation driven by $1.5 billion in construction at the Expo site and $8.5 billion being spent in Seville and the rest of southern Spain. The other was that the United States now needed its pavilion built in a hurry. Early this year, embarrassed American officials quietly shrank their project to match their more modest resources.
 In a nod to Seville's 90-degree summer temperatures, a wall of water, an unspecified number of cooling towers and three shade "sails" representing Columbus's caravelles have survived in the American project. But the main exhibition space will now be provided by two United States Government-owned geodesic domes that have traveled Europe for the last 20 years and will be brought here for the occasion.
 
Others Have Daring Designs
 The pavilion's original theme, "Rediscovering America," is another casualty, although General Motors will turn one of the domes into a standing-only theater and finance production of a film about the United States. Other American companies are also now showing interest, while Texas will run the pavilion's main restaurant.
 Making the best of things, the new American Commissioner for Expo '92, Frederick M. Bush, who is not related to the President, insists that the United States will still do well because the purpose of a universal exhibition is not to build architectural monuments but to display the contents of pavilions.
 That opinion, though, is clearly not shared by other developed countries who have chosen daring designs to represent them in Seville. Japan, for example, is building the world's largest wooden building. Switzerland's 80-foot-high tower will be made entirely of paper. Britain's glass pavilion will have water cascading down one side.
 Spain hopes that more than 100 countries will be represented at Expo '92. To insure the participation of small or poor third-world countries, Spain is providing them with exhibition space, although five former Spanish colonies -- Mexico, Chile, Venezuela, Cuba and Puerto Rico -- will have their own pavilions.
 With 70 percent of the main infrastructure completed and work under way at most pavilion sites, an advertising blitz starts this fall to insure that Expo '92 meets its target of 18 million visitors before it closes on Columbus Day next year. And with 500,000 visitors expected from the United States, Spain is gambling that there will be an American pavilion for them to see.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With only one year until the opening of Seville's Expo '92, construction has yet to begin at the American Pavilion site. Building is well advanced at other sites including the New Zealand pavilion, in the background. (Alan Riding/The New York Times) Map of Spain showing location of Seville

HEADLINE: Often-Ravenous Hanson Takes a Taste of I.C.I.

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 17

 BODY:
As politicians, union leaders and management prepared to fight a possible takeover of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., investors waited today to see if I.C.I., Britain's third-largest company, would become the next and largest course for Hanson P.L.C., a conglomerate that has swallowed a slew of American and British corporations.
 On Wednesday, Hanson disclosed that it had purchased about 20 million, or 2.8 percent, of I.C.I.'s shares. Analysts say they think Hanson paid a total of about L240 million ($417.2 million), or about L11.94 a share.
 
Just to Hanson's Taste
 Few business executives are considered the match of Lord Hanson, the chairman of Hanson, and his partner, Sir Gordon White, chairman of its American arm, in reaping big profits by buying industrial companies, selling vast parts of them and improving the performance of what remains. With its broad array of products, which include commodity, agricultural and specialty chemicals; drugs; paint, and explosives, I.C.I. seems like the kind of conglomerate they love to devour.
 The stock, which had risen since Monday as much as 17 percent, slipped a bit today, closing on the London International Stock Exchange at L12.47 ($21.44), down 19 pence. On the New York Stock Exchange, I.C.I.'s American depository receipts closed at $84.875, down $1.75. 
 When asked in an interview today if Hanson had bought more I.C.I. shares, Martin Taylor, vice chairman of Hanson, would only say, "I haven't got anything to add to the Wednesday statement." Hanson had said on Wednesday that the purchase was for investment purposes. Mr. Taylor declined to say whether that might mean a takeover bid.
 If Hanson does acquire I.C.I., analysts say the price will be at least L10 billion ($17.2 billion). That would make it the biggest takeover in British history, exceeding the record that Hanson set in 1989, when it paid $5.3 billion for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. Analysts predict that if I.C.I. were sold piecemeal, it would be worth as much as L20 a share, or a total of L14.2 billion ($24.42 billion).
 I.C.I. executives declined to comment today. But people close to the company say a management team led by Sir Denys Henderson, I.C.I.'s chairman, and Frank Whitely, its deputy chairman, have dusted off a takeover-defense plan and enlisted the help of S. G. Warburg & Company, the British investment bank, and Goldman, Sachs & Company, the American investment bank.
 I.C.I. had worldwide sales of $22.84 billion last year, of which the United States accounted for $4.5 billion. The company employs more than 18,000 people in its American operations. It is the fourth-largest chemical company in America, where its other major products include Glidden paint; drugs for treating depression, cancer and cardiovascular diseases, and seeds.
 Companies that have fallen to Hanson in the last six years include Imperial Group, which was bought for $3.85 billion; the SCM Corporation ($930 million), Kidde ($1.6 billion), Consolidated Gold Fields, Cavenham Forest Industries ($1.3 billion) and Peabody Holding ($1.2 billion).
 According to Hanson's last earnings statement, it had $12.88 billion in cash as of March 31. In April it sold $894.3 million worth of convertible bonds. And Mr. Smith noted that his company had the ability to borrow up to $29.2 billion.
 
Has Sold Other Stakes
 Will Hanson pounce, or is it only playing the stock because it sees I.C.I. as an undervalued company in a depressed industry that may be bottoming out? Analysts are divided.
 Hanson has bought and then sold large stakes in companies like Midland Bank P.L.C.; Westland Group P.L.C., the British maker of helicopters and Hovercraft, and the Cummins Engine Company. But with interest rates in Britain and the United States falling, and with many thinking that the recessions in the two countries are easing, some think Lord Hanson is eager to make a move.
 "He has moved from assets into cash over the last three years," said Geoffrey Allum of County NatWest Securities Ltd. "Now he wants to put the cash back into assets and ride the cycle back up again."
 But others note that Hanson could face problems from antitrust regulators if it tries to buy I.C.I. Both Hanson and I.C.I. are two of the world's biggest producers of titanium oxide, a pigment widely used in products like paint, paper and plastics.
 Even if there were no antitrust problem, some analysts say, the Government would never allow a company so important to Britain to be acquired and split up. "I.C.I. is not takeover-able," said Charles Lambert of Smith New Court Securities Ltd.
 I.C.I. employs more than 50,000 people in Britain, where it is a leader in research and development. These analysts note that Lord Hanson likes mature businesses with a strong cash flow and is not likely to keep research-intensive businesses like drugs and specialty chemicals.
 Before Hanson's announcement, I.C.I. had shareholder authority to buy back up to 10 percent of its shares. And its executives indicated to analysts this week that they would move quickly to slash costs and prune some lackluster operations.
 
Stock Has Underperformed
 Indeed, some in the financial community have long contended that I.C.I. is too diverse and suggested that its financial performance and stock price would be stronger had it been more aggressive in withdrawing from cyclical commodity chemicals and focused more on higher-potential businesses like specialty chemicals and drugs.
 For years, I.C.I.'s stock has underperformed the market as the slump in commodity chemicals and recessions in Britain and the United States have depressed earnings. Pretax profits fell 36 percent last year, to L1 billion ($1.93 billion) on sales of L12.9 billion ($24.88 billion), and profits in the first quarter of 1991 plunged 52 percent.
 Indeed, with Britain's economy mired in a recession, Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Government, which must hold a general election by mid-1992, has plenty to worry about without a huge acquisition that could threaten jobs and raise issues about Britain's competitiveness.
 Officials of the opposition Labor Party and of unions representing I.C.I. workers called on the Government to prevent Lord Hanson from trying to acquire I.C.I. Some have demanded that he be hauled in front of a parliamentary committee to explain his intentions.
 John Redwood, the Government's Minister of Corporate Affairs, hinted that the Government might block a takeover that would result in I.C.I.'s dismemberment. "Our main concern is to see competitive markets," he said, "but there are other issues that could come up because the law says it is about the public interest."
 
Investors Take Profits
 The possibility of Government intervention and an article in The Financial Times questioning whether banks would lend Hanson the remaining money it would need for a takeover bid apparently caused some investors to decide to take their profits and sell I.C.I. shares, analysts said.
 I.C.I. has made great strides in diversifying out of commodity petrochemicals, plastics, fibers and fertilizers.
 In February, Sir Denys, I.C.I.'s 58-year-old chairman, announced that his company would accelerate its drive to close or sell lackluster operations and to cut costs. And I.C.I. took a $901 million charge.
 But analysts criticize I.C.I. for not doing more sooner and for not taking advantage of the strong market for commodity chemicals in 1987 and 1988 by selling or spinning off a great part, if not all, of that business. "At the end of the day, they still have too much of their business in bulk chemicals," said Jeremy Chantry of Kleinwort Benson Securities.

HEADLINE: Madonna and the Master at Cannes

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

DATELINE: CANNES, France 

 BODY:
Madonna and Akira Kurosawa: flesh and the spirit. Also, for that matter, spirit and the flesh. To be a show-business legend in your own time, you can't have one without the other. This was what film aficionados might call the subtext of the first week of the 44th Cannes Film Festival, which ends tomorrow night after 12 days of screenings.
 The presence of Madonna added a lot of redeeming lunacy to this year's festival, which has been mostly serious and often lugubrious. Mr. Kurosawa, his productivity undiminished at 81, has been the festival's implacable conscience. Their work was cut out for them. The uncertainty of current business conditions and of the further economic integration of the European Community, scheduled for 1992, somewhat dampened the enthusiasm, if not the hyperbole, of the hundreds of movie traders who came to Cannes this year. 
 Their object: to attend the main competition, subsidiary shows and the Film Market, and to buy and sell the rights to what the trade calls "product," even though many of these haven't yet been made. This year, the still-to-be-produced category includes two big-budget productions, celebrating the 500th anniversary of Columbus's first voyage to the New World. They may or may not be what the New World needs now. 
 This festival definitely needed both the ephemeral razzle-dazzle created by Madonna and her entourage and the prestige conferred on it by the great Kurosawa.
 Like "Rhapsody in August," the Japanese master's new work, "Madonna: Truth or Dare," Alek Keshishian's authorized documentary, now playing in New York, was shown in the main part of the festival but out of competition. It was also the week's second toughest ticket to obtain, the toughest being a ticket to the party celebrating the film's showing. Priorities tend to get confused when Madonna is around. She's not yet a cinema icon; she's a vibrant new public personality who creates the kind of excitement that helps movie makers survive.
 Another sort of necessity entirely is Mr. Kurosawa, who directed his first film in 1942 and appears to be in the midst of a vigorous Golden Age. It's a measure of the true originality of "Rhapsody in August" that it has not been a major festival hit. It doesn't cater to an audience's preconceptions of the new. It's not self-consciously inventive in the way of the films of Werner Schroeter, Lars Von Trier and the other avant-garde directors who come to Cannes.
 Instead, it is distilled, utterly direct, abrasive. It reflects the manner of a man who is no longer interested in superficial effects, only in expressing what is on his mind as efficiently as possible. The film is a message from a director who was born four years before the guns of August were fired in 1914. It is a report from that generation of directors who are supposed to be dead or at least retired and modestly grateful for honorary awards.
 Like "Akira Kurosawa's Dreams," shown out of competition at last year's Cannes festival, "Rhapsody in August" is visually splendid. Unlike "Dreams," though, it is almost willfully austere. It suggests something of the rigor of Roberto Rossellini's late films, though the two men otherwise don't have much in common. It is also a movie that could prompt righteous outrage in some quarters of the United States. At one point or another, there is something in it to offend everybody, including me. Mr. Kurosawa doesn't make it easy to accept man's higher nature, at least in part because the movie doesn't work in the way he seems to have intended.
 "Rhapsody in August," adapted by the director from a Japanese novel, "Nabe-No-Naka," by Kiyoko Murata, is about the dropping of America's second atom bomb, on Aug. 9, 1945, on the city of Nagasaki. Unlike Shohei Imamura's "Black Rain" (1989), in which the effects of the Hiroshima bomb are explicity detailed, "Rhapsody in August" avoids any attempt to recreate the spectacle of atomic holocaust.
 The time is now, and the setting is an idyllic farm on the far side of the mountains outside Nagasaki. Four teen-age children have been parked for the summer with their grandmother, widowed long ago in the Nagasaki raid, while their parents go off to Hawaii to visit the grandmother's dying brother, who became rich in Hawaii as a pineapple planter.
 The Hawaiian household includes the half-American children of the grandmother's dead sister. Kane, the grandmother, now mentally confused in her old age, had 10 brothers and sisters and has trouble keeping them straight, as does the audience, though that's not important.
 When Kane and the children are invited to join the others in Hawaii, she refuses. She doesn't hate all Americans, she says, but she doesn't especially cherish them. Little by little, she begins to tell the children stories about the bombing. Some are grimly factual; some sound like myth. 
 She had a younger brother who, though not caught directly in the raid, lost all his hair from the effects of radiation. He was so embarrassed that he spent the rest of his life in his room in the farmhouse. He was a painter, but his sole subject was a large eye, which Kane describes as "the eye of the flash" they saw on the far side of the mountain on the morning of the raid.
 At a key moment, Mr. Kurosawa shows the audience that eye. It is large and red and fills the sky. The effect is both shocking and magical. It's not an evil eye; neither is it good. It is a presence that hovers over their lives. The youngest grandson later sees the eye in a snake he finds in the mountain pool where Kane's bald brother used to swim at night.
 Kane remembers when a skinny-legged, dwarfish creature showed up at the farmhouse, having fished her nearly drowned brother out of the mountain pool. "A kappa," she says, as if describing a village policeman, "a water spirit." According to Kane, kappas do that occasionally.
 "Rhapsody in August" vividly recalls the atomic holocaust, but entirely by indirection. Though Mr. Kurosawa says he intended that the movie should be about the awakening of the children to the bomb's meaning, the children are less important to the movie than the indirectly evoked bombing itself and the vision of the apocalypse.
 The children, who range in age from late to early teens, remain largely uncharacterized. At first they miss television and the other pleasures they left at home in Tokyo. They are generic children, differentiated only by age, sex and the M.I.T. and U.S.C. T-shirts they wear.
 Somewhat too quickly and obligingly, they begin to explore Nagasaki on their own, looking for evidence of the Aug. 9 raid. It's as if Mr. Kurosawa didn't have time to waste in creating especially compelling children.
 Yet this doesn't interfere with Mr. Kurosawa's extraordinarily heartfelt recollection of the war and what it meant to the generations that survived it. Where the film gets tricky, and even ticklish, is when Richard Gere shows up as Kane's half-American nephew from Hawaii, who has come to pay his respects to his Japanese cousins and to apologize for the war.
 Mr. Gere gives a good, self-effacing performance in a role that's a little unreal. He speaks his own Japanese dialogue easily and is at the center of one of Mr. Kurosawa's most breathtaking moments. 
 During a ceremony honoring the bomb victims, the camera shifts away from the shrine to show a line of ants making a purposeful ant-line toward a rosebush. The ants climb the bushy stalk, single file, to arrive at the magnificent blood-red bloom.
 This may suggest that the ants, like the bomb's victims, have found their peace. However, it is far more effective if left uninterpreted. The film is full of such moments that might have pleased Luis Bunuel.
 When the movie's politics were questioned at a post-screening news conference, Mr. Kurosawa denied any intention to sidestep Japanese responsibility for the war. "We Japanese," he said, "were also the victims of Japanese militarism." The subject of the film, he insisted, is not guilt and responsibility but the horrors of war, in particular of the bomb, which has made possible the absolute end of everything. 
 It is, indeed, a subject about which he has been ruminating for years, most memorably in the 1955 "I Live in Fear," about a man obsessed by atomic destruction, and the wildly garish end-of-the-world nightmare sequence in "Dreams" last year.
 Later, at lunch at the Hotel du Cap in Antibes, sitting on a sun-drenched terrace, looking at the Mediterranean, Mr. Kurosawa expressed satisfaction with the film's reception here. The film maker looks a good 10 to 15 years younger than his age and is ready for a new project.
 He noted that his longtime associate, Ishiro Honda (the director of "Godzilla" and other Japanese sci-fi classics), had directed the stunning ant sequence in "Rhapsody in August." Ants, it seems, are more difficult to direct than dogs, cats and children. Mr. Kurosawa doesn't have the patience for it.
 Nor did he have patience for several grimly insistent autograph hunters who suddenly turned up on the closely guarded hotel terrace. He signed the first sheet of a paper shoved in front of him, then erupted in the formidable style of the man who is called "sensei" ("master") on the set. It was a ferocious but short outburst, after which the appetite, the charm and the concentration returned.

HEADLINE: Americas' Game

BYLINE: By Tina Rosenberg; Tina Rosenberg is the author of the forthcoming "Children of Cain," a study of violence in Latin America.

 BODY:

SUGARBALL
The American Game,
the Dominican Dream.
By Alan M. Klein.
Illustrated. 179 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $19.95. 
 
BEISBOL
Latin Americans and the Grand Old Game.
By Michael M. Oleksak and Mary Adams Oleksak.
303 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.:
Masters Press. $22.95.  
 Immediately after the Nicaraguan revolution in 1979 the Sandinistas changed the name of Managua's baseball stadium. The Estadio Anastasio Somoza Garcia, so titled in honor of the father of the Somoza dynasty, became the Estadio Rigoberto Lopez Perez, for the poet who shot him. For the 11 years of the Sandinista Government, the Estadio was home to revolutionary baseball. Some of the teams were named for Sandinista martyrs or revolutionary battles; on opening day politicians gave impassioned anti-Yanqui speeches. After the Sandinistas lost the elections of 1990, the stadium was renamed the Estadio Nacional; the new Government, it seemed, was eager for reconciliation.
If baseball in the United States has come to be not just a sport but a repository of cultural myths, this is doubly true of beisbol. It is the national sport of Nicaragua, Cuba, Venezuela, Puerto Rico and especially the Dominican Republic, which has produced more professional players proportionate to its population than any other country, including the United States. Baseball in Latin America began in Cuba, brought there by Cubans educated in the United States, but it was mainly spread by United States diplomats, businessmen and Marines. It is strongest where United States influence has been most prevalent, which helps to explain the coincidence of baseball and revolution.
Alan M. Klein, who teaches sociology and anthropology at Northeastern University, calls Dominican baseball "sugarball"; baseball grew as sugar grew there, and most amateur teams are still sponsored by sugar refineries. "The bonds between American and Dominican baseball came increasingly to resemble other economic and political relations between the two countries," Mr. Klein writes.
Although the author draws from social theorists such as Antonio Gramsci and Frantz Fanon, "Sugarball" is not a mere anti-imperialist critique. Mr. Klein concludes that baseball's effects on the Dominican Republic are ambiguous: a United States export dominates Dominican culture, but Dominicans have made the sport their own. The United States leagues draw the best players out of the Dominican Republic and then often prohibit them from playing winter ball in front of the home fans. But once in the ligas grandes, players such as Pedro Guerrero, George Bell and Manny Mota have become Dominican heroes and perhaps the single most important source of national pride.
There is a vivid and affectionate chapter about going to games at Santo Domingo's Quisqueya Stadium, and a wonderful depiction of the Los Angeles Dodgers' recruiting academy east of Santo Domingo, which in addition to sorting and signing prospects serves as a boot camp. There players who may have never before seen plumbing or gotten beyond fourth grade are taught to deal with discipline, teamwork, fame, wealth, gringo culture and race relations and the English language.
"Beisbol: Latin Americans and the Grand Old Game," the first book by Michael M. Oleksak and Mary Adams Oleksak, contains a brief description of the history of Caribbean ball, but the book centers on the fates of Latin players in the United States, with many statistics and stories. It is an enthusiastic, somewhat naively written guide for United States fans of Latin players.
Perhaps the Oleksaks' most intriguing anecdote is that during World War II Joe Cambria, a scout for the Washington Senators, twice rejected a certain Cuban pitching prospect named Fidel Castro. His arm was not major league, Cambria concluded. One can only speculate on the implications of the future President of Cuba playing for the Washington Senators, and not just the effect it would have had on Cuba; a great comic novel begs to be written in which Fidel lets loose his curveball on the American League.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: 'Does Your Flesh Wobble and Seem Dimpled?'

BYLINE: By Margo Jefferson; Margo Jefferson teaches English and writing at Columbia University and writes criticism for various magazines.

 BODY:

THE BEAUTY MYTH
How Images of Beauty Are Used Against Women.
By Naomi Wolf.
348 pp. New York:
William Morrow & Company. $21.95. 
 I am gazing at a glossy, full-color, seven-page advertisement for a new line of cosmetics produced by Ultima II, a division of Revlon sold mostly in department stores. They are called the Nakeds II. The Nakeds offer "HUNDREDS OF SHADES IN EVERY NUANCE OF NEUTRAL . . . FOR WHENEVER A WOMAN WANTS THE LOOK OF LESS FOR SATURDAY" (she's likely to be around trees, bushes and other naturalistic props), "THE LOOK OF MORE FOR WORK" (more money, more competence, hence more facial armature), "OR FOR EVENING, THE LOOK OF WOW!" ("Apply 2 coats of black mascara. Brush the blush in 'Bashful' on apples of cheeks. . . . Line lips with lipliner in 'Smooch.' ").
It's utterly ridiculous -- still, I can't help liking the packaging, those cream-colored makeup containers with black piping that so resemble ladies' hatboxes in the photograph on the three-page foldout. But that's my weakness, and it's there to be played on. How could it be otherwise, Naomi Wolf asks in "The Beauty Myth," a sweeping, messy, vigorous, callow but stouthearted book dedicated to the proposition that the icon of the educated, middle-class woman as wife, mother and tasteful sexual appliance has been replaced by the icon of the educated, middle-class, wage-earning woman as a flaw-free specimen of physical perfection. The operative principle here is that no society ever rights a wrong without finding a new one to put in its place: ours, having yielded ground on matters of social, political, economic and sexual freedom for women, dug in its heels when faced with the more psychologically nuanced issues of female beauty, desirability and self-esteem.
Ms. Wolf, a graduate of Yale who is now a Rhodes scholar at New College, Oxford, believes that from the Cult of Domesticity to the Feminine Mystique to the Beauty Myth and its backlash -- that is, over the past 35 years -- "inexhaustible but ephemeral beauty work took over from inexhaustible but ephemeral housework. As the economy, law, religion, sexual mores, education, and culture were forcibly opened up to include women more fairly, a private reality colonized female consciousness. By using ideas about 'beauty,' it reconstructed an alternative female world with its own laws, economy, religion, sexuality, education, and culture, each element as repressive as any that had gone before."
Ms. Wolf maps out this "alternative female world" by recording just about every form of obsession and exploitation a $20 billion-a-year cosmetics industry, a $33 billion diet industry, a $300 million cosmetic-surgery industry and a $7 billion pornography industry can nurture and supply.
There's the language of upwardly mobile beauty and fitness, austere one moment, sweetly lascivious the next: packed with technological intimidation (makeup containing mock-scientific ingredients such as "reticulin and mucopolysaccharides") and with born-again bullying ("Take the shades from your eyes and face the truth of the situation," says one ad. "Does your flesh wobble and seem dimpled?"). There are the women who take cosmetic surgery to she-devil lengths of pain and desperation, and the many more who empty their pocketbooks daily to look like any and everyone but themselves. There is anorexia and there is bulimia: anorexia alone is said to kill 150,000 American women each year; together with bulimia it afflicts one million a year.
Is this new information? No (as Ms. Wolf's plentiful footnotes verify), but it is information we keep refusing to process, and we must be reminded of it until we begin to do so. As a feminist muckraker and media critic, Naomi Wolf does her work well. But as a feminist cultural historian, she has two big problems. The first is the intellectual equivalent of beauty follies. She overdoes glittery, special-effect metaphors -- beauty as the cult millenarianism; beauty as the Iron Maiden, a body-shaped casket painted with the limbs and face of a young woman that served as a medieval instrument of torture. She is also addicted to cosmetic touch-ups of her thesis in the form of brief quotations and one-liners from critics, scholars and poets through the ages.
I'll put the second problem in question form: Why does every generation frame its recognition of lies and injustice in the claim that no previous generation has ever suffered them so acutely? I believe Ms. Wolf when she writes that "today's children and young men and women have sexual identities that spiral around paper and celluloid phantoms: from Playboy to music videos to the blank female torsos in women's magazines, features obscured and eyes extinguished, they are being imprinted with a sexuality that is mass-produced, deliberately dehumanizing and inhuman."
But I don't believe this is taking place "for the first time in history": it's taking place at this moment in history through the particular methods that media and technology provide. After all, the conventions, excesses and grotesqueries of the beauty industry were securely in place by the 1920's, from the pseudoscientific jargon and faux intime exhortations to the carelessly regulated health and safety standards to the ties that bind advertisers to women's magazines.
As for beauty standards -- from body shape to feature size -- they were a lot more restrictive and bigoted just 25 years ago than they are now, and while Ms. Wolf is right to say that the muscled and worked body in fashion today has its alien and bionic side, the 1950's exaggeration of "natural" female flesh and curves was just as artificial and (if you lacked them) debilitating. One body canonized pseudowomanliness; the other appropriates pseudomanliness.
Beauty is such a strange thing -- it's a fantasy, a pastime and a profession (like sports), and we bring a daunting range of emotions and associations to it. I like the fact that Ms. Wolf ends her book by saying we need more, not less of it. "The beauty myth is harmful and pompous and grave because so much, too much, depends upon it," she writes: we should treat it (and we do, sometimes) like theater and play.
"The Beauty Myth" shows us yet again how much we need new ways of seeing. I regret that it also shows how much we need new ways of writing -- polemics and manifestoes that will make room amidst their facts and theories for the contradictory particulars of each reader's life.
