HEADLINE: Brazil's Forests in the Balance

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE ;JAMES BROOKE is chief of the Rio de Janeiro bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
WITH "green tourism" expected to triple in the Amazon basin in the 1990's, environmentalists in the region's largest city are weighing its impact on the fate of the forest.
Aided by reports of farmers burning the rain forest, the world's discovery of this isolated region is well-established. Visitors, largely Americans and Europeans, come to the Amazon to fish for piranhas, study monkeys in treetops and fall asleep at night listening to choruses of jungle birds. 
 Manaus, a humid, riverfront city that stagnated after the collapse of the rubber boom in the early 1900's, now ranks after Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo as the Brazilian city with the most international air links. On May 27, Varig, Brazil's international airline, will inaugurate a weekly flight connecting Manaus to Los Angeles and San Francisco. Already, flights link Manaus to Miami and nine Latin American nations.
Brazil's national tourism authority, Embratur, based in Brasilia, is making nature tourism its priority this year, and Manaus hoteliers plan to double the number of five-star hotel rooms to 3,000 by 1999. The number of foreign tourists coming to Manaus had been growing steadily from 12,000 in 1983 to 59,000 in 1989, before dropping last year to 39,357 -- a decline that has been largely attributed to the country's economic disarray. The economy is expected to have little impact on Manaus' tourism industry this year. The number of cruise ships stopping at Manaus has also increased -- in the winter of 1982-83, one ship called here; 21 called in 1988-89. On the surface, the impact of tourism on the sea of rain forest that laps at the edges of this state capital of one million people is minimal. Almost entirely forested, Amazonas state sprawls over an area three times the size of France.
"Green tourism is a good thing, but not something you can count on for protecting a lot of forest," said Philip M. Fearnside, an American ecologist who studies deforestation here at the National Institute for Research in the Amazon. "Tourists find walking around a few acres to be enough. That doesn't provide economic justification for preserving hundreds of square miles of forest."
For reasons that have little to do with tourism, satellite surveys show that only 5,334 square miles of forest were burned in 1990 -- the lowest level in recent years. In 1989, 7,273 square miles were burned. Seeking explanations, analysts cite Brazil's economic slowdown, an increase in rainfall, making it more difficult to clear the forest and to burn trees, and a new Brazilian Government policy that discourages burning.
However, many people versed in the Realpolitik of environmentalism say green tourism does help conservation.
Forming the embryo of a powerful lobby, the number of Manaus travel agencies catering to tourists quadrupled in the last five years to 67. By 1999, tourism is expected to become the state's largest source of international exchange.
"If we have a large contingent of people visiting the Amazon, ideas will change," said Silvio Magalhaes Barros, president of Emamtur, the state tourism authority.
Aware of the growing tourism lobby, Gilberto Mestrinho, the new governor of Amazonas state, has moved away from the confrontational stands that the five other state governors in Brazil's Amazon region often take on environmental issues. A 35-year veteran of political life in Amazonas state, which makes up 44 percent of Brazil's Amazon region, Mr. Mestrinho has displayed a fine nose for future trends.
According to a recent study by the Organization of American States, the number of foreigners participating in nature tours in the Amazon basin, which includes parts of Brazil, Peru, Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Bolivia, Suriname and Guiana, is expected to increase from 123,000 in 1988 to at least 375,000 by 1999. In a poll of 436 international travelers at Latin American airports, the World Wildlife Fund found that 47 percent cited nature destinations as an important factor in vacation planning.
Although tourism is a labor-intensive industry, some critics predict that its benefits will bypass the Amazonians, either the Indians or the caboclos -- peasants who fish and farm along the region's riverbanks.
"ALL the profits go out of the area, and the local communities are left by the wayside," said Diana Propper de Callejon, Brazil's representative to Cultural Survival, an international organization dedicated to defending indigenous groups. "Local groups should be given investment shares in tour companies."
In one effort, a Manaus environmental group plans to train caboclos to work as park guards and ecological guides in the Jau National Park, a vast wilderness area 150 miles upriver from here.
"The idea is that the caboclos will depend on the conservation of the park, which is the largest in Brazil," said Leonardo Lacerda, a planner with the group, the Fundacao Vitoria Amazonica .
Mark J. Baker, owner of Ecotour Expeditions of Cambridge, Mass., said that the tours not only provide employment, but also "provide justification for the newly emerged park system in Brazil."
"Brazilian parks have often been paper parks," Mr. Baker said, referring to parks that appear on maps, but do not have guards, guides or trails.
Another fear is that uncontrolled green tourism will result in the overcrowding and degrading of the same wilderness areas that attracted visitors in the first place. One site, the Janauary Lake, across the Rio Negro from Manaus, is often cluttered with boats visiting giant water lily pads.
"Carrying capacity is the key word," said Silvana Campello, a Brazilian biologist who administers programs in Brazil for the United States' Nature Conservancy. "Ecotourism is not the destination, but what you do when you get there."
But caveats notwithstanding, most environmentalists said that tourism improves the prospects for survival of the forest. They predict that tourists -- foreign and Brazilian -- will create an informed international constituency for its defense.
"It is easy to sit in an air-conditioned room and say, 'We need to save the trees,"' Eugene Aull, a tourist from New York, said as he relaxed from a river trip. "There is incredible poverty down here. You have to give them something in return."
Peter N. Lahanas, a University of Miami biologist who served as tour guide, added: "These people are more informed, they will have a real image when they get back. The next time someone knocks on their door asking for money for the rain forest, they will give. "
 
HEADING DOWN THE RIO NEGRO
 
A River Journey
 Every Tuesday, the Tuna, a flat-bottomed 85-footriver boat, departs from the quay at Manaus's Hotel Tropical and heads up the Rio Negro for an exploration of the Anavilhas Archipelago, the largest river archipelago in the world. Taking side trips in powered canoes or on foot down forest trails, travelers see immense lily pads, wild orchids, jungle birds, alligators, jute plantations and stands of wild rubber trees. During the day, they can swim in the river or trawl for such Amazon fish as tucunare.
The Tuna has 10 cabins, each with private bath. Prices, including meals, are $549 a person for a three-day cruise, and $989 for a six-day cruise. Reservations can be made through Brazil Nuts (800) 553-9959.
 
Getting There
Lloyd Aereo Boliviano, (305) 374-4600, and Varig Airlines, (800) 468-2744, fly to Manaus from Miami for $930 round trip. Starting May 27, Varig will fly to Manaus from San Francisco and Los Angeles, for $1,958 roundtrip. -- J. B.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Corporate Relocations;
Heads or Torsos Remain While the Limbs Move On

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
MET LIFE had good and bad news for Manhattan last month. First the good news: Its headquarters would stay on Madison Square. Then the bad news: Some 4,000 jobs would not.
This split decision by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company illustrates a new complexity in corporate geography. 
 There seems to be less in the way of lock-stock-and-barrel relocation and more of the divided operation, in which a headquarters is maintained in New York City but many central-office functions -- not just the back offices -- go elsewhere.
"It's a quiet exodus," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "These are companies that never say, 'We're leaving town.' They're still here. But it's the hollowing out of their labor force. What remains is the head of the company. Many parts of the body -- the legs, arms and other key appurtenances -- are shifted somewhere else."
The chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Rosemary Scanlon, said: "In the late 1980's, there was an enormous national trend to hollow out corporations, so New York may not be all that exceptional. When I look at the whole corporate headquarters phenomenon of the 1980's, we had very few move-outs."
But the maintenance of a headquarters in New York, while significant, may mask a general trend to shift employees out of town.
"The scope of operations that a company finds necessary to keep in proximity to headquarters, that grouping has narrowed," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "And the grouping that companies are willing to forego having in the immediate vicinity has broadened."
The broadening has occurred as a result of advances in computers and telecommunications. "That has made it possible to divorce many activities that have to do with record-keeping and transaction-handling from the location of the headquarters and still maintain control," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
"That has made activities of the headquarters footloose," he said. "They are no longer anchored in New York. They can be spun off and located in whatever area has a competitive advantage. That's a major concern for the future because New York has traditionally been the nation's premier clerical capital. This means that many of the 600,000 clerical jobs in New York are at risk."
BY early summer, Gamco Investors expects to move most of its operations and some 90 employees from 655 Third Avenue, at 42d Street, to the International Corporate Center at Rye, 555 Theodore Fremd Avenue, near the border with Harrison, N.Y. The center is being developed by the Gateside Corporation of Rye, headed by Norman Feinberg.
It may be that a few employees, particularly research analysts, will remain in Manhattan. "We are in the financial-services business and New York City is still the international financial center," said Doug Jamieson, executive vice president of Gamco, a subsidiary of Gabelli Funds. "That's why I'd say we're anticipating having some presence in New York City. But for the most part, we'll be relocating to the Corporate Center."
Perhaps the clearest example of a footloose -- and hollowed out -- operation is the ITT Corporation, which once had 4,000 employees in its headquarters at 320 Park Avenue, between 50th and 51st Streets. It is now a smaller company, and since it left Park Avenue last fall, has maintained two "World Headquarters," each designated as such.
Some 250 employees work in the ITT Building, 1330 Avenue of the Americas, at 54th Street. This is the former ABC Building, now owned by the Shuwa Corporation. And 150 employees work at 100 Plaza Drive in Secaucus, N.J., part of the Harmon Meadow Corporate Park, developed by Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus.
"The dual headquarters is operating quite effectively," said James P. Gallagher, vice president and director of public relations. "Everybody is over their initial trepidation. Employees who have gone over to New Jersey have settled in and are quite pleasantly surprised by how much they like it."
"Employees who went over to Secaucus are no less important than employees at the Manhattan office," he added. "It's just that their jobs are such that they are not required to be in Manhattan on a daily basis. We save a bit of money because the space is less expensive over there."
A shuttle bus runs between the buildings several times a day, Mr. Gallagher said, noting that "we obviously give the fax machines quite a workout." Several senior executives, including the chairman, Rand V. Araskog, keep offices at both locations.
"I'd be hard pressed to come up with the percentage of business they do in one place or the other," Mr. Gallagher said. "But it's gotten to the point where, if you want to see or talk with Mr. Araskog, you first ask, 'Where is he?' "
Mr. Gallagher said that no serious thought had ever been given to quitting Manhattan entirely and that he was not quite sure" that Fax technology could "ever replace the effect of a face-to-face meeting and a handshake across the table."
This month, the Home Insurance Company said it would move 150 employees in its claims division to the new Exchange Place Centre, at 10 Exchange Place, in Jersey City, which has been developed by the Prudential Property Company of Newark. Home's headquarters, with 1,200 employees, will remain in lower Manhattan, at Maiden Lane and William Street.
Nearly 1,500 jobs at Metropolitan Life are bound for New Jersey -- Bridgewater, Paramus and East Hanover -- as the result of the impending renovation of the insurance company's 59-year-old North Building, on Madison Avenue, between 24th and 25th Streets. Another 1,500 of the 4,000 employees who work in that 29-story building will be relocated elsewhere around the country. The other 1,000 jobs will be eliminated. Five thousand Met Life jobs will remain in New York City, in the landmark tower across the street from the North Building and in the adjacent South Building, at Madison Avenue and 23d Street.
THE company is not only renovating the North Building, at a cost of up to $150 million, but also its Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town housing developments, between First Avenue and Avenue C, 14th and 23d Streets. "From a real-estate point of view, Met Life is putting a lot of money into its New York properties," said Charles Sahner, manager of public relations.
Commonly, a headquarters core remains in Manhattan while other operations move to less expensive space elsewhere.
In something of a twist on that, the corporate core of Macmillan Inc., a subsidiary of Maxwell Communication Corporation, is moving to Greenwich, Conn.
Meanwhile, the bulk of the staff in the giant publishing company will remain in the Maxwell Macmillan Building, 866 Third Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets.
"The operations that we have in New York at this point in time we have no intention to move out," said David H. Shaffer, president of the Maxwell Macmillan Group. "They are editorial or they have a heavy orientation around advertising -- people who need to be in New York for the most part."
About 90 people will eventually move to the new quarters at 55 Railroad Avenue, a 129,000-square-foot building owned by Pontiac Associates of Greenwich.
Mr. Shaffer said the relocation would involve the "traditional corporate functions": executive, personnel, legal, accounting, tax, technology, treasury. "It was convenient that they be in Manhattan but not vital," he said.
There is another relocation twist to this story. The space that Macmillan is taking on Railroad Avenue was vacated by Amax Inc., the metals and energy company.
And where did Amax headquarters go from Greenwich? To the Pan Am Building, astride Park Avenue.

HEADLINE: A New Program Tries To Catch Welfare Fraud

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE County Social Services Department is receiving statewide attention for a program to prevent welfare fraud
The program, called the Front End Detection System, has tightened the review process for welfare applicants by training workers to spot suspicious responses that could signal potential abuse. 
 In the seven months since the program began, 1,887 applications for public assistancehave been more closely scrutinized, and 908, or 48 percent, have been denied or terminated.
County taxpayers have saved $1.6 million because of the new program, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said at a news conference last week.
 
$5 Million in Savings
 The program is expected to save Westchester taxpayers $5 million this year, Mr. O'Rourke said, adding that state and Federal taxpayers would save an additional $7 million in their shares of public-assistance payments.
Mary E. Glass, the county's Commissioner of Social Services, who developed the concept, has been invited to present her ideas before the New York Welfare Fraud Investigators Association and the New York Public Welfare Association. State Senator Mary Goodhue has recommended the program to the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., as a budget-cutting measure.
The new system "is not an attempt to deny welfare to anyone who needs it," Mr. O'Rourke said. "But in an economic crunch, it is only fair to look at the way we use taxpayers' money." Westchester residents, he said, "cannot afford to underwrite people who want to use the welfare rolls and who don't deserve to be there."
The county received 29,532 requests for public assistance last year, and many were given special scrutiny, social-service administrators said last week. They were reluctant to disclose details of the new detection system for fear the information would be used for fraud.
 
Existing Patterns of Fraud
 But Nancy Shull, the department's director of field operations, said "red flags" were identified by studying existing patterns of welfare fraud by clients already in the system, and then applying the information to new applicants with the help of computers and old-fashioned investigative techniques.
"We looked at the tape match, using our computers to compare which people on assistance also had taxes being withheld by an employer," Ms. Shull said, referring to information the department receives from the state. In cases in which an applicant reported living at a particular address, Ms. Shull said, department workers were dispatched to check the facts by knocking on the door. In one instance, Ms. Shull said, a family reporting they were homeless were found to have a house in Connecticut.
The fraud-detection system is the newest phase of a larger reform effort in the county to reduce welfare dependence and to take an innovative look at the way it is administered. The change was prompted, in part, by the 1988 Family Support Act, which required that job and educational programs be part of welfare services.
 
Studying for Their Degrees
 In Westchester, the Moms on the Move program has tested 800 women receiving county support and found 46 percent ready for a college-level program, Ms. Glass said. Five hundred are now enrolled in special education and training programs, including 300 studying for their degrees at Westchester Community College in Valhalla.
The Pride in Work program has identified able-bodied welfare recipients who can work for their checks. Ms. Glass said that last year 2,370 individuals contributed 518,000 hours working for towns and community organizations in the county.
She called the new fraud-detection program an important addition to the welfare-reform effort in the county. "Fraud detracts from the integrity of the product," she said, "and makes people who must pay for this crazy."
A properly run welfare program "should help people who need help and do it very, very well," she added. "People should not look at our welfare budget and be suspicious."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
A WALK IN PARK HILL
 Park Hill, one of the country's earliest planned residential communities, dating from 1888, will hold its second House and Walking Tour today from 11:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Last year for the first time, the historic Yonkers neighborhood overlooking the Hudson River was opened to the public for tours, led by a local architect.
Once again Stephen F. Byrns, a Manhattan architect, will conduct one-hour exterior walking tours at noon, 2 and 4 P.M., discussing the wide variety of architectural styles, the history and development of the enclave and the geological and other natural features of the area.
 Because of winding, hilly, tree-lined streets and its nearness to Manhattan only 20 minutes away, Park Hill has attracted many artists, writers, architects and musicians of many races and economic levels. Altogether, the neighborhood, about three-fourths of a square mile, has 1,400 households, about 300 of them in co-ops, the rest in single-family homes.
 "Although the lots average only an eighth of an acre, there is a great deal of privacy," Mr. Byrns said, "because of the mature plantings and the changes of level in the terrain."
 Four houses will be featured: an 1898 Colonial Revival mansion with a domed and polychromed dining room ceiling; a 1901 Shingle-style house with a huge fireplace; a 1921 Colonial Revival home with a copper-shingled roof; and another Shingle-style residence built in 1910 with a densely beamed ceiling. All the homes are furnished appropriately to their periods and styles, and all the stained glass, decorative woodwork, balconies, staircases and other integral features have been scrupulously maintained.
 Visitors may inspect the interiors, unguided, all day. The houses will be staffed with volunteers, and the street where tickets will be sold at the intersection of Hillside Drive and Park Hill Avenue will be closed to traffic. From the Cross County Parkway West take Exit 1, or from the Saw Mill River Parkway South take Exit 4A, Rumsey Road. From either highway, continue south on Rumsey Road to a fork; bear right to the stop sign and Park Hill Avenue. Admission is $12.
 
ENDING WITH THE BLUES
 Today's headliners in the last of the Sunday Jazz Series at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls will be Della Griffin and Her All-Stars. Ms. Griffin specializes in blues, and she also plays the drums. Joining her in the 7 P.M. performance will be Gynne Michaels, a vocalist; Mac Goldsberry, a saxophonist; Dave Braham, an organist, and Randy Johnston on guitar.
 The Schoolhouse is on Owens Road, and tickets are $20. Discounts are available for students, the elderly and groups. Call 277-8477 for reservations or more information.
 
CRAB COURTSHIPS
 Making love at midnight, by flashlight, while being observed by a group of interested bystanders is the lot of horseshoe crabs who attract nature mavens. Beginning just after midnight Saturday, Alison Beall, curator of the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye, will lead a very quiet group to the courtship site on the sandy shores of Long Island Sound, where the mating and egg-laying ritual will take place. Participants will meet at the Conservancy on Route 1, just south of the Rye Golf Club. They should take flashlights and insect repellant, and wear clothing appropriate to the weather. It could take a while before the vigil produces results. Call 835-4466 for more information.
 
DEALING WITH NAZI PAST
 "Germany Today: How Has it Dealt With Ethical Dilemmas Presented by Nazism?" is the subject of a lecture at 8 P.M. Wednesday by Dr. Marion A. Kaplan, professor of history at Queens College in New York City.
The program is the last in a series offered by the Rockland Center for Holocaust Studies on the theme of resistance to resurgent Nazism. It will take place at the Center, at 17 South Madison Avenue in Spring Valley in Rockland County.
Dr. Kaplan, a graduate of the City University of New York, has devoted many years to research on German-speaking Jewry, and she has written several books on the historical roles of European Jewish women. Her talk is free. Call 356-2700 for more information.
 
ART OF HAPPIER WORLD
 "Visions for a Better World" is an art exhibition by children from kindergarten through eighth grade attending schools throughout northern Westchester. Eighty drawings, paintings, collages, posters, photographs, prints and mixed-media works will be on display today through June 21 at the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts.
 The purpose was to elicit the children's ideas and attitudes about a better world, one in which people of all races, religions and colors live together in harmony. They were encouraged to express their thoughts on preserving the environment, providing food and shelter for everyone and dealing with the technological challenges of the future.
 A reception will be held today from 3 to 5 P.M. at the center, on Old Bedford Road in Golden"s Bridge. Viewing hours are Mondays through Fridays from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M., Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. The phone number for more information is 232-5740.
 
NEWBORNS ON THE FARM
 Springtime at Muscoot Farm, when new baby animals and birds are in profusion, is a treat for young children. At 2 P.M. today the staff will conduct a program in which children will see newborn baby calves, lambs, piglets and newly hatched chicks. There will be demonstrations of feeding and care, children can see the chick hatchery and they will be able to feed corn kernels to the older ducks and geese.
 The farm is run by the County Parks Department on Route 100 in Somers. There is a picnic area, and admission and parking are free. To reach the site take I-684 to Exit 6, go west on Route 35 to Route 100 and turn left. Proceed one-and-a-half miles to the entrance.
 
FOLK MEETS METAL
 The four members of Boiled in Lead perform an intense brand of rock on a variety of instruments, applying their unusual style to traditional folk tunes, to original material and to samplings of Serbian, Armenian, Swedish and Thai music picked up on their travels.
 They will give a concert on Friday at 9:30 P.M. in the Towne Crier Cafe at 62 Route 22 in Pawling. Admission is $12.50. Call 855-1300 for more information.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Bucknell;
Protest on Dorm Plan Splits Fraternity Groups

DATELINE: LEWISBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
Bucknell University is sending letters to more than 5,000 alumni to counter what university administrators say are attempts by 10 fraternities and sororities to hamper fund raising.
The national fraternities have sent letters urging alumni not to contribute to the university. 
 The president of the university, Gary A. Sojka, estimated that the protest could cost Bucknell up to $100,000 in lost contributions. The fraternity chapters here are trying to distance themselves from the protest, chapter leaders said.
The national organizations say they acted after Bucknell, in May, moved the rush period from the freshman year to the start of sophomore year.
 
 'Something Special' About Year
 "It is widely recognized that there is something special about the freshman year," Mr. Sojka wrote, "and that it is not unusual or inappropriate to ask students to become oriented to the institution before becoming too heavily involved in too many activities that are intense, emotionally exhausting and time consuming."
The national groups contend that the move was based on an assumption that the fraternity system is inherently bad and that students have to be protected from it until the sophomore year. Students, the groups pointed out, can join all other organizations at Bucknell in their freshman year.
"Any time our organizations are denied access to members for an entire year, we are concerned," said Margaret Watkins, national executive director of Delta Gamma sorority in Columbus, Ohio. "It is discriminatory to students to say, 'You can join other groups, but you cannot have access to the Greek system.' "
The director of programs for Phi Gamma Delta, Thomas DesJardin, said the move limited rights of association. "Our issue is not specifically with Bucknell," he said. "We can't let that first domino fall and be fighting it on 100 campuses instead of one."
Bucknell is trying to create alternative living arrangements. A plan formulated by a committee including national and local fraternity representatives was presented to the trustees on May 4. The board has not voted on it.
 
To Widen Membership
 The plan would include the fraternities in the dormitory system by requiring resident assistants to be in all houses and a resident manager to oversee the assistants. The plan also urges the chapters to sponsor activities other than parties, and it calls for chapters to coordinate admissions so that every student applying for membership is admitted somewhere.
In their letters to alumni, the national organizations said that the recommendations indicated a lack of support for the fraternity experience. "Instead of working closely with the nationals and the students on campus," Ms. Watkins said, "they took the other tack."
Mr. Sojka rejects allegations about a hidden agenda to abolish the system. "The board last year affirmed the value of the Greek system," he said in an interview last week, "and it is very clear the system is not in jeopardy here."
Mr. Sojka called the national groups' response to a perceived threat "an 11th-hour coordinated attack" that left him "with the anger of someone who feels betrayed, abused and personally insulted."
 
'Their Chapters Are Guests'
 "It's upsetting when people who are far from our campus actively interfere with our efforts," he said. "They may have forgotten that their chapters are guests on this campus."
Ms. Watkins said, "It was not an unusual occurrence" for the national office to contact alumni. But she added: "We do not ask our alumni to withhold financial support. It doesn't make any sense for us to sabotage the university."
Ms. Watkins's organization sent letters to its alumni advising them to let administrators "know your continued support for Bucknell depends on their satisfactory support of this situation."
The president of the Interfraternity Council, Denis Maguire, a sophomore economics major from Bath, Me., said administrators did not intend to shut the system. "They've made that clear several times," he said.
David Skena, vice president of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon chapter and co-chairman of the implementation committee, said, "The whole idea of a hidden agenda is a baseless construct by the nationals to play on the worst fears of Greek alumni."
Mr. Skena, a junior economics and political science major from Murrysville, added, "At the time the nationals should be most ready and anxious to help us, they are denying the reality we've already accepted."

HEADLINE: Bottom-Fishing in the Gas Patch

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
If natural gas ever had a chance to move closer to center stage in supplying the nation's energy needs, the time is now. The war in the Persian Gulf exposed anew America's vulnerability to imported oil. Five years after Chernobyl, nuclear power is still shunned. And global warming has further darkened the cloud over coal.
Cleaner and cheaper than oil, natural gas has become the favored fuel among manufacturers and power generators -- but only ideologically. Despite reserves in the United States and Canada that could last 50 years or more, gas has taken a back seat to oil, supplying only 23 percent of its fuel needs in 1989. A tangle of regulations has choked demand, produced shortages and kept prices low and most gas producers too small to vie for lucrative long-term industrial contracts. And unless it can overcome its reputation as an unreliable long-term fuel source, the gas industry will blow the nation's best chance for clearer skies, lower fuel bills and fewer geopolitical scares in the future. 
 "In many ways, the natural gas industry has been its own worst enemy," said Kenneth L. Lay, the head of the Enron Corporation and perhaps the country's most outspoken proponent of shifting the economy toward gas.
But his company, the nation's largest company devoted almost exclusively to the gas business, thinks it has found a way to make the most of the industry's hodge-podge of gas patches. To woo big users -- the electric power generators that are the best shot for gas to replace oil -- Enron is building what it calls a "gas bank." Instead of deposits, Enron pools supply commitments from producers for varying lengths -- two years, six years, eight years, say. Enron then stitches these commitments together, pitching some of its own supplies into the pool, to create long-term contracts of 15 years or more for industrial users.
 
'A Portfolio of Supplies'
 "We're conducting an activity like asset-liability management at a bank," said Jeffrey K. Skilling, a former consultant at McKinsey & Company who joined Enron last year to help set up the gas bank. "We have a portfolio of supplies and a portfolio of markets. To the buyer, it's all coming from Enron in the sense that Enron has a corporate guarantee behind the contract."
For Enron, with $13.2 billion in revenues in 1990 and $9.8 billion in assets, the plan is part of a wide-sweeping vision to sells and deliver gas to industrial America and to build and operate the power generators that keep their plants humming. Eventually, it even hopes to sell compressed natural gas to a host of service stations for use in cars, buses and trucks.
If it pulls off these ambitious plans, as many on Wall Street and in the industry are betting, Enron could point the way to the long-forecasted bright future for natural gas and give the country the gift of reduced dependency on foreign crude that has eluded Washington for more than a decade. Enron predicts the gas industry could cut this reliance by at least three million barrels a day of oil by the end of the decade -- a bit more than the country now imports daily from the Persian Gulf.
"Natural gas probably has the greatest potential to displace foreign oil of any alternatives over the next 20 years," said the 49-year-old Mr. Lay. "But we can't realize that growth unless we package our product to meet what the market needs."
Since it formed its gas marketing group two years ago to package these long-term contracts, Enron has signed up about 35 producers and more than 50 customers, including six buyers and two suppliers in the last week, Mr. Skilling said.
 
Premium Prices
 Because gas is much more economical than oil, industrial customers and power generators are willing to pay a premium for a guaranteed extended supply. Some Wall Street analysts say Enron has sold some gas in fixed-price, 10-year contracts at an average price of as high as $3.50 per 1,000 cubic feet. In today's depressed market, gas is selling for $1.30.
As an intermediary, Enron could insure a tidy profit as long as it maintains a comfortable spread between what it pays and what it sells gas for. With limited reserves and resources, many producers are squeezed, living hand to mouth by selling supplies on the open market, where buyers have the upper hand. Eager for the cash advances offered by Enron, some are willing to lock in prices slightly higher than those on the open market for a few year to keep their businesses alive.
Analysts said the gas services unit contributed to Enron's 49.3 percent increase in the first-quarter earnings, excluding transactions not related to operations, to $101.5 million.
Some on Wall Street are so enthusiastic about these and other prospects of the company that they have sharply increased 1990 earnings forecasts. Ronald J. Barone, a managing director at Kidder, Peabody & Company, thinks Enron will earn $3.70 a share this year and $4.35 in 1992, rather than the $2.90 for both years that he had projected last month. Curt Launer, of Donaldson, Lufkin, Jenrette Securities, raised his 1992 estimate to $5.15 a share.
And while market values of most natural gas companies are slumping, Enron's shares have been trading not far below their all-time high of $62.75, set last November. They closed Friday at $58.25.
Still, some producers wonder whether Enron can sign up enough producers to keep its customers in gas. The healthiest producers are unlikely to sign up with Enron because they would rather hold out for higher gas prices than get locked into a long-term commitment at a fixed rate. And if prices do spurt, even some weaker producers may not be so eager to give up potential sales for the security of a predictable cash flow.
 
Harvesting the Needy
 That leaves Enron the hard-luck cases. "Enron is replacing commercial banks, which no longer loan on reserves," said Jeff Sandefer, president of Sandefer Offshore, a small oil and gas producer in Houston with 25 employees. "Some companies are in such trouble they can't borrow enough from Enron to get them out of trouble. Others are more bullish on prices and don't want to give up the up side to do a deal with Enron. That's where we are."
Enron, however, says there are plenty of needy producers for it to draw on. Few of the nation's 2,000-plus producers escaped unscathed when a mild winter and new discoveries of gas fields in Alabama, Oklahoma, New Mexico and the Gulf of Mexico forced prices down 20 percent from a year ago.
What is more, producers are still reeling from the lower prices that followed the Government's decontrol of gas prices in the mid-1980's and a supply glut that has persisted since 1981. The surplus developed when gas prices jumped in tandem with crude oil. When many gas users responded by switching back to coal or fuel oil, a drilling binge sparked by high prices collapsed and pipelines and producers were stuck with massive supplies and few customers. To save the industry from collapse, the Government eventually canceled long-term contracts amounting to more than $8 billion owed by pipelines to producers.
The long-term gas contract became nearly extinct and producers resorted to plying the spot market, where 80 percent of all gas is now sold, under contracts that typically are for 30 days or less, with some as long as five or six months.
But without ironclad guarantees for 15 years or more of supply, lenders have refused to finance the construction of gas-fired power plants for utilities. And even if prices were to rise enough to stimulate drilling, producers might resist making long-term pledges. Unlike the 25-year life cycles of gas fields in Canada and those of 200 years in Indonesia, American gas fields often give out within 10 years, or as few as two in the Gulf of Mexico.
Even so, taken together, reserves of natural gas in North America are far more abundant than crude oil by most accounts. The Energy Department estimates that proven supplies of recoverable gas in the United States would last less than eight years at current consumption rates, or just as long as the nation's known quantities of recoverable oil. And many industry executives and analysts say that new discoveries and technological improvements have increased the supply to 50 years or more.
 Nevertheless, oil continues to provide 40 percent of the country's energy needs. The United States consumed about 6 billion barrels of crude last year, 42 percent of it imported, according to the Energy Department. That compares with about 19 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, with all but 1.5 trillion cubic feet, from Canada, produced domestically.
 
A Connected Champion
 But Mr. Lay, for one, hopes to alter those proportions. And his political influence could help his cause. A former economics professor and head of energy affairs at the Interior Department, the Republican casts a long shadow in Washington and in local politics and counts the President among his acquaintances. He helped orchestrate last year's economic summit in Houston for President Bush. His connections clearly helped get ideas championed by the natural gas industry included in the National Energy Strategy crafted earlier this year by the Administration.
Although industrial customers are generally wary of the gas industry, having been burned badly in the helter-skelter of deregulation, Enron has moved to blunt some of their worries. Enron removes producers from the picture by guaranteeing long-term supplies and reduces the risks associated with drawing on only one supplier by allying with many. And it is able to fill any last-minute gaps that may surface in a contract with its own gas and, in fact, says about 20 percent of the gas pledged in long-term contracts will come from its own reserves.
While buyers are responsible for setting up their own deliveries, Enron -- as the country's largest pipeline network, it ships 18 percent of daily gas supplies -- can be of service. Half of the gas sold by the gas bank so far will be shipped over its pipeline. And its role as a pipeline gives it access to critical information about pricing gas.
 
The Biggest Deal
 The gas bank's biggest deal so far is with Florida Power and Light, which ordered 343 million cubic feet of gas a year for 15 years, enough electricity a day for 1.7 million homes. The New York Power Authority has agreed to buy 34 million cubic feet of gas a day for 23 years, starting in January. The deal enabled the power authority, New York State's largest electricity producer, to win a bidding competition to build a new power plant in Suffolk County that, when completed in 1994, will produce 150,000 kilowatts a day for the Long Island Lighting Company. That utility currently generates 70 percent of the electricity it produces from oil-fired plants.
Richard M. Flynn, chairman of the power authority, said the Enron contract "will be a key factor in our efforts to reduce New York's dependence on foreign oil and diversify its fuel mix for electricity production." Despite its growing alliance with often forlorn gas producers, Enron has taken precautions to minimize its risks. After spending several million dollars and 18 months on legal research, Enron came up with a plan under which it legally acquires the rights to specific gas reserves from producers under what are called production payment agreements. That way, Enron provides money for producers to invest in other gas development while avoiding losses if any of its producers stumble into bankruptcy.
Little of the money comes from Enron's coffers. Much of the cash is coming from big pension funds, insurers and credit companies, which buy securities backed by Enron's fixed-price gas contracts, just as they buy securities backed by home loans from mortgage bankers.
 While it is still too early to tell if Enron can create a market for long-term gas deals, many are betting that it can. "They've done a lot of business," said Mr. Sandefer. "They've placed a lot of money, hundreds of millions of dollars."
Mike Naeve, who specializes in energy issues as a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom, in Washington, and who is a former commissioner of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, agrees. "My view is they are making a dent," he said. "One way they are making a dent is in the development of sophisticated hedging and packaging techniques that enable them to enter into these transactions. Clearly they are a leader in that area. A lot of people are watching Enron to see how it works."
And if others pile into the gas banking business, if nothing else to keep their customers from signing up with Enron, as some analysts expect, it may be only a matter of time before long-term contracts become a fixture of the gas world once more.
 
 
A NEED FOR NEW PLANTS
 Part of Enron's plan for creating a market for long-term gas contracts depends on utilities' need to build new gas-fired plants. Some energy analysts say the timing is just right.
Gas-fired projects are scarcer than those fueled by coal and nuclear energy. For nine years, until 1987, the Government banned construction by utilities of gas-fired plants, fearing that conversion to gas under deregulation would renew shortages that gripped some regions in 1977. Utilities have built few gas plants since, discouraged by the lack of long-term contracts that lenders insist upon. And many regions had plenty of electricity, thanks to the overbuilding of capacity in the 1970's.
The industry may be ready to build again. "Demand for electricity is growing faster than in the mid-1980's," said Mike Naeve, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom in Washington and a former commissioner of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. "There is an opportunity for gas to fill that void, especially given the environmental benefits."
New technologies make gas very efficient. Modern combined-cycle plants include one gas turbine and a second powered by heat from the first one. Their operating costs are up to 30 percent below those of oil- or coal-fired plants.
 
 
FROM TEXAS TO SCOTLAND, A SPRAWLING GAS EMPIRE
 From searching for new gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico to building the world's largest electricity plant powered by gas in Scotland, Kenneth L. Lay has assembled a sprawling empire since the 1985 merger that created Enron.
The deal married two big pipeline companies, the Houston Natural Gas Company, headed by Mr. Lay, and the larger Internorth Corporation at a time when Washington was loosening its grip on price controls for pipelines and in the gas fields and competition was heated. As Enron's chairman and chief executive since 1986, Mr. Lay has exploited advantages endowed by the company's size. His latest attempt to hook industrial users on gas will benefit many of its businesses.
 In the last two years, he became the first executive of a major American gas company to expand into Europe in ventures unrelated to gas production. On the northeast coast of Scotland, in Teesside, Enron's power generation unit is building the world's biggest cogeneration plant. The colossus will consume 300 million cubic feet daily of natural gas shipped from North Sea fields more than 140 miles away by a group of gas producers headed by Amoco Inc. The plant will displace the equivalent of 52,000 barrels a day of crude oil that would have been needed.
The same construction unit has completed four gas-fired cogeneration plants in the United States since 1987, including one in Bayonne, N.J., for Jersey Central Power. In addition to producing electricity, cogeneration plants recapture heat generated by turbines and transform it to steam used by nearby industrial plants. In conventional electric power plants, heat generated by turbines is wasted. Enron is building another gas-fired plant for a group of investors in Milford, Mass., which will supply power to the local utility, the New England Power Company. Mr. Lay is counting on Enron's new gas-marketing units to accelerate this business.
Enron's pipeline network could also benefit. It dominates in the Middle West and Florida and has new links to California, but has no connections in the northeast, the region where analysts expect gas demand will grow most rapidly in years ahead.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Good Bargain in Blue Chips?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Back in the Roaring Twenties, when the national cocktail was bathtub gin and the stock market was everybody's dream machine, the Adams Express Company was at a crossroads. Its basic business, shipping small parcels around the country, had been invaded by the Post Office Department, and the nation's booming railroads were offering handsome prices for its rolling stock. It was time for a change.
The transformation came in January 1929, when Adams Express became a closed-end mutual fund, listed on the New York Stock Exchange. It promised its investors it would preserve their capital and give them "reasonable" income and opportunity for capital gains. It kept the promise. Through Depression, wars and countless stock market cycles, Adams Express has built up a $600 million portfolio of blue-chip stocks, the stuff that Old Money is made of. 
 Yet today, its own shares routinely trade for less than the market value of the sterling stocks it owns. One reason may be that the fund's portfolio, rich in capital gains, exposes most investors to an unattractive tax bite. But for tax-exempt investors, like pension funds and retirement accounts, that tax cloud just makes a good bargain even better.
Unlike open-end mutual funds, closed-end funds have a fixed number of shares and they do not redeem their old shares for cash. Closed-end funds simply sell stock and invest the proceeds for their shareholders' benefit.
The 20's saw a boom in new closed-end funds. But the changes at Adams Express were not some flapper-era fad. Although Adams Express had been one of the leading shipping companies in the country -- its leading rivals were American Express and Wells Fargo -- its management decided that the future lay elsewhere.
On Wall Street, in fact. Thus, the company sold its railcars and "plunked the money into the stock market," said Douglas G. Ober, chairman of the fund.
The timing, of course, was not ideal. Only a few public stock funds born in the 20's survived the 1929 crash and the industrial collapse that followed. Besides Adams Express, this hardy band includes General American Investors, traded since 1927; the Niagara Share Corporation, founded in early 1929 to specialize in public utilities; and the Salomon Brothers Fund, founded as the Lehman Corporation a month before the 1929 crash.
Today, when so many companies seem to have the life span of a butterfly, all of these pre-Depression survivors have a certain dowager charm. General American Investors, in fact, has become something of a market darling lately, having recently been recommended by Prudential Securities. Niagara Shares broadened its portfolio in 1952, and now invests in common stocks here and abroad. The Salomon Brothers Fund has perhaps undergone the most dramatic alterations, changing its name and shifting from internal to outside management.
There have been a few changes at Adams Express, too. In 1976, it packed up and moved from New York City to Baltimore to take advantage of a kinder tax environment for mutual funds. More recently, on April 1, it got a new chairman when Mr. Ober, 44 years old, succeeded W. D. MacCallan, who had been chairman for 20 years.
But do not look for a housecleaning in the portfolio now that he has stepped down. "You might see some very, very minimal changes," Mr. Ober said. "But I came to this business from commercial banking -- back when that was still a conservative business -- and balance sheets are my specialty. So I would have to say we would probably be as conservative as in the past."
What one sees in the Adams Express portfolio these days is all "pretty close to the consumer dollar," as Mr. MacCallan used to say. The fund's managers do not expect a hefty economic revival until late this year, at the earliest, and they have put the fund's money into consumer staples like Borden and General Mills, health care companies like Bristol-Myers Squibb, and public utilities like the Baby Bells and New England Electric System.
But although the fund owns blue-chip names -- and consistently has charged extremely low management fees, compared with its rival funds -- the stock market has typically not given it full credit for its holdings. Right now, the fund is trading at an 8 percent discount to the per-share value of its net assets; in the past year, the gap has been as big as 16 percent.
Most analysts attribute the size of that gap to the rich lode of taxable capital gains embedded in the fund's well-seasoned portfolio. Thomas J. Herzfeld, an investment adviser in Miami who specializes in closed-end funds, notes that Adams Express has been taking profits on its stocks for years and has paid those profits out as taxable capital gains to investors.
"I think that's why they trade at such a discount," Mr. Herzfeld said. "I've been recommending them to our pension fund clients -- that way, they're getting the advantage of other people's tax liabilities."
Mr. Ober, the fund's chairman, said he thinks the chronic discount is rooted more "in the market's perception of the portfolio." When blue chips look attractive, he pointed out, his fund's discount shrinks; when smaller, riskier stocks are hot, the discount widens. He conceded, however, that pension funds and people managing their own individual retirement accounts might well favor the fund more than taxable investors would.
"It's a strong income vehicle," he said, "and the yield, when you include the capital gains, is something like 9 percent. I would think that our fund would be attractive to someone who has got a good-sized pension or fairly large I.R.A. and is looking to safeguard what they have."
After a moment's thought, he added: "I really wouldn't recommend buying, though, until the discount widens to about 12 percent. It would be a much better bargain then."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Trouble Sleeping? Call a 24-Hour Trading Desk

BYLINE: By Mary Billard

 BODY:
The band was loud. The music was good. The beer was cold. But George Kaufman's mind started to drift thousands of miles away from CBGB, the downtown rock club. Around midnight, Mr. Kaufman walked out to the deserted Manhattan street -- the Bowery -- and made a phone call. He came back smiling. "I needed to find out what gold was trading at in Hong Kong," he told his friends, a little sheepishly.
To find out, Mr. Kaufman, a principal in the New York commodities firm of T&S Commodities Inc. had called the trading desk of Credit Lyonnais Rouse. 
 Like any other trading desk, it provides market information and executes orders for its customers. And its customers are a breed apart: they trade everything the world's major exchanges have to offer, primarily currencies and precious metals, and they are acutely aware that something is trading at every hour of the day or night.
Mr. Kaufman describes one of his friends, a successful speculator, as a real maniac. "He calls me first thing in the morning and says, 'Can you believe where the Swiss franc was trading last night at 3 in the morning? ' " says Mr. Kaufman. "I ask him, 'How do you know that?' And he'll say, 'I called on the way to the bathroom. Doesn't everybody? ' "
At Credit Lyonnais Rouse, customers range from small operations like T&S to foreign banks and money managers, all of whom need a central place where they can trade around the clock. The late shift, which comes on at midnight, takes care of select customers for whom uninterrupted sleeping has become passe, eclipsed by the need to plug into the pulsating markets. It is such a small group on most nights that one executive noted, "You could make a pot of coffee at night and it would take care of everyone trading. And their parents."
Located on the 21st floor of a high-rise building on lower Broadway, the Credit Lyonnais office shows the wear and tear of a 24-hour operation. Many chairs have broken springs, the carpet could use cleaning and the clock that tells Sydney time has fallen down. But the firm, a subsidiary of the big French bank, has more than 2,000 clients.
 "The overseas exchanges keep growing and more people are taking an interest in them, particularly money managers," said John Hannam, president of Credit Lyonnais Rouse.
Like surfers prowling the world in search of the perfect wave, traders who call the overnight desk at Credit Lyonnais are striving to find the perfect market -- huge, fluid and offering a breathtaking ride. And Credit Lyonnais Rouse is not the only firm with such a clientele; others nearby include Refco Inc., in Manhattan, and the AIG Trading Corporation in Fort Lee, N.J.
When it is lunchtime in Tokyo, it is 11 P.M. at the Credit Lyonnais trading desk in New York. The four traders on duty are flapping their jaws like auctioneers on a record-breaking day. All eyes are glued to the green numbers on the Reuters monitors; all shoulders cradle phones. The two younger traders -- Seth Brufsky and Chris Curtain -- keep pacing, but only as far as phone wires allow.
No conversation lasts more than 30 seconds. Snatches of phrases ring out: gold is up; Singapore has a demand for silver; the D-mark is unchanged; the yen is up; the "Swiss-ee" is down; the pound unchanged. "I need spot gold," shouts Mr. Curtain. It is a symphonic ode to the free flow of capital currency and commodities.
But still there is not enough action. Phone conversations reveal that the traders are finding things a tad too tame. There is no volatility in the market. Mr. Brufsky recites a litany of numbers to a customer and then concludes: "Nothing's moving up here." Nothing is worse than nothing. When the phone rings, everyone grabs it. Roy Friedman, one of the traders, even has time to joke with a customer who calls every night. "Isn't your wife home from the gym yet?"
Jack Trapp, who has worked nights for five years, tells tales of yore -- four months ago -- when the bombing of Baghdad began. "The phones stayed lit up for days," he says, staring forlornly at the one lighted phone line.
After hearing bedtime stories of riches in faraway lands, most of the customers go to sleep and the calls drop off. Around midnight, the next shift at Credit Lyonnais comes in. Some nights Andrew Gilbride and Rodolfo Gutierrez, traders in their 20's, are as lonely as the repairman in the Maytag ads. They talk to the London office to see what is happening and joke with the trader they nicknamed Elvis for a reason they have long since forgotten. They watch CNN and wait for the deli to open at 5 A.M.
If there is political or economic news anywhere in the world, the Credit Lyonnais traders start speed-dialing their customers. For example, when Margaret Thatcher resigned last fall, the pound went haywire. Mr. Gilbride and Mr. Gutierrez started dialing customers even though it was before dawn on Thanksgiving morning in New York.
Even on a relatively slow day, Mr. Gilbride is the cause of interrupted dreams. Many customers leave word that they wish to be alerted if certain levels are reached in the markets. Picking up the phone around 5 A.M., he dutifully calls a customer about a specific market fluctuation. The call takes less than a minute. Hanging up, Mr. Gilbride sighs, "I haven't let him sleep a full night in a year."
At around 5:30, the phones start ringing more frequently. By 6, the calls are nonstop. There are regulars -- money managers, traders, bankers -- who call every morning to see what they missed by sleeping. When the markets have been active, Mr. Gilbride says he can almost hear his customer's heart rate quicken.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE -- American Intelligence: Do We Still Need the C.I.A.?;
Independence Means Integrity

BYLINE: By Bud Shuster; Bud Shuster, Republican of Pennsylvania, is a member of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's effort to abolish the Central Intelligence Agency and transfer its functions to the State Department is a recipe for disaster. Giving the Secretary of State chief responsibility for intelligence raises the specter of "cooking" intelligence to support a preconceived policy. The separation of intelligence-gathering and foreign policy is a fundamental principle.
As Dave Durenberger, ex-chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said: "There's danger when your eyes and ears become your brain. You start seeing what you want to see." 
 Senator Moynihan is using his bill to promote his thesis that the C.I.A. is synonymous with the cold war and that the cold war is dead. Therefore, the agency should now be buried in the State Department. But contrary to his intimations, the C.I.A. has plenty of missions other than analyzing the Soviet Union. Some experts argue that other priorities have been neglected: nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking and terrorism, for example. There has been an explosion in the need for information difficult to acquire.
Moreover, though the security risks that motivated our traditional intelligence effort have abated, it has become harder, not easier, to keep tabs on the Soviet Union, which remains our main geopolitical and military rival. The monitoring of arms control agreements -- involving a key C.I.A. role -- will continue to be crucial to U.S. security.
True, Senator Moynihan advocates moving C.I.A. functions to the State Department, not abolishing them. He claims he was prompted as much by the agency's inadequate performance as by the waning of the cold war. He cites the failure to recognize the Soviet economic crisis, implying a lack of objectivity by officials eager to bolster the Reagan military buildup. Mr. Moynihan mistakes the causes of this error. That aside, what makes him think the C.I.A. will be more objective subsumed in a politicized State Department?
He cites U.S. overestimates of Moscow's military abilities in the 1950's and early 1960's, before we had the technical ability to reduce the guesswork, but ignores the underestimate of Soviet military might in the late 1960's and 1970's. Opponents of the Reagan Pentagon budget used the relatively low C.I.A. estimates of Soviet military spending to undercut it. So much for cold war paranoia.
As already noted, a rationale for a separate C.I.A. is to protect analysts from pressure to gather information favorable to an Administration's initiatives. It is doubtful that the State Department would relish a reversal of this wise policy. For reasons of safety and credibility, foreign service officers distance themselves from "spies." In addition, Senator Moynihan does not indicate how transferring the functions of the Director of Central Intelligence to the Secretary of State would affect Defense Department components like the Defense Intelligence Agency and National Security Agency, over whom the Director of Central Intelligence has considerable authority.
Mr. Moynihan's is a bad idea whose time will never come. By the late 20th century, America should have outgrown the notion that it has little need for intelligence collection and analysis. After World War I, the U.S. reduced its intelligence effort. We paid the price at Pearl Harbor. We nearly made the same mistake after the war, until Soviet expansionism led to creation of the C.I.A. in 1947.
The focus of U.S. intelligence may fluctuate with our interests and roles. But we should get over the idea that intelligence is dirty, that it represents the abandonment of American innocence and ideals rather than a wise way to preserve those ideals. We can improve U.S. intelligence, but proposals for doing so will have to be more thoughtful than Mr. Moynihan's.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Recycling? Try Reverse Shopping

 BODY:
The article about recycled commingled materials demonstrates that the only moneymaker for the intermediate processing plants to which the mixed items are delivered is the aluminum beverage can portion.
Community and county programs now pay $25 to $40 a ton to get rid of the aluminum cans, which the processing facilities remove from the mix, flatten and sell for up to $1,100 a ton gross profit to nearby end-users. That is quite a markup. If there were no aluminum cans, the tipping fee for the commingled plastic containers, tin cans and glass would be almost as high as the cost to bury garbage.
Programs that collect the aluminum cans separately and sell them for their own account retain the income themselves. Also, those programs that have realized that glass is the only material in the mix that breaks, and that collect the glass containers separated by color, not only earn as much as they would pay out if the glass were commingled, but also avoid the cost of disposing of 15 to 25 percent of the mixed glassy aggregate that is a byproduct of every commingled operation.
Politicians have bought the commingling concept under the mistaken fear that the public will throw them out of office if they ask voters to separate their recyclable items for economic reasons. Many public works departments opt for commingling also; it reduces their responsibilities.
There are dozens of examples of New Jersey recycling programs that have made reclamation less costly by building around intelligent collection procedures. They avoid landfilling as many tons of recyclable materials as the commingling concept because they don't have any below-grade glass aggregate to dispose of -- they source-separate.
 
 RICHARD A. MENKES
 
The writer is president of Menkes Municipal Services, a West Orange-based company that markets recycled glass.

HEADLINE: Kohl Due in U.S. With Pledge of Strong Ties

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 18

 BODY:
The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, begins a two-day visit to Washington on Sunday with the message that reunited Germany places great value on continued close ties with the United States.
Mr. Kohl's visit, his first since the Germanys reunified in October, will afford him a chance to soothe some Americans' pique over what they perceived as Germany's grudging commitment of resources to the Persian Gulf war. But the deeper purpose appears to be to dispel doubts about the future course of united Germany and its role in the European Community, which is seeking deeper economic, political and security links. 
At a news conference on Friday in Bonn to discuss the visit, Mr. Kohl emphasized that his message in the United States would be that reunited Germany, Western Europe's wealthiest and most populous country, places great value on the closest possible cooperation with the United States. He will stress, he said, the extent of Germany's political and financial support of Western policy in the Middle East and Eastern Europe.
Mr. Kohl reiterated his often stated proposal to seek parliamentary passage of laws to allow German troops, for the first time since the World War II, to be deployed in regions outside the NATO area. But Mr. Kohl's opponents in the Social Democratic party, whose parliamentary support is needed for passage, immediately repeated their opposition, serving notice that the Chancellor will face an uphill legislative battle.
The Chancellor will be accompanied to Washington by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and will meet with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. But an aide who will accompany Mr. Kohl emphasized that the visit was an effort not so much to reach the President, with whom Mr. Kohl talks by telephone almost weekly, but to reach members of Congress and other policymakers in meetings and a series of foreign policy speeches, most notably an address on Monday at Georgetown University.
The aide said Mr. Kohl would stress the need for strong continued endorsement of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Germany has been particularly receptive to calls by Mr. Gorbachev that the major industrial nations of the Group of Seven agree at their meeting this summer to approve aid for Moscow's transition to free markets and open borders.
Mr. Kohl is expected to reiterate the view that by strengthening European security structures, such as the Western European Union, a long-disused military organization, European governments were not weakening NATO, but bolstering its European leg.
The trip may also allow Mr. Kohl to regain some political ground lost this spring. The public perception that he lacked resolve in dealing with the deepening economic problems in the east was a major factor in the defeat of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Party in his home state, Rhineland-Palatinate, in elections in April.
Mr. Kohl has recently seemed at pains to appear more assertive, sending German soldiers to Iran for relief work among the Kurds, challenging protesters in depressed eastern German cities where they pelted him recently with eggs and taking controversial domestic stands, like his whole-hearted endorsement of Berlin as the seat of government.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); GERMANY (98%); EUROPE (94%); WESTERN EUROPE (92%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (92%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (57%);

HEADLINE: Darman Tackles Domestic Issues in Talk at College

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Solving America's toughest domestic problems cannot be done with just money and a sense of mission, the Bush Administration's budget director said today, but requires basic changes in technology and values, from the development of a better car battery to the determination that children spend more time in school.
Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, told graduates at Bryant College in Smithfield, R.I., that it was a mistake to conclude from the United States' success in the Persian Gulf war that sufficient money and an agreed-upon purpose could solve domestic problems as well. 
 His remarks were broader than the usual budget office concerns, but throughout his tenure he has occasionally given speeches on economic and social philosophy as he has sought to be known as more than an accountant. Today's focus on education reflected his enthusiasm at working with the new Secretary of Education, Lamar Alexander, and his interest in finding new ideas and financing for the nation's public schools.
Mr. Darman said the right education goals were already there, in the six objectives set last year by the nation's governors and President Bush. Without citing the complaint of most Democrats that the Administration's education program amounted to more talk than dollars, he maintained that money was not an issue because "we already spend more per capita than our major competitors," referring to foreign countries.
Improved technology is especially important to educational progress he said, because while computer terminals can finally be found in classrooms, "most school budgets remain about as labor-intensive as they must have been in ancient Egypt."
He said the educational system has hardly begun to transfer "rote teaching functions to interesting software." If it did, he suggested in an interview Friday, computers could teach the basics more effectively, reduce the number of teachers being used for that purpose and, with a smaller work force, be able to pay teachers more.
But the opportunities provided by technology are unlikely to be realized, he told the graduates, if major changes in values do not accompany them. While more is being expected from the nation's schools, students spend only 175 days a year in school and 90 percent of their time outside the classroom, much of it watching television. "We've trained a generation of experts in the Wheel of Fortune," he said.
The nation has to put greater value on accountability and choice, employing a "market orientation" and allowing parents to "shop around" among various schools, he said in the interview. Hitting a central theme of the Administration's education program, he said pressure for improvement of the schools has to come from "performance measures and freedom of choice."
He applied the same argument of values and technology to the nation's health care costs and its reliance on imported oil.
Reducing dependence on imported oil, he told the Bryant graduates, also requires basic changes in technology and values.
"Over time, our culture must be weaned from the excessive value it places on the traditional automobile," he said.
The changes in values, he said, can only accompany "commercially sound breakthroughs in battery technology and in high-speed rail technology." He said there is already a clear Federal role in these areas, in encouraging battery research and in helping to finance basic research into superconductors that were relevant to magnetic rail technology. The Government, through its control of interstate highways, may also provide rail right-of-ways that would otherwise be very costly.
Dealing with rising health costs, he said, is obviously essential, since they have grown from 3 percent of the gross national product three decades ago to 12 percent today and are expected to grow to 18 percent in the 90's.
 
Tackling Health Care Costs

But solving the problem without risking either personal health or the nation's economic health would require new technology and new values, he said.
One obvious value change, he said, would be "to reduce drug abuse, alcohol consumption and high-risk behavior generally."
"Controlling such risk factors could prevent, perhaps, half of all premature deaths and cases of disability." he said.
The technology, he said, should involve medical advances that would do more than just keep people alive. While the first artificial hearts allowed no real mobility, he said in the interview, recent advances enable patients to live nearly normal lives.
But along with medical advances, he said, the nation will also need changes in values that would encourage patients to keep working or find new work so they can continue to earn money to help pay for health care costs.
