HEADLINE: In Fiscal Crunch, Frills of Office Can Loom Large

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
When City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman appears in public, two police detectives accompany her. When Mayor David N. Dinkins arrives each morning at City Hall from Gracie Mansion, one of his police bodyguards carries a cooler containing the Mayor's specially prepared diet lunch. When Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown travels the two blocks from Police Headquarters to City Hall, he drives, with a back-up car.
The customary perquisites of life at the top of New York City government -- cars with drivers and telephones, police protection for senior elected officials, helicopter rides or even the occasional trip abroad -- may appear impolitic, if not imperial, when local officials are contemplating laying off thousands of city workers and eliminating or sharply reducing services to close a $3.5 billion budget gap. 
 For some New Yorkers who have consumed a steady diet of news reports on the issue in recent days, the question of whether curtailing such perks would really make a dent in the city's financial mess is beside the point.
"Why should they be driving around in $20,000 cars when the city has the problems it has?" asked Tracy Stwaerd of Brooklyn, who is 20 years old. "They should take a taxi, or they should take the subway."
Andy Rothstein, a lawyer who also lives in Brooklyn, said of city officials: "Essentially, they are on my payroll. I don't live like that, so why should they?"
 
'Penny-Ante Stuff'
 "Since Boss Tweed they've been living too well," said Allen Seaman, who works in a Manhattan textile-manufacturing company. "But this is penny-ante stuff. He was a bigger crook than all these guys put together."
One morning last week, two newspapers devoted their front pages to what they portrayed as extravagant behavior by city officials. The Daily News took to task the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, for purchasing three new city cars in the last year. And New York Newsday heaped scorn on what it called a "Riviera Romp" -- a trip to the Cannes Film Festival by two city officials, Jaynne Keyes and Nina Streich of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting.
There have also been articles about limousines rented by a city commission to take members home after meetings; about vice presidents of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation who were dismissed but then given temporary jobs in the agency while they looked for new employment; and about a helicopter taken by the head of the Housing Authority, Laura D. Blackburne, to deliver a speech in Atlantic City.
"There is no question that it's open season on government officials," said Henry J. Stern, a former Parks Commissioner who is president of the Citizens Union, a nonprofit civic group. "On a slow day, one can at least go out to the motor pool and see what's up."
 
Symbolic Impact
 But Mr. Stern also said that lavish perks should be questioned, especially when the city government was preparing Draconian measures to meet its fiscal problems. Cutting back on such practices would not solve the budget crunch -- Mr. Golden would have to get rid of 175,000 city cars at $20,000 each to close the city's $3.5 billion gap for the next fiscal year -- but reducing amenities would have strong symbolic value, many people said.
"The details may be trivial -- obviously we're talking about pennies," Mr. Stern said. "But it's important for symbolism. It's difficult to defend even minor excesses when you're talking about laying off 18,000 people and doing away with important programs."
"Appearance is important in public life," he added.
Ms. Stwaerd, Mr. Rothstein and many other New Yorkers interviewed last week said they thought only the Mayor and a handful of other top officials deserved cars, drivers and police protection.
Gene Russianoff, senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit lobbying organization, said he thought the public would firmly support a shift from dark sedans to the D train.
 
Who Has to Suffer
 "I don't think it's just symbolic," he said. "City officials should use city services, particularly if they are talking about cutting them." Mr. Russianoff said that at public meetings where transit officials are discussing service cuts, he has often seen cars and drivers waiting outside for the officials.
"I think the public says to itself, 'If the fiscal crisis is real and we're going to have to suffer and we're going to have to change our behavior, so do the people who run the city,' " he said.
But others called the issue inconsequential and argued that the criticisms were simplistic. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch called the news reports "a lot of petty buffalo chips," because such expenditures actually involve very little money.
Mr. Koch said that officials like Mr. Golden, an old political adversary, needed city cars to perform their jobs. The subway is not always practical for elected officials who spend a large part of their day traveling to many different places, he said.
"The Mayor and other officials are performing important jobs, and you want to make it easier for them, not harder," Mr. Koch said.
Mr. Stern said he thought the use of city cars was often appropriate, particularly because city business can be conducted on the car phones. "It's a way for a top official to get around, and you don't want them lining up at pay phones," he said. But he said the use of cars and drivers by many mid-level officials should be curtailed.
Have some officials been insensitive to the austerity that has overtaken local government?
Mr. Golden bought three new cars with city money in the last year, The Daily News reported. Two cost about $22,000 each, The News said, and the other cost $16,000. Mr. Golden's spokesman, Pat Smith, said in a statement that the third car was for the Borough President's staff, and it replaced a seven-year-old car that had become unserviceable. He said the two cars bought for Mr. Golden replaced a car that had been stolen and a four-year-old car that had become too costly to maintain.
New York Newsday, in a column on the trip to the Cannes Film Festival by the two members of the mayoral office that promotes the shooting of movies in New York, said the trip cost $10,000. The next day, though, the paper published an article from a staff correspondent in Cannes, which said that Ms. Keyes and Ms. Streich had bought $385 round-trip plane tickets, had traveled by overnight train from Paris to the Riviera, were staying 10 miles out of town and were getting by on an expense allotment of $25 a day.
 
Spending Money Wisely
 The story also said that the officials had already signed up one movie for New York at the festival and were working on several others. Movie production in the city pumps hundreds of thousands of dollars into its economy.
"It is a real principle of both the private and public sectors that sometimes you have to spend money to make money," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "Certainly the film trip is a good example of that."
Ms. Messinger said that every city official had to concentrate on ways to reduce costs, and that news reports highlighting excesses were often helpful. But she also said that government leaders should not be so afraid of the potential for negative publicity that they fail to spend money intelligently.
"Some of this has a chilling effect," Ms. Messinger said. "It makes people afraid to do things that ought to be done, because they are afraid that it will be picked up."

HEADLINE: CROATIA REJECTS A YUGOSLAV PANEL

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 18

 BODY:
Leaders of the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today rejected a federal panel formed on Friday by the country's Prime Minister to keep this six-republic federation functioning after the collapse of the federal presidency.
"We are questioning the constitutionality of the move," said Darko Bekic, an adviser to Croatia's President, referring to Prime Minister Ante Markovic's appointment of the panel. "This is something that is his private initiative." 
 Mr. Markovic formed the team Friday evening after the republics of Serbia and Montenegro plunged Yugoslavia into yet another constitutional crisis by preventing Stipe Mesic, Croatia's delegate to the eight-member national presidency, from assuming the body's chairmanship. The move violated the system of annual rotation of the chairmanship and has effectively left Yugoslavia without a head of state and its armed forces without a commander in chief.
It is still unclear which powers will be assumed by the panel appointed on Friday, especially those powers relating to control of the military. The members of Mr. Markovic's team have not been officially identified, although it reportedly includes Yugoslavia's Defense Minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, and other key ministers.
 
Violent Serb-Croat Clashes
 At a meeting in Belgrade today, the army's high command spelled out the steps it will take to carry out a May 9 decision of the federal presidency, which set a 30-day deadline for the ending of all armed conflicts in Yugoslavia and the disarming of all illegal paramilitary groups in the country, a Defense Ministry statement said without elaboration.
The high command also "reviewed the defense and security aspects of the current situation in Yugoslavia and international reactions to it," the statement said.
Violent clashes between Serbs and Croats have claimed 19 lives in the last three weeks, and the United States and the European Community have issued statements warning the Yugoslav Army, whose officer corps is dominated by Serbs, against trying to resolve the tense political situation by seizing power.
"Croatia will not be obligated by anything undertaken outside the Constitution," Mr. Mesic said in an interview today. "I am afraid that the team will not be able to act in any way to resolve the present situation."
Zvonko Lerotic, another adviser to Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, said: "Mr. Markovic is attempting to find a compromise between both groups. He is acting as a savior or mediator who is attempting to find institutions through which both sides can negotiate."
Mr. Lerotic said: "Mr. Markovic thinks he has the support to do this. I don't think he does."
"It will last until its first failure," he said. "When the first serious problem appears before this group it will be blockaded, half and half. Every federal group, every initiative is broken up half and half. It is impossible to take any decisions except on peripheral issues."
In a brief interview today, Mr. Markovic described the team only in the most general terms.
 
No-Confidence Vote Urged
 "It is an interdepartmental team which will work on the realization of our goals," he said, refusing to elaborate.
Serbia's government has yet to react to the formation of team, but its President, Slobodan Milosevic, is a political enemy of Mr. Markovic and his program to introduce market economic changes in Yugoslavia.
"A new attack from Serbia will be directed at the Government of Mr. Markovic," Mr. Mesic said.
A Serbian representative has already called for the federal Parliament to take a vote of no confidence in the Government later this month.
"For Milosevic, no kind of Yugoslavia is acceptable, only Greater Serbia," Mr. Mesic said. "I am satisfied only by the fact that the world can now see with whom Croatia has to deal."
Mr. Mesic said that Croatia's President, Mr. Tudjman, and the republic's Parliament would decide how to respond to Serbia's blocking his appointment to the presidency's top post. Before Friday's vote in the presidency, Mr. Mesic said Croatia would secede if he were not named the presidency's chairman.
Voters in Croatia are to cast ballots on Sunday in a referendum on whether they want the republic to be a sovereign independent state joined in confederation with other Yugoslav republics.
Mr. Lerotic said Croatia's leaders hoped the vote would be a huge show of support for the republic's government and provide impetus for the United States and European Community to recognize Yugoslavia's internal borders as inviolable international frontiers.
 
Role of Yugoslav Army
 "We think that the referendum will help America and the European Community to think about recognizing the internal borders as international borders," he said, adding that he expects about 80 percent of the Croatian electorate to go to the polls and for the proposition on sovereignty to win 70 to 80 percent of the votes.
Widespread support in the referendum is important for the Croatian government's relations with the Yugoslav National Army, Mr. Lerotic said, because it will dispel assertions by the army leadership that only the Croatian government desires Croatia's distancing from the Yugoslav federation.
"The leadership of the Yugoslav National Army will be in a very bad position after this referendum," he said.
A senior Western diplomat today described Mr. Markovic's team as a kind of Government task force.
 
'The Presidency Is Paralyzed'
 "I have no sense that there are people other than those in the Government on the committee," he said. "You need the Government to keep the army under civilian control."
"I don't think you'll see it doing dramatic things," he added. "It doesn't seem to be a committee of public safety."
"The Government is acting as a government, as the only functioning federal executive organ," he said. "The presidency is paralyzed."

HEADLINE: BUDGET THREATENS PHYSICS PROJECT

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
The search for the top quark, an elusive subnuclear particle regarded by high-energy physicists as a kind of Holy Grail, will probably be delayed for years because of financing problems, leading physicists say.
The top quark, believed to be a building block of an exotic form of matter, may hold a clue to one of the most puzzling questions in physics: why matter has mass. Unless the quark is found, this line of inquiry is stymied. 
 Last week, the House Subcommittee on Energy and Water Development, headed by Representative Tom Bevill, an Alabama Democrat, completed work on the Federal appropriations bill for 1992. The panel cut $100 million from the $534 million requested by the Administration for the Superconducting Supercollider particle accelerator planned for Texas. The subcommittee also omitted financing for an upgrading project that had been planned for the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Illinois. Both actions affect the quest for the top quark.
The Fermilab project, which would cost $177.8 million, is an injector that would pump additional tightly bunched swarmsof protons and antiprotons into the Fermilab Tevatron, the most powerful particle accelerator in the world. By increasing the number of particles forced to collide with each other in the machine, physicists say, there will be a better chance of spotting the very rare collisions in which top quarks are expected to appear.
 
Fermilab as Best Hope
 Many of the greatest high-energy accelerators in the world, including Petra at Hamburg, Germany, PEP and the Stanford Linear Collider in California, Tristan and KEK in Japan, and the Large Electron-Positron collider at Geneva, have all tried and failed to find the top quark.
But the best hope lay in Fermilab's Tevatron, which can smash protons and antiprotons into each other with a combined energy of nearly two trillion electron-volts. The energy unleashed by such collisions is spontaneously converted into matter, including not only the kinds familiar today, but also forms of matter that existed immediately after the Big Bang explosion from which scientists say the universe emerged.
Most scientists believed that after the Tevatron was completed in 1987, it would take only a few months to find the top quark. But despite a succession of improvements made in the machine since then, even the mighty Tevatron has failed to turn up the particle.
Physicists worry about this for economic as well as scientific reasons. Part of the justification for spending billions of dollars for high-energy research is the assumption that important discoveries will result. The failure to find the top quark could be interpreted as a failure of physics and as a reason for reducing or eliminating funds for gigantic accelerator projects.
 
At Least a Year's Delay
 There is a consensus among physicists that Fermilab now offers the best prospect for finding the elusive quark, provided that the new, upgraded injector is built for the Tevatron accelerator. But last week's action in the House appeared to have delayed the project for at least a year.
Dr. Leon M. Lederman, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and a Nobel laureate in physics, deplored the development.
"If I were still the director of Fermilab, I think I'd cut my wrists," he said. "Eliminating funds for the injector will mean throwing away the world's pre-eminent machine of its kind. It is snatching defeat from the jaws of victory."
Fermilab's current director, Dr. John Peoples Jr., was less pessimistic. "This is a great disappointment," he said. "But if it's only a year's delay, we can live with it. But if the cut in funds for the injector is permanent, the result will be devastating."
Spokesmen for the House subcommittee and Representative Bevill refused to comment on the deliberations that led to the cuts.
 
Other Projects' Problems
 Two other big accelerators still in the planning stage, the supercollider and Europe's Large Hadron Collider, could both provide the energy and tight packing of particles needed to produce the top quark. But both projects face major uncertainties. High-energy physicists say that it is unlikely that the supercollider could be completed before 2005, and that the whole project might still be scuttled by spending constraints.
The European accelerator, which would be built near Geneva in an existing accelerator tunnel 17 miles in circumference, also faces financial and technical problems. Scientists say that major difficulties in designing huge magnets to control the accelerator's proton beams have yet to be resolved.
Physicists believe that the fundamental building blocks of all matter are particles called quarks and leptons, which are related to each other in terms of a theory called the Standard Model. This theory, which has been almost perfectly verified by experiments, supposes the existence of six kinds of quarks, which have been given the whimsical names "up," "down," "charmed," "strange," "bottom" (or, alternatively, "beauty,") and "top."
All the matter in the ordinary realm of existence is based on up and down quarks, which combine to form the protons and neutrons from which atomic nuclei are assembled. The other quarks are not seen outside accelerator laboratories.

HEADLINE: Waves of Sewage and Auto Traffic Sweep Down on U.S. From Canada

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLAINE, Wash.

 BODY:
The complaints from American officials sound familiar: pollution from an outdated sewage system fouling international waters, and a surge of people crossing the border, some of them illegally, in search of economic oppportunity.
Tijuana? El Paso? Try the 49th Parallel, where Washington State meets British Columbia. In a rare display of friction, United States officials are upset over what they call a "1950's-era" approach to pollution control in Canada, and for gridlock at a border entry area that is now the most heavily traveled on the nation's northern boundary. 
 The pollution complaints arise because every day Victoria, the capital city of the fastest-growing province in Canada, dumps 20 million gallons of raw, untreated household sewage from the 250,000 people in its metropolitan area into waters shared by Canada and the United States. It is the only major city on this vast coastal region that does not treat its sewage.
"It is astonishing that a city the size of Victoria is dumping so much raw sewage into the water," said Robert Burd, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's regional director for water programs. "That is a lot of gross stuff being flushed out to sea. The problem is that Canada just doesn't have the environmental laws we have. They are about where the United States was in the 1950's."
 
 Mobs of Bargain Hunters
 The other major source of complaints is about Canadian bargain hunters who are overwhelming border communities in unprecedented numbers. Driven by high taxes and a cost of living that is nearly double that of Washington State, Canadians crossed the border into northwest Washington about 27 million times last year. The number of crossings, equal to Canada's entire population, was reported by five border stations within a 30-mile area.
The visitors came to shop for things like gasoline, cheese, milk or even real estate. Unleaded gasoline, for example, sells for about $1.20 a gallon here, while it can cost more than $3 in United States money in British Columbia, where taxes and higher costs for processing run the price up.
"We've not only lost control of our town, but the whole economy has shifted," said Bruce Brown, publisher of The Sumas Astonisher, the newspaper in another border town in northwest Washington. "Here's a little town of 749 people and you've got gridlock at 11 o'clock in the morning."
Mr. Brown calculated that there is one gasoline dispenser for every three residents of the town.
Moreover, prices are higher here than they are elsewhere in Washington because merchants know the Canadians will pay. This sends some local residents up to 70 miles south in search of basic goods.
A recent study by the Chamber of Commerce in British Columbia estimated that the province was losing $1.2 billion (United States money) each year because of Canadians who were taking their business south.
 
 Opening of Commuter Lane
 To ease the border congestion, Canadian national officials have started a commuter lane for frequent international shoppers, but they say the only thing that will really reduce border crossings is a major shift in the Canadian economy.
They say they are pressuring Victoria to clean up its municipal sewage system, but it could be years before Victoria builds plants to start treating its sewage.
Victorians seem somewhat embarrassed by the sewage dispute, which has been the subject of many newspaper editorials on both sides of the border, and comments in British Columbia's Parliament and Washington's Legislature.
The friction is a reversal of the early 1980's, when Canadians, primarily in the East, were complaining about pollution coming from the American side, in the form of acid rain. And Canadians in the Great Lakes region have long criticized water pollution originating in the United States.
After spending billions of dollars to clean up sewage treatment plants in Washington State, officials on the United States side say the Canadians should do their share to remove effluents from the Strait of Juan de Fuca, which opens to the Pacific Ocean. They also complain about the flow of industrial chemicals from pulp and paper mills into the Fraser River, which empties into international waters.
Mr. Burd said past analysis of raw sewage indicates that toxic waste and chemicals are sent out to sea with the sewage. The sewage endangers a rich fishery that includes crab, halibut, salmon, cod, squid, oysters and clams, he said.
Victoria officials say there is no proof that the sewage is harmful to marine life. "The sewage is 99 percent water, and the other 1 percent is made up of waste from us humans and chemicals that we throw away," said Michael Williams, the chief engineer of the agency that controls Victoria's sewage. "The concern that we have at the technnical level is chemicals. With respect to human waste, mother nature tends to take care of that."
A longstanding agreement between the two countries says that if damage to fish can be proven, the polluting source can be forced to close. In recent meetings where United States officials raised the issue of Victoria's sewage, Canadian officials indicated willingness to cooperate, Mr. Burd said.
 
 An 'Unacceptable' Situation

Canadian national officials have joined the criticism of Victoria. "We have told the City of Victoria that the present situation is unacceptable," said Alain David, a water pollution expert with Environment Canada, the federal pollution control agency.
Last week, Victoria unveiled a study on how the city could clean up its sewage. The options could cost up to $350 million, the study said.
While Victoria officials debate whether to spend the money to clean up their sewage, a solution for the other border is nowhere near a solution.
Last year, according to evidence presented at a Congressional hearing on the problem, this border area became the most heavily used, passing the Buffalo and Detroit crossings. A recent Canadian tax of 7 percent on virtually all goods and services added to the incentive for Canadians to shop in the United States.
Warehouses stocked with groceries and electronic goods draw near-capacity crowds every day. Many goods cost at least 50 percent less on the United States side of the border.
Gasoline stations have sprouted in former dairy fields. Lines of returning Canadian cars stretch for miles on the United States side, waiting as long as three hours to re-enter their country. The delay is caused mostly by the collection of duties on goods purchased in this country.
 
 Traffic Chokes Town
 "They back up so far at the border station that it stretches three miles into town, blocks everything and our town comes to a stop," said Butch Hinchey, the Chief of Police here in Blaine, the American border town of 2,600 people that has become the main entry point. "We basically lose our town."
To avoid the long waits at official border points, some Canadians have been crossing illegally, driving across thick wooden planks they place across an irrigation ditch that separates the two countries, customs officials say.
While many businesses are prospering from the influx, some longtime residents do not like it. Chief Hinchey, a resident of Blaine for 22 years, said the only time he has seen border traffic this bad was in the 1970's, when a Canadian beer strike sent crowds south.
In its experiment for the tourist season, the Canadians have started a commuter lane, open to people who cross the border frequently and have applied for a special decal.
But only 20,000 applicants will be allowed to use the new system. Traffic jams will not go away, Mr. Watt said, until one country is less of a bargain than the other.

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Todd S. Purdum

 BODY:
Feud Gathers Momentum
Aides to the New York City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, were apoplectic last week when they got their hands on a memo saying that Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch would be in charge of negotiations on the city's $29 billion budget. 
 That's because the Council leadership has been feuding bitterly, though indirectly, with Mr. Lynch over drawing new districts to expand the Council and fill 16 new seats this fall. Mr. Lynch has let it be known that he intends to field candidates to challenge incumbents and try to fill the new seats with members more loyal to the Mayor than to Mr. Vallone.
 "Why is Bill Lynch doing this?" one Council aide asked. "He never talks to us."
 But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who wrote the budget memo to city agency heads, said it was intended merely to emphasize that they should not try to negotiate pet programs on their own with Council members, but go through Mr. Lynch, whose portfolio puts him in charge of intergovernmental affairs.
The stakes on the budget are so high that in a recent meeting, some city officials said, Mr. Steisel told commssioners that anyone who tried to make private deals with the Council "will never work on a Dinkins budget again."
 
 No Campaign Intended
 They all insist that it has nothing to do with preparing for any future political campaigns, but two men who ran for governor against Mario M. Cuomo and a third who wanted to are among the founders of a new anti-tax lobbying group.
The organization, known as Change-NY, recently began a direct-mail campaign criticizing Governor Cuomo for proposing more than $1 billion in tax and fee increases this year. It also attacks the Legislature for being more interested in "preserving its privileges, perks and pork than in giving taxpayers a break."
The letter was signed by Lewis E. Lehrman, a businessman who was the Republican-Conservative candidate against Mr. Cuomo in 1982; Herb London, last year's Conservative candidate for Governor, and Evan G. Galbraith, a former Ambassador to France who wanted to run as a Republican against Mr. Cuomo last year but did not meet state residency requirements.
Asked if he saw the group and the letter campaign as a sign of growing anti-tax sentiment, Mr. Cuomo said: "I don't regard it as a movement. Some rich people got together and started a group. They could bail out our budget, these guys."
 
Public-Relations Lesson
 When Gov. Thomas H. Kean first went on the air with tourism ads for New Jersey in 1984, his popularity rating was already 57 percent. Five years later, it had soared to 80 percent.
 A bustling economy and a building boom had a lot to do with it, but the public-relations lesson has not been lost on Gov. Jim Florio, whose popularity has sagged to 20 percent in several polls over the last year since he rammed the largest tax increase in state history through the Legislature.
Now Mr. Florio is poised to go before the cameras within the next week or so, his aides say, also in the name of promoting the Garden State's garden spots.
"New Juhsey and you, puhfect together," became Mr. Kean's trademark, in his purring patrician accent. Mr. Florio's terse, tough-guy inflection is another thing altogether, but at 20 percent there is no place much to go but up.
 
 D'Amato Under Fire

Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is under fire because of a Federal investigation into influence-peddling allegations, has lost the support of a major lobbyist for New York gun owners.
Gerald Preiser, president of the 4,000-member Federation of New York State Rifle and Pistol Clubs, said last week that his group could no longer back Mr. D'Amato because of his recent votes on legislation that could affect gun owners and because of "the sleaze factor."
"It's bye-bye, Al," Mr. Preiser said. He said he would no longer send mailings supporting Mr. D'Amato, a Republican, to the one million names on his list of gun owners and opponents of gun control, and would support whoever the Democratic nominee is.
Mr. D'Amato said in a statement that "What Mr. Preiser chooses to do or support is his business," and that "like most New Yorkers, I support increased penalties for criminals who commit crimes with guns."
 
 What's in a Name?
 It's the loveliest room in New York's City Hall, with its clean white columns and benches that look like pews. But no one can agree what to call it.
It's the old Board of Estimate chamber on the second floor.
But since the United States Supreme Court declared the board unconstitutional and a new City Charter redistributed its powers to the Mayor and City Council in 1989, the room's name has become a political football.
Some official city announcements refer to it as the public hearing room, and some call it the Board of Estimate chamber. So what is it really?
"It's an ideological question," said Kenneth J. Knuckles, the Commissioner of General Services and therefore the landlord of City Hall. But Mr. Knuckles, who sat on the board, said it would "always be the Board of Estimate to me."

HEADLINE: Poor and Illegal, Mexicans Lose Hope in New York

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Beaten down by a dismal economy, Lucas V. left his construction job, a wife and two children in Mexico and ventured to New York in search of the nest egg that would enable him to open a small business back home. After two years of laboring on construction sites for $260 a week, he is no closer to his goal than when he first arrived.
"I think I made a mistake coming here," the trim 30-year-old said one recent afternoon on the sidelines of a soccer match in upper Manhattan, one of his few diversions. "What you earn here stays here." 
 Lucas, who scrapes by without immigration documents or English, is like many in a new wave of Mexican immigrants who have arrived in the New York metropolitan region in recent years. The exact numbers are uncertain, since many are here illegally, but the Mexican Consulate in New York estimated that since the mid-1980's, the number of Mexicans living in the region has grown from about 60,000 to as many as 200,000, with increasing numbers of women and children making the trek north.
While the United States and Mexico are discussing the technicalities of a possible free-trade agreement, the stream of new arrivals in New York City shows a human dimension often overlooked in the economic equation.
"When we talk about globalization, we mostly talk about capital, but it's happening at the level of people," said Saskia Sassen, a professor of urban planning at Columbia who has studied the city's burgeoning Mexican community.
In past decades, the city attracted a small group of Mexican professionals, businessmen and artists. But the most recent migration, which gathered steam about five years ago, is bringing many poorer, mostly illegal Mexican immigrants. Many of them have settled in small pockets in the city's established Hispanic neighborhoods, like East Harlem in Manhattan, the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and the Tremont section of the Bronx.
 
Farming to Dishwashing
 Peasant farmers who once picked vegetables in the fields of Mexico now wash and stack produce at greengrocers or peddle flowers from rickety shopping carts at busy intersections. For others, the journey that began on sun-baked dirt roads in distant corners of Mexico ends with a spray of hot water, washing dishes inside a humid kitchen.
The tales of friends and relatives who returned home sporting new suits and lugging boxes and suitcases bulging with the trappings of North American success have lured them here. But many find themselves underpaid by employers, overcharged by landlords and overrun by neighborhood toughs who see them as easy prey, since their fear of deportation often forces them to endure indignities in silence.
It is a cruel test of faith. "They are carriers of the American Dream in a way those who have been here a long time no longer are," said Ms. Sassen. "They really believe it will work out. But for a growing number, it is not working out."
The most recent Mexican immigrants are unlike earlier waves of Dominicans or Colombians who came to the United States with some money and education. They are coming from some of the poorest regions of Mexico -- the states of Puebla, Oaxaca, Guerrero and the capital, Mexico City, said Robert Smith, a doctoral candidate in political science at Columbia who is writing his dissertation on the new immigrants.
 
Demand for Cheap Labor
 Traditional destinations in the Southwestern United States had become saturated with new migrants -- and also riskier, as immigration authorities cracked down on employers who were hiring illegal immigrants, Mr. Smith said. Cities like New York became attractive, he said, because jobs were plentiful and attention from immigration authorities minimal.
"What happened in the mid- and late 80's was the economic need had become so much worse and the demand for cheap labor in New York found this source, so immigration spread quickly," Mr. Smith said.
Ms. Sassen said the 1986 Federal law imposing penalties on employers who hire undocumented workers also pushed down wages. She said some employers decided that if hiring undocumented workers would put them at risk of fines, they would minimize their losses by hiring the cheapest labor possible.
So the new Mexican immigrants have become the favored source of cheap labor. In some garment factories, workers are getting as little as $2 an hour, while others who make restaurant deliveries work just for tips, Ms. Sassen said.
At a park by the Hudson River in upper Manhattan, Alejandro M. weaves through the crowd with an instant camera, ready to shoot portraits against the backdrop of the Palisades for $4. During the week, he pushes a cart loaded down with a block of ice and jangling bottles of fruit flavors, selling snow cones along Broadway.
 
'They Return Defeated'
 "It's not dignified work, but it's serious," said Alejandro, who like other illegal immigrants interviewed for this article spoke on condition that his last name not be used. On a good day, he can earn $50, which combined with his wife's work at home as a hairdresser helps pay their rent of $500 a month, feed and clothe their two children and perhaps salt away a few dollars.
"We came with the illusion of earning a little money, investing it and doing something in Mexico," he said.
"In any country, those who work can survive. But those who get $180 for working seven days, what can they do? They return defeated to Mexico."
Going back to Mexico is out of the question for Lucila M. and her brothers, Leandro and Eduardo, since their jobs help support their parents and four brothers and sisters in Puebla.
"We came to New York because we are poor farmers and our parents did not have enough resources to send us to school," said Leandro, 26, who earns $200 a week delivering food.
"Here we found work, but nobody pays us," said Lucila, adding that her employers at a garment factory owe her three weeks' back wages.
Lucila, Leandro and Eduardo live with Lucila's two children and three other relatives in a two-bedroom apartment on the Lower East Side, splitting the $380 rent. Though the water sputters out for days at a time, the heat fails often in the winter and the walls have crumbled so badly that her two children have been diagnosed as having lead poisoning, Lucila and her relatives do not complain. "We're scared because if we say anything, the landlady might throw us out," she said.
The fear of arbitrary evictions, dismissal from their jobs and the threat of deportation keeps many illegal immigrants silent.
Alberto L., an 18-year-old factory worker, was robbed recently of $75 as he walked home in the nascent Mexican community on the fringe of the Belmont section of the Bronx. Rather than report the robbery, he borrowed some money until the next pay day.
"I can't go to the police -- I don't have documents," he said. "The police will only add to my problems."
That is a common misconception, immigrants' rights advocates say. An executive order issued during the Koch administration prohibits city agencies from turning over information on immigrants to the Federal authorities unless the person involved committed a crime, said Elizabeth Aivars, director of the Mayor's Office on Immigrant Affairs. But getting that message out has proved difficult.
"Part of the problem of the undocumented is they don't know what rights they have," said Marie Guiardinu, director of Hermandad Hispana, an immigrant-rights group in Manhattan.
She has tried cajoling the flower vendors she sees on the street into coming into her organization's office for help with labor and immigration problems. She considers them among the poorest and most vulnerable of the immigrants, sometimes pooling their meager incomes to rent basement apartments where 10 or more people live huddled together.
But despite her entreaties, they never come in. "I think they are worried about losing whatever they have," she said.
In recent years, the Mexican Consulate has tried to strengthen the handful of nonprofit agencies working with the immigrants, said Jose Antonio Lagunas, the vice consul in charge of the effort. He said he has tried to make city agencies more aware of the problems in the community and is hoping to get volunteers to offer immigrants legal advice.
But many immigrants seek guidance in more familiar settings. La Tejanita, a tiny Mexican grocery, is an unofficial center for Mexicans in the Belmont section. Jose Andon opened the store last year after working in cafeterias and hotels in New York for 23 years.
He knows his newly arrived countrymen can have a hard time surviving in New York, so he helps when he can with clothing or job leads.
"When they arrive in this country, they make you want to cry," he said. Still, he thinks that for those who work hard, some measure of success -- a car, or money for a nicer home in Mexico -- is attainable.
But many immigrants remain adrift, unsure whom to trust for help.
After six months working for a greengrocer who paid him $150 a week -- when he was paid at all -- Guadalupe G. started selling oranges on the streets of upper Manhattan. He can earn $30 a day, enough to feed his wife and three young daughters and pay the $450 rent on a basement apartment.
His oldest daughter, Susana, is 6 years old, but he is afraid to enroll her in school since the family is here illegally. Instead, she and the other children stay at home or scamper nearby as he peels oranges.
He expected life would be hard, and it has gotten tougher with the arrival of more Mexicans. "There are too many for work," he said. "It's filling up here."
Like the others, he had hoped to save money, but has failed. "The reality is, you work here so you won't suffer much, and pay the rent," he said. "At least we're not dying of hunger."

HEADLINE: U.S., Citing Human Rights, Halts Economic Aid to Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has quietly suspended all economic assistance to Yugoslavia, including support in international financial institutions for loans and credits.
In 1952, Yugoslavia, then a maverick Communist country, began receiving large amounts of United States aid to help it continue its defiance of Stalin. In recent years, the Belgrade Government benefited repeatedly from American backing for international loans and credits for its economy. 
 The suspension was begun May 6 under the provisions of a law passed by Congress in November, requiring the United States to end all forms of economic assistance to Yugoslavia and its six constituent republics in six months if it was determined that "a pattern of systematic gross violations of human rights" was occurring there.
In a voice vote last month, the Senate declared that a complete cutoff of aid for Yugoslavia was warranted.
 
'A Big Turning Point'
 The legislation says Yugoslav compliance is to be certified by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. When the deadline arrived, Mr. Baker permitted the sanctions to take effect without declaring a position on the issue.
"This marks a big turning point in our relations with Yugoslavia," an Administration official said. "It really does change our policy."
United States policy toward Yugoslavia for five decades has been to support "the territorial integrity and independence" of the country. On the same day the Administration decided on the aid suspension, Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, when asked about disarray and communal violence in the country, said, "We support a democratic unified Yugoslavia achieved through peaceful dialogue."
The six-month deadline mandated by Congress passed as nationalist turmoil was spreading in the multinational Balkan country, and Mr. Baker decided not to commit himself one way or another on whether the terms of the law had been met. Instead, the State Department press office was instructed simply to say, "No actions that would be prohibited under the legislation will be taken." That meant, in effect, no American economic aid.
 
Possible Effect in I.M.F.
 Although no new assistance programs are under consideration by the United States now, the cutoff could soon have an effect in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, where the United States would, under the law, be compelled to vote no on loans or credits for Yugoslavia.
In a separate measure, the Export-Import Bank is expected to announce next week that it no longer considers the Belgrade Government to be creditworthy, meaning eligible for guarantees for financing exports to Yugoslavia, Government officials said.
As the Congressional deadline on the Yugoslavia issue drew near, some State Department legal advisers said they concluded that the human rights criteria legislated by Congress in this case could be applied to several countries, possibly with disastrous effects on United States foreign relations.
Partly as a result of this conclusion, Mr. Baker determined not to set a precedent by taking a clear-cut position on the Yugoslav human rights matter, State Department officials said. Rather, he chose to let the sanctions go into force for the time being, leaving him the option to say later that Yugoslavia had or had not met the human rights criteria.
The legislation passed last year is an amendment to the Foreign Operations Appropriations Act for the 1991 fiscal year, which ends in September. Called the Nickles Amendment for its principal author, Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, the measure instructs the Administration to oppose any assistance to Yugoslavia proposed in international financial institutions such as the I.M.F. or the World Bank. That could eventually have a crippling effect on Yugoslavia's efforts to reform its battered economy.
The motive behind the Nickles Amendment originally was to find a legislative vehicle for a group of senators and representatives to penalize the government of the Serbian Republic in particular and Yugoslavia in general for the repression of ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo region of Serbia.
 
Albanian-Americans Lobby
 That effort has been spearheaded by Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader. In recent years, Mr. Dole, Republican of Kansas, and other members of Congress have received hundreds of thousands of dollars in political action committee contributions from the Albanian-American lobby. Albanian-American organizations have often called for United States steps against Serbia.
There are about 1.7 million ethnic Albanians in the formerly autonomous province of Kosovo. In recent years, the Serbian government of President Slobodan Milosevic has imposed a form of martial law in Kosovo. More than 90 Albanians have been killed in clashes with Serbian security forces in the last two years.
But Senator Dole and his supporters on this issue found it impossible to single out Serbia, one of Yugoslavia's six constituent republics, in any meaningful legislation. They settled instead in conference with the House for an amendment that would hold Yugoslavia's federal Government responsible for human rights violations in any part of the country.
Since then, however, Yugoslavia has plunged ever deeper into a constitutional crisis, leaving the federal Government virtually paralyzed and the country without an armed forces chief or a head of state.
On April 18, Mr. Dole submitted a resolution to the Senate that said the criteria established in the Nickles Amendment "have not been met by the Yugoslav and Serbian governments." Passed by a voice vote, it singled out Slobodan Milosevic, calling on him "to cease all repressive policies against the Albanian population."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
As Team Owners Consider Designating Two Cities, What Price Expansion?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Is baseball ready for the Miami Vise or perhaps the Denver Sprawl? For the first time since 1977, major league owners are preparing to make room in their elite circle. And in spite of the $95 million initiation fee, they do not want for applicants.
The decision by the owners on which two cities from a group that includes Buffalo, Washington, Denver, Miami, Orlando and St. Petersburg will get the new National League franchises may be made next month. And it is bound to disappoint the also-rans, as well as fans in a dozen other places who lust after big-league baseball teams of their own. But in the view of economists who study sports, the chances of baseball's opening the door much wider are small. 
 The public's interest in expansion, argues James Quirk, an economist formerly at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, conflicts with the interests of established players and owners. Adding even a half-dozen teams would dilute the financial windfall they now divide among themselves. Only a fundamental change in the business would alter baseball's incentive to resist growth. And only Congress is in a position to force change.
 Major league baseball is a shared monopoly, in which the exceptionally high returns to the principals can only be maintained if entry into the business is severely restricted.
Consider the $362 million annual take from national television contracts, roughly one-quarter of major league baseball's income, which is divided evenly among the clubs. Quirk believes that expansion would split the television pie into smaller pieces without guaranteeing any growth in baseball's television audience.
"It is hard to believe that more teams would add much to the national television market,." Quirk said.
Roger Noll an economist at Stanford University who has long tracked baseball's finances, agreed, noting that 80 percent of CBS's $250 million contract represents payment for the broadcast rights to the playoffs and the World Series.
Irwin Stelzer, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, sees other ways in which expansion clubs could dilute the cartel's profits. Those situated near established teams, like the proposed Buffalo or Washington franchises, would be sure to cut into attendance and television audiences in Toronto and Baltimore.
 
No Traditional Rivalries
 New franchises are even likely to reduce the total drawing power of clubs thousands of miles away: Expansion clubs typically generate sparse attendance on the road, both because they play poorly and because there is no historical rivalry to bring out the fans.
Quantifying baseball's potential losses in future income and comparing them with the gain from franchise fees is guesswork. What does seem clear to economists is that relatively few cities could hope to support expansion franchises costing anything close to the $95 million entry fee that major league baseball is charging for this year's expansion franchises.
And as Noll noted, the cities with the best financial prospects are probably the least likely to be offered teams anytime soon. Expansion teams in suburbs of Los Angeles and New York, both lucrative markets, would almost certainly be vetoed by the owners of established franchises.
Free-agent players might imagine some immediate advantage in expansion; it's always nice to have more teams bidding for your services. But the equation of more bidders with fatter paychecks is almost certainly an illusion. While the rare superstar might lend credibility to a new franchise and thus be worth a few extra million dollars, adding many more teams would work against established players' interests because they would dilute major league baseball's total profit.
 If both owners and senior players have good reasons to choke off growth after this round of expansion, what hope is there for fans in cities like Sacramento, Calif., Phoenix, Indianapolis, San Antonio or Charlotte, N.C.?
 Were the Federal antitrust laws applied to baseball, the wish to maximize monopoly profits would not be a legal defense and the major leagues would probably not be able to prevent entry. But the courts, said Gerald Scully, a professor of management at the University of Texas at Dallas and the author of "The Business of Major League Baseball," have always been reluctant to take on the major leagues.
Might Congress rush in where the courts fear to tread? Senators Tim Wirth of Colorado and Connie Mack of Florida have pressed for expansion franchises for their states, using the threat of the antitrust hook as a door opener. But it is hard to find anyone who believes that Congress would be prepared to buck the major league's army of lobbyists and campaign contributors on the question of broader expansion.
Then there's the question of whether the cities that want the new franchises can truly support them. To a large degree the financial fortunes of teams in smaller cities turn on the loyalty of fans, the league standing of the team and the success of management in holding down costs without eviscerating the quality of play.
The three Florida cities in contention for the two new National League franchises -- Miami, Orlando and Tampa Bay -- show the greatest potential. Denver is positioning itself as the Rocky Mountain team, able to capture the loyalty of the entire Mountain time zone. More people live within driving range of Washington, but the franchise would have to compete for fans with the Baltimore Orioles. Buffalo, now home to a successful minor league team, suffers from a small population and its proximity to both Toronto and Cleveland.
However one rates the candidates, the key to their financial viability is television. The new franchises, which will field their first teams in 1993, will not be offered a piece of the current, four-year $1.4 billion contracts for national broadcast rights from CBS and ESPN, which expire that year. But they will no doubt be able to sell local television rights for a hefty sum.
None could hope to come close to the Yankees' deal with the MSG cable network, worth a minimum $36 million annually until the year 2000.

HEADLINE: Say Ouch;
Demands to Fix U.S. Health Care Reach a Crescendo

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE American health care system is the most expensive in the world, but for those not in its mainstream, the care it offers is among the most unsatisfactory. Americans pay $700 billion a year for health care but 34 million of them remain uninsured. Life expectancy in the United States is shorter than in 15 other nations, and infant mortality is worse than in 22 other countries.
Many believe that this is a system in crisis, a crisis marked by sharp contrasts drawn mostly along class lines but permeating every segment of society. Now, after decades of fruitless debate, it has inspired a sense of urgency. In Congress, there have been more than a dozen proposals to revamp the system. And last week the medical establishment, through its leading professional publication, the Journal of the American Medical Association, trumpeted its concern and called for action. While these and other advocates have produced a bewildering diversity of overhaul plans, they agree on at least a couple of things: reforming health care is essentially a political problem; and it will be difficult to solve without leadership from the White House, which so far has had little to say on the issue. 
 A main concern of reformers is that patients' medical needs play so small a role in determining levels of care and reimbursement. Ron Pollack, executive director of Families U.S.A., a nonprofit health reform group, tells of a Maryland couple with full health insurance that has been bankrupted by their son's ailment. A star soccer player by day, the boy suffers near suffocation every night because of a nerve disorder. The family's policy, as most policies do, has an upper limit on some expenses, and theirs -- $100,000 per dependent -- was exceeded when the boy was 11 months old. He is now 10 years old; his family is $600,000 in debt.
For the public, fear is growing. In any two-year period there are 34 million people without health insurance. But the number who lose their insurance at least temporarily is nearly double that many, 63 million.
For businesses, tension is rising. Companies watch as health care spending devours ever larger portions of their profits. In the 1960's, businesses spent about 4 to 8 cents of each dollar of profits on health care. In 1990, it was 25 to 50 cents per dollar and rising.
For labor, anger mounts. The Service Employees International Union reports that the proportion of workers involved in health-care related strikes rose from 18 percent of all strikers in 1986 to 78 percent in 1989.
Enter the doctors. On Wednesday, the American Medical Association, a group usually seen as fiercely opposed to all social reform in medicine, shed its inhibitions. The Journal of the American Medical Association and all of its nine attendant journals were devoted to calls for health care reform. There were no fewer than 13 separate proposed solutions.
The new leadership at the physicians' group made strong statements of new-found fervor for reform.
"The A.M.A.'s old style was to react and be against things," said C. John Tupper, president of the association. "But there has been a philosophical change in our house of delegates," the group's policy-making body. "We will be out front where the action is. We'll stop being just selfish and only thinking of our own welfare. If we start taking good care of our patients, they will take care of us."
He added: "I think we will see health care reform high on the list of both presidential candidates in the next election."
But on the Potomac, when there is too much interest in a subject a political paralysis can result. In Congress there have been no fewer than 14 proposals to revamp the national system. At the White House, there have been no major proposals, as political specialists wait for the right conservative proposal and the right moment -- just before or just after the election -- to put it forward.
Still, there is some optimism in Congress, especially among staff members in Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Committee on Labor and Health, where last fall, for the first time, a huge health care proposal received a favorable vote and was reported out of committee.
A committee aide said the difference is that the Democratic leadership is behind the bill. "It brings many Democrats on board and almost certainly leads to a floor vote," the aide said. "That in turn means people from the different groups have to come in to start cutting deals. Let me not mislead you. It will be a tough fight. If it weren't hard, we would have passed reform 20 years ago like every other industrialized country did."
Senator Kennedy, who along with Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine is an author of the leadership bill, said on Friday that Congress "has been slow to respond, and so has the Administration."
"More and more businesses, labor unions, hospitals and doctors understand that something must be done, Mr. Kennedy said. "We are closer to enacting real reform today than at any time since Medicare was enacted in 1965."
In the House, the Democratic majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, has asked committee chairmen to put together a broader proposal that could be accepted by many of the interested parties.
Congressional staff members believe there are at least two ways the politics might work. If enough momentum can be gained to pass some major legislation or several smaller bills in this Congress, the result will likely be a proposal that requires employers to give insurance to employees or pay some amount into a pool to cover all those now uninsured. President Bush would likely veto such a plan because it puts too great a burden on businesses.
Others believe that if it appeared that Congress would produce a proposal that might pass, the President might feel obliged to have his own proposal and work for a compromise.
When the Administration came forth with its first proposal of any kind on health care reform last week, a plan to curb the costs of malpractice, it was met with a negative chorus from Capitol Hill. One Congressional staff member called it "laughable," because it addressed such a narrow part of the problem, and did so two years after similar proposals were made in Congress.
While not all Bush Administration officials want to get involved in the issue, among those pressing for a plan are Richard G. Darman, the Budget Director, and Secretary of Health and Human Services Louis W. Sullivan. But generally the attitude is wait and see.
"We're not neglecting the issue," a White House official said. "But we would rather have a good proposal than a quick one. There are two questions here. One about the timing and one about what kind of proposal would be the one we would want to put forward. It is true that this has traditionally been viewed as a Democratic issue, that Republicans can only lose. And we don't want to be leading with our chins by putting out a proposal that will fail or can't work."
One possibility is to put forward a plan in the months just before the election so that the President can come into office with a mandate to put his proposal into action. Somewhat more likely right now is that no major proposal, or package of minor proposals, will be forthcoming until after the election.
An official at the Department of Health and Human Services said, "We simply don't have a consensus now in the country on what should be done, even though we all agree something must be done."
The trouble in any case is money. The simplest reform idea, for a national health service akin to Canada's, is almost universally pronounced dead because it is too great a change for politicians to accomplish, at least in one stroke. All other proposals require major taxes or shifts of tax burden in society. Many liberals propose plans that require employers to pay for insurance for employees; many conservatives propose plans that require individuals to buy their own coverage with tax credits after new health taxes are levied.
In a worried economy, any such programs will meet with resistance, so prognosticators in both the Administration and Congress say that while momentum for reform will probably continue, no major action is likely until the end of 1992, or in the new Congress beginning in 1993. But no one now doubts that it will come.

LENGTH: 979 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Glimpsing the Future, The Red Army Frets

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
THE American military successes in the gulf war seem to hold a clear message for the Soviet high command: a professional army with exotic electronic weaponry can make mince-meat of a massive land force of conscripts and tanks. Indeed, Soviet marshals have been quick to seize on the demonstration of the West's high-tech muscle to call for a tune-up in their air defenses and, not surprisingly, to argue for more money.
"What happened in Kuwait and Iraq necessitates a review of the attitude towards army air defenses and the country's entire air defense system," declared Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov shortly after the war's end. "When we ask ourselves, did it work in Iraq, we have to answer, mostly it did not. And then we ask, why not?" 
 Soon after the war broke out, the military set up a special group to answer questions like that, and in March the General Staff conducted a conference to assess the war's implications. In purely military terms, the issues seemed straightforward, and they suggested that the Kremlin would do well to go ahead with the much-discussed shift to an all-volunteer army and to reconsider its presumption that a war would involve defending against a huge ground invasion. Last week, the Supreme Soviet passed a bill creating an experimental volunteer unit in the Navy.
The gulf war also raised questions about the doctrines limiting the military to strictly defensive measures. The allies' effectiveness in neutralizing Iraqi defenses, Soviet military analysts have argued, showed that an army cannot wait passively for an attack. Accordingly, Soviet statements now talk of a strategy of "adequate response."
What this will eventually mean in practical terms, however, probably depends less on the analyses of the gulf war or recommendations of military experts than on the complex mess in which the Soviet Union finds itself.
Of all Soviet institutions, the military probably faces the most profound challenge from the collapse of the Stalinist model. For one thing, the Soviet economy simply cannot continue to shovel exorbitant resources at the military, and there is no way a democratic government would allow this.
 
An Exorbitant Cost
 The real cost of the military is still something of a mystery, but no one denies that it consumes a ridiculous portion of the national wealth. According to various official figures, the military absorbed 40 percent of the machinery output, 50 percent of the Russian Federation's industrial output, 40 percent of the national budget, 18 percent of the gross national product. Thus the problem, as Georgy Arbatov, head of the U.S.A. Institute, wrote, goes beyond military organization: "Both the reduction of armed forces and the conversion of the defense industry have become less of a military and political problem than a social one: In our supermilitarized society, they are threatening the interests of hundreds of thousands, even millions, of military personnel and employees in the military industry and defense research."
There is also an institutional reluctance in the military -- common to any bureaucracy and exacerbated in time of economic crisis -- to surrender any of its possessions, even if they are acknowledged as superfluous. Marshal Yazov inadvertently gave voice to this anxiety in a recent interview: "They ask us, do you really need the tanks right now? No, we can do without new tanks for three or four years. But what do we do with the factories? With the working class? Dismiss the workers? In four years' time they'll convert the plant to produce something else, and in five years we'll go to them and say, 'Comrades, make us some tanks; ours have reached the end of their service life.' "
Soviet generals are proving equally reluctant to shed the enormous political and social role the military played in the old order. Since Stalin, the vast military-industrial complex and the conscript army have been a fundamental lever of state power, used to indoctrinate every Soviet man in ideology and discipline, and to extend control throughout the empire.
Initially, Marshal Yazov and the Chief of Staff, Mikhail Moiseyev -- who is in Washington this week for talks on conventional arms reduction -- were viewed as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's hand-picked partners in reform. But as with so many carryovers from the pre-Gorbachev era -- not least Mr. Gorbachev himself -- they have had second thoughts.
 
The Enemy Within

The withdrawal from Eastern Europe and Afghanistan, collapse of the Warsaw Pact, shrinking budgets, abuse from newly vocal critics, criticism over domestic bloodshed, increases in defections, revelations of brutality in the ranks, demise of ideology and general disintegration of Soviet society -- all this has led men like Marshal Yazov and General Moiseyev to voice open revulsion for the fruits of liberalization. "Things have reached the point where the October anniversary is not observed as a national holiday in some places," Marshal Yazov groused in the interview, referring to Revolution Day, "and neither is Soviet Army Day."
That sort of talk points to another reality, that after spending their lives bracing to defend "socialism," the military -- and the K.G.B. and the rest of the ideological apparatus set up by the Communists -- realized that the enemy was not out there, but within, in the yearning for democracy and the failure of Communism.
Such thoughts are bound to have effects as the military command ponders its future and the lessons of the gulf war. On the theoretical side, it may be clear that an elite high-tech force is the way of the future. But that would also mean a different role for the military in Soviet society, a retreat from its central role in the ideological and social spheres. For old soldiers sworn to defend socialism, the choice may not be obvious.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Task: Slip Spies Into the New World Order

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF confirmed by the Senate as the Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates may well take the United States intelligence "community" through its most important transition since President Harry Truman set the structure for America's bureaucracy of spies in 1947.
Despite the best efforts by the departing director, William H. Webster, to define a new role for the spy agencies he has supervised since the death of William J. Casey in 1987, the farflung American intelligence apparatus remains in search of enemies and threats to justify not just its $30 billion budget, but its very existence. 
 Saddam Hussein and the Persian Gulf war provided a respite from the "What-are-we-about?" debate that has seized the nation's intelligence agencies since the Berlin wall came down. But President Bush's nomination of Mr. Gates last week abruptly returned the spotlight to the intelligence agenda, which is anything but in order.
Both the House and Senate oversight committees are warning that if the new C.I.A. director does not bring discipline to intelligence spending and cut duplication between military and civilian agencies, they will force changes by legislation. Mr. Gates is viewed as a forceful bureaucrat with C.I.A. and White House training who will seek to pre-empt the intelligence committees by making his own changes. But any major restructuring will meet formidable institutional resistance.
"My concern about the new director," said the House Intelligence Committee chairman, Dave McCurdy, "is that he be willing to take on the bureaucracy and the culture in order to bring about the necessary changes and have a much broader focus for intelligence."
One of the changes both committees are considering could strip away the broad mandate the C.I.A. head currently has to direct the entire intelligence community, leaving him to run only his agency, and create a director of national intelligence to be the President's intelligence czar.
Aside from the C.I.A., the "community" includes the National Reconnaissance Office, which is in charge of imagery satellites; the National Security Agency, which is in charge of signal interception; the Defense Intelligence Agency, the Pentagon's analytical arm, and an assortment of military intelligence services.
Whatever changes are wrought by Mr. Gates or the oversight committees, the C.I.A. and its sister agencies appear to be headed for a period of budgetary decline. "There are actually greater requirements for sophisticated intelligence than ever before," said Mr. McCurdy, "but they are going to have to be accomplished with fewer resources."
 
Shrinking Threats
 In the same pattern as the Pentagon's $300 billion budget, more than half of the dollars spent for intelligence collection and analysis over the last four decades have been targeted at the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies. With that threat gone, American intelligence czars have yet to answer the questions about what they are going to do in the next century.
To be sure, there will be drug trafficking to combat, terrorism to counter and third world brush-fire wars to monitor, but these problems pale against the overarching military threat the Soviet Union once posed -- although some monitoring of Soviet strategic and conventional forces will be necessary for years to come.
With a fleet of high-technology reconnaissance satellites, scores of aircraft, submarines, underwater sensors, mountaintop listening posts, legions of spies and analysts, the intelligence agencies live in an insular and well-funded world, issuing reports on worldwide trends and events, but driven less and less by the engines of East-West competition.
Many experts believe the problems of the future, such as economic collapse in the third world, ethnic and regional conflict, environmental degradation and population control, will be readily apparent. The challenge will be more to understand what is visible than to ferret out what is hidden.
Today, and increasingly in the future, large parts of the multibillion dollar intelligence programs are destined to suffer the crisis of justification that has befallen the B-2 Stealth Bomber, a weapon built to penetrate Soviet air space during nuclear war but now seeking a new mission in a safer world.
An intelligence parallel is the National Security Agency, with 27,000 employees and an annual budget of $4 billon. Behind the high security fences at its headquarters in Ft. Meade, Md., one of N.S.A.'s largest single activities is collating, interpreting and breaking the codes of Soviet communications, radar signals, telemetry and computer data intercepted by $1 billion-plus satellites or by squadrons of spy planes. Billions of dollars have been spent for the banks of supercomputers the agency uses to run programs that decode what Soviet political leaders and military commanders are saying to each other.
Is this agency ripe for cutting? "Yes," said Bobby Ray Inman, a former N.S.A. director and now a member of the President's intelligence advisory board.
"But before you start reorganizing, you need to decide what you want to know about the outside world and you need to look ten years out and not five," he said. "We will have almost no concerns about military activity in Eastern Europe, but we will be vastly more interested in internal stability, economic and political developments. It's not that we are going to be doing vastly less, but we're going to be doing it in the open."
One former intelligence officer observed that more could be learned today about the implosion of the Soviet empire by openly sending American cultural attaches to each of the Soviet Republics than by recruiting networks of spies to dig out secret data.
"I think American intelligence needs to have a better feel for the societies in which they operate overseas," said Graham Fuller, a former Middle East analyst for the C.I.A. "It isn't just the collection of secrets that helps the agency predict events, it's getting our fingers on the pulse of society. That's not secret, it's just hard to find out."
For all the billions of dollars sunk into intelligence systems in the last decade, the intelligence community has a mixed record on spotting trouble. In the national security review Mr. Bush conducted in early 1989, C.I.A. analysts predicted: "War weary Iraq will pose a military threat to small neighboring states during this period, but will be reluctant to engage in foreign military adventures. It is more likely to resort to diplomacy and subversion to achieve its goals." By March 1990, the agency was saying that the Iraqi leader might undertake a new military campaign in the region after three more years of recuperation from its war with Iran.
Even Mr. Gates, who built his reputation as a C.I.A. analyst with well-grounded predictive powers, was confidently forecasting in January 1989 that the Afghan leader, Najibullah, would not last through the summer after the Soviet army's pullout. Yet Najibullah still dominates Kabul two years later and has confounded American policy in Afghanistan.
These and other examples demonstrate that the intelligence business is a very expensive game of informed assessments and predictions in which truth is often the most elusive product. The question is, said the Senate Intelligence Committee chairman, David Boren, in recent hearings, how much should the United States pay for it?
As Mr. Gates heads for what may be a grueling series of confirmation hearings, he will have to be concerned not just about the price, but how, in a rapidly changing world, to find the product.
