HEADLINE: The Everyday Disaster of Life in Bangladesh

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh

 BODY:
A CYCLONE in the south, flooding in the north, and tornadoes in the center. Those are the latest natural disasters in a country that is often regarded, by Bangladeshis and foreign aid workers alike, as bountiful primarily in misfortune.
"No country has got a worse natural and environmental deal than Bangladesh," The Dhaka Courier said in an editorial this month. "One must seriously consider whether there is a curse on this land or not." 
 To be sure, even for the poorest Bangladeshis, lives are less miserable than they used to be. The economy is growing, and there is generally more ethnic, religious and linguistic harmony than in India and other countries in the region. Even the terrible floods are a blessing of sorts, for they irrigate and fertilize the land.
But the 8,000 American troops who arrived a few days ago to help with cyclone relief efforts seem struck mostly by the scenes of wretchedness: babies dying of diarrhea, ragged children begging in the streets, destitute families huddled in shanties and forced to use any bit of open ground as their toilet. They are found not only among the cyclone victims but routinely throughout the country. The cyclone was merely a spectacular addition to a misery that is endemic.
When the American military assistance for Kurds is completed, many of the Kurds may be able to return to their homes and resume normal lives. But when American troops leave Bangladesh, the people will continue to die in appalling numbers.
The cyclone captured international attention by killing some 139,000 people, an official count that could be way off in either direction. But each year, even without a cyclone, more than 260,000 children under the age of 5 die of nothing more than diarrhea. Respiratory infections kill another 157,000 each year, and even measles takes the lives of more than 60,000 children.
Inevitably, death by natural disaster catches the eye more than death by diarrhea, and Bangladesh's geographical location insures plenty of catastrophes.
"It's very unlucky," says Charles H. Larsimont, the resident representative of the United Nations Development Program. "When you're in a configuration like this, where big rivers lead to a flood plain, then that causes a big mess every once in a while."
In addition to the flooding from the north and west, Bangladesh faces cyclones from the south and east. Poor communications and government mismanagement sometimes compound the disasters in Bangladesh by slowing the relief efforts and allowing people to die afterward of hunger or illness.
With the floods and cyclones, Bangladesh has faced a series of calamities: the 1970 cyclone killed some 300,000 to 500,000 people, the war for independence in 1971 claimed an immense number of lives variously estimated from several hundred thousand to several million, and then there was a famine in 1974, and periodic floods and cyclones ever since.
In a richer country, the weather would not be so lethal, but population pressures have obliged people to live in thatched huts on any clump of land that rises above the sea, accepting the risk of drowning as preferable to the risk of starvation.
These population pressures will get far worse. The population, now 118 million, is growing by about 2.5 percent a year and by some forecasts will reach 219 million by the year 2025 -- in a country that is the size of Wisconsin.
The Government encourages family planning, and the birth control pill and injectable contraceptives are free, while condoms are available at a subsidized price equivalent to one-eighth of a penny each. One-third of Bangladeshi couples now use contraceptives, and population experts see some hope that the population growth will eventually be controlled.
But in other important areas, the situation may be deteriorating. Most important, the literacy rate is only 24 percent and has been dropping in recent years. The education system is in disarray, and one-third of children of elementary school age are not enrolled.
In some respects, Bangladesh resembles countries like China before their Communist revolutions. Not only is it poor -- per capita income is $170 a year -- but social inequities are overwhelming, with homeless beggars sharing streets with tycoons riding in imported cars. There is a substantial class of peasants without property, who must till the soil of others.
Yet while socialist rhetoric has had some resonance here, Communists have never made many inroads in Bangladesh. A prime reason may be that 84 percent of the people are Muslims and disapprove of Communist assertions of athiesm. In any case, Bangladesh now has a democratic government and a tolerance for free expression that may allow steam to be released without challenging the system directly.
There is also a measure of hope that life will improve. Real economic growth has averaged between 3 percent and 4 percent in recent years -- a modest increment above the population growth rate -- and Bangladesh has improved its infrastructure and built up an impressive garment export industry.
Some foreign development experts and diplomats, and more Bangladeshis, cite these achievements to voice a cautious optimism for the country. They note that headlines about disasters tend to obscure the country's progress. This year, for example, there may well be a record rice harvest, despite the cyclone, and Bangladesh will be nearly self-sufficient in food.
A Western diplomat cited several strengths of the country: a resilient people, absence of major communal violence or secessionist warfare, the presence of an educated group of technocrats, a brand of Islam that is relatively pragmatic and is not anti-Western, and a widespread desire for stability and political dialogue.
"There is a lot more going on here than just disasters," he said.

HEADLINE: The World;
Castro Reopens The Gate To Exodus

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
LAST summer, when a few dozen Cubans sought to flee by taking refuge in Havana's foreign embassies, an uncompromising President Fidel Castro defused one of the most delicate crises he has faced in recent years, vowing that not a single asylum seeker would be allowed to leave the island.
But with Cuba's moribund economy unravelling faster than its Communist leadership can devise reforms, a sharp reversal in Mr. Castro's tactics has set off a wave of Cuban emigration that is becoming a sensitive challenge for the United States as well. 
 The Cuban Government's new strategy, including steep reductions in age minimums for exit visas needed to leave the country legally and a relaxation of once-aggressive efforts to police the island's shores against escapees, has spurred a sudden rush toward the United States. Many say the initial reaction of Cubans recalls the prelude to the 1980 Mariel boatlift, when a similar burst of asylum-seekers led to the hectic exodus of 125,000 people.
In recent months, as basic goods from soap to razors to fish to fruit have disappeared from Cuban shelves, the number of refugees trying to reach South Florida by perilous sea journey aboard inner tubes and makeshift rafts has jumped dramatically. While summer, with its calm seas, has normally been the preferred season for such journeys, well over 600 Cubans have already been rescued this year by the United States Coast Guard, a record.
At the same time, according to the State Department, visa applications at the United States Interests Section in Havana, where one officer processes all requests, have also been increasing at a record rate. So far this year, 25,000 non-immigrant visas have already been issued in Havana, compared with 34,000 for all of last year. "We have a backlog of about 30,000 applications sitting in boxes that we haven't even opened yet," said one United States official.
 
Many Will Stay
 Immigration officials say they have no way of knowing how many Cubans decide to stay in the United States after arriving with non-immigrant visas. Cubans are automatically eligible for legal residency after a six-month stay in the United States, and as conditions worsen in Cuba, the percentage of those availing themselves of this privilege is thought to be rising.
While officials in Washington acknowledge discussions on the matter between the State Department, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Coast Guard, they declined to provide any details of possible responses to further steep rises in the numbers of Cuban boat refugees. Noting reports that Havana would soon lower its exit visa age minimum to 18, from 35 for men, one official said only, "Our policy is the same worldwide, and each case's merits will be adjudicated on an individual basis."
While Washington issues coolly worded statements of principle, experts in hemispheric affairs say that any surge in attempts by Cubans to take refuge in the United States will present American policymakers with a nettlesome tangle of political and diplomatic questions.
 
'A No-Win Situation'
 "This is a clear case of a no-win situation for the United States," said Gillian Gunn, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "Whichever way the Government responds, there will be real liabilities."
Ms. Gunn and other Cuba watchers say another wave of Cuban immigration to this country would open the Administration to criticism from conservatives and from Havana's staunchest Cuban-American foes that it is helping rescue Mr. Castro's Communist system from terminal decline.
Moreover, these analysts say, special measures to open the United States' doors wider for Cubans fleeing a sharp deterioration in their living standards would draw charges of inconsistency from countries like El Salvador and Haiti, whose citizens have enjoyed no favors while fleeing arguably harsher circumstances.
Cuban affairs experts argue, meanwhile, that if the United States maintains its current policies, Mr. Castro will attempt to blame the United States for the deaths at sea and the frustrations of Cubans unable to travel to this country.
"If all we do is keep rescuing people at sea, we will have a crisis in the making," said Jorge I. Dominguez, a political scientist who studies Cuban affairs at Harvard. "We are signalling to ordinary Cubans that it is all right for them to come this way."
Other pressure to accommodate fleeing Cubans is likely to come from the Cuban-American community, which could use its influence within Florida and the Republican Party to demand emergency relief.
Even on this issue, however, Cuban-Americans, who number about one million people, are as deeply ambivalent as anyone. Some groups have already begun to call for all those fleeing Cuba to be treated as human rights cases, immediately eligible for residence, while others, anxious to precipitate Mr. Castro's fall, urge more caution. Hard-liners say that Mr. Castro has already encouraged large-scale emigration from Cuba three times during his reign, to relieve social pressures and purge the island of its most disaffected citizens. To take in more Cubans now, they say, would only help him maintain control.
A growing number of Cuba experts say that the debate over the immigration issue misses the point of the potentially explosive change facing a country whose 32-year Communist system is in steep decline.
"Unless they can make the necessary changes toward a mixed economy we could see a very bloody process that would leave both countries in real trouble," said Wayne Smith, the former chief American diplomat in Havana and the director of Cuban Studies at Johns Hopkins University. "If we don't want to see a huge number of people coming to the United States from Cuba, then what we should be working for is a peaceful transition."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Dinkins's Nightmare Budget Gains A Frightening Air of Plausibility

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
JUST a week after Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed a New York City budget so grim that he called it a worst-case warning, it seemed the worst might really come to pass.
Mr. Dinkins's hopes for avoiding the harshest of $2 billion in spending cuts to balance the $29 billion budget got a setback when one of the angels he'd counted on, Felix G. Rohatyn, had his wings clipped. 
Mr. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up to borrow money on the city's behalf in the last fiscal crisis, said he could not proceed with plans to give the city $1 billion over the next four years by refinancing the corporation's bonds. The Standard & Poor's credit rating agency had warned him that this might let the city paper over its problems and would cause a lowering of the city's bond rating.
Since a downgrade would make it harder and more costly for the city to borrow money in the credit markets -- the very problem MAC was created to avoid -- Mr. Rohatyn said it was a risk he could not take and the corporation's help would have to wait. That left the municipal unions, from whom Mr. Dinkins has been seeking wage and benefit concessions, saying they'd have to wait and see, too.
So the City Council, six weeks before the start of the new fiscal year, is left with the budget Mr. Dinkins gave it. That would mean thousands of layoffs, dirtier streets, darkened streetlamps and closed health clinics, pharmacies and homeless shelters.
"I think that the worst-case scenario is clearly going to be a worst case," said the Council's finance chairman, Herbert E. Berman of Brooklyn. "You can't create any false expectations. There's an inability to do anything dramatic."
That sounded less sanguine than the pledge of the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a week earlier to spare the city some of the nearly $1 billion in proposed taxes and avert the worst of Mr. Dinkins's threatened cuts, which would be a neat trick in the best of times. But Mr. Berman insisted: "I do think we can hold down taxes. I think we can look at reordering priorities."
 
Left in the Lurch
 The week's developments left Mr. Dinkins in the lurch, too, since he had proposed cutting many programs dear to him as a way of prodding the unions, Mr. Rohatyn and the state to help. Now he risks having some of those cuts accepted by the Council and being blamed for them. "I can't believe that this is the set of cuts he would have chosen if he thought he'd have to carry them out," said a state official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Many city officials viewed Mr. Rohatyn's setback as transitory. Wall Street may downgrade the city's bonds in any event, they say. Then, even after a budget full of cuts is passed, Mr. Rohatyn could be free to go ahead and help the city by refinancing some of the Assistance Corporation's bonds. The money could then be used as a reserve to help the city in the event of even further downturns in the economy.
"In some strange ways, I think this makes it even more certain," said a senior mayoral aide, who asked not be identified, referring to the eventuality of the corporation helping.
The contretemps pointed up again the reality that the strict controls imposed on the city after the crisis of the mid-1970's -- which force it to balance its budget precisely and adjust it perpetually -- compel it to make cuts in services from sanitation to parks that other cities would seldom be forced to consider.
And because of the city's consuming need to maintain access to the public credit markets -- to finance the cost of building the roads and bridges and schools and jails it needs -- a handful of analysts and experts on Wall Street hold powerful sway over its priorities, even while insisting it is not their job to tell the Mayor what to cut.
 
Staying on Planet Earth
 One of the rating agencies' main objections to help from Mr. Rohatyn was that it would be a nonrecurring revenue. But Mr. Dinkins, noting that it would come over four years, wondered to reporters just how long a revenue must flow to be continuing.
"You know, 'recurring' is a question of definitions," Mr. Dinkins said. "How often need it appear to be recurring? Four years is not enough? Maybe it's six or seven."
The Mayor, confronted with a checklist of tactics for balancing the budget that one group or another considers verboten -- from higher taxes to deeper cuts to one-shot revenues -- has sometimes wavered in his rhetoric, forswearing each by turns, but unable to forswear all of them.
For example, while looking askance at "one-shots," he accepted a private, one-time donation from a charitable foundation to keep the city's 32 swimming pools open for part of the summer, though private donations are not generally the sort of one-shots fiscal monitors frown on. Or as Roger Altman, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and one of his financial advisers, put it, "When people say no one-shots, I ask them what planet they're on."
By law, Mr. Dinkins's feet must stay planted firmly on the earth of a balanced budget. But just as it seemed the challenges could hardly rise higher around him, they rose again.
"Sometimes I feel as if we're in the last half of the fourth game of the World Series, and the news is filled each night with player profiles, scores and instant replays," the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, told a civic group on Friday. "The bookies are making a fortune, and I'm up to bat. This is the World Series all right. But the game isn't baseball. It's the survival and supremacy of our city that is at stake."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Oil Facts and Follies

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

 BODY:
Certain facts pack a thermonuclear bang. Consider this one: Before the end of the decade, the Soviet Union -- the world's largest oil producer -- will become a net importer of oil.
 That future fact could explode most of America's most vital national security objectives. It means virtually no hope for economic development and democracy in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. And it guarantees massive dependence on volatile Persian Gulf states, the only producers capable of filling the shortfall. 
 Top Bush Administration officials, Soviet leaders and oil experts everywhere are well aware of the situation. But few are doing anything about it. Inaction, when much can be done quickly, amounts to reckless irresponsibility.
Here are the facts as understood by oil experts, and laid bare again last week by Yevgeni Khartukov, a senior Soviet energy official:
 Soviet oil output, without market reforms and Western help, will decline from 11.5 million barrels daily in 1990 to possibly 9 million by 2000. Net exports, which totaled 3 million barrels daily in 1990, will fall to zero by 1994 or sooner. By the end of the decade, Moscow will run a net deficit of about 2 million barrels daily, assuming present rates of Soviet domestic consumption. The plus to minus turnaround could be 5 million barrels per day in this pessimistic but realistic scenario.
 Oil exports represent 40 to 60 percent of Soviet hard currency earnings. Their loss plus the new bill for oil imports would wipe out Moscow's hard currency reserves and sharply reduce funds to buy essential Western goods. Efforts at economic reform almost certainly would collapse. Moscow could turn to selling more arms to make up the cash deficit, but that is the last thing the West would want. It is hard to imagine fragile democratic roots surviving in such dire economic circumstances.
 Declining Soviet oil output also would create upward pressures on world oil prices. The effects on Eastern Europe (not to speak of all developing countries) would be immediate and devastating. These economies would tumble, with fatal repercussions on democratic movements.
 Meantime, U.S. oil production has declined by 2 million barrels daily since 1986, and consumption continues to rise here and around the world. By the end of the century, the world shortfall could be 7 to 9 million barrels daily. That gap could be closed easily by the gulf states. But no leader of an industrialized nation would wish for that state of affairs for painfully obvious reasons.
 To avert the fallout of declining Soviet oil production, first steps are up to Soviet leaders. They have to clear the mine field of restrictive laws and practices that seriously retard joint ventures with eager Western oil companies. For example, The Petroleum Intelligence Weekly will report the breakdown of critical negotiations between Chevron and Moscow, largely because of conflicts between the Moscow bureaucracy and the Azerbaijan republic.
 Next steps belong to Western oil conglomerates. They cannot be too greedy. Reportedly, Chevron was demanding all export profits from the proposed joint venture. Industrialized governments have to help by approving technology exports. Desperately needed new equipment can be put in place rapidly, thus halting the slide in Soviet oil production and exports.
 Finally, Americans have to stop behaving like infants and act in their clear self-interest. President Bush's energy policy is laughable in its inattention to conservation and its unwillingness to entertain a high gas tax. So say many of his own experts, especially in light of the Soviet situation.
 This would not be the first time that the Soviet and Russian oil industry has had decisive effects on the world market. In the late 1870's, Imperial Russia's entry into oil trade broke Standard Oil's monopoly on the world market. In the late 1920's, Soviet dumping of exports prompted major oil companies to counter with a cartel. Similar Soviet dumping in 1960 led even more dramatically to the formation of OPEC.
 The coming Soviet-induced oil crisis will be far more threatening to goals held most dear by Soviet reformers and American leaders. Solutions are well within their power if only they would focus on the thermonuclear fact staring them in the face.

HEADLINE: A Sampling of Expeditions

BYLINE: By NANCY SHARKEY

 BODY:
ECOTOURISM is the travel buzzword of the 90's. Dozens of nonprofit environmental groups are vigorously working to preserve natural areas and selling field excursions to their members. And a new crop of environmental entrepeneurs -- scientists, professors, former Peace Corps workers and tour operators -- has begun capitalizing on the interests of a generation raised on Rachel Carson and Jacques-Yves Cousteau.
The destinations selected by these organizations tend to be clustered in developing countries, in Central and South America, Africa, Asia and the South Pacific, where vast tracts of pristine land are home to endangered animals, rare birds, and exotic plants and trees. But worthy tours are also offered in the United States, the Caribbean and Hawaii. 
 This listing highlights 20 of the 500 or so organizations whose trips are marketed as evironmental travel. It is not all-inclusive; many smaller companies have tours with regional focuses, like the Rain Forest Alliance, a New York-based group with trips to Brazil, and Baja Expeditions of San Diego, known for its whale-watching trips. And virtually every trekking company can claim to follow one of the key tenets of ecotourism: take nothing from the land; leave only your footprints.
These companies are divided into nonprofit organizations, many of whom subcontract with private operators and add their own specialists as guides, and private operators who, conversely, are beginning to found and finance their own nonprofit research organizations in the areas they visit. Some of the nonprofit trips have an added appeal: tax deductions. Earthwatch, for example, says its trips are virtually entirely deductible.
A sample tour for each company is listed. These were selected for geographic range and diversity. Prices are for one person, based on double occupancy, and unless otherwise specified include all meals, lodging, local transportation and guides.
 
NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY
DISCOVERY TOURS
Central Park West at 79th Street, New York, N.Y. 10024
800-462-8687 or 212-769-5700
The largest natural history institution in the world, the museum has been conducting study tours since 1953 and attracts about 1,100 participants a year. Proceeds benefit the museum, whose exhibits attract three million visitors a year. Trips may be more expensive than those with identical itineraries offered by private companies, but they are led by teams of museum scientists. The museum offers 14 cruises, ranging from Scandinavia to Melanesia, and nine tours in Hawaii, Africa, India, Central America and Mexico. Special Expeditions (720 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019; 800-762-0003) is the main operator for the cruises.
 
Jungle Rivers of South America
 A cruise on Special Expeditions' 84-passenger Polaris on the Amazon and the Orinoco with a stop at Devils Island. On board will be four scientists: Ross MacPhee, curator of the mammalogy department; Robert Carneiro, curator of the anthropology department; Roger Pasquier, a former member of the ornithology department who is now director of foundations at the Environmental Defense Fund, and Carl Ferraris, a research associate in the herpetology and ichthyology department.
Cost: $5,200 to $8,420, depending on cabin. Includes 14 nights aboard ship and one night in Ciudad Guayana, Venezuela, on the Orinoco River. Air fare extra.
Dates: Oct. 6 to 21, 1991.
 
CORNELL ADULT UNIVERSITY
626 Thurston Avenue, Ithaca, N.Y. 14850
607-255-6260
 Founded in 1968, this twofold program offers natural history workshops at Cornell's campus during the summer and two dozen expeditions of varying lengths year round, all led by Cornell professors. The programs, designed by the university's professors and the adult university, range from New Zealand treks to insect-study in upstate New York. Group size 25 to 80, with larger groups led by several professors or Cornell associates.

Assateague Ornithology and Ecology
A two-night field study on the 9,900-acre Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge on Assateague Island, Va., home to 262 species of birds, as well as the sika deer and the wild ponies of Chincoteague. Led by four naturalists.
Cost: $410, excluding air fare.
Date: Oct. 3 to 6.
 
EARTHWATCH
680 Mount Auburn Street, Post Office Box 403-N, Watertown, Mass. 02272
617-926-8200
With its hands-on environmental agenda, Earthwatch was founded in 1971 to preserve fragile lands, monitor change and conserve endangered species. Its scientific expeditions draw about 3,500 people a year who are willing to work on their vacation. Members have supported nearly 2,000 projects throughout the world and contributed $17 million to scientific research. This year, Earthwatch offers 120 projects, primarily in the United States, Central America, the Caribbean and Europe. The range of programs is wide, from tracking timber wolves and counting the humpback whale population off Mozambique to exploring ancient civilizations in Europe and Africa. Volunteers sign up for a week or two; some projects have as few as three teams, others go year round.
 
Canary Island Sea Life
The goal is to assess whether island tourism can be encouraged without endangering fragile marine environments. Team members who are divers make one or two dives a day to depths of 60 feet, recording algae growth, counting fish and looking at habitats. Nondivers document life in tidepools and intertidal areas. The research is led by James Van Tassell of the American Museum of Natural History, Dr. Steve Bortone of the University of West Florida and Dr. Alberto Drito Hernandez of the University of La Laguna in the Canary Islands.
Cost: $1,295 for the 12-night stay, including accommodations in apartments and some restaurant meals but excluding air fare to Las Palmas in the Canary Islands.
Dates: July 10 to 23, July 25 to Aug. 7 and Aug. 9 to 22.
 
FOUNDATION FOR FIELD RESEARCH
Post Office Box 2010, Alpine, Calif. 91903
619-445-9264
Founded in 1982 as a matching service between scientific researchers and volunteer assistants, the foundation supports projects in anthropology, oceanography, archeology, botany and biology. Volunteers are both expedition members and a financing source. Accommodations are Spartan; work is hard. The number of volunteers on a team ranges from 5 to 25, with an average of 10. Programs range from protecting leatherback turtles in Michoacan, Mexico, to examining agricultural problems caused by protected prairie dogs in Missouri. The foundation's current offering of 38 programs travels mostly to Mexico and the Western United States, but also to Grenada, Wales, Mali, Liberia, Micronesia and British Columbia. The foundation says that an average of 76 percent of the program cost goes directly into the field for research. The remainder is for advertising, tour planning and administration.
 
Creating a National Park in Mali
In the southwest of Mali, the Government has established a reservation, the first step to protecting the region. Scientists, led by a Senegalese researcher, are conducting a census of animal life, including baboons, buffalo and chimpanzees, which will help set boundaries for a national park. The study will also involve an anthropologist analyzing the park's impact on local communities.
Project cost: $1,672 with housing in tents, with field kitchen, shower and latrine. Excludes air fare to Mali.
Dates: Two-week periods from Feb. 10, 1992, to May 2, 1992.
 
NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY TRAVEL PROGRAMS
950 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022
212-546-9140
Like the American Museum of Natural History, the society enriches existing tours and cruises with its own experts. The society offers natural history cruises on Special Expeditions ships in the Pacific Northwest, the Amazon (the Amazon-Orinoco cruise begins the day after the museum's cruise ends), Greenland, Iceland and the North Atlantic, and the Hudson River and Chesapeake Bay aboard Clipper Cruise Line's 100-passenger Nantucket Clipper.
 
Cruise Beyond the North Cape of Norway
From Spitsbergen to Bergen on Special Expeditions' 84-passenger Polaris, through the Arctic habitat of the reindeer, polar bears, tusked walruses and giant colonies of sea birds. Leading the trip will be Jean Porter, director of operations at Audubon's National Environmental Education Center in Greenwich, Conn. Special Expeditions provides on-board naturalists.
Cost: $5,615 to $8,835, depending on cabin location. Includes lodging, meals, excursions and lectures; excludes transportation to and from Oslo.
Dates: July 8 to 24 (cruise starts July 11).
 
NATURE CONSERVANCY INTERNATIONAL PROGRAM
1815 North Lynn Street, Arlington, Va. 22209
703-247-3720
Helping to preserve fragile areas by buying land in North America, or helping local groups abroad who make the acquisition, the conservancy protects the world's largest private reserve system, consisting of 5.5 million acres in 50 states and Canada in 1,200 individual preserves. In addition, a vigorous Latin American program has protected 25 million acres in Belize, Bolivia, Costa Rica and other countries. The international travel program, begun four years ago, sends about 400 people a year to Central and South America. Part of their payment includes $300 for an emergency land-protection fund. The trips are packaged by International Expeditions, Geostar Travel and Society Expeditions and use two guides: a Nature Conservancy escort and an in-country naturalist. The average group size is 15.
 
Argentine Pampas
A 14-night tour to the Punta Rosa Biological Station to see migratory bird species, the Patagonia region and the Magellan penguin colony at Punto Tombo, the Valdes Peninsula (with its elephant seals) and Argentina's Glacier National Park, where participants cruise along the Upsala Glacier, then sail to Tierra del Fuego and Beagle Channel.
Cost: $3,598, including air fare from Miami, contribution to the conservancy, accommodations in lodges and hotels, meals and a cruise.
Date: Oct. 20 to Nov. 3.
 
OCEANIC SOCIETY EXPEDITIONS
Fort Mason Center, Building E, San Francisco, Calif. 94123
415-441-1106 or 800-326-7491
Founded in 1972, the society designs its own programs, supporting research and further conservation with proceeds and donations. The organization recently merged with Friends of the Earth, an environmental advocacy group. More than half the trips focus on sea coasts and oceans, with whale watching, dolphin research, shore bird photography and marine mammals. The society's naturalists and marine biologists are on hand for the trips. Group size is limited to about 15.
 
Bahamas Dolphin Research
Swimming with wild Atlantic spotted dolphins off Grand Bahama, where researchers are studing the family and social structure of the mammals. The seven-night trip includes six days of swimming with the dolphins, photographing them and recording behavior. Led by marine biologists doing field work.
Cost: $1,250, including hotel, meals and transportation on the sailboat Jennifer Marie to or from Grand Bahama.
 Dates: Departures from Fort Lauderdale on May 26, June 13, July 1, July 19, Aug. 6 and Aug. 24 and from West End, Grand Bahama, on June 3, June 21, July 9, July 27 and Aug. 14.
 
SIERRA CLUB OUTING DEPARTMENT
730 Polk Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94109
415-923-5630
The organization founded by a group of private citizens to preserve California wilderness begins its centennial year this month. The club has 600,000 members and attracts about 5,000 travelers a year for its programs. Almost 90 percent of the trips are domestic, with many in national parks. A large number are active vacations, with hiking, biking, cross-country skiing and river rafting featured. The travel program reflects the grass-roots philosophy of the organization: tour leaders design their own trips and itineraries, while the San Francisco office coordinates them.
While leaders often have scientific backgrounds, their fields may not be directly related to their tour. An American chemistry professor who lives half the year in Nepal, for example, leads the trek to see blooming rhododendrons in the Annapurna Sanctuary every March. Groups are usually no more than 15.
 
Rajasthan Desert Kingdoms
A 17-day tour in India from New Delhi to Jaipur, Bikaner, Jaisalmer, Jodphur and Udaipur, with a three-night camel safari in the Thar Desert. The Sierra Club catalogue specifies that the club is opposing development of the Sardar Sarovar Dam Project, which is expected to cause deforestation and wildlife depletion in Rajasthan.
Cost: $2,360 for 12 to 15 participants; $2,610 for 11 or fewer. Price includes meals and accommodations in hotels, sightseeing tours, train trips and transfers, safari and all meals. Excluded is airfare to New Delhi.
Dates: Sept. 14 to Oct. 2
 
SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION NATIONAL ASSOCIATE PROGRAM STUDY TOURS AND SEMINARS
1100 Jefferson Drive, S.W., Washington, D.C. 20560
202-357-4700
The Smithsonian, like the American Museum of Natural History and the Audubon Society, contracts with private operators to offer tours but adds Smithsonian lecturers. Of the 150 study tours offered, half are domestic and half international. The majority are academic -- with topics like Rembrandt's art in the Netherlands to the literature of Ireland to projecting global air power, a study program at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio. But the Smithsonian has begun offering research expeditions both to natural areas like Costa Rica, where an active volcano is being monitored, and to cultural events, such as the Crow Indian fair in Montana.
 
Colorado Rockies Natural History
Families stay at the Nature Place in Florissant, Colo., an environmental education center on 6,000 acres, ranging from desert to alpine life. Ten learning centers include a working cattle ranch, a sawmill and a restored 1880's homestead. Accommodations are in a studio apartment with loft. The staff includes university professors and naturalists who lead families on nature walks that focus on all aspects of the various life zones.
Cost: $850 ($1,150 in single occupancy); $560 for children 7 to 15. Includes lodging and group meals; excludes air fare to Colorado Springs, Colo.
Dates: July 20 to 26, 1991
 
WORLD WILDLIFE FUND MEMBERSHIP TRAVEL PROGRAM
1250 24th Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20037
202-293-4800
With one million members in the United States, the World Wildlife Fund, and its partner the Conservation Foundation, works to preserve tropical forests in Latin America, Asia and Africa. The organization also works with local residents to help improve living standards, thereby confronting root causes of threats to nature. In Annapurna, for example, the fund has helped set up a program that combines habitat protection with sustainable development in forestry, agriculture and tourism. The fund commissioned the major study to date of ecotourism's potential effect on developing countries.
 
Thailand and Nepal Expedition
A 19-night expedition through Thailand and Nepal, including the Khao Yai National Park, home of the elusive forest elephant, islands in the Andaman Sea, a cruise on the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok for the annual festival of Lights, and a trip to one of the fund's Thai projects, a rural community development program. The group then flies to Katmandu, takes elephant ride in Royal Chitwan Park and hikes in the Annapurna Conservation Area. Group size limit: 18.
Cost: $6,275, including air fare from Seattle.
Dates: Nov. 19 to Dec. 8, 1991.
 
PRIVATE OPERATORS
 
ABERCROMBIE & KENT AND SOCIETY EXPEDITIONS
1520 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 69521
800-323-7308 or 708-954-2944
A luxury tour operator, Abercrombie & Kent started offering safaris in Africa 29 years ago. The company's owners, Geoffrey and Jorie Butler Kent, founded a nonprofit organization, the Friends of Conservation, which helps preserve land and assists the Kenya Wildlife Service, headed by Dr. Richard Leakey, in a variety of programs -- from providing vehicles for antipoaching patrols to relocating and providing veterinary care for endangered rhinoceroses. About half the company's business is to Africa and the Galapagos for nature tours. The company offers 15 itineraries in Africa with 300 scheduled departures a year. Maximum group size averages 16. The company has 26 departures a year to the Galapagos, with maximum group size of 18 to 20.
Abercrombie & Kent also markets Society Expeditions cruises. The company, based in Seattle, was founded in 1974 with a cruise to Easter Island that helped restoration of the giant Maoi statues there. About 85 cruises are scheduled next year on 45 itineraries to Indonesia, the Amazon, the Cook Islands, Easter Island, Greenland and Hudson Bay, the Indian Ocean and Antarctica. The company's three vessels range in capacity from 98 to 160 passengers. Some of its cruises are operated in collaboration with nonprofit academic and environmental organizations.
 
Tanzania-Kenya Tent Safari
A 14-night Abercrombie & Kent safari that includes game watching at Ngorongoro, Serengeti National Park and the Masai Mara, where the Friends of Conservation has undertaken a community conservation project to help ease conflicts between the tourism industry, interested in preserving wildlife, and the adjacent landowners, under increasing pressure to lease land to ranchers for grazing. Accommodations are in luxury campgrounds with local guides.
Cost: $6,470 from June 1 to 30 and from Nov. 1 to Dec. 14; $6,990 the rest of the year, including all meals, transportation in Land Rovers, guides and lodging. Excluded is air fare from New York, estimated at $1,800.
Dates: Departures on June 5, June 12, July 3, July 10, July 31, Aug. 7, Sept. 4, Sept. 11, Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 16, Oct. 23, Dec. 11 and Dec. 18.
 
ECOTOUR EXPEDITIONS
39 Mount Pleasant Street, Suite 2, Post Office Box 1066, Cambridge, Mass. 02238
800-688-1822 or, within Massachusetts, 617-876-5817.
Founded by an American lumber exporter in Brazil who did an about-face two years ago and decided to help prevent deforestation instead, this small company conducts tours in three regions of South America: Amazonia, Matto Grosso, site of the vast savannah known as the Pantanal, and Ecuador, with its wildly varied terrain. Guides are scientists and naturalists who lead excursions into remote areas of the Amazon jungle, sometimes as far as 200 miles from Manaus. On a recent Ecuadorian night trek at night, the escort, a herpetologist, identified 25 different kinds of frogs in the rain forest. Average group size is 6 to 8, with a maximum of 12.
 
Igapo Flooded Forest
An 11-night expedition that includes seven days' travel on the Negro River in Brazil from its confluence with the Amazon to the Rio Branco. The trip stops at small inlets and streams in rarely visited areas, with nature hikes on shore and nightly ecology discussions. Participants sleep on board the expedition vessel (six cabins with three shared bathrooms) and have opportunities to camp on shore. The trip ends in Manaus.
Cost: $1,750, including accommodations, meals and tours.
Dates: Aug. 14 to 25.
 
GEO EXPEDITIONS
Post Office Box 3656, Sonora, Calif. 95370
800-351-5041 or 209-532-0152
This nine-year-old company was started by a geographer who wanted to offer educational tours with a wildlife focus, Geo offers East African safaris and Galapagos tours, with a few additional trips in Asia and Australia, for a total of about 30 trips a year with 50 departures. Group size is limited to 15 on African trips, 10 on Galapagos trips.
 
Kenya and Tanzania Wildlife Safari
Led by experts in animal behavior, this 19-night safari avoids the overcrowded Amboseli park and goes instead to the alpine highlands of the Aberdares, the Samburu, home of the reticulated giraffe; Lake Nakuru and the Masai Mara in the Serengeti and continues into Tanzania, ending at Ngorongoro Crater. Transportation in Landcruisers, with lodging in tents large enough to stand up in.
Cost: $3,870, including $380 in Tanzania park fees, meals, transportation and accommodations; air fare from New York, add about $2,000.
Dates: July 3 to 23, Aug. 7 to 27, Oct. 9 to 29.
 
INTERNATIONAL EXPEDITIONS
1 Environs Park, Helena, Ala. 35080
800-633-4734 or 205-428-1700
Founded in 1980 by a research scientist with a doctorate in biological sciences, International Expeditions focuses on rain-forest expeditions in Ecuador, Costa Rica, Belize, the Peruvian Amazon and Venezuela, but also offers safaris in Africa, a cruise and river raft trip in Alaska and visits to parks and wildlife refuges in Australia, India, Thailand, Malaysia, Nepal and China. Trips are accompanied by members of the International Expeditions staff of experts in botany, zoology and archeology. Average group size is 15, depending on destination.
The company has founded a nonprofit center in Peru, near Iquitos, on previously imperiled land. The 4,400-acre site was set aside as forever-wild land by the Peruvian Government, and the new nonprofit center, called the Amazon Center for Environmental Education and Research, provides a research station for scientists and a headquarters for visitors. The center, near Iquitos, Peru, was founded with $60,000 raised in March from a rain-forest workshop that drew 150 participants and 20 scientists and naturalists representing the World Wildlife Fund, the Smithsonian Institution and the Nature Conservancy. Plans for the site, called the Amazon Biosphere Reserve, call for expansion to 100,000 acres in the next year. The center will be supported by proceeds from International Expedition trips to the center.
 
Naturalist Tour of Belize
A 10-night trip from Belize City covering wildlife refuges for Howler monkeys, birds, a boat trip down the Macal River, Rio Frio Cave, botanical walk in the jungle, the jungle at Tikal and its ruins and a snorkeling trip off Ambergris Caye, the huge barrier reef off Belize.
Cost: $1,998, including air fare from Miami, hotel accommodations (one, the Tikal Inn, has no electricity and no hot water, however), meals, transfers, excursions and permits.
 Dates: Departures on May 17, June 7, July 19, Aug. 9, Oct. 18, Nov. 1, Nov. 22, Dec. 6, Dec. 16, Dec. 18, Dec. 20, Dec. 22 and Dec. 26.
 
JOURNEYS
4011 Jackson Road, Ann Arbor, Mich. 48103
800-255-8735 or 313-665-4407
Founded by a former Peace Corps volunteer with a doctorate in natural resources, the company's focus is to support environmental conservation with adventure travel. While some of the trips are strictly adventure in focus, some profits -- about $50 a trekker -- are turned over to a nonprofit corporation, the Earth Preservation Fund, that supports local environmental programs in Zimbabwe, Botswana, Nepal and other places on the company's itinerary. Among the projects funded by this nonprofit arm are school construction, bridges, restoration of a monastery, seed distribution and solar heating projects. The solar project attempts to provide a cheap alternative power source to Nepalese, thereby preventing deforestation for firewood (the chief energy supply for more than 90 percent of the people). The company also has a community forestry project near Sirendanda, Nepal, in which trekkers help plant trees from a Katmandu nursery.
Journeys has about 25 itineraries, with 150 departures a year. The average group size is 6 to 8, with a maximum of 12. Local guides accompany participants. Accommodation on most trips is in tents.
Tree-Planting Trek in Nepal
This 20-day expedition initiates the Journeys forestry program each year. Trekkers bring seedlings and agricultural and forestry materials from Katmandu to the nursery at Sirendanda, the site of a Buddhist monastery. The trek is timed to coincide with Buddha's birthday and accompanying festivities. The trip departs from Katmandu for a nine-day trek along the ridge east of Annapurna in the rhododendron forests of Baudha Himalaya. Six days are spent at Sirendanda.
Cost: About $1,500 a person. A two-day whitewater raft trip to Royal Chitwan National Park and two days in the park can be added for about $400. Estimated air fare from New York to Katmandu: $2,000.
Dates: Next April.
 
MOUNTAIN TRAVEL-SOBEK
6420 Fairmount Avenue, El Cerrito, Calif. 94530
800-227-2384 or 415-527-8100
Two of the leading adventure travel companies are in the process of merging. Mountain Travel got its start in trekking, Sobek in river rafting. While adventure travel remains the primary purpose of both organizations, they offer environmental programs as well, with trips to the Amazon rain forest and to Prince William Sound to observe the after-effects of the Valdez oil spill. Sobek's founder, Richard Bangs, has been active in publicizing the shrinking of the Aral Sea in the Soviet Union, caused by diversion of rivers feeding it. Mr. Bangs, who started his career as a guide on the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon, launched a rafting business in 1973, taking it to African rivers. From there, it expanded to other great rivers, and in the late 1970's the company began to include trekking, climbing, biking and other activity vacations. Today the company offers 125 different itineraries, about 20 percent of which are river trips, with more than 1,000 departures a year.
Mountain Travel's extensive itinerary includes both strenuous climbing trips and easier hikes. Begun in 1967 to take advantage of the growing interest in trekking -- its first trip was to Nepal -- the company has expanded into softer adventure trips, focusing on wildlife and natural history. The company now has 125 different itineraries and about 400 departures a year to Asia, Africa, Europe and South America, with a few programs in North America, Australia and Indonesia.
Environmental Challenge in the Ukraine
On this Sobek trip, participants will explore Ukrainian villages and the Carpathian mountains, while learning about environmental devastation from nuclear and coal projects and industrial waste. The trip will be escorted by Kristin Suokko, a Soviet expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council. Trip includes stays in Moscow, Kiev and Odessa, with a four-day bicycling tour of the Carpathians. The trip does not go into the devastated Chernobyl area, because of the continuing radiation danger.
Cost: $2,490, including a $250 donation to the N.D.R.C., local transportation, lodging in hotels and campsites and meals. Excludes air fare to Moscow. Maximum group size is 15.
Date: Aug. 4 to 17.
 
NATURE EXPEDITIONS INTERNATIONAL
474 Willamette, Post Office Box 11496, Eugene, Ore. 97440
800-869-0639 or 503-484-6529
Founded by a pair of science professors in Palo Alto, Calif., the company grew out of a series of armchair lectures on natural history. Gradually, demand for field trips increased, and the company expanded to a full-fledged itinerary of expeditions and safaris in Africa, Asia, South America, Australia, the South Pacific and Alaska, Hawaii and the Southwest. Leaders, who all have college-level teaching experience, give informal evening lectures and daily interpretive sessions along the trail. The company sends out 30 to 50 tours a year, with a maximum group size of 8 to 12 participants.
 
Easter Island Expedition
A 13-night journey with 10 days on the island and three in Santiago, Chile. Led by Sergio Rapu, director of archeological investigations and a former Governor of Easter Island, and an ethnologist. Mr. Rapu was raised on the island and is a doctoral candidate at the University of Hawaii. Tour focuses on the giant statues of Easter Island but also visits digs and restorations throughout the islands. Evening lectures cover culture and anthropology, flora and fauna and archeological research
Cost: $1,990, including accommodations in hotels, all meals and lectures, but excluding air fare.
Dates: Departures June 23, Oct. 6 and Dec. 15.
 
QUESTERS TOURS AND TRAVEL
257 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10010
800-468-8668 or 212-673-3120
Questers was founded in 1973 by a naturalist-book publisher and an employee of a tour operator, who consulted naturalists to devise itineraries. Their goal was to offer trips in search of the natural world. "Our own curiosity about earth's life forms and their ecology -- and our conviction that nature-oriented tourism could aid the cause of conservation -- spurred us on," their current catalog says. The company now offers 34 tours in 30 countries, with 104 departures a year. Maximum group size is 20. Staff naturalists accompany the groups.
 
Alaska Natural History
A comprehensive 16-night tour from Juneau to Anchorage that includes a catamaran ride in Glacier Bay, nature walks, a visit to Denali National Park, the Seward Peninsula, a chartered plane ride over the Kiglauk and Kougarok Mountains and Bering Strait and a float plane trip to Katmai National Park. Limited to 20 participants.
Cost: $5,800, including accommodations in hotels, meals, entrance fees and air fare from Seattle.
Dates: Departs June 16, July 7 and Aug. 11.
 
 
SALEN LINDBLAD CRUISING
333 Ludlow Street, Post Office Box 120076, Stamford, Conn. 06912
800-223-5688 or 203-967-2900
The company, started in 1982 by the son of a Swedish sea captain, is best known in environmental circles for its 164-passenger Frontier Spirit, a nonpolluting vessel with an onboard sewage treatment device, trash compactors, refrigerators for storing garbage, an oil separator in the bilge to prevent accidental spills and onboard recycling bins. Salen Lindblad, like other private operators, has its own nonprofit arm, called the Oceanites Foundation, an educational organization to foster marine preservation. The company offers trips, with about 55 departures a year, into ecologically sensitive areas like Antarctica, the Arctic, the Indian Ocean, Indonesia and the Amazon. Lindblad's other vessel is the Caledonian Star.
 
Northwest Passage
A 30-night voyage from the Aleutian Islands through the Northwest Passage of Canada and onto Greenland. Zodiac landing craft take passengers to view such wildlife as polar bears, whales, walruses, caribou and puffins. Onboard naturalists act as guides. The ship has an ice-breaking hull that enables it to make the journey.
Cost: $17,500, including meals, excursions and lectures.
Dates: Aug. 18 to Sept. 16.
 
VICTOR EMANUEL NATURE TOURS
Post Office Box 33008, Austin, Tex. 78764
800-328-8368 or 512-328-5221
The leading tour operator for birders, Victor Emanuel founded the company bearing his name 17 years ago and now offers 100 birding and natural history tours around the world. Leaders include well-known ornithologists and naturalists; Roger Tory Peterson is one of the company's directors. Group size ranges from 8 to 16, with 150 departures a year in an equal mix of international and domestic itineraries. The company donates part of the tour fee to half a dozen specific projects in regions visited, and it estimates that 70 to 80 percent of foreign tours directly benefit local economies. For example, Victor Emanuel's donkey tender at El Triunfo reserve in southern Mexico used to be a subsistence farmer, deforesting the very area he is not benefitting from. On the King Ranch tour in south Texas, $50 of the tour fee of eachvisitor goes to Caesar Kleberg Wildlife Institute, winter home of the endangered whooping crane. Only 200 are left.
 
El Triunfo
An eight-night tour from Mexico City to the cloud forest set in the high mountains of southern Mexico, the El Triunfo journey is more active than most of Victor Emanuel's offerings. Pack animals carry gear; participants hike to the valley in a three-day ascent that covers 20 miles. The habitat includes 40-foot ferns, enormous trees and a chorus of bird life that includes the rare azure-rumped tanager.
Cost: Estimated at $1,850. Excludes air fare.
Date: March 21, 1992.
 
IF YOU PLAN A TOUR
Here are some questions to ask before signing up for an ecotour.
1. How large are the tour groups and what is the ratio of tour guide to traveler? (More than 20 to 1 is considered undesirable.)
2. Does the company make an effort to protect the environment by using low-impact forms of transportation like canoes instead of ships or horses instead of buses? What are the sources of fire wood? Is waste disposed of in an environmentally sound manner?
3. Do trained naturalists accompany the group?
4. Does part of the cost of the trip go to a local conservation project?
5. Does the trip employ local guides, use locally owned lodges or in some other way insure that the economic benefits of the tour help the community?
6. For nonprofit groups, does the company design its own tours or hire a private tour operator and add its own experts as guides? -- E. W.

A listing last week of companies offering environmental travel vacations characterized the relationship between Salen Lindblad Cruising and the Oceanites Foundation incorrectly. The foundation is an independent nonprofit organization; it is not owned or operated by Salen Lindblad.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Green Machine

BYLINE: By RACHEL POWELL

 BODY:
Baby boomers who spent much of the 1980's tending their bank accounts now seem to be turning to more organic pursuits: growing flowers, trees and vegetables.
"They're cocooning, spending more time at home," said a pleased Harris Ashton, chief executive of the General Host Corporation, which owns Frank's Nursery and Crafts, the nation's largest lawn and garden retail chain. 
 With the boomers and other greenthumbers out in force these spring growing days, Mr. Ashton is counting on General Host to grow with them. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., expects sales of $550 million in fiscal 1991, up from $515 million for 1990. Besides Frank's, the company owns Calloway's, an 11-store chain in the Dallas area.
For the industry as a whole, sales reached almost $21 billion in 1990, from $16 billion in 1989, according to the National Gardening Association, a nonprofit group of gardening enthusiasts based in Burlington, Vt.
Demographics are perhaps the most compelling reason for the increase, along with heightened environmental concerns. The recession has even helped, experts say. Some people are sprucing up their yards to shore up sagging home values; others are discovering that gardening can be a relatively inexpensive form of entertainment.
General Host bought Frank's in 1983, when the chain had $63 million in sales. Since then, Frank's has grown to 280 stores, from 99, while adopting a supermarket look, complete with bright lights and shopping carts. This makes the stores less threatening to the novice than the traditional nursery, said Mr. Ashton, who is 59 and has been head of General Host since 1970.
Though aficionados might not buy their plants at Frank's, preferring the wider and more exotic selection offered by independent retailers, Mr. Ashton said they will still come in for more mundane supplies, like hoses, because prices are lower.
Frank's "made a conscious effort to have good selection and good quality," said Bruce Butterfield, research director of the National Gardening Association.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the "Making a Difference" column last Sunday about the General Host Corporation included an erroneous sales figure supplied by the company for its lawn and garden chain, Frank's Nursery and Crafts. In 1983, the year it was acquired by General Host, Frank's had sales of $150 million, not $63 million.

HEADLINE: 5 Massachusetts Towns Continue a Tradition of Tax Rebellions

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHELBURNE, Mass.

 BODY:
The hill towns of western Massachusetts have a long history of independent mindedness, going back to 1786, when a band of impoverished farmers took pitchforks and guns and headed down from the hills to protest high taxes. The insurrection, known as Shays' Rebellion for its leader, Daniel Shays, was ultimately put down.
But as Massachusetts's financial crisis deepens, another rebellion is brewing in these hills. Five towns recently voted not to pay off two loans for school projects. 
 The action may jeopardize their ability to take out future loans, but the residents, pressed by growing numbers of students in their schools and expensive state-mandated programs, said they had no choice.
 
'An Outright Insurrection'
 "What you are seeing out here is a populist form of spontaneous combustion," said David Newell, business manager of the Mohawk Trail Regional School District, which is at the center of the rebellion. "These people aren't kidding. They've had it. Unless something changes, I think you are going to see something verging on an outright insurrection."
The Mohawk school district is made up of eight towns. Five of them, Ashfield, Buckland, Charlemont, Colrain and Shelburne, have voted to default on the loans. One town, Hawley, voted not to default. The other two, Heath and Plainfield, have scheduled votes for next month. All eight towns share a high school, and several of them share grammar schools.
One loan is for $285,000, which the towns of Buckland and Shelburne used to repair the roof of an elementary school. Town officials say that when they applied for the loan in 1987, the state told them that 75 percent of it would be reimbursed when money became available. So far, the state has not given the towns any money. The next payment is due in August.
The other loan is for $230,000, which all eight towns took out to pay for construction of an access ramp for the handicapped at the high school. The next payment on that loan is due next April, and the state has partly reimbursed the towns for its share of the costs.
It is not unusual, especially in this time of recession in New England, for cities and towns to be in financial straits. Massachusetts has been especially hard hit.
Last Thursday, the State House Ways and Means Committee approved a $12.8 billion budget that includes a reduction of $480 million in aid to the state's 351 cities and towns. Under that plan, about a third of the state's communities, mostly rural and suburban towns, would receive little or no state assistance in the coming fiscal year.
But the plan, which ran into immediate bipartisan opposition, is now expected to be scrapped.
Some cities and towns are considering making up for the cuts in state aid by voting to override the state's 2.5 percent limit on property tax increases.
But in poor rural towns like Shelburne, where the unemployment rate is 17.5 percent, town officials say a big tax increase is out of the question. Half the residents make less than $10,500 a year per capita. Thousands of dollars in debt, many of the small dairy farmers have closed their barns.
So far, reaction to the votes to default has been mixed. Those who see the default as a desperate protest say it will make the state realize the severity of the cuts. Others, including bond rating officials, say it may only damage the credit-worthiness of the towns.
"If this is a problem with the state, it could cause us to look again at what's going on there," said Richard P. Larkin, a managing director at the Standard and Poor's Corporation, a bond rating agency in New York.
The BB bond rating of Massachusetts is already the lowest rating of any state, and Wall Street has threatened to downgrade the state's securities to "junk bond" status.
"But if they are doing this for a protest, an action like this could hurt them for a long time to come," said Mr. Larkin.
For the five towns, the lesson of Shays' Rebellion is a double-edged one. In 1787, the insurgents were crushed by an army hastily raised by the governor. But the Legislature later met some of their demands for tax relief.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about five towns' refusal to repay the State of Massachusetts for school repair and construction loans misstated the state's bond rating. The Standard & Poor's Corporation rates Massachusetts bonds BBB, not BB. The BBB category reflects an "adequate capacity to pay interest and repay principle," in Standard & Poor's words; BB is considered "speculative."

Recently, five towns there voted not to pay off two loans for school projects. (Illustration by Howard Pyle from "Book of a the American Nation")

HEADLINE: Business Diary: May 12-17

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A Giant Killer Stumbles and Takes a Big Fall
 

Joseph R. Canion, president of the Compaq Computer Corporation, has to be more careful when he speaks. Last week, before the company's annual meeting, he predicted that Compaq's earnings would be down 79 percent this quarter. The analysts did not have to run those numbers through their laptops. The market value of the stock tumbled by $1.2 billion on the news. Share prices fell from $49.25 to $36. It finished the week at 35.75. Back in 1982, when Mr. Canion started the company, it was the giant killer. But inexpensive computers, some with more features, ate into its market share. Inventories built up. Last April, Compaq was forced to cut prices, which hurt profits, and Mr. Canion sold 20 percent of his stock, which hurt morale. Compaq announced that it will buy back up to 10 million shares of its stock. Good for the stock, but what about the company? Compaq should invest in high-end products, analysts say.

Putting a Price on T.W.A.'s Debt
 
Trans World Airlines missed several payments on its $1.2 billion in debt, and now its creditors are threatening to repossess 10 airplanes and dozens of engines. That would cripple the airline. Carl C. Icahn, who owns T.W.A., wants to keep it in the air, so he is offering his creditors a deal. Mr. Icahn is willing to buy back T.W.A.'s debt, but at a deep discount -- 17.5 cents to 73 cents on the dollar, depending of what they hold. Not bad, he says, since some T.W.A. paper is trading at just 15 cents on the dollar. The creditors are understandably angry. But Mr. Icahn has leverage. He can put the airline under the protection of Chapter 11. Or, since he sold his stock in the USX Corporation last week for $1.02 billion, he could buy T.W.A.'s debt at full price.
 
School Construction at a Profit?
 
The man who brought advertising into the classroom now wants to build schools -- 200 of them beginning in 1996. Christopher Whittle, chairman of Whittle Communications Inc., in Knoxville, Tenn., expects his schools to make a profit, but he vows not to line the hallways with billboards. He wants to blend technology with traditional methods, all for $4,300 per pupil a year -- about the national average. To build the schools, Mr. Whittle still needs to raise $2.5 billion to $3 billion. Education Secretary Lamar Alexander sits on the company's board, but Mr. Whittle claims he does not want government money. However, he will accept payment vouchers, as proposed by the Bush Administration, if that program ever gets off the ground.
 
S&L Properties by the Bundle
 
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolutution Trust Corporation, figured it would take 300 years to sell off all the properties remaining from the savings and loan bailout. So he came up with a plan: Bundle the properties together, sell them to big developers and let the buyers pay the government out of earnings. Congress wants cash.

Buying Loyalty from Viewers
 
People used to watch CBS voluntarily. Now they need to be paid off. The network unveiled a plan last week to build viewer loyalty that is based on the frequent flyer programs of the airlines. The more you watch, the more you win, said CBS. But the network's experience with buying viewers with promotions has been almost as bad as the airlines'. Shoppers who see the CBS promotions at K-Mart stores are still going home to watch reruns on cable TV.
 
The End of a Fight
 
They fought for 10 weeks, taking out advertisements in newspapers around the country, but in the end they made a deal. France's Groupe Schneider S.A., the giant electrical equipment company, acquired the Square D Company for $2.23 billion. Square D makes electrical controls for factories and the home market. So does Schneider. With the acquisition, Schneider will become the world's largest producer of electrical control products, with more than 30 percent of the American market. In the dim days of the past -- before the Reagan and Bush Administrations, that is -- that much concentration might have raised an eyebrow at the Justice Department. But Justice has given the deal a nod.
 
A Costly Way to Increase Sales
 
The Saturn Corporation is trying desperately to run rings around its competition with better service and a better car. It is the General Motors Corporation's import fighter.When it mistakenly put the wrong coolant into the engines of 1,100 Saturn cars, it decided to replace the cars at no cost. A pretty good deal. But last week, G.M. said it will count each of the cars it replaces as a new-car sale. With sales like that, how long can the Saturn last?
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY


Housing Starts Rise Sharply . . .
 
The housing industry is sending signals that the end of the slump is near. The first three months were erratic, with sharp ups and downs. But April, the Commerce Department said last week, was a relief, especially for the nation's home builders. Housing starts climbed by 6.2 percent, quite a nice jump. "The way recoveries begin is with an upturn in housing," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Does this upturn say the recession is nearing its end? "Growth by the end of the year could be a positive 3.5 percent," he said.
 
. . . as Consumer Prices Inch Up
 
Consumer prices crept up, but only by a smidgeon. They rose by 0.2 percent in April, according to the Labor Department. "Commodity prices are falling, and prices are rising mainly in the services," said Kevin Logan, chief economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. Medical services were up. So were personal and educational services like college and private school tuition. Health club memberships cost more, too. A concern, yes, but nothing that the economy cannot sustain. "My overall outlook is for a decline in the rate of inflation," he said.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Defender of the Mark Resigns
 
Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, has a line in its charter saying it must defend the mark. Karl Otto Pohl,who said that he will resign in October as the bank's president, did that job well. The mark never varied as Europe's strongest currency during his 10-year tenure. But lately Mr. Pohl has despaired. The economic merger between the two Germanys is a disaster -- his word. Economists agree. "Since the merger, there has been no true price stability." said Carl Weinberg of High Frequency Economics in New York. "I give Hans Tietmeyer, who's on the bank council, 70 percent odds of getting the job."
 
Burning Renoirs and van Goghs?
 
Last week the badly slumping art market received a jolt. Ryoei Saito, the Japanese industrialist who controls Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Company, said his paintings would be cremated with him when he dies. Mr. Saito owns van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet," which he bought for $82.5 million last year, and "At the Moulin de la Galette" by Renoir. Having the paintings burned would cut inheritance taxes, Mr. Saito said. When the art world gasped, Mr. Saito reconsidered. Maybe the masterpieces would go into storage.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Business Diary column on May 19 describing CBS's efforts to attract viewers referred incorrectly to a promotional plan, based on airlines' frequent flyer programs, that would reward customers for watching more CBS programming. The promotional idea was one of many considered by the company, but has not been carried out.

LENGTH: 1069 words

HEADLINE: The Region;
Leading The Sacred Cow Of Rent Control To Slaughter?

 BODY:
FOR 44 years, New York City's system of rent-control laws, which affect more than a million apartments, has been politically unassailable. But as the city's economic problems deepen, and a rising rental vacancy rate chews at the law's legal foundation, some of the city's leaders have begun to think about ending controls on some higher-priced apartments in order to save the rest of the law.
 "That is an option, in myopinion, that has got to be loked at," said Archie Spigner, the Queens Democrat who heads the City Council's housing committee, and who helped renew the law for three years last month. "It can't be dismissed." 
 Mr. Spigner was reacting to the likelihood that the vacancy rate in the rental apartment market may already have passed 5 percent, the legal threshold that signals an end to the city's housing-availability crisis - and to rent regulations.
 Earlier this month, the city's largest landlord group sued the city to end the rent rules, citing the city's inability to take the legally required steps toprove the law was needed.
 Although the vacancy rate was only 2.47 percent in 1987, when the last triennial vacancy survey was made, the trend has been steadilyupward since then. Although no one knows how many apartments have become vacant in the interval, the rate over the last 10 years has risen with the addition of more than 100,000 new dwellin units - most of them higher-priced apartments. In the current real-estate slump, developers have added many unsold co-ops and condominiums to the rental market. And thousands of new condominum apartments have been turned into rentals by speculators.
 The rgulated rental market is divided into two categories: controlled and stabilized. Rent-controlled apartments, which number about 155,000, are those built before 1947 that have been continuously occupied by the current tenant, or a legal successor, since 1971. These tenants have no leases but a statutory right to occupancy for as long as they want. Compared with stabilized apartments, rent increases in controlled units are more restrictive, so rents tend to be quite low. Once such an apartment is vacated, it comes under rent stabilization.
 About 850,000 apartments are managegd under the Rent Stabilization Law, which sets a percentage limit on annual rent increases based on an index of operating costs, and applies to buildings built between 1947 and 1974. Those built after that date are subject to stabilization only if their owners choose one of the city's tax abatement programs, which they invariably do. The controls end when the abatement expires after 10 or 12 years, now widely occurring around the city.
 Last year the city could not conduct a new vacancy survey because the Census Bureau, which establishes a vacancy rate from studying about 18,000 apartments, was taking the national census. Needing a low vacancy figure to renew the law, the city cited the first quarter 1990 statistics from a much smaller Census Bureau survey, which showed a vacancy rate of 4.8 while ignoring the same study's conclusion that the rate rose over the limit to 5.2 percent from July to December.
 On May 7, the Rent Stabilization Associateion, the landlords' group, sued the city in State Supreme Court to end controls outright. The landlords' double-barreled argument: the stopgap vacancy survey failed to meet the terms of the law, and if it did, the 5.2 percent vacancy rate shoudl apply. Either way, the landlords argued, the law is dead.
 The city will respond to the suit by the end of the month. Both sides are sure to appeal an adverse ruling, pushing any legal outcome into the future.
 "It may be the case that a differential solution is wanted," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan BoroughPresident, whose constituents have the highest rate of regulated housing. But, she said, the rising vacancy rate may be due to the large number of co-ops and condominiums that have gone on the rental market in recent years and are not subject to rent rules.
 Regardless, the rent law, which predates the co-op-condominium boom, counts those units. But the landlords would probably settle - in the short term at least - for the deregulation of the approximately 100,000 apartments renting for $750 and above, which would take in most condominiums and co-ops. The landlords suggest such an outcome in their suit, and add that the apartments would be decontrolled only at the expiration of current leases.
 Such a partial decontrol might also buy more time for the law, since the overall vacancy rate would be more likely to drop below 5 percent.
 The landlords' willingness to compromise shows no extraordinary generosity. While the regulated system has tended to concentrate its benefits in the richest parts of the city, it has become almost irrelevent in many poorer areas, according to several studies. Outside Manhattan's core residential areas, regulated rents are close to market levels.
 Earlier this month, a Citizens Budget Commission study reported that the city would take in an additional $80 to $100 milion a year in real estate taxes by limiting rent protection to renters earning less than $57,000 for a family of four.
 But city officials dispute any windfalls soon after decontrol, and scoff at the likelihood of being able to collect and verify income statements from a million prickly renters a year.
 John Gilbert 3d, head of the landlord's group, said the Citizens Budget Commission study on lost real estate taxes had special meaning during the current fiscal crisis.
 "There are a lot of legislators in New York City who do not represent a high incidence of controlled renters," Mr. Gilbert said. "They are the ones who will be facing the choice between closing a library or closing a pool and deregulating luxury apartments."
 To Ms. Messinger, however, fiddling with rent rules during a recession could send the wrong signal to New Yorkers. "The one thing we don't want in this city, especially in a time of fiscal crisis, is a change so dramatic that literally tens of thousands of people use it as a reason to leave the city," she said.
 The sweep of Ms. Messinger's warning gives some hint at the passions that rent protections can inspire, and any attempt to modify the law would have to go through the City Council, where powerful tenant lobbies have demonstrated consistent strength to repulse attacks on the law.
