HEADLINE: An African Park in Peril

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ ;JANE PERLEZ is chief of the Nairobi bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
KENYA's Amboseli National Park is advertised as an extraordinary wildlife experience for visitors to Africa. Set beneath the snowy dome of Mount Kilimanjaro, Amboseli offers lions, cheetah, elephant and buffalo. A photographer's dream shot -- a giraffe or an elephant browsing on a green plain with the blue-tinged mountain as the backdrop -- is usually displayed in tourist brochures.
The pitch has little to do with reality. It is based on the old Amboseli, the place where veteran Kenya guides once took their big-money safari clients to view game in an unsurpassed setting. Today's Amboseli resembles a moonscape, shrouded in swirls of yellowish dust. The vegetation is reduced to broken tree trunks. Many of the animals have disappeared. 
 In a way, Amboseli has become, over the last decade or two, nature's equivalent of a once-elegant inner city block, now vandalized. Why? One reason is too many tourists. Another reason is what the tourists come for: hundreds of elephants -- too many, in fact.
Amboseli -- about 150 square miles -- is a small park by African standards, but . more than 750 elephants have crowded into the area in the past decade to seek sanctuary from poachers. In search of food, the elephants have destroyed the once lush woodlands, transforming the trees into dry, scattered shrubs. The thinning of the vegetation has pushed giraffes, monkeys and bush bucks into feeding areas outside the park's boundaries.
Damage by the elephants has been compounded by tourists, who pour into the park at the rate of 200,000 a year, said Dr. David Western, the director of Wildlife Conservation International, the research and conservation division of the New York Zoological Society. "The areas that were thick woodland have been eaten by the elephants, making it easier for the tourists to careen through in their vehicles," Dr. Western said. "The vans are often driven at 50 to 60 kilometers an hour. It's like a racetrack."
In theory, it is easy to understand the attraction of Amboseli to a first-time safari-goer. The park is only 150 miles from Nairobi.And it offers the highest density of elephants anywhere on the continent, according to Dr. Western. The smallness of the park makes it possible to see the so-called "big five" African game animals -- elephant, buffalo, leopard, lion and rhinoceros -- in one morning. About 20 percent of the park's visitors fly up from beach holidays at Mombasa on the Kenyan coast for a 90-minute drive around the park and then leave, after lunch at one of the park's lodges.
This short amount of time in the park makes it imperative for the tour driver to find as many of the popular animals as possible. (The driver's tip often depends on whether he has been able to pull off the "big five" in one drive). Thus, it is not unusual to see 40 vehicles circled bumper-to-bumper around a couple of lions, who, as is their habit during the day, are usually dozing.
The former quiet of the Amboseli wilderness has been shattered by the clicking of cameras, the hum of video recorders and the chorus of exclamations from hundreds ofvisitors gaping at a few animals. Tourists tend to peer at the animals for only as long as it takes to snap a few pictures. Research by zoologists working with Dr. Western shows that tourists spend an average of only eight to ten minutes looking at lions. "Then people get bored. The lion is still lying there, they've thrown a film cannister to try and wake it up, and they move on," said Dr. Western. "The average time is four to five minutes with elephants -- they are less attractive to the tourists than lions and cheetahs."
The invasion of the mini-vans has been bad for the animals. In the mid-1970's, Dr. Western estimates there were 12 to 15 cheetah in the park. Now there are less than eight. The crowding of the vans around the cheetahs -- sometimes vans even chase the animals -- has disturbed the cheetahs' hunting patterns, and they have departed for less crowded regions. In the Masai Mara National Reserve, another popular Kenyan game-viewing area, but one less visited by tourists, Dr. Western found that the cheetahs had been forced to change their hunting hours from dawn and dusk (favorite game-viewing periods) to the middle of the day.
 Two years ago there were 40 to 50 lions in Amboseli; today only two or three remain, according to Dr. Western. The drop is due in part to the poisoning of some of them by Masai tribesmen. (The lions frequently attack the Masai's cattle.) Interference in the lions' hunting patterns by tour vans has also contributed to their decline in Amboseli, Dr. Western said.
That Amboseli is in such perilous shape is no secret to the managers of Kenya's parks or to tour operators. Some of the more discerning outfitters, including Ker & Downey, have scratched Amboseli from their itineraries. Still, many tourists are willing to pay the $175 for an overnight excursion into the park, offered by many Nairobi-based operators. Or they can fly in from Nairobi for $125 day trips, which are offered by some of the park's lodges.
Dr. Richard E. Leakey, the director of the Kenya Wildlife Service, sums up Amboseli: "It has become one big dust-bowl." Ever the optimist, Dr. Leakey believes the park can be rescued. So does Dr. Western, although the zoologist wonders whether the Kenya Wildlife Service has the capability to do what is necessary.
At one point, Dr. Leakey contemplated shutting the park down in order to give the vegetation time to restore itself. But economic necessities dictate otherwise. Gate receipts, at about $10 a person,make Amboseli one of the biggest money earners for the Wildlife Service. In turn, tourism is the biggest source of foreign exchange for Kenya, a poor country, which has seen a decline in its coffee and tea earnings, due to the worldwide drop in prices.
The idea of fencing off areas of the park to stop the elephants feeding on the trees was also scotched. "To recover sufficient woodland you would need to fence off large parts of the park, which would be totally anti-tourist," said Dr. Leakey. "My impression is that Amboseli can be rehabilitated if you ban off-the-road driving and move the tourists further out into the park."
Road reconstruction is already underway. Initially, about 14 miles of road are being resurfaced to make a one-way circuit for vans. This new roadway is designed to prevent two-way traffic and to discourage off-the-road driving. The poor quality of Amboseli's roads has encouraged tour drivers to make their own rutted tracks as they dash from one cluster of animals to another.
Dr. Leakey is also considering different pricing policies within the park as a way of encouraging tourists to explore larger areas. At the moment, Dr. Western estimates that 90 percent of the tourist vans use 10 percent of the park -- that 10 percent includes most of the park's watering holes, the parts frequented by wildlife. A recent gimmick by some tour operators has aggravated the problem: some drivers are given financial incentives by the operators to drive fewer miles as a way of saving gas. But driving less has the deleterious side effect of keeping vans in the overused central core of the park.
Under differential pricing, visitors would actually pay more to drive on the inner circuit of the park.
There is also the possibility that Amboseli will become the bottom layer of a three-tiered tourism plan for Kenya. Dr. Leakey envisions a "more eco-friendly" top tier involving walking trips and camel safaris into the remoter areas of Kenya. Other areas, such as Masai Mara, Mount Kenya and parts of the Tsavo National Park, would be medium-priced and retain some exclusivity. And Amboseli would remain what it has become -- an enclave for inexpensive, mass tourism.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 21, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 19 about the Amboseli National Park in Kenya included an outdated reference to Wildlife Conservation International's specialist in the region. As the organization pointed out in a letter on July 8, Dr. David Western is senior conservationist, in charge of East African projects; Dr. John Robinson became the organization's director in February 1990.

HEADLINE: What Is Chris Whittle Teaching Our Children?

BYLINE: By N. R. Kleinfield; N. R. Kleinfield is a reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
It was warm in the living room of Chris Whittle's relentlessly neat living quarters. Outside, rain began to spit from the troubled Tennessee skies, spoiling the arboreal view. Sitting on the couch, straight as a furled umbrella, Whittle placed a phone call to Phil Guarascio, the head of advertising at General Motors. Earlier, he had booked a call with him at this time. But Guarascio was not there. Whittle gave a withering look. "Some day, someone is going to invent a phone system that will automatically find people," he said. "They could be in another city, but the phone will get them. It has to happen. One of the biggest wastes of time is not being able to reach people, even if, like now, you've made an appointment to call them."
The way Chris Whittle figures it, if he doesn't like something, then someone -- often himself -- ought to reinvent it. Over the last two decades, Whittle has acquired a national profile as something of the bete noire of the media industry. His proliferating array of unorthodox magazines, posters and video systems go out to highly targeted audiences or are planted in veterinarians' offices, dentists' offices, health clubs, doctors' waiting rooms and schools. He once considered muffler shops. 
 Whittle has almost no compunctions about where you can put advertising, and thus in propagating his projects he has tapped into some raw emotions. Last year, much of the nation seemed caught in passionate debate over the ethics of Channel One, Whittle's newscast for secondary schools that contains plugs for hamburgers and corn chips. The uproar over Channel One has quieted down, but last week Whittle was all set to stir up fresh commotion with the disclosure of his most ambitious and jarring undertaking. He plans to establish a laboratory called the Edison Project in Knoxville, Tenn., where his Whittle Communications empire is based, staffed by 100 yet-unselected people culled from education, business and science who will try to sketch out a blueprint for a new breed of elementary and secondary schools.
Once the outline is complete, Whittle intends to build 200 schools around the country, to open in the fall of 1996. The cost, he imagines, could approach $3 billion, which he might raise by selling shares to large companies. Within 15 years, Whittle foresees 1,000 Whittle schools educating as many as two million students. Whittle's initiative will run parallel to the new education plan unveiled by President Bush and Education Secretary Lamar Alexander (a Whittle friend and former member of the Channel One board), which calls for grants to invent experimental public schools and for the building of 535 model schools by 1996.
What makes Chris Whittle think he can educate our kids? After his bruising experience with Channel One, his bravura has clearly increased. He is bent on transforming Whittle Communications into a multibillion-dollar company that will touch people virtually every place they venture.
WHITTLE HAD BEEN GNAWING ON A PEN, DRINKING in the zealous discussion among his development team of a project code-named Doc TV. Whittle's expression had veered from quizzical to displeased to keenly interested. Now he absently pulled at his ear and asked what he ultimately always wants to know: What's the potential?
"It doesn't sound completely crazy to me that this is a $200 million property," someone said. "The possibilities are 100,000 doctors have the system and 50,000 watch it daily."
Wearing his trademark bow tie, with his floppy brown hair jouncing about, Whittle drifted over to a side table, where there were piles of sandwiches and fruit salad. He asked, "How much is spent on medical detail forces?" (The drug company salesmen who personally visit doctors.)
"Merck alone spends half a billion bucks," came the answer. "We want to tell them to fire 10 percent of these people, pocket $30 million and give us $25 million."
"Sounds good," Whittle said grandly, and a vulpine smile crossed his face. "Sounds very good."
The airy conference room at Whittle's New York offices in the Seagram Building contained seven members of a development team, gathered several months ago to plot Doc TV, a product still a year away from being tested. It was to be a television system to go into either doctors' offices or their homes. Every day, a 12-minute broadcast informing physicians of the latest doings in their specialty would be sent via satellite or cable and automatically recorded on video tape. (As with Channel One, Whittle would chip in all the electronic gear.) Each of the daily programs would carry a commercial plug from a drug company.
Several constituencies are likely to bewail the project. Whittle expects to grab perhaps 20 percent of the $452 million of ads carried by medical trade journals. He smugly says some journals will doubtless fold. Further money should be siphoned out of the vast outlays by drug houses on detail men. A fair number of them, Whittle believes, will lose their jobs.
As the development meeting wore on, someone said, "Now we ought to think what else could we do to make this thing as attractive as possible."
Whittle joined the discussion: "How about, you push a button at the end of the show and samples come pouring out like a slot machine?"
That got excited nods.
Alan Greenberg, a Whittle vice chairman, said: "Well, there could be sweepstakes."
"Yeah, Wingo," someone threw in.
Everyone seemed really happy.
At the age of 43, Herbert Christopher Whittle is both lampooned as a flimflam man and hailed as an ingenious marketer.
"He has set the bar rather high for expectations of advertising creativity," says David R. Verklin, senior vice president and corporate media director of Hal Riney Partners.
On the other hand, Whittle gives competitors conniptions. "He tells people: 'Why are you bothering to buy space in that magazine that doesn't care about you? All I care about, Mr. Advertiser, is selling your product,' " says John R. MacArthur, publisher of Harper's Magazine. "We hear all the time, 'Why can't you come up with a Whittle-like package?' We've been asked to do a short-story contest where the winner has to name the advertiser's product in the story. We constantly get asked to sell the Harper's Index, have it be the Acme Screw Index or something. We say no to this stuff, but we do it at our peril."
Increasingly, marketers have concluded that traditional mass-market media are flawed. Thus, Whittle has managed, beneath his somewhat fulsome hype, to persuade a small but swelling list of about 30 clients that his products do work. And while both Whittle and his customers are wary of sharing specifics, Whittle spent several hours with me poring through studies that indicated products advertised in his media gained in consumer awareness. One well-known service firm, according to one report, picked up 8 percent in brand awareness in a print project. A snack advertiser on Channel One went up from a 29 percent awareness to 53 percent.
For 17 years, Nissan has been merrily sponsoring Whittle's biannual Student Traveler magazine for college students. Francis Gace, the president of Lewis & Gace, an advertising agency that has used several Whittle medical publications, says: "Whittle has produced some very convincing independent research that shows his products stand up. In a cluttered world, here is a less cluttered medium, and that makes it attractive."
Nevertheless, all research can be ambiguous, and since so many Whittle properties appear in odd locations, advertisers have trouble judging the true size and attentiveness of the audiences. At times, the task can seem as slippery as trying to gauge how many motorists flashing by a billboard actually spied the sun-screen ad. Moreover, marketers say Whittle generally seeks a fat premium over comparable ways to spend marketing dollars. Part of Whittle's wiliness is that he has invented products that are maddeningly difficult to compare with anything else. Still, agency people estimate that Whittle prices sometimes run two or three times above competing possibilities. Often, princely sums are paid well before a new idea has proved itself, a practice that makes some marketers feel as if they're being asked to fund a wild-eyed experiment.
"The world of media is changing, and he's going in the correct direction," says Jack Irving, head of media operations at the Saatchi & Saatchi agency. "But there's been no overwhelming evidence yet to convince the ad community that his properties work." What's more, Whittle's biggest products -- like Channel One and Special Reports TV, a feature-type television system that began in October 1990 in doctors' waiting rooms -- are still young and face intensifying competition. Healthlink, for instance, is a rival doctors' system, and Turner Broadcasting runs a plug-free program for schools.
But the Whittle bandwagon rolls on. Last year, Whittle introduced a series of short books called "The Larger Agenda," written by respected authors and sent free to 150,000 politicians and officers of influential corporations. About six books appear each year, all sprinkled with advertisements from Federal Express. The series has been so profitable that he just began another series, and has organized a book division presided over by William S. Rukeyser, a former managing editor of Fortune magazine, and Hamilton Jordan, chief of staff for President Jimmy Carter.
Next year, Whittle expects to try displaying consumer products in malls. He won't reveal the products, though he has attracted interest among manufacturers. The idea would work like this: Whittle stores would show models of competing brands of a product -- say, lawn mowers. The mowers, according to Whittle people, would be more attractively displayed and in wider assortment than in conventional stores. Since the Whittle outlets would contain nothing else, the mowers presumably would lure a focused audience. There would be no stock. If you found the mower of your dreams, you would snatch up a phone in the store and order it for shipment to your home.
Whittle's pride and hope, however, are what he calls place-based television systems. These systems can be viewed only in locations outside the home, where Whittle knows precisely who is watching. This is a world in which there are no remote controls to switch stations when commercials blare, because there are no other channels. Whittle envisions systems for bankers, school administrators -- who knows, maybe circus performers. His projection is that revenues from place-based TV will grow from less than $100,000 in 1990 to almost $3 billion by the year 2000. The entire cable industry has revenues of about $2 billion. The three commercial networks together bring in $9 billion.
"WE'LL DO $220 MILLION in revenues in 1990," Chris Whittle said. "We have 1,000 employees. Increasingly we will be a television force. We are one of the media industry's fastest-growing companies."
Whittle was addressing executives from FCB/Leber Katz Partners at the ad agency's Manhattan offices, his notable reserves of charm on glaring display. He had recently begun paying courtesy calls on agencies to try to redress past snubbing. In doing his selling, Whittle had typically called directly on advertisers and bypassed their agencies, unlike conventional publishers and broadcasters, and there is a chasm of animosity and suspicion between many agencies and Whittle.
Whittle has come a ways. Five years ago, his company, which for the last two years has been half-owned by Time Warner, collected just $80 million in revenues, and the largest property was a poster in dentists' offices that brought in $7 million. Whittle says pretax earnings averaged 15 percent of revenues over the last five years, with the bulk of the profits from a total of 30-odd magazines and wall posters devoted to such advertiser-friendly subjects as travel, health and beauty.
Whittle told the Leber group that his company has two major goals: to provide new services to advertisers and readers and to bring greater value to advertisers. "I'm going to pick one arena to illustrate this -- television."
He went on: "When we look at television, we see a medium in serious decline. We think the commercial audience erosion is worse than admitted. We think the remote control has been a disaster in this regard and the full story of this has not been told. "
Laurel Cutler, the agency's vice chairman, nodded, and said, "I watch my teen-agers and they watch with their thumb."
"We estimate that upward of 40 percent of Americans rarely see commercials, even the biggest campaigns," Whittle said. (While network officials admit that many TV viewers otherwise occupy themselves during commercials, they contend that the figure is far below 40 percent. Yet no one knows for sure.)
Whittle went on to tell about his plans for place-based networks: "What are the advantages? There is much greater targeting. I can promise you that everyone in a high school is a teen-ager. I can promise you everyone in a pediatrician's has a child."
He paused, then sped on: "This fact will surprise you. Ninety-five percent of television activity is followed by one activity -- sleep. Because it happens at night. That's not true of place-based television. For example, some 61 percent of people who leave a doctor's office have a prescription. They are going to a retail environment. So that changes the impact of the commercial."
(Subsequently, Whittle admitted he couldn't support the surprising sleep "fact.")
"We look at media differently," Whittle continued. "We ask, 'Is a commercial that is seen more valuable than one that is not?' Most media evaluations don't take that into account. In homes, what is the zap level? We ask, 'Is the first impression on an individual more valuable than the 100th?' "
Joseph W. Ostrow, the Leber agency's worldwide media director, said: "We have a client who feels that a commercial seen the 100th or 99th time is wasted money. So we set frequency levels."
Whittle nodded and went on: "Is a person who will never see your competitor's commercial more valuable than one who will see it 100 times? We think absolutely, yet most agencies don't care about proprietary levels."
Cutler: "I think that is overstated. You say 'never see your competitor's commercial.' But take your waiting-room example. You only own that person for an hour."
"It is overstated to make a point," Whittle conceded.
Whittle invited ideas, and Ellen W. Oppenheim, the senior vice president and media director, said: "I'd like to see you come to us during the planning stage of a project. And listen. Because as much as you accuse the agencies of not listening, I don't think you always have. It's been, O.K., if we don't get what we want today, we'll go to the client. Goodbye."
IN THE AIR, FLYING between Knoxville and Columbus, Ohio, Chris Whittle said: "One of the frightening things is the media terrain is going to radically change. It's not frightening to me, but it will be to others. I don't think the major media will become extinct, just smaller and different."
Of course, not all Whittle media work, either. The latest of the dozen or so failures over the years include American Style, a magazine for beauty parlors, which was unable to capture requisite advertising and was recently shut down. It meant a loss of several million dollars, the worst Whittle flop. He hit rocky shoals, as well, with his six magazines for doctors' waiting rooms. By bungling relations with ad agencies, Whittle caused them to bad-mouth the project; some advertisers withdrew. So Whittle brought out a television system, reduced the magazines to three publications and gave advertisers who buy spots on the TV system free ads in the magazines.
If the Whittle ventures sound more like marketing than media, it's because marketing is all he has ever known.
He grew up in Etowah, Tenn., the son of a country doctor. While attending the University of Tennessee, he embarked on a college magazine project called "Knoxville in a Nutshell" with Phillip Moffitt and two other students. They formed a company called 13-30, alluding to the age group they wished to reach, and out of a former pillow factory engineered Nutshells for other campuses. Whittle was always the glad-handing salesman.
The company grew too fast, the other Nutshells fared less well and 13-30 creaked with debt. One magical day, it found bliss when it agreed to develop a magazine for Nissan in which the car maker was the sole advertiser. This single-sponsorship notion caught fire and life went along beautifully. Still, the company was obscure until 1979, when it bought and revitalized Esquire magazine. In 1986, Whittle and Moffitt tired of each other, and a vinegary divorce took place. Moffitt retained Esquire, which he soon sold to Hearst. Whittle kept the stable of magazines and wall posters and renamed the company Whittle Communications.
Even as it has expanded, Whittle Communications has operated in emphatically entrepreneurial fashion. The fuel of the company is ideas. At any given time, some 20 development teams are devising fresh possibilities, and employees often find themselves shuttled from development team to working property back to development team.
Whittle readily confesses that he is not much of a reader or watcher: he sees news and movies on TV and reads a daily paper, but he studies no magazines on a regular basis and finishes perhaps three or four nonfiction books a year. If an advertiser wishes to catch Whittle's attention, he says, "I am damn near impossible to reach." But he does act on ads that do penetrate him. He recently spied an ad for Polo/Ralph Lauren pants and went out and bought some.
While most of Whittle's magazines and wall posters are no longer backed by a single advertiser, competing brands are forbidden. Although the publications are slick-looking, the majority are rather pallid echoes of well-established magazines like Time or The Atlantic. Who gets them is strictly controlled.
David Halberstam has mused a good bit about Whittle. He contracted to do a Whittle book, but withdrew when he encountered editorial resistance. Published by Morrow, "The Next Century" became a best seller. Despite that episode, Halberstam says he likes Whittle and feels the book idea is a sensible one. But he dislikes Channel One and he wonders about Whittle's convictions. "I don't want to underestimate what he is," Halberstam said. "He's smart. His ideas are original. There is no doubt he has an instinct for marketing. But I didn't get a feeling that anything matters to him. I don't know what he really cares about."
JOE MANCINI squinted down the hall, bustling with students flowing to their next class. Then Mancini, the principal of Bishop Ready High School in Columbus, Ohio, turned his attention to his special guests. "Welcome, and c'mon into my office," he said. Straightening his bow tie, Chris Whittle, trailed by Bill Rukeyser, followed him into a drab room.
Since Channel One has been his biggest gamble (for one thing, Whittle last year spent $70 million for about 9 percent of all the 19-inch color TV sets sold in this country) and since he is plunging deeper into education, Whittle likes to make periodic trips to see how things are going.
Channel One can best be described as an MTV-like newscast -- a compression of news, features tailored for teen-agers, trivia questions and a series on a topical issue like the Soviet Union or the handicapped. Everything is boppy. The smily anchors are in their 20's, and the pace is snappy and the graphics flashy. The commercials, though sometimes identical to those on regular TV, are increasingly shot specifically for Channel One. While many shamelessly encourage consumption of candy bars and costly footwear, some are message-oriented. Burger King ran a five-part ad that chronicled the pitiful plight of "Tiny," a school dropout who degenerated into a prostitute, drug addict and alcoholic.
"How long you been on?" Whittle asked.
"March 4," Mancini said. "We were on the first day. Our kids are excited. We like the quality. We have, though, made some calls with some complaints. Slow down the presentation was the main one."
"What about the parents?" Whittle asked.
"They're thrilled," Mancini said. "Of course, I also get the nasty letters about why are you tainting our kids."
"What can we do better?" Whittle asked.
"Well, we have a problem with geography here," Mancini said. "You have these flat maps that are sometimes hard to understand where something is. Maybe you could make them spin like they do on 'Wide World of Sports.' "
While many teachers and students extol the 12-minute newscast, others will never accept the infusion of commercialism. Whittle often likes to defend the project by pointing out that there is already commercialism in the free skin creams given out in home economics classes and the ads on stadium scoreboards. For Whittle the matter has largely been detoxified by the project's economic viability. Whittle has gotten the 8,600 schools he sought to cover his capital costs and achieve the audience size he felt would interest advertisers. (As an incentive, Whittle rains $50,000 of free TV's, VCR's and satellite dishes on schools that take the system.)
Whittle now envisions further expansion, and does not rule out a program geared for elementary grades. It is little known that for years Whittle has had a wall display called "Big Picture" (actually a set of three wall posters boasting short articles and graphics with ads running along the bottom) in 11,000 elementary schools, and it is not uncommon for grade-schoolers to be surveyed by Whittle-funded researchers to see how vividly they recall brands like M & M's that advertise in Big Picture.
At some places, Channel One has roused boiling emotions. There was a walkout of students in Fargo, N.D., protesting what they felt was dull and condescending programming. Rhode Island and New York prohibit the system in public schools, and similar legislation has been introduced in California. What's more, Whittle finds it necessary to agree to occasional odd stipulations. Whittle said one that school demanded contractual assurance that the programming would contain no subliminal advertising. School board members mentioned that they feared that the Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi might sponsor subliminal messages. Whittle swears he is not kidding.
Under a sun that glazed the trees, Whittle was taken on the 20-minute drive to Grove City High School. Thomas D. Rutan, the principal, told him that teachers had complained that the school personnel weren't always starting the show at the same time, and so three alarm clocks were arranged atop the receiver set to shriek at the appointed moment. Whittle chuckled.
"What do the teachers think?" Whittle asked.
"Some really like it," the principal said. "And some get so engrossed in what they're teaching that they get annoyed when the TV comes on and they just pull the plug."
Whittle looked horrified.
Upstairs, in a sophomore English class, Whittle wedged himself into a desk to watch the day's broadcast. It embraced some coverage of the gulf war, a study suggesting that too much TV viewing could be bad for the heart, a feature on agriculture, a segment on mentally handicapped students and part of a series on American Indians.
After the show ended, Whittle rose to ask questions. The class was sullen and reticent.
"Have you learned where places are?" Whittle wondered. "For instance, have you learned where Hussein lives?"
"Not really," a boy said, "because we already learned that on other news or in the newspapers."
Whittle had noticed that a number of students did homework or doodled throughout the program. The teacher said the rule is that they don't have to watch, but they must be quiet.
"Was this a typical experience with just a few doing homework?" Whittle said.
"I think more were watching it because you were here," another boy said.
The teacher added, "I would say half work on homework and half watch."
Driving away with Rukeyser, Whittle said, "Interesting visit."
"Every one's different," Rukeyser said.
OUTSIDE THE CAR window, leafy streets, tracts of lush farmland and then a tight strip of commercialism flicked by beneath the emergent light. Accompanied by a bleary-eyed team, Whittle has been rousted out of bed early to descend on a small Midwestern city to try to wring $5.5 million from a major advertiser, a maker of household products, for Whittle's waiting-room television system.
On sales pitches, Whittle's pattern is always the same: two or three people show up with a tornado of charts and printed material and, for a video sale, a television and a VCR. Whittle also insists on two hours of the client's time. If he shows up for an appointment and is told there's now only an hour, he will reschedule. Sometimes he flies hundreds of miles only to make a new scribbling in his appointment book.
Whittle spoke in a soothing, sociable voice, often in a tone of wonder, and in short, simple sentences. "In conventional media, there is no competitive advantage," he said. "You have to outspend or outcreate. You don't outflank. We allow you to outflank."
Then he let Bill Connell, president of Whittle Communications, say a few words before Alan Greenberg delivered the core pitch. "You're doing a good job on commercial television," he said to the group, "but I'll tell you, 40 percent are not seeing your ads. We have the ability to fundamentally change the way in which spending is delivered to consumers."
Whittle cut in: "A typical response of an agency is, 'We buy around that.' You can't buy around that. You can't get people who don't watch television to watch television."
"With us," Greenberg said, "you can't zap, you can't graze, you can't plug your Nintendo into the set."
The case was hitting the right ears. The company had recently hired a new president who wanted to market the company's products more effectively. In particular, the company needed to reach mothers, and it had found commercial television frustratingly inefficient.
Whittle spoke about how company trucks delivered magazines and new broadcasts to the doctors' offices every two weeks. "One thing to think about," he said, "is those trucks have room on them. We could take other stuff. Samples of yours."
Once the presentation was over, the president leaned back and said: "This just fits so perfectly. And it ought to be something we'll say yes to right now, and we'll figure out the details later."
Just like that, $5.5 million was committed.
"In closing," Whittle said, "I'd like to say that, like all media, we're not perfect. After a meeting like this, people say, 'Hooray, we've found the Holy Grail.' We ain't the Holy Grail. But we're far better than anything else out there."
That said, the team dispersed. On the way to the airport, Whittle allowed his grin to widen until it was huge.
THE DINNER HOUR was ripening, and as a ragged line of tables at the stylish Memphis restaurant on the Upper West Side of Manhattan filled up, voices lunged forward and overlapped one another. Around the long dark bar, men and women stalked one another.
Whittle and Rinker Buck, the editorial director of AdWeek's Marketing Week, were meeting to get to know one another better. Whittle had made the overture because he had been miffed at some rather blistering coverage in Buck's publication.
Whittle sipped a drink, as Buck spun an anecdote that had to do with keeping recipes on his refrigerator.
"We've thought of ads on refrigerators," Whittle interrupted.
Buck laughed.
It wasn't a joke.
In fact, Whittle later told me, the company had thought of trying to interest a maker like Whirlpool into building frames for wall media on its refrigerators, and then homeowners could pick up the material at the supermarket and slide it in.
Buck lit into Whittle on Channel One. He told Whittle how irritating it is to watch commercial-ridden Saturday-morning television with his 5-year-old daughter. "The other day, I asked her what she wanted to do," he said, "and she said, 'I want to be an actress in commercials.' Not movies or TV, in commercials. So I pretty profoundly disagree with the concept of Channel One."
"Advertising is making available a good program," Whittle said. "It is a trade-off."
After some back and forth, Buck said, "Listen, you're an alternative medium. You consider the high schools a segment. Have you considered the churches?"
Slight embarrassment prickled his face, but Whittle just laughed. (Later on, he told me he hadn't ruled out churches, but couldn't think of anything he might do there.)
I walked a few blocks with Buck. "You look at Whittle and you have to realize he still doesn't have that much of a track record," he said. "Something doesn't work, and he's quickly into something else. He's like a chameleon. If something doesn't work, he becomes something else."
THE HOME CHRIS Whittle owns in Knoxville resembles an old mansion of buff bricks. In fact, it is a converted apartment house with four sizable three-bedroom apartments. The place suits Whittle fine, though most nights he's there alone. He was married for the first time last August, to Priscilla Rattazzi, niece of the Fiat magnate Gianni Agnelli, and in January they had a daughter. (She has a son by a previous marriage.) His wife prefers their showy New York dwelling in the Dakota apartment house, and so Whittle sees his family mostly on the weekends.
Channel One, Whittle said, has radically revised his career aspirations. Until a year ago, Whittle intended to retire from business in 1994 and enter politics. Not any more. "Channel One has such an impact on education that I realized I could never do anything like this in four years of politics. So I decided I would rather stay in business."
It seems certain that Whittle will be the focus of continued truculence and agitation. In the years to come, he faces more serious obstacles. His projects are much riskier and his reach is bumping up against more powerful franchises and constituencies, none of which is likely to concede territory without a vicious battle. Whittle is unlikely to emerge unscathed.
Whittle grabbed some gym clothes and prepared to work out. As he bent into his blue Porsche, he admitted something about himself, perhaps a serious flaw. "I'm not a good competitor," he said. "I don't think competitively." For a long time, he hasn't really had to. He has gone where others have not, but now he is playing in a bigger and rougher league.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Encountering Those Mercurial Days in the Bullpens

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Dennis Eckersley of Oakland, generally considered the best relief pitcher working today, has raised eyebrows by already giving up four home runs (double his total for the entire 1990 season), allowing seven earned runs (two more than all of last season) and failing in two save situations (as many as all of last season).
 Rob Dibble of Cincinnati, on the other hand, has pitched with eye-popping precision, striking out 34 batters and walking only four in 19 2/3 innings while registering a perfect save record in 10 chances. 
Those have been some of the more intriguing developments in the fraternity of closing relief pitchers in the early weeks of the season. Some others:
 *Dibble's dominance has been in stark contrast with the problems encountered by his bullpen mate, Randy Myers, who has three saves in six save situations and a strikeout-to-walk ratio slightly less impressive than Dibble's: 14 walks and 13 strikeouts in 16 innings.
 *Veterans Jeff Reardon of Boston and Lee Smith of St. Louis have pitched impressively, Reardon registering 12 saves, including his first 8 in a 9-victory, 11-game span, and Smith reeling off 11 saves in a dominating performance that continues to belie the four-year-old whispers that he no longer could be effective because of problems with his knees. Duane Ward, stepping in for the injured Tom Henke, has matched Reardon with 12 saves for Toronto.
 *The Yankees don't miss Dave Righetti, their career saves leader, who defected to San Francisco during the winter. They don't miss him because they haven't had many games to be saved: four, to be exact. The Giants, on the other hand, haven't overused the $10 million Righetti. He has relieved in only two save situations, succeeding once and squandering his chance the other time.
 *Doug Jones of Cleveland, who in the previous three seasons amassed 112 saves, has temporarily pitched himself out of his closing role with four successive ineffective efforts, including three that lost games.
 *Before getting his seventh save Friday night, Bobby Thigpen of the Chicago White Sox had not had a save in the team's previous 14 games. Last year, when Thigpen had a major league record 57 saves, his longest stretch without a save was eight games, and that was the only time he went beyond five games without one.
 
They're Not Machines
 Closing relief pitchers, of course, are notorious for their mercurial performances, both from season to season and month to month. Rare is the reliever who avoids a slump the entire season or doesn't have a below-par season.
 Eckersley, whose ascent to late-inning stardom parallels the Athletics' dominance of the American League, is not having a poor season by any means. True, he has given up more home runs and runs than he did all of last season, when he registered 48 saves in 50 save situations, but he nevertheless has 9 saves in 11 opportunities.
 "Guys are so good for so long, you come to expect perfection," Dave Duncan, the Oakland pitching coach, said. "A guy gives up a hit, and people wonder what's wrong with him. He's human. That's what's the matter. He's not a machine."
 Speaking specifically of Eckersley, Duncan said he was "going through a period where he's making mistakes and not getting away with them."
 "They haven't hit any good pitches off him; he's made bad pitches," the coach added.
 Why should Eckersley throw poor pitches?
 "Maybe he's distracted," Duncan said. "When everything is going well, everything flows. He's not getting the results he's accustomed to so that can be a little distracting to him."
 When a pitcher is distracted, the coach explained, instead of hitting the corners with his pitches, he could "leave the ball in the middle." That's when batters can hit home runs, as Alvin Davis, Greg Gagne, Matt Nokes and Beau Allred have done against Eckersley.
 Dave Smith, who moved from the Houston Astros to the Chicago Cubs as a free agent, has had six successive seasons of 23 or more saves. Yet after getting four saves in the Cubs' first six victories, he encountered a rough period in which he lost three saves in four days, twice after Andre Dawson hit grand slams that either gave the Cubs the lead or increased it.
 Jones, who will temporarily work in middle relief while Shawn Hillegas does his job with the Indians, hasn't had a save since April 28, and it's not because he hasn't had the opportunity. Once three games before that date and three times in six games after, Jones was called on to preserve victories, but the Indians lost all four games.
 The last-place Giants haven't given Righetti the chance to lose that many victories. They asked him to save a 9-6 victory against San Diego on April 11, but he gave up a pinch-hit three-run home run to Marty Barrett, who has not driven in another run. Righetti did save a victory five days later, but he has not relieved in a save situation since. Jeff Brantley has, but he has blown three of six chances. Righetti was asked to preserve a 5-1 victory last Thursday night (not a save situation), but all four batters he faced got hits and three scored.
 
Having Fun at the Top
 Sure, Dave Henderson said, "You always look at the averages in the Sunday paper to check out your buddies." But his buddies haven't had to wait until Sunday to check out Henderson.
 "It's kind of nice," Oakland's center fielder said, "to see your name on top of a lot of offensive categories. The guys around the league who know you, they know you're doing well without talking to them."
 In recent days, Henderson has led the American League in just about every major category -- batting average, slugging percentage, home runs, runs batted in, runs scored, hits, extra-base hits, total bases. "I had a good month," he said modestly, then added, "I think people are more surprised because it's at the beginning of the year rather than at the end of the year. I think players around the league know I'm capable of this."
 Henderson, 32 years old, had his best season in 1988, batting .304 with 24 home runs and 94 r.b.i. But he is best known for his post-season hitting, especially the home runs.
 "This guy has hit as many big home runs as a lot of guys," said Reggie Jackson, a part-time Oakland coach, who hit more big home runs than most.
 
Status and Deflation
 Scott Sanderson obviously adopted the wrong strategy in his effort to play for the Athletics again this year. A 17-game winner for them last season, Sanderson was a free agent who wanted to remain with Oakland, but the salary-heavy Athletics opted to go with lower-paid pitchers.
 So Sanderson winds up with the Yankees and becomes their biggest winner. Meanwhile, Andy Hawkins pitches so dreadfully for the Yankees that they release him, and he goes off and signs with -- the Athletics. His price is right: less than $80,000 based on the $100,000 minimum, with the Yankees responsible for the remainder of his guaranteed salary. Suddenly, Hawkins, if he can pitch at all effectively, can wind up in the World Series while Sanderson can finish in last place.
 With batting averages that didn't total .300 and one r.b.i. between them, Jim Leyritz and Mike Blowers provided a stunning example of the deflation of major league standards when they openly complained about their lack of playing time, saying the Yankees should play them or trade them (Blowers got his wish Friday, going to the Mariners; Leyritz was sent to the minors). Not long ago, it seems, a player had to have attained some semblance of status to be able to utter such ultimatums.
 Another example: This being the first week 50 years later of Joe DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak, the television and radio announcers who talk about John Doe's seven-game hitting streak and the public relations directors who provide that information should feel sufficiently embarrassed and cease and desist.
 
Now for the Hard Part
 The owners, in settling their collusion crime against free agents, are getting the last laugh. They are paying the players $280 million, but the Players Association must determine how much money should go to which players, and it is no easy task. Hundreds of players will file claims by tomorrow's deadline.
 The real tipoff on the bizarre ramifications of the settlement came last Thursday when Richard Moss, who as the union's general counsel won some of the most significant arbitration cases in baseball labor history, debated union lawyers before two arbitrators in Los Angeles.
 Moss, who represents about 50 players making claims, had filed an objection to the framework of the payment of claims on behalf of some players who lost jobs because of collusion. Other lawyers and agents presented other arguments in other hearings.
 The union probably missed a chance to add funds to the collusion treasury. They should have charged admission to the hearings. Management officials surely would have paid top prices to see players' representatives squabbling among themselves over money.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1765 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Providence

BYLINE: By MARCIA R. LIEBERMAN; MARCIA R. LIEBERMAN lives in Providence.

 BODY:
When I moved to Providence over a dozen years ago, a friend who grew up in New York said, "Oh, that's the place where my father always got lost when we drove to Cape Cod." Now that the final Interstate connections are in place, motorists can zip right through Providence. What they are missing is a city with one of the largest and finest collections of 18th- and 19th-century buildings in the country.
Although handsome buildings are scattered throughout the city, the College Hill district takes pride of place. It is one of 15 Urban National Historic Landmark Districts designated by the Department of the Interior. Benefit Street, near the base of College Hill, is surely one of the most distinctive streets in America. 
 Eminently walkable because of its scale, the city has many inviting areas like the old downtown waterfront, where the Woonasquatucket and Moshassuck rivers merge. These rivers, rerouted and then paved over in the 19th century, have now been uncovered; bridges, walkways and gardens will be completed by 1993.
Providence is not merely quaint, however. Its population of 160,728 includes sizable groups of recent immigrants from Asia, including Cambodians and Hmong, as well as Dominicans. The city also has a distinct Portuguese heritage; the language is widely spoken.
There is also a large college population, notably at Brown University and the Rhode Island School of Design (R.I.S.D., pronounced locally as RIZ-dee). The art students, a frisky crowd in funky clothes, lend a lively air.
 
Architecture
 Benefit Street, near the base of College Hill, is a quietly stunning thoroughfare that displays in one mile a timeline of architectural history, from Colonial through Federal, Greek Revival, Gothic Revival and Victorian. The oldest houses, dating from the mid to late 1700's, are severely beautiful in their simplicity and proportions. Many small streets like John and Arnold, above the southern end of Benefit, are lined with these forthright little houses. The 18th-century merchants who prospered in the China trade erected grander houses, with elegant fanlights and porticos.
The annual Festival of Historic Houses (June 7, 8 and 9), co-sponsored by the Providence Preservation Society and The Providence Journal-Bulletin, gives people a chance to get inside about three dozen houses. There are three separate events. On Friday and Saturday evenings, a gala "Night of a Thousand Candles" tour covers about a dozen Colonial and Federal houses. Among them is the Thomas Hoppin House, scene of a brilliant reception for President Rutherford B. Hayes in 1877 that earned it the epithet "The House of a Thousand Candles." Saturday will feature a lecture on decorative painting, highlighting the 1863 Gov. Henry Lippitt House at 199 Hope Street, (401) 751-2110, which is set to open on July 1 as a museum, and "Houses in Bloom," a tour of Victorian, Queen Anne and Colonial Revival houses, with floral arrangements adorning the interiors.
Following the candlelight tour on Saturday, there will be a dessert and Champagne reception in the 18th-century John Brown House. On Sunday afternoon there will be a tour of the city's Victorian Armory District, an area being restored. Visitors on the tours are free to come and go as they wish, although guides are on hand. Tour tickets cost $17.50; the Decorative Arts Lecture is $5; the Saturday night tour is $25; a Deluxe Festival Package (Saturday only) is $60.
Visitors who cannot attend the Festival can see the exteriors of College Hill's private homes and other historic sites on their own. The Providence Preservation Society at 21 Meeting Street, (401) 831-7440, has tours on tape, maps and other publications. The society's office is open weekdays from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 
Other Sights
 Benefit Street is also the setting for other fine buildings, including two splendid churches. The First Baptist Church in America (1775) is a classic New England meetinghouse with a steeple 185 feet high. At Benefit and Benevolent Streets, the First Unitarian Church (1816), a Federal structure, has the largest bell cast by Paul Revere & Son in Canton, Mass.
Between the churches, at Benefit and College Streets, is the Providence Athenaeum Library (1838). The austere gray Greek revival building gives no hint of the cozy interior, reminiscent of an English club. Open Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday from 8:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; Wednesday 8:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M.; Saturday 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.
The Museum of Art of the Rhode Island School of Design is at 224 Benefit. Its holdings include 19th-century French Impressionist paintings and the Colonial art and furnishings in Pendleton House, the first American wing created by any museum, with 4 paintings by John Singleton Copley and 2 of 10 surviving Townsend and Goddard secretary desks (c. 1770). Scheduled for June 21 to Sept. 1 is "The English Eye," a show of British art from the 18th century to the present (the museum owns a superlative collection of British watercolors, including 18 Turners). The museum is open Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday from 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursday noon to 8 P.M.; Sunday 2 to 5 P.M.; from June 16 to Aug. 31: Tuesday to Saturday from noon to 5 P.M.; $2, $1 for those 60 and over, 50 cents for those 5 to 18.
The Gov. Stephen Hopkins House, 15 Hopkins Street on the corner of Benefit, is a small, beautifully preserved house dating from 1743. Open from April to December, Wednesday and Saturday from 1 to 4 P.M.; free. In striking contrast is the John Brown House, across Benefit Street (entrance at 52 Power Street). This imposing Georgian house is a showcase of period furniture, wallpaper, porcelain, silver and fabric. Open Tuesday to Saturday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Sunday 1 to 4 P.M.; $5.
On the crest of College Hill, at Brown University, are fine Colonial, Greek Revival and Victorian buildings around the College Green. University Hall (1770 to 1771) was used as a hospital for Colonial troops in 1776. The university's Bell Gallery at the List Art Center, 64 College Street, will exhibit prints by Elizabeth Murray until June 2. Open Monday to Friday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M.
 
Diversions
 The Trinity Repertory Company, (401) 351-4242, one of the country's leading regional theaters, performs on two stages at 201 Washington Street. Jerome Sterner's "Other People's Money" plays upstairs to June 9; "The Stick Wife," by Darrah Cloud, is downstairs to June 2. Tickets: $22 to $30.
At the Providence Performing Arts Center, 220 Weybosset Street, (401) 421-2787, Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform with the White Oak Dance Project on Thursday at 8 P.M.; $35 to $75. Diana Ross will appear June 20 at 7:30 P.M.; $28.50 to $38.50.
On May 27, starting at 8:30 A.M. prior to Brown University's commencement at the First Baptist Church, faculty, graduating students and bands will march down College Street and along Benefit Street to the church, then at about 10:30 A.M. up Angel and George Streets back to the campus.
 On July 7, there will be a Cape Verdean outdoor festival in India Point Park at the head of Narragansett Bay, with food and folk dancing.
On the Fourth of July in Bristol, about a half-hour's drive from Providence, the 206th Bristol Civic, Military and Fireman's Parade, billed as the country's oldest continuous Independence Day parade, starts at 10:30 A.M. and marches down Hope and High Streets, with floats and bands. For a good view, get there by 8 A.M.; the town is closed to traffic afterward. Details: Bristol County Chamber of Commerce; (401) 245-0750.
 
Where to Eat
 In the last few years, Providence has seen a burgeoning of stylish and innovative restaurants. Angels, 125 North Main Street, (401) 273-0310, serves novel American food, often with a Portuguese or Spanish flair; a three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine, about $85. Grilled mahi mahi with ginger-lime vinaigrette and grilled asparagus is $19.95. Closed Sunday.
New Rivers, 7 Steeple Street (401) 751-0350, is an American bistro that draws on various ethnic cuisines and changes its menu seasonally. A three-course dinner for two with wine, about $65. Closed Sunday.
Lucky's, (401) 272-7980, and Al Forno, (401) 273-9767, are under the same ownership and share the same building at 577 South Main Street. Three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine, about $75. Lucky's serves country French and Al Forno northern Italian food. Pizza grilled on a wood fire is $11.95. Lucky's dirty steak with mashed potatoes is $24.95; at Al Forno, grilled Chicken breast with potato-stuffed eggplant sandwich and roasted peppers is $19.95. Both closed Sunday. They are usually crowded, and neither takes reservations; go early.
Leo's, 99 Chestnut Street, (401) 274-3541, is a colorful hangout for artists and politicians, with changing displays of local art; sandwiches are $4.95 to $5.95; dinner entrees, $9.95. Dinner for two with wine, about $45.
The Apsara at 716 Public Street, off Elmwood Avenue, (401) 785-1490, is popular for Cambodian food; an appetizer, soup and entree will cost $12. No liquor license; bring your own.
Angelo's Civita Farnese, 141 Atwells Avenue (401) 621-8171, is a local institution serving southern Italian food. Shells are $2.95, lasagne $4.95. People share tables, family style. A glass of red wine, $1.60.
 
Where to Stay
 The Omni Biltmore, in downtown Kennedy Plaza, (401) 421-0700, is the grandest hotel in town, with 246 rooms from $149 to $169 for two; weekend packages occasionally available for $99 to $119 with Continental breakfast.
The Marriott, (401) 272-2400, near the State House, at Charles and Orms streets, has 345 rooms and an indoor and an outdoor pool; $156; weekend packages, $79 to $89 with breakfast.
The 136-room Days Hotel on the Harbor, (401) 272-5577, 220 India Street, is between Interstate 195 and the bay; $85.
Among bed and breakfasts are the Old Court, (401) 351-0747, 144 Benefit, an imposing old house in an excellent location with 10 rooms, all with private bath, furnished with antiques and period wallpaper ($110), and C. C. Ledbetter, (401) 351-4699, 326 Benefit, which has a sitting room for guests and five bedrooms, four that share a bath; T.V. in every room; $65, $70 with private bath.
Budget choice: The Cady House, (401) 273-5398, 127 Power Street (near Brown and R.I.S.D.), dates from 1836; its three rooms -- one with private bath, two sharing a bath -- are decorated with American and Mexican folk art; $65.

PUB-DATE: May 19, 1991,

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1288 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Speculative Mansions;
Making Fantasy a Reality -- and Selling It

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, FLA.

 BODY:
AT night, Sam Caliendo lies awake thinking of interior waterfalls, indoor lagoons and rooftop pools. He is always thinking of unusual features for the multimillion-dollar homes he designs and builds to sell on speculation here.
By day, the 40-year-old builder travels the world selecting art, artifacts and furniture to adorn his showcase residences, which he sells fully furnished. He has bought handpainted silks in India and China, marble and leathers in Italy, golf carts in Poland, a 2,000-pound solid teak elephant sculpture in Africa, sharkskin furniture in Thailand and an antique wedding dress in Morocco to use as a wall hanging. 
 Mr. Caliendo is among a handful of people who specialize in building multimillion-dollar mansions speculatively. Most such homes are built as vacation retreats in resort areas, but some are also built as primary residences in metropolitan areas. In Montgomery County, Md., for example, a $4 million speculative house is on the market and one builder in Houston has been producing mansions speculatively since 1982.
"We're not seeing the wild speculative building of luxury homes that was the national craze in the mid to late 80's," said Stuart Siegel, executive vice president of Sotheby's International Realty Company. But there still is activity in areas with high concentrations of wealth, he said.
In Palm Beach, Fla., the dream of home ownership has catapulted into the realm of fantasy. The most expensive speculative house on the market there now is an unfurnished Italian villa-style oceanfront mansion for $11.5 million. The 27,300-square-foot home has 7 bedrooms; 10 full and 4 half baths; a heated saltwater swimming pool of marble with a 2,200-square-foot cabana; a tennis pavilion with a fireplace and wet bar, and separate tasting rooms for red and white wine, each 22 by 16 feet.
The house has been on the market a year. "But it usually takes 18 to 24 months to sell this kind of property," said Martha Gottfried, the listing broker for the property and the wife of the builder, Robert W. Gottfried.
The Gottfrieds also own the 115- by 491-foot vacant oceanfront lot next door, which they have on the market for $6.5 million. Mr. Gottfried has just started building three smaller inland speculative homes of 7,000 to 9,000 square feet that will be priced at $3.5 million and $4 million.
"We put a lot of our own money in the houses, but we have no trouble getting financing for the rest from the bank," Mrs. Gottfried said. "There are buyers out there more than willing to pay for this kind of property." Her sales have exceeded $100 million each year for the last five years.
"These buyers are people looking for instant gratification," she said, "People who walk into a Rolls-Royce dealership with cash and drive home in a new car."
THE demand for such luxury has slackened somewhat because of the recession, said Ken Dodson, a real estate agent here, but by no means has it dried up. Mr. Dodson's office receives calls regularly from potential buyers from all over the country looking for lavish homes in Florida.
These are typically impulse buyers, Mr. Dodson said, weighty on cash but short on the time, patience and imagination necessary to have homes custom-built for themselves. They are usually retired executives from the North looking for a second or third vacation home where they can spend a month or two a year in a tropical climate.
Despite their taste for flash and glitz, such wealthy buyers are generally "conservative types who might just as well show up in a rented car with Bermuda shorts, dark socks and tie-up shoes," he said.
Most of the "megahomes" are sold turnkey, or fully furnished so that buyers can move right in. But Mr. Caliendo has elevated the turnkey concept to new levels. His homes come complete with monogrammed bathrobes and custom-designed nightclothes hanging in the closets. Dining tables are set with fine china and crystal, freezers are filled with prime beef and the wine cellar is stocked. A custom-designed limousine may even be parked in an air-conditioned garage.
The amenities in Mr. Caliendo's homes are limited only by his imagination, which seems boundless. Who else would think of a lynx throw for the master bed, a handcarved lighted Lucite staircase, a tropical garden surrounded by a moat in the entrance foyer, etched glass walls, a bar trimmed in snakeskin, a carved stone and frogskin desk, and glass elevators?
He piles it on: fully equipped exercise rooms with padded floors; walk-in, climate-controlled bank vaults for fur storage; $40,000 entrance doors; theaters; media rooms with state-of-the-art video equipment, electronic juke boxes; oversized saunas and Jacuzzis; stereo systems with 82 speakers inside and out; sunken living rooms, and three-level entertaining rooms.
Mr. Caliendo's most recent creation is a $4.5 million home on a half-acre waterfront lot in Boca Raton's Royal Palm Yacht and Country Club. It is a 10,000-square-foot 17-room house. The $250,000 kitchen has mother-of-pearl cabinets. A two-story waterfall cascades inside the front entrance.
The developer, who also builds equally grandiose custom homes, said he builds his speculative homes "out of pocket" with his own capital or puts up 50 percent equity and borrows the rest from a bank.
Not all builders in Boca Raton are so fortunate, however. Mr. Dodson, the broker, recently lost the sale of a $1.5 million lot to a builder who could not get financing to produce a speculative house. Lack of real estate financing has not hurt buyers because they buy with cash, he said, but there is no question it has hurt builders.
Even in Aspen, Colo., where the average price of a single-family home has risen to $1.1 million, the unavailability of financing has thrown a wet blanket on the once-hot speculative home building market. "Banks here are only lending 50 percent of cost or one-third of the final appraised value on spec homes," Robert D. Ritchie, a real estate broker, said.
GORDON MATHEWS, a real estate developer in Pittsburgh, has been building and selling multimillion-dollar homes in Aspen and the nearby ski resort community of Snowmass for 10 years. He recently completed a 10,000-square-foot home on Red Mountain overlooking Aspen that is on the market, fully furnished, for $5.4 million. It has five bedrooms, six baths and a heated outdoor pool.
The biggest mistake a speculative builder of such houses can make is not providing sufficient living area. "But if done right, a builder can get $400 to $500 a square foot," he said. Most multimillion-dollar speculative homes in Aspen sell within months of completion, but Mr. Ritchie cites the example of one poorly planned home still on the market after three and a half years, despite a price reduction of $800,000, to $3.5 million.
Houston, unlike the resort areas of Colorado and Florida, has multimillion-dollar speculative homes being built as primary residences, but the perspective of the buyer is basically the same. Diane Lokey, the listing agent for a newly built 10,000-square-foot Georgian-style mansion priced at $2.95 million, said her customers are either too busy making money or too busy spending it to put in the time and energy needed to have a home custom built.
The mansion is in the River Oaks neighborhood, where half-acre lots sell for $1.1 million. A Houston builder, Ted Lazarides, who has a $2.4 million speculative home under construction in River Oaks, said his company has run out of land to build on. "We use our own money, so we can carry two or three houses at a time," he said. "If they don't sell quickly, obviously we don't sleep at night, but we don't face financial ruin either."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The most expensive speculative house in Palm Beach, Fla., is this oceanfront mansion with seven bedrooms, priced at $11.5 million. (John Gosman); In Aspen, Colo., this 10,000-square-foot house on Red Mountain is offered at $5.4 million, fully furnished. (Theodore K. Guy)

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
A Rare Breed of Speculators Who Builds Mansions

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

PUB-DATE: May 19, 1991,

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1678 words

HEADLINE: In Oyster Bay, Old Order Changeth Slowly

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
IN the early 1900's, when Theodore Roosevelt established his summer White House in the Victorian mansion of Sagamore Hill, he was lured by the beauty of the sheltered bay and surrounding woodlands, the quiet streets of Oyster Bay and the village's importance in American history.
Through the years, residents of the hamlet, many of them third and fourth generations of the same families, have fought to preserve the history and charm of their village. 
 On numerous occasions they have resisted intrusions into their historic 1.24-square-mile community, whose roots have been traced from the early 1600's. Recent community opposition blocked a proposal to develop one of the last vacant waterfront parcels.
But in Oyster Bay, as elsewhere, change has been inevitable. Last month the Town of Oyster Bay approved an application for a McDonald's on Pine Hollow Road, near the entrance to the hamlet. If the site plan is also approved, a fast-food restaurant will soon become part of the village for the first time.
On an adjacent parcel, formerly the site of a car dealership and a Carvel ice-cream store, land has been cleared and bulldozed for a strip shopping center that will include a large discount pharmacy and a video-rental chain.
Residents' reactions are mixed.
Everything in the town generates several schools of thought, the executive director of the Chamber of Commerce, Myralee Machol, said.
Although some residents have complained that McDonald's will create too much traffic and will prevent people from coming into the hamlet, she said,others argue that it will help to keep people in the community because they will not have to go to another town for fast food.
"There is a great fear of change, especially among longtime residents who want to keep everything the way it was," Mrs. Machol said. "Then there is a new generation of young families who want modernization and new goods and services, but they still want the old facades and to retain the historic quality of the town. Oyster Bay is due for a lot of changes. It's a throwback from an earlier era. But let's face it. We can't buy a nickel Coke anymore."
McDonald's application for a restaurant was a result of a comprehensive study, said Jeffrey Forchelli, whose law firm in Mineola represents the company. The community needs that type of restaurant, he said, adding that although at a hearing concerns were expressed over traffic and a precedent for fast-food, there was also a groundswell of support, particularly from the elderly and firefighters.
Mrs. Machol said McDonald's was known for its good-neighbor policy. "They like to put back into the community what they take out," she said. "They are known to use local services, to hire senior citizens and teen-agers from the community to fill their jobs."
But many residents and merchants said they feared that the restaurant and mall would be another step in changing the small-town flavor of their community. The community began to feel the changes several years ago, when its lone supermarket in the heart of the hamlet closed and moved south along Pine Hollow Road. There was no longer a base store in the village, and merchants suffered, said Larry Sussman, owner of the East Norwich Pharmacy in the Pine Hollow shopping center. Residents were forced to leave the hamlet to shop, signifying a shift from the friendly home atmosphere that Oyster Bay has always stood for, he said.
"The feeling in the village has always been the service-oriented mom-and-pop stores, where owners know their customers by their first names," Mr. Sussman added. "The more impersonal chain stores can only hurt the older stores, because there's just not enough business to go around."
The community is losing some of its identification with a small-town feeling, said Rose Kester, president of the East Norwich Civic Association and a resident for 36 years. The decision to allow a McDonald's will destroy luncheonettes and delis, she said, adding that approving a drive-in window would worsen traffic and pollution from idling cars.
 
'Another Jericho Turnpike'
 "The Town Board acted against the best interests of the local community," she said. "I am concerned that Pine Hollow Road will eventually deteriorate to another Jericho Turnpike."
There are many empty stores, from businesses that have closed, said Bob Basta, a resident. "If we make the town more convenient with a McDonald's, maybe we can bring business into the town," he said.
"It's interesting that in these hard economic times the company feels strong enough about our village, which is off the beaten track, to want to open up here. The Sleepy Hollow aura of Oyster Bay and its history make it a unique village and have kept it, even in hard times, from falling apart."
The sleepiness of the hamlet is often a draw for homeowners, said Vera Wiedenhaefer, a resident and a real-estate agent for Daniel Gale Associates. Victorian houses, she said, sell for an average of $350,000. Even during the hardest hit market, houses sell, she said, adding that there are 36 homes on multiple listings in the hamlet, a small number in comparison with nearby communities.
Built around the waterfront, Oyster Bay is different from most other shore communities on the Island. There are no restaurants on the water, and most of the waterfront development is industrial.
 
A Waterfront Flavor
 Yet the flavor is still of a waterfront community, Ms. Wiedenhaefer said, adding that most people move to the hamlet because they want to be near the water and boats.
Fear of overdevelopment in the hamlet and concerns about water quality in the harbor are not new. For years opposition has been growing to a proposal to convert seven acres of waterfront land, including the Jakobson Shipyard and an adjacent parcel, into a condominium complex, with a full-service marina and boat-repair center.
In response to opposition, Oyster Bay imposed a moratorium on waterfront building and authorized environmental studies. This year the town rejected the plan for development and decided to purchase the land for open space, said a spokeswoman for the town, Phyllis Barry.
The commitment from the town has just been verbal, said Ralph Naranjo, executive director of Friends of the Bay. The 4,000-member organization was instrumental in blocking the project. The group is primarily concerned about water quality.
Mr. Naranjo said a preliminary study showed that marina development and associated problems were not compatible with the harbor. The results of a final study of the effects are expected next month, he said.
 
Master Plan Is Sought
 "We hope that once it is complete, the town will adopt a zoning master plan," Mr. Naranjo said. "The Federal Government has committed to help subsidize a marine-education center, which we would welcome on this site. In the village, we're now seeing the eradication of the old and the intrusion of the new. We are not opposed to change, but want to see a better plan, so that there are not disastrous effects on the water quality."
If development is not conducted properly, the water in the bay will be degraded, and the oyster business will be destroyed, said Frank Flower, a descendant of a family running a 100-year-old oyster company, Frank Flower & Sons Inc., the last family owned oyster operation on the Island.
Oyster Bay and Cold Spring Harbor are the last Long Island bays open to shellfishing.
The hamlet's historical richness is evident in its buildings and its people.
Best known for Sagamore Hill, Oyster Bay is also the home of Raynam Hall, a colonial salt-box structure dating from the Revolution, when it was a Loyalist headquarters.
 
Early Telephone Switchboard
 The first Presbyterian Church on East Main Street, a Stick-style church built in 1873, is on the National Register of Landmarks.
The Town has designated landmarks like Snouder's corner drugstore, where the first telephone switchboard in Oyster Bay was installed in 1887 and where Roosevelt received his phone messages. Others are the Wightman House, built in 1720; the Masonic Temple, built as the Oyster Bay Inn in 1902, and the Printery, the original home of The Oyster Bay Guardian, founded in 1899.
Among the hamlet's population of 7,500 are many third- and fourth-generation families who continue to live and work in the village.
Oyster Bay is a multigenerational community, and people want to keep it that way, said Barbara Hadel, a longtime resident.
"I'd say that more than half of the residents work in town, and many walk to work and go home for lunch," she said. "There are many homes in which the same families have lived for several generations, and there are many kids in the high school whose parents and grandparents went through the schools. It's the old and new mixed together that makes the village unique."
 
Schools Also Feel Change
 But the inevitability of change has recently been felt even by the small Oyster Bay-East Norwich School District. Last month Superintendent Sidney Freund announced that he would move to the Herricks School District by the end of the school year.
Planning for reorganizing the district to eliminate overcrowding also divides the community. A school board proposal to expand the middle school in two phases at a cost of $2.8 million was voted down on Jan. 30, after which the board approved a modified plan with no extra cost for taxpayers.
The community is still divided on the issue, the president of the board, John Specce, said. One side wants to move the seventh and eighth grades to the high school. He said that based on demographic studies the board felt that would be shortsighted and was looking at long-range planning.
"Oyster Bay is a unique community that tries to hold on to its past," Mr. Specce said. "Each time change is seen in this town, there's an uproar before it's finally accepted. But change is inevitable. We can't bring back the horse and buggy. We must carefully plan for change and bring the 20th century into this village."
