HEADLINE: FILM;
How the 'Homeboys' Got That Way

BYLINE: By CHARLES SALZBERG; Charles Salzberg has written about film for Elle and Moviegoer.

 BODY:
It's early spring, six months after principal photography has been completed on "Hangin' With the Homeboys," and the director/screenwriter, Joe Vasquez, is back in the South Bronx neighborhood where he grew up and where most of his film was shot.
"The neighborhood has changed a lot in the past several years," he says, as he walks the familiar streets, the air punctuated by salsa music blaring from storefronts. "Drugs. Especially crack. I think what happened was a lot of people said, 'Hey, another drug you smoke, so it can't be that bad.' There's this girl I grew up with. Everybody was always saying, 'Oh, Zenobia, is so beautiful, man.' Now you can buy Zenobia for $5 dollars." 
 "Hangin' With the Homeboys," which opens in New York City on Friday, is the third film by the 28-year-old Jospeh B. Vasquez. Made on a modest budget of $2 million, it is a gentle, autobiographical film that chronicles the adventures of four young men -- two black, two hispanic -- from the Mott Haven section of the Bronx -- on a typical Friday night as they cruise the neighborhood. They get tossed out of a party, are nearly arrested for turnstile jumping, wreck their car and sneak into a disco.
 Along the way, their friendship is tested, as they confront the issue of race and the direction their lives will take. In the tradition of "Breaking Away" and "Diner," "Hangin' With the Homeboys" is an episodic male-bonding film with a difference. It's about minorities, although, as Mr. Vasqueza, whose father was Hispanic and mother black, points out: "It could have been about anybody. What I wanted to say by making them black and Hispanic is that you expect certain things of us that are sometimes negative, but it doesn't have to be that way."
 The events were based on a compilation of some of the wildest nights he and his own "homeboys" had, says Mr. Vasquez, who shared best screenwriter award (with Hal Hartley for "Trust") this year at the Sundance Film Festival. "The four guys are really me at different stages of my life."
 As Mr. Vasquez walks through his old neighborhood, he talks about how the four characters developed from a blending of the real-life indicidents, his own evolving persona and push-and-pull discussions between him and the actors during filming. Later, in talking to the actors themselves, there emerges a clearer portrait of how the four homeboys came to life on screen.
 
Johnny
The Quiet One, the Innocent One
 "When I was 17 or 18, I was a Johnny," Mr. Vasquez explains. "Very innocent, scared of girls."
 Johnny is quiet, introspective, the one most likely to make it out of the ghetto by going to college. Yet he is conflicted. Shy, paralyzed by his incredible naivete, he works in a supermarket while struggling with his aspirations.
 "Joe has a definite idea of who my caracter was," says John Leguizamo, as he strectches out in a chair in his tiny, one-room Manhattan apartment only a few blocks from the American Palace Theater, where he performs his highly praised one-man show, "Mambo Mouth." I wanted to make him more hip-hop, Red Zone, with big, baggy jeans and bright shirts. If I'd been able to play Johnny the way I wanted, he would've been seriously smoking. I had all the moves down. But Joe wanted him to be more Everyman Hispanic Kid."
 Johnny's innocence puzzled Mr. Leguizamo, who grew up in the Jackson Heights section of Queens. "I has a hard time because I was dating when I was 13, I used to say 'Joe, nobody's this naive.' And he'd go, 'You wannt bet?' "
 "It's embarassing," Mr. Vasquez says, reflecting on the conversation with Mr. Leguizamo months earlier on the set. Passing a carnival set up in a vacant lot, he tries to explain the forces that retarded his own social development. "I was really screwed up by Catholicism by my grandmother. John Leguizamo's the same way. One day, we were on the set of what was supposed to be his apartment. We'd built a little altar for his mother, thinking she'd be into religion, and I saw John flicking his finger at a picture of Jesus. I said, 'You too, huh?' "
 Mr. Lequizamo recalls: "Yeah, I remember that. My grandmother was a religious fanatic. Everything was the devil and God. Those were the only two forces she would listen to. There was nothing in between. Not even CNN. When I saw the 'The Exorcist,' I thought it was a documentary. You grow up thinking, 'God, I want to be so good.' And whenever you do something bad, you think, 'Oh, the devil is in me.' And then you rebel and you don't want to be thinking that way. You hate all that 3-D and velvet Jesus stuff. But later, you find you need something spiritual, something to hope for. Johnny's in that first stage. He wants to be so good, so kind, so gentle. Johnny the saint. He hasn't rebelled yet, but he will when he gets to college.
For Mr. Vasquez, this struggle with Catholicism resulted in a good deal of anger, which found its way into his earlier films, "Street Story" (1988) and "Bronx Wars" (1989), which made the rounds of film festivals but received no commercial release.
"I'm not always conscious of it," he says, "but it's there. In 'Homeboys,' I thought I'd completely left religion out of it, but then I saw the early screenings of a scene in the supermarket with Johnny and this girl he likes and there she is reaching for an apple. I said, 'Man, that's Adam and Eve.' " He shakes his head. "I guess I can't help it. It's so deep-rooted in me."
 
Willie
Confused, Heading Nowhere
 In a prologue scene, Willie is sitting in a welfare office confronted
by a black woman welfare worker berating him for not attending his job-training programs. She threatens to take away his welfare check.
Looking crazed and angry, Willie sputters, "You're just doing this to me because I'm black."
This was Joe Vasquez in his second phase.
"After college, I was trying to get work in the industry," he explains. "I couldn't get in the front door and I'd say, "This is because I'm a Puerto Rican guy. That was always my reason for everything. Sometimes I was right, but sometimes I was wrong."
Doug E. Doug, a 20-year-old standup comedian from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn who plays the role, says: "I thought I knew what was Willie was all about when I read the script. But Joe's interpretation was a little different from mine. He viewed Willie as being angry at the world and not wanting to do anything about it. I told Joe, 'I been a Willie. I've seen a trillion Willies, and it's not the fact that they don't want to do something; it's more like they need something to inspire them. I thought Willie was not that far gone, and Joe saw him as almost hopeless. We came in at someplace in the middle."
What Mr. Doug brings to Willie, who is confused, unemployed and totally without direction, is a sense of irony, an ambiguity which results in the suspicion that to some extent he uses his anger to manipulate people. "He uses that 'You're just doing this to me because I'm black stuff,' almost like a line in a bar to a girl," explains Mr. Doug, who, unlike Willie, has a ready smile and has made a living performing in comedy clubs starting when he was a student at St. John's University. He has also appeared in Spike Lee's 1990 film "Mo Better Blues."
"Willie might be a lot angrier in a Spike Lee movie," admits Mr. Vasquez, "because Spike would probably find my Willie a little insulting. I can see myself getting a call from Spike about this saying, 'What are you trying to say about our people ?' What I'm trying to say is you can use anything as a crutch, if you want to. Sure, there are some moments when it's justified, but not always. That's why I made the woman in the welfare office black, because if I made her white, people might say, 'Oh, yeah, he's got a point.' The thing is, in this instance, he doesn't have a point."
 
Tom
The Normal One, the Shallow One
 Tom, played by the 29-year-old stand-up comedian Mario Joyner, Tom is the most normal and probably the shallowest of the four homeboys. An aspiring actor, he makes his living trying to sell magazine by telephone. His claim to fame is that he would have played a waiter in "Rain Man," if the part hadn't been cut. He owns the car, allowing the homeboys mobility.
"The Tom character is me when I started getting settled," explains Mr. Vasquez. "I had a job as a film editor and a steady girl friend. Tom is the one I see out of the four of them as being most normal. He's got the girlfriend, the car, the 9 to 5 job, and the goal he's going after."
 
Vinnie
Faux Italian, He's Just a Gigolo
 Vinnie is a gigolo. His given name is Fernando, but he insists everyone call him Vinnie, so he can be mistaken for being Italian, which he thinks will make him more desirable to women. At 26, he's the oldest of the group and, as Mr. Vasquez describes him, he's the type who, "when he's 50, with a belly out to here, playing dominoes on a street corner, will still be hanging out with guys twenty years younger than he is."
"The Italian thing came from the guys I used to hang out with. They called me Vinnie, because I got into this fashion where I wore my hair slicked back. They accused me of trying to be Italian. It wasn't that I had an identity crisis; it's just they thought I did."
Mr. Vasquez, who is also an actor, originally planned to take the role of Vinnie himself, but he was eventually convinced the the film would be better served if he concentrated on directing. As a result, Vinnie is played by the 35-year-old Nestor Serrano, who has appeared opposite Robert DeNiro in the Broadway play "Cuba and His Teddy Bear," as well as in the films "Lethal Weapon 2" and The Money Pit." "I knew that character," says Mr. Serrano. "Those were the guys I hated. They were obnoxious and thought they were better than anyone else."
As it turned out, Mr. Serrano was so strong in his characterization that he was overpowering the rest of the ensemble. "He qas bugging me out," said Mr. Doug. "When I first saw hem, I said to myself, 'This is not a Vinnie.' But when I saw him act, I said, 'Oh, my God, you couldn't have picked a better Vinnie.
 To maintain the balance of the ensemble, the role was trimmed during editing. "I knew that would happen," says Mr. Vasquez, "because I was biased, since Vinnie was going to be played by me and because that whoring phase was the one I'd most recently been through."
As to what phase of his life Mr. Vasquez is in now, audiences will have to guess, since in his next project, "The Writing on the Wall," he will be working from someone else's script. Nevertheless, chances are it will still turn out to be a singularly personal film.
 
 
 
HAZARDS OF THE TRADE
 Filming "Hangin' With the Homeboys" late at night in the South Bronx was an adventure that included the mugging of several crew members and the occasional sound of gunfire. "They must have said, 'Let's get the 50 worst locations in one city and put them in a film,' " says Doug E. Doug. The area around Willis Avenue and 138th Street in Mott Haven was so bad that Nestor Serrano, who, like Joe Vasquez, was brought up in the Bronx, said to the director: "I can act like we're in the ghetto; I don't have to be in the ghetto."
One step that Richard Brick, the producer, took to minimize potential problems was to hire local residents as trouble spotters. "We had people who could tell from 100 meters away if someone was on crack, simply by their body language," he said.
Unlike his fellow actors, John Leguizamo appreciated shooting on location. "It's always nice to be in the real place, because even when you're not aware of it, while you're hanging around waiting for your scene, you pick up a lot of stuff," he says. "The neighborhood feeds you. You see people passing by and talking, and it's real and it sinks in."
Some of the film takes place in a car that was towed through the streets so slowly that local residents could run alongside. "They would sometimes throw things, or yell things at us," says Mr. Doug. "Everybody associated everybody with something else. Like they'd go, 'Oh, Mario Joyner, MTV guy.' For me they'd go, 'Oh, comedy guy.' Others would ask, 'Who's in the movie?' We'd say, 'Just us.' They'd say, 'Is Eddie Murphy in the movie?' We'd say, 'No.' They'd say, 'Then you're not in a movie.' "

HEADLINE: Brazil Denial On Currency

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19

 BODY:
The Economy Minister of Brazil, Marcilio Marques Moreira, has denied rumors that Latin America's biggest economy would imitate Argentina's latest anti-inflation plan and link its currency to the United States dollar.
"In Brazil no type of dollarization scheme is being considered," Mr. Moreira said at a news conference after meeting with his Argentine counterpart, Domingo Cavallo. 
 Mr. Cavallo's sudden arrival in Rio de Janeiro for a meeting with Mr. Moreira led to speculation in the local press that Brazil might be considering its own version of Argentina's anti-inflation measures, which began March 20.
Before the meeting, Mr. Cavallo said, "It will be interesting for us and the Brazilian team to exchange ideas on some specific aspects of our respective economic management." He refused to speculate on whether linking Brazil's currency to the dollar would work.
Under "dollarization," a government guarantees the local currency's value against the dollar at a fixed rate. The aim is to halt inflation and restore confidence in local currencies ravaged by galloping prices.
Like Argentina, Brazil in recent years has suffered repeated bouts of extremely high inflation, each followed by a drastic economic shock plan that has not had long-term success.

HEADLINE: Darman Sees Signs of Revival

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
President Bush's budget director, Richard Darman, said today that the economy was starting to recover from the recession, but that he could not predict how strong or how long the recovery would be.
"We are coming out of the recession," Mr. Darman said in an interview on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." 
 He predicted that the Federal budget deficit would ease slightly for the coming fiscal year, to less than $300 billion, but not enough below the earlier estimate of $318 billion to allow any increase in Government spending.
"We are exactly on course with our own forecast," Mr. Darman said. "We said it would be turning in this quarter; it is turning in this quarter."
After 10 months of contraction, the economy has begun to show signs of recovery, but analysts say they expect to see mixed signals from housing, industry, construction and employment figures for the next few months.
Mr. Darman's views echoed those of Michael Boskin, the White House's chief economic adviser, and Treasury Under Secretary David Mulford, who told Congress last week that the economy was turning around.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Upward Pressure Seen for Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Wall Street, still struggling to digest a record $37 billion worth of securities sold at the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions this month, is about to be served another heaping pile of paper.
This week, in what some analysts have called a shadow refunding, the Treasury will sell $37.5 billion worth of securities. Analysts said the auctions would probably put upward pressure on short-term interest rates. 
 An important reason these rates may rise is that the Treasury needs to drum up much more demand for the securities to be auctioned this week than it did earlier this month.
 
$27.5 Billion in New Cash
 The refunding auctions raised $19.5 billion in new cash. The securities to be sold this week, which include new two-year and five-year notes and $16 billion of cash management bills that have a one-year maturity, will raise $27.5 billion in new cash.
"These auctions may appeal to a variety of financial institutions, both domestic and foreign, as well as to investors seeking shelter from a nervous bond market," Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit. "However, the market may need much more help in the form of favorable economic news to absorb this new rush of supply."
That sort of news is unlikely to emerge this week, as few substantive reports on the economy are expected.
 
Spread Likely to Flatten
 With the Federal Reserve's target for the overnight Federal funds rate anchored at 5 7/8 percent, short-term rates are not likely to head up sharply, analysts said. But the difference, or spread, between rates on two-year notes and 30-year bonds is likely to flatten from what has been the widest gap in years. At the end of last week the spread between two-year notes and 30-year bonds stood at 1.45 percentage points.
After this week's auctions, "I would bet that the spread would drop to 135 basis points," said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "The supply problem will continue to be a focus for the market." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In addition to the Treasury auctions, the State of Massachusetts, troubled by the recession, is expected to tap the municipal bond market this week. In its first offering since Gov. William F. Weld took office, Massachusetts, which has the lowest debt rating of any state, will offer investors $475 million worth of securities.
 
Test of Confidence
 The offering will be a test of investor confidence in the Governor's recently proposed budget for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1.
To help close a budget gap that may reach $2 billion, Mr. Weld has proposed more than $800 million in spending cuts. Property tax increases are almost certain to follow, analysts said.
The stern measures will not be unique to Massachusetts, and are an important reason economists say that an economic recovery, when it finally arrives, will be muted.
"State and local governments were an engine of growth in the 1980's, but I expect they will be a drag on the recovery," said Cynthia Latta, senior financial economist at Data Resources Inc., an economic forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass.
With some 15 million employees, state and local government spending accounts for slightly more than 10 percent of gross national product.
In California, where the new Governor, Pete Wilson, has recently proposed a sales tax that would halve a projected $13 billion deficit, "our growth rate is going to be less than half what it was in the prior three years," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "That is a very substantial decline. And it is the best we are going to do."
Aside from cutting spending, layoffs will probably be widespread. And the effects of the layoffs are just beginning. For the first time in many months, employment at state and local governments declined in April,as some 18,000 people lost their jobs.
 
Crisis Called Severe
 "This is probably the most severe state and local government crisis since the Depression," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc. "Operating-budget deficits in the early 1980's were nowhere near as severe as they are now."
The good news for cash-strapped borrowers is that demand for tax-exempt securities remains very strong.
Underwriters at the First Boston Corporation, which is acting as lead manager for the negotiated sale of the Massachusetts bonds, would not speculate on what level of interest rates it would take to sell the new securities. At the end of last week, however, yields on outstanding Massachusetts bonds stood at 7.75 percent. The outstanding bonds carry ratings of Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: Exams in Other Nations Studied in U.S. for Ideas

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
In France, students must write a four-hour essay on what it means to be free. Germany's national test asks the significance of the French Revolution. Japan's examination demands that high school students hoping to make it into college identify the astronomer Ptolemy and Voltaire.
A month after President Bush called for a voluntary national test to improve American education, the National Endowment for the Humanities has entered a national debate with a report, "National Tests: What Other Countries Expect Their Students to Know," which compares the examinations given in other Western countries. The study, made public yesterday, raises an increasingly urgent question: what can America learn from its competitors, and what should it shun? 
 In many other countries, national tests are used to select the elite that goes on to a university education and high-paying, high status jobs. Americans say they do not want that kind of test, leading to questions about what an American national test should be. What kind of test should be given? Who should decide the contents? What should the stakes be? How could a test raise standards while preserving the American ideals of democracy and opportunity for all?
 
Learning From Others
 A host of competing interest groups, from politicians to educators, are vying to answer these questions. Lynne V. Cheney, the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, argues in the report that other countries' experiences provide some clues.
Americans can learn from these nations' high educational standards, the challenging questions on their tests and the explicit connection between what students study in school and what they will be tested on, Ms. Cheney said.
The closest American version of a national test, the Scholastic Aptitude Test, or S.A.T., deliberately avoids testing specific knowledge, so that schools can adopt their own curriculums. Because it does not test what students have learned, the S.A.T. is not comparable to other countries' national tests.
But an American national test would also have to be considerably different from European or Japanese models, say Ms. Cheney and others who endorse a national test.
 
Molding Test to U.S.
 "As we progress through this, people interested in education need to watch very closely to be sure the test we get reflects the country we are," she said.
While in Europe and Japan, most national tests are taken by a college- bound elite, President Bush has called for tests and high standards to be applied to every student, in 4th, 8th, and 12th grades. Such tests, his advisers argued, would show students why they need to study, enforce higher educational standards and help parents evaluate schools.
Europe and Japan use their tests to sort out students, allowing the successful few to move on to college and relegating the less successful to lower-paying, lower-prestige jobs. But an American test should be used to find and help those children who are not doing well, backers of the idea argue.
"What's tragic now is that these people are stuck with $4-an-hour jobs at McDonald's for the rest of their lives, and we're not admitting it," said Thomas H. Kean, the former Governor of New Jersey who is president of Drew University and heads Educate America, Inc., an organization that calls for a national test. "If we identify these people, we have some chance of saving people."
 
Ambition and Depth
 The most important lesson America can learn from other countries' examinations, according to the Cheney report and other testing experts, is their ambition and intellectual depth.
The French baccalaureat examination, for example, determines whether students can advance to college. The tests in history and geography offer detailed chronologies, maps, graphs, flow charts, political cartoons and excerpts from speeches, and ask students to use the materials in essays on subjects like resistance to the Nazis in Europe, debt in developing countries and the value of space in China.
Perhaps the closest parallel to the proposed American national examination among the examples offered in the report is the General Certificate of Secondary Education test given to most 16-year-olds in England and Wales. Low grades on this examination mean students will not be able to continue with advanced studies leading to college entrance.
Using such materials as historical drawings, lists of exports, population charts and excerpts from textbooks, students must be able to write essays that balance contradictory or opinionated historical sources. The topics include British colonization, the economic impact of enclosure (when fields once regarded as common lands were fenced off), social order in Tudor England and 16th-century education in Britain.
The only comparable American test that asks these kinds of sophisticated, open-ended questions is the Advanced Placement test, which can lead to students' receiving college credit. But that test is taken by only about 7 percent of American students, Ms. Cheney said. The achievement tests given by the Educational Testing Service do test what students have learned, but they also use multiple choice questions.
While the National Endowment for the Humanities report included only history, geography, philosophy and literature tests, similar kinds of open-ended questions are included on mathematics and science tests in many other countries.
"The European exam systems have a lot of the features we're looking for," said Lauren B. Resnick, director of the Learning Research and Development Center of the University of Pittsburgh. "They have extended, complicated kinds of tasks that students perform. In many of these countries, the day after the tests, the questions show up in the newspapers and are discussed on television. There is a whole culture that shapes the public's understanding of what the standards are."
In her report, Ms. Cheney also drew another lesson from other countries: a national examination system does not have to mean that every student takes the same test. In England, France and Germany, for example, different regions or states offer different examinations, which are checked to make sure they are equally difficult and are graded according to a single standard.
The National Governors' Association, one of several groups working to spell out how to meet President Bush's education goals, has called for a series of regional exams, with scores adjusted so that students could rank themselves nationally. Ms. Resnick said she was working on several ways to do that. But Gregory R. Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service, which developed the S.A.T., the Advanced Placement and the Achievement tests, warned that would be an expensive and difficult undertaking.
Other experts said the examples in the report also showed what Americans should not imitate. Japan's entrance examination, for example, is fiendishly difficult and requires memorization of arcane facts in a numbing multiple-choice format.
"What we're going to be building is a uniquely American system," Dr. Resnick said. The United States' cultural diversity and the need to give tests to everybody mean that an American test would have to include more varied questions geared to several age levels, she said.
 
A Question of Cost
 The format of any national examination is just one of several unknowns about President Bush's proposal. Although more detailed announcements are expected in the next few weeks, it is not clear who would decide the contents of a test, how long a good test would take to develop, and how much it would cost.
Many educators, among them Joe Nathan of the University of Minnesota, remain worried that a national test, even if drawn up by different regions, could impose curriculums and inhibit teachers' creativity and responsiveness to their students' interests. In France, Japan, and England, for example, national education ministries do set curriculums.
The National Endowment report does not say how much it costs to develop and administer the tests in other countries, and statistics are hard to come by. A press officer at England's Department of Education said she had no national figure because tests are drawn up by different regional examining boards. But it is clear that tests with essay questions are expensive.
The S.A.T. now costs $16 per student, and the Advanced Placement exam costs $65 per student, Mr. Anrig said. A preliminary estimate places the cost of England's General Certificate of Secondary Education exam at $110 per student, according to the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

HEADLINE: New Shopping Center Opens in South Bronx

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Concourse Plaza, a $150 million shopping center just off the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx that has come to symbolize the area's quest for economic well-being, opened for business yesterday with overflow crowds thronging its stores but with the shadow of the city's fiscal problems hanging over it.
The opening seemed to underscore subtly the dismay Bronx officials feel at the possibility that New York City's fiscal troubles may severely undermine other facets of their broader boroughwide development plan. 
 That plan seeks to tie various housing, commercial and city-government construction projects into a minutely coordinated whole. Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, has made its fruition the major test of his term in office.
But the city's fiscal crisis has dealt those plans a series of setbacks recently. A new $200 million Police Academy, that was to have been built on 153d Street, east of the Grand Concourse, has been shelved for the time being. Instead, the city will renovate the present Police Academy near Gramercy Park in Manhattan.
 
'Welcome to the New Bronx'
 And financing for an expansion of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, which is also part of the plan to lace significant development from one end of the Bronx to the other, may also be in jeopardy.
Such uncertainty prompted Mr. Ferrer to remark to an outburst of applause from the audience that while Concourse Plaza "means jobs and a furthering of the economic development of our community, we're not going to stop."
"We're still going to fight for the Police Academy," he added.
"Welcome to the new Bronx," Mr. Ferrer declared to the scores of people who watched the brief opening ceremonies in the center's parking lot. "Yes, this, too, is in the South Bronx."
The 10-acre development on 161st Street just east of the Grand Concourse includes a 60,000-square-foot Waldbaum's supermarket that will be open 24 hours, a 10-screen cinema, 40 retail shops, and a 3,300-car garage. Construction will begin on the center's final piece, a 10-story office building, next month, Bronx officials said.
 
Relatively Moderate Prices
 Bronx residents and officials have long complained that they lacked a huge supermarket that could accommodate large crowds -- and bring the relatively moderate prices and fresher produce that chain stores could offer.
Scarlet Pellecer, a senior at Bronx Comprehensive High School and a part-time cashier at the Waldbaum's, said that the line of customers for the store had already formed when she arrived for work at 7:30 A.M. The line to enter the supermarket stretched nearly 70 yards.
That line enabled Bernard Rosenshein, whose New Rochelle, N.Y.-based firm, Rosenshein Associates, developed the shopping park, to pose and answer the oratorical question of whether such a development could work in the South Bronx.
"There's your answer," he said, beaming. "The jury's in."
Stanley Lang, president of Waldbaum's, said studies showing that 1.5 million people live within a two-mile radius of the site convinced them that the project could work.
 
'Just Like Everyone Else'
 "When we found that out, we knew there was no risk," Mr. Lang said. "The people of the Bronx are just like everyone else. They want good food and good service. We've seen before that when you bring something to the community, they'll turn out for you."
Jose Caban, a maintenance worker at the Bronxchester Houses, was one of those who did, arriving at the Waldbaum's line in the late morning. The line was so long that Mr. Caban and his friends decided to wait until the evening to go shopping. But he was far from upset as he browsed through the rest of the center.
"This is the best thing that ever happened to the South Bronx," Mr. Caban, 33 years old, said, holding 3-year-old Melissa Sergera, the daughter of a friend. "A big supermarket like this will help people save because you can take advantage of coupons and sales. There's the movies and parking, and lots of security, too. This is a place you can bring the family."
That Concourse Plaza was built solely by private funds, and that Mr. Rosenshein and James Hyland, Waldbaum's executive vice president had grown up in the Bronx, as he had, seemed to be a particular point of pride to Mr. Ferrer.
"They said it couldn't be done," he said with a smile before snipping the ceremonial ribbon to the development. "Some said it shouldn't be done, But it's here and it's all ours."

HEADLINE: AUSTIN JOURNAL;
Ham's Kissing Cousin Gets a Hug

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Minn., May 18

 BODY:
Geo. A. Hormel & Com pany threw itself one humdinger of a 100th birthday party today. There was a hot-air balloon, rock music and more cans of Spam, the company's most famous product, than seemed remotely digestible.
It was a day to celebrate how George Hormel, a German immigrant, chanced upon southern Minnesota's "cool blue skies," and stayed to found a meat-packing empire whose sales last year topped $2.6 billion. Along the way, the company claims to have invented Canadian bacon, marketed the first canned ham and sent 200 million pigs to hog heaven. 
 Chilly, windy weather eroded the expected turnout of 5,000 people. But it did nothing to spoil the fun of the hundreds on hand.
For Hormel, it was most of all a day to sing the praises of Spam, albeit just one of the company's 1,600 products. There were Spam breakfasts, a Spam eating contest, Spam sculptures and a pageant to choose the children who would reign as king and queen of Spam. Prowling tirelessly about was Spam Man, dressed to resemble a can of you-know-what.
The self-portrait clearly intended to emerge from this "Spam Jamboree Day" was of a company robustly back on track after labor battles that peaked in early 1986 when the Governor called in the National Guard. Name-calling, vandalism and violence marked the 13-month battle, which ended with hundreds of union workers losing their jobs.
There remains bitterness against the company long known for its benevolence, as reflected by its 1938 initiation of one of the nation's earliest profit-sharing plans. The worst acrimony, though, was between friends and relatives who diverged on whether to cross the picket line.
Some say the passions are cooling. "Everyone is coming around and looking up," said Cheryl Cook, who works in Hormel's consumer affairs department. "It's a healing process."
Others disagree. "It's like toasting the executioner, the guy who pulls the lever," said Pete Winkles, who is business agent for Local P-9 of the United Food and Commercial Workers union.
And some see deeper motives. "They're trying to control how people remember history," said Peter Rachleff, a labor historian at Macalester College in St. Paul.
Since before it employed George Burns, Gracie Allen and a pig named Spammy to star in radio commercials, Hormel has been aggressively promotional. It seems never to tire of disseminating Spam lore -- from its much-maligned role in feeding troops to the boggling statistic that Americans down 3.8 seven-ounce cans of the stuff a second.
The company even revels in the abuse heaped on Spam, calling it "the Rodney Dangerfield of the food world." Hormel recalls the old Army line that Spam is ham that couldn't pass its physical. Spam, short for spiced ham, is made from chopped pork shoulder meat and ham.
Today's events evoked a sort of America one associates with country fairs. Instead of pie contests, people were invited to concoct original creations from Spam. There was Spam fried rice, Spam wild rice casserole, and much more.
After the judging, people lined up to heap plates with samples of the Spam masterpieces. Some then wandered over to watch people making sculptures from Spam, including fair likenesses of Rodin's "The Thinker."
The contest to be Spam King and Queen, limited to those 5 to 8 years old, was to die for. David, 6, was asked when he last had Spam. "I can't remember," he said. The announcer pressed on: "Was it a short time or a long time?" The reply: "A long time." Ashley, shivering in a pink leotard and a pig snout, was asked how much Spam she could eat at one time. "A spoonful," she said.
Justin, 8, was chosen king, perhaps because he said he would eat 10 million cans if given the opportunity and wouldn't share with anybody.
The eating contest was most frenetic. Contestants raced to see who could most rapidly consume a can of Spam and glass of water. Some picked up the entire pink block and ate it like a candy bar, and others nipped like terriers.
The winner, with a time of 56.71 seconds, was Steve Kirschenman. Mr. Kirschenman attributed his victory to his mother, but did not explain.
It is doubtful Hormel's birthday party changed much of anything. Those who led the strike are still bitter. "They're trying so hard to make this thing go away, and it won't go away," declared Jim Retterath, a former Hormel worker and union officer who now does maintenance work in a nursing home.
Others cited Hormel's big contribution to the economy and charities of Austin, a town of 23,000. "It's a blessed community, all the way," said Gordon S. Anderson, who owns a contracting company.

HEADLINE: Americans Find Royal Visit Moving Some to Adulation, Others to Outrage

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 19

 BODY:
Americans see Queen Elizabeth II as an anachronism, a touchstone of history or the epitome of all this democratic nation's most cherished fantasies of royalty. As she and her husband make their stately way through a 13-day visit to the United States, they are evoking reactions from adulation to outrage, amusement to befuddlement.
The famous breach of protocol in Washington, in which an enthusiastic woman wrapped her arms around the Queen in a spontaneous hug on Wednesday, was a tangible demonstration of many Americans' fascination with the British monarchy. So are the huge sales of supermarket tabloids and popular magazines filled with tidbits about the royal family. 
During the Queen's 12-hour visit to Miami this weekend, the local NBC-TV affiliate offered continuous coverage and a special telephone line, in English and Spanish, to tell callers the best places to spot the Queen. And many people treated the royal visitor and her husband, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, with a reverence they would be unlikely to show almost any American.
 
'Various Stages of Grovel'
 "It has been hilarious watching social Miami, in various stages of grovel, trying to figure out how to act in front of this short lady who never says anything," said Dave Barry, The Miami Herald humor columnist.
But others have found the pomp and circumstance distasteful, an extravagance unbecoming in hard economic times. "The Queen is such an anachronism," said Trudy Harris, a retired librarian from Willingboro, N.J., who was visiting her daughter here. "The U.S. shouldn't pay that kind of money for such a grand reception and tour. It's not healthy thinking in our time to be spending our energies on this cardboard figure."
The Queen is not cardboard, but neither is she a movie star who climbed her way to opulence and privilege. Nor is she a saintly humanist like Mother Teresa. The Queen exists on a plane few others inhabit. The mixed reactions of Americans, from blue-collar baseball fans in Baltimore to socialites from Highland Park in Dallas, reflect that rare reality.
Amitai Etzioni, a sociologist at George Washington University, sees a distinction between Americans' interest in the Queen and their interest in younger figures -- not only celebrities like Madonna and Michael Jackson, but even other members of the royal family.
"The latter are part of the youth culture, of risque behavior," said Professor Etzioni. "The Queen has her own pedestal. We used to see this in our Presidency, but we've always been ambivalent about treating our Presidents with too much awe. They are, after all, politicians.
"But the Queen, she's above politics. She's not anti-abortion or anti-anything. She's a symbol rather than a person. We can all project on her our own values and views. There is no controversy with her."
To be sure, not everyone along the Queen's journey has felt that way. Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, and several other Congressional colleagues boycotted her historic first speech to Congress on Friday "in protest to the British occupation in Northern Ireland," Mr. Kennedy said. Irish-Americans protested her visit in Baltimore and Washington.
Here in Miami, a group of blacks and whites gathered on the sidewalk in front of the Hotel Intercontinental, a short distance from where the royal yacht Britannia was moored, to protest the city's welcome for the Queen. The protest was organized by Boycott Miami, a black group that lobbies against Miami as a convention site until more blacks are included in the tourist industry.
 
Examples of Democracy
 Leibole Muchnik, a Honduran Jew who recently immigrated to the United States from Tegucigalpa, operates a hot-dog stand near the hotel. For him, the combination of American fascination and protest over the Queen's visit to Miami epitomized what had brought him to this country.
"To me this is democracy," said Mr. Muchnik, who was doing a brisk business in both hot dogs and interviews. "Over here, you've got protesters against the Queen. Over there, you've got people who love her. Me, I've got business from both."
Richard Green, a seafood supplier, said the Queen's visit was "nice."
"It represents a bygone era, part of history that wasn't torn down," he said.
At Booker T. Washington, a school that the Queen visited here, the royal visit was a rare opportunity for Luz Rivera, a seventh grader, to curtsy, although the gesture is not required of Americans. It was, she said, an occasion to "walk straight, sit down properly and talk properly."
Friday evening, over by the Port of Miami's Terminal 12 where the royal yacht Britannia was anchored, Maria Fuentes Howard and her husband, Henry Howard, stood several hours with their baby, Alexander Joseph, hoping for a glimpse of the Queen and of former President Ronald Reagan, who was one of her dinner guests. The Howards' baby's carriage sported a British flag.
"We like the Queen," said Mrs. Howard. "And I wanted to see President Reagan because I'm originally from Nicaragua and he supported our fight for democracy."
For Janet Bryant of Washington, however, the Queen's visit to the capital was one big inconvenience.
"I only thought about her when it was time to go home since I have to go up Pennsylvania Avenue and it was always blocked off," said Mrs. Bryant, who is an office manager for a law firm. "For two or three days it was just madness. I don't see the point. She doesn't pay taxes. Her children don't work. She doesn't lift a finger to do much of anything."
In Tampa, where the the Queen is to arrive on her yacht on Monday morning for a two-and-a-half-hour visit that will include a meeting with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, invitations to royal events are much sought after. "People who are business or corporate types who usually don't get ruffled, when it comes to the Queen, they lose it," said John Dunn, a spokesman for Mayor Sandra W. Freedman. "People who ordinarily wouldn't stoop so low to call in chits are doing it to see the Queen."
Is it a love of human hierarchy that prompts Americans to go all goosey over the Windsors? Is it a hankering for hauteur after almost three centuries of leveling? Or is it the triumph of a toney accent over common sense?
"Every time I go to London, I feel it," said Mr. Barry, the columnist. "Americans just don't feel as classy as the British. I mean, I tell myself, I know I'm as smart as this person -- he's lying down drunk on the subway -- but he's got this accent like Alistair Cooke, and that intimidates me."

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1991,

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2557 words

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
At Notre Dame, a Call to 'Be Informed'

 BODY:
Margaret O'Brien Steinfels, the editor of Commonweal magazine, advised graduates at the University of Notre Dame yesterday not to ignore the poverty and suffering of millions of people around the world but to "be informed, think carefully and take responsibility."
Speaking to the 1,700 undergraduates and 578 recipients of advanced degrees at Notre Dame's 146th commencement, Ms. Steinfels said: "We all start out in very ordinary ways. Our responsibilities lie before us, in the work we choose, in the friends we make and keep, in the prayers we offer." 
 Ms. Steinfels, author of "Who's Minding the Children -- The History and Politics of Day Care in America" (Simon & Schuster, 1973), received an honorary law degree at the commencement ceremonies.
Former Representative Lindy Boggs from Louisiana, in addition to receiving an honorary degree, received the Laetare Medal, given by the university each year to honor the contributions of an American Catholic.
Marva Collins, founder of the Westside Preparatory School in Chicago and a pioneer in inner-city education, was also honored.
Other honorary degrees were given to Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey or Ireland, Jane Pauley of NBC News, Archbishop John R. Quinn of San Francisco and Surgeon General Antonia Novello.
 
University of Wisconsin
John T. Darnton, weekend news editor of The New York Times and winner of the 1982 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting, spoke at two ceremonies on Saturday, for undergraduates in the College of Letters and Science in the afternoon and for master's and bachelor's degree recipients in journalism, social work and science in the evening. He called on graduates to move away from the materialism of the 1980's.
The 138th commencement at University of Wisconsin at Madison was held in five ceremonies over the weekend for the 3,392 undergraduate and 1,416 graduate students.
"It's time for something new, for commitment, involvement, altruism," said Mr. Darnton, a 1967 graduate of the university. "It's time for a new political activism. We need sacrifice and ideals to fill the vacuum of the Cold War."
James Crow, professor emeritus of genetics and zoology, urged yesterday's group, those receiving degrees in education, agricultural science, nursing and medicine, to "keep on learning for the rest of their lives."
 
Smith College
The author Robert Fulghum delivered the 113th commencement address yesterday at Smith College.
Mr. Fulghum, a Unitarian minister who describes himself as a philosopher, wrote the best-selling book "All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten" (Villard, 1988).
Smith awarded 742 diplomas at its campus in Northampton, Mass. Honorary degrees were awarded to Toni Morrison, who won a Pulitzer Prize for her book "Beloved" (Knopf, 1987); Dame R. Nita Barrow, Governor-General of Barbados, and Mildred Berendsen, headmistress of the Chapin School in New York.
 
Haverford College
Haverford College awarded four honorary degrees to individuals distinguished in the fields of government, journalism, nuclear physics and women's legal rights at the college's 158th commencement. The ceremony for 306 graduating seniors was held yesterday in front of Roberts Hall on the college's campus near Philadelphia.
Haverford awarded a Doctor of Letters degree to Dave Barry, a nationally syndicated humor columnist, who is a 1969 Haverford graduate and a 1988 Pulitzer Prize winner for commentary. A Doctor of Laws degree was awarded to Catharine A. MacKinnon, a law professor who pioneered the legal theory defining sexual harassment as an actionable form of sex discrimination.
Diane J. Abbott, the first black woman elected to the British Parliament, received a Doctor of Laws degree. The last honorary degree was awarded to Freeman J. Dyson. Mr. Dyson received a Doctor of Science degree for his achievement in nuclear physics at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University.
 
Bryn Mawr College
Harris Wofford, the newly appointed United States Senator from Pennsylvania, was one of several speakers at the 105th commencement yesterday at Bryn Mawr College.
Senator Wofford, a Democrat appointed by Gov. Robert P. Casey to succeed the late Senator John Heinz, served as president of the College from 1970 to 1978 and was a special assistant to President John F. Kennedy on civil rights.
The commencement ceremonies began on Saturday and were held over two days in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
Barbara Ehrenreich, who has written seven books including "Fear of Falling" (Pantheon, 1989) and "The Worst Years of Our Lives" (Pantheon, 1990), addressed the graduates on Saturday.
Bryn Mawr, an all female institution for undergraduates, awarded 294 bachelor degrees. The graduate schools, which are co-educational, awarded 33 doctorates, 124 masters.
 
Pennsylvania State University
Pennsylvania State University awarded 7,547 diplomas at the University Park campus over the weekend.
Penn State held 11 different ceremonies: 10 for undergraduate colleges and another for its graduate school. It is the 130th year the university has held commencements.
In his address before the College of Earth and Mineral Sciences, William A. Schreyer, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch and Company, told students not to be too discouraged if they have a hard time finding a job.
"Things weren't much different when I graduated from Penn State in 1948," he said. "Inflation was heating up and most people suspected we were heading back toward depression. How could we know, just over the horizon, the biggest economic boom in history was about to start?"
Speakers at other graduations included David R. Jones, assistant managing editor of The New York Times, who graduated from the university in 1954, at the School of Communication, and State Senator Chaka Fattah at the College of Education.
 
University of Virginia
The American Ambassador to Kuwait, W. Nathaniel Howell, told graduates at the University of Virginia yesterday to use "a healthy dose of informed skepticism" in judging how news events are presented by the media.
Mr. Howell is an alumnus of the University of Virginia, which awarded 4,105 diplomas yesterday in Charlottesville.
Mr. Howell kept the Embassy in Kuwait open for more than four months after the invasion by Iraq last August.
He said many journalists in the Middle East were not well-informed about the cultures of the different countries and, therefore, were unable to properly present information.
 
Spelman College
Spelman College's commencement exercises were held yesterday morning in the Atlanta Civic Center. The keynote address was delivered to 365 senoirs by Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon of Washington. Other speakers included the actress Ruby Dee, Miriam Makeba, the South African folk singer, and Marguerite Ross Barnett, the first black female president of the University of Houston.
Mayor Dixon made history in November by becoming the first female leader of the capital. She is also the first black woman to serve as mayor of a major American city.
 
Morehouse College
Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was the keynote speaker at Morehouse College's 107th commencement yesterday on the campus in Atlanta.
Honorary Doctor of Law degrees were awarded to Condoleezza Rice, former Special Assistant to President Bush for National Security Affairs, and Dr. Asa Yancey Sr., medical director of Grady Memorial Hospital and a 1937 graduate of Morehouse.
 
SUNY
Mathilde Krim, an AIDS researcher and educator, told the 4,278 graduates at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, "AIDS is giving us a lesson in humility," yesterday during the school's 31st commencement exercises. Dr. Krim, who was a recipient of an honorary degree, explained, "It teaches us that the relentless evolutionary forces at play in nature continue to create new forms of life, and that for all mankind's arrogance and destructive powers, we are not yet the masters of the universe, nor even necessarily nature's most favored creature."
 Dr. Krim is the founder of the AIDS Medical Foundation, a group that fosters support for AIDS research, and merged with the American Foundation for AIDS Research in 1985. In her speech, she referred to the nondiscriminate nature of the AIDS virus, and urged graduates to "enjoy the love, the friendships, the work and the beauties the world offers you." "Because AIDS makes us suffer," she said, "and grieve for those we have lost, it is teaching us to value life."
Also honored with a degree was the author Isabel Allende, the niece of Salvador Allende, the assassinated President of Chile. Other university campuses enjoyed a sunny, pleasant day of mass exodus. At SUNY New Paltz, 1,600 students gathered at the college's old main quadrangle for its 104th commencement exercises. The speaker and honorary degree recipient was Robert Jay Lifton, an award-winning writer and psychiatrist.
At SUNY Buffalo's 145th commencement, 6,500 students received degrees during 12 exercises over the weekend. Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, was awarded the Chancellor Norton Medal for his contributions to national and world affairs. Receiving honorary degrees were Dr. John W. Gardner, founder of philanthropic organizations; Dr. James P. Comer, an urban education reformer and Dr. Jerome Kassirer, who becomes the editor in chief of The New England Journal of Medicine in July.
 
St. John's University
In a speech at St. John's University's 121st commencement this weekend, the university's president told students to be conscious of the effects of violence on the world, especially after the Persian Gulf war. "We must not overlook the pain and suffering which still is being endured by many as a result of this war." the Rev. Donald J. Harrington said. "Whenever there is such violence, there is great ambiguity in victory."
 More than 2,000 students at both the Queens and Staten Island campuses participated in the commencement. In Jamaica, Queens, 900 diplomas were awarded to students at St. Vincent's College, part of the university's system, yesterday. Honorary degrees were awarded to Delores Bernadette Grier, the Vice Chancellor from Community Relations of the Archdiocese of New York, and Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
 On Saturday, when 800 students graduated from the colleges of business administration and pharmacy in Jamaica, Queens, two former students were awarded honorary doctorates. They were Patricia D. Collins, a New York State Supreme Court Justice, and John T. Roche, president of his own company that specializes in investments and the securities trade. Earlier Saturday, at the university's Grymes Hill campus in Staten Island, the Notre Dame College, the College of Business Administration and St. Vincent's awarded degrees to 386 undergraduates.
 
University of Hartford
Dr. Carl E. Sagan, the astronomer and author, told students "to care for, preserve, protect and cherish" the earth's environment in his keynote address at the University of Hartford's 34th commencement yesterday. Dr. Sagan received an honorary degree from the university, which graduated about 1,300 undergraduates and graduate students.
Also honored were Dr. Frederick G. Adams, a former state health commissioner; Nicolaas Bloembergen, a Nobel laureate and physics professor at Harvard University; the author Francine du Plessix Gray; Lloyd Richards, the dean of the Yale School of Drama, and James D. Wolfensohn, the head of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
 
University of Connecticut
The President of Hungary and the children's television host Mister Rogers were the keynote speakers at the 108th commencement of the University of Connecticut in Storrs this weekend. More than 5,000 students graduated. On Saturday, Arpad Goncz, Hungary's President, spoke to 1,066 graduate students about what the recently democratized country can offer the American investor. Fred Rogers, the host of "Mister Rogers's Neighborhood," spoke at dual ceremonies yesterday. "Listen to the children, he told the 3,500 undergraduates. "Learn from them." The two received honorary degrees, as did James Comer, an innovator in child education, and Harold Seidman, who served six Presidents at the Bureau of the Budget.
 
Manhattan College
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former Republican candidate for New York City mayor, told the graduates of Manhattan College yesterday to shun the advice of cynics who say "problems are so complex that is useless to try and solve them." Speaking at the college's 143d commencement, he told the 550 graduates from four schools to enter public service and try to reverse the growing tolerance of crime, including violence on the streets and "the white-collar crime and business crime which create some of our most pressing political and social problems."
He urged that drug-treatment programs be improved and that law and ethics be made required courses in primary and secondary schools. The Roman Catholic college awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree to Mr. Guiliani, a 1965 graduate of the college.
 
Colgate University
More than 700 graduates at Colgate University's 170th commencement heard Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, encourage them to make American society more nurturing of the arts and education. Senator Lugar was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree by the university in Hamilton, N.Y. Other honorary degree recipients were: the Rev. Dr. Samuel Proctor, pastor emiritus of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem; Judith Jamison, artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater; Kevin Phillips, a political commentator; Judy Woodruff, a correspondent for the "MacNeil-Lehrer" television news program, and E. Garrett Bewkes, the retiring chairman of the Colgate board.
 
Adelphi University
Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., conferred 2,400 degrees yesterday at its 95th commencement. The university's president, Peter Diamandopoulos, urged the graduates to "make the most of your education" by seeking the truth through critical thought. "You ought to do what your intellectually cultivated individuality obliges you to do," he said. "That is, become good by doing good." Adelphi awarded honorary degrees to Dr. Martin Feldstein, the economist and Harvard University professor; Dr. Leszek Kolakowski, a philosophy professor at the University of Chicago; Ilias Lalaounis, an artist, and Dr. Tsung-Dao Lee, a Nobel laureate and physics professor at Columbia University.
 
St. Lawrence University
More than 500 graduates at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., were told yesterday by Mark H. McCormack, a sports agent, that they should find their genius and make it their occupation, in the university's 136th commencement. The university awarded honorary degrees to four people including Mr. McCormack, the founder and chief executive of International Management Group. The others were Virginia Hazzard, an advocate for charities; Wilcomb E. Washburn, a scholar of American history, and John R. Dunne, assistant United States Attorney General for civil rights and a former New York State Senator.

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1284 words

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Democrats Stick Toes In Waters of 1992 Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Nine months before the Presidential contests begin, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts remains the only official candidate for the Democratic nomination, but a number of Democrats are suddenly sniffing the air.
Politics, after all, abhors a vacuum. Ambitious men can see opportunity where others see only a doomed battle against a popular incumbent. The political heavyweights, like Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, continue to hang back. But a new cadre of potential candidates is moving onto the scene, from Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. 
 They are, by and large, newcomers to Presidential politics, with a chance of making a name in a wide-open contest, and perhaps with less to lose than those higher on the ladder of Democratic leadership.
As the clock winds down, this disparate collection of Democrats is struggling with decisions that are equal parts electoral calculus, simple faith and raw desire. Here is a look at some of the most-watched "potentials," as they are known in Democratic circles, with the caveat that this is an ever-expanding and contracting field:
Senator Lloyd Bentsen Friends have long said that Mr. Bentsen was "considering a race but not actively exploring it." With his name recognition and fund-raising ability, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee has more time than most to ruminate over a decision. But there are very few signs of fire in the belly, and more and more Democrats are convinced that Mr. Bentsen will not run.
"My sense is that while he hasn't slammed the door shut, he's done everything but," said Robert Strauss, the former national party chairman and longtime friend. One Democratic House member noted that Mr. Bentsen is building a new vacation home in San Diego, not customary behavior for a man beginning the forced march of a presidential campaign.
Gov. Bill Clinton The Arkansas Democrat said he would serve out his four-year term when he ran for re-election last year, but he clearly enjoys the Presidential speculation now swirling around him. Betsey Wright, the state Democratic chairwoman and a longtime Clinton adviser, said she saw "no signs that he has been seriously seduced by it."
But Mr. Clinton has a national platform as chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrist and conservative Democrats, and he has been traveling the country honing a domestic message. When pressed on his presidential ambitions in a recent interview, Mr. Clinton said: "It's not anything I've ruled out over the long run. It's just a question of whether it should be done now."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo He said he has "no plans and no plans to make plans" for a Presidential campaign. He said: "I'm not a candidate. I'm not a potential candidate. I'm not a make-believe candidate." But the Governor of New York sends other signals that he wants to be a national player: Once the state budget is put to rest, he says he wants to travel the country to challenge President Bush's domestic policies. He has mixed it up with the Democratic Leadership Council. He is proposing a new Federal investment tax credit and assailing supply side economics.
Ronald H. Brown, the national Democratic chairman, said Friday that he believed Mr. Cuomo was "looking seriously" at a race and that his decision would be clear by the end of summer. When asked about that, Mr. Cuomo shot back, "He didn't say that." But he did -- one of the few hard facts in the miasma of hints and conflicting signals surrounding Mr. Cuomo's presidential ambitions.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt "He's gone hot and cold at least three or four times since January," said a Democratic House member close to Mr. Gephardt. As House majority leader, Mr. Gephardt is on a glide path to the speakership and arguably has the most to lose by a second, unsuccessful campaign for the Presidency. Perhaps that explains his insistence in recent weeks that "I am not running."
But Mr. Gephardt seems a tad conflicted. He sounds like a Presidential candidate in his speeches. And he is raising money very aggressively for his Congressional campaign fund, which can be rolled over for a Presidential campaign; he held more than a dozen fund-raising events during a recent swing through California. Mr. Gephardt, in short, seems to be keeping his options open.
Senator Al Gore The Senator from Tennessee is still considered among the most likely Presidential contenders, although he has yet to make his move. "He's said over and over again that there's a deadline out there, but he doesn't see it on the horizon yet," said his spokeswoman, Marla Romash.
Senator Tom Harkin This liberal Iowan never throttled back from his 1990 re-election campaign. He is traveling the country, bashing Mr. Bush and the Republicans, often before labor crowds. He is a key mover in the Coalition for Democratic Values, a group arguing for a full-throated "progressive" message for the Democratic Party; its members warn of the dangers of "shadow Republicans" in the party.
Should he enter the race, Mr. Harkin could radically change, probably devalue, the Iowa caucuses. He could give other Democrats an excuse to skip this first contest of the nominating season, a prospect that has already caused some nervousness among Iowa Democrats.
Rev. Jesse Jackson His Presidential plans are one of the biggest variables in the race. Mr. Jackson consistently says he will decide sometime this fall whether to seek the Democratic nomination for a third time. His recent spat with the Democratic Leadership Council, which pointedly did not invite him to speak at its meeting in Cleveland, shows that he wants to remain a player -- at the very least.
Senator Bob Kerrey Steve Jarding, a spokesman for the Nebraska Democrat, said, "He says he has no desire to be President at this time. but he's also said he doesn't feel it necessary to close any doors."
Former Senator George S. McGovern The South Dakota Democrat said he was resolved to think through his decision this weekend and announce it next Thursday in a speech to the National Press Club in Washington. "It's basically a struggle between personal factors that say no and the public service side that says yes," Mr. McGovern said in an interview last week.
The 1972 Democratic nominee, who lost in a landslide, said it "makes a difference" that other liberals like Mr. Harkin are considering a race. "I'm a liberal Democrat and I don't run away from that," he said. "That's the message I want heard in '92. If I were sure that case were going to be made, I'd bow out."
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th Early on, the West Virginia Democrat seemed something of a dabbler in Presidential politics, acknowledging i March that he was not really interested in a race in 1992. But he reopened the door to '92 two weeks ago and headed off to New Hampshire this weekend. "He is surprisingly serious about this," said one Democrat close to Mr. Rockefeller. His focus, so far, has been on health care.
Name recognition is not a problem, thanks to John D., John D. 2d and John D. 3d, a background he handles with humor. "When I was growing up, there were a lot of reasons for me to become a Republican," he says, "a lot of reasons." But Mr. Rockefeller is untested in national politics, and at times it shows, as in his on-again, off-again stance on 1992.
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder The Governor of Virginia, building his national message on a promise of "progressive" domestic policies tempered with fiscal responsibility, said again last week that he would decide whether to seek the nomination by mid-summer.
