HEADLINE: Council Flexing New Muscles For New York's Middle Class

SERIES: Playing for Power: The Council's Bid for Influence - First of a series of articles.

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
From the shadows of City Hall, the New York City Council is emerging as the greatest beneficiary of a historic fight to make government more reflective of the city's under-represented and often impoverished minorities.
On the verge of its greatest expansion and change, the Council has challenged the Mayor on some major initiatives, developed a staff of some competence in areas like municipal finance and even put a City Commissioner under oath when he testified before it, all in a dogged effort to be taken seriously after more than a century as an ineffectual joke. 
 Yet even as it amasses great powers under the new City Charter, which took effect a year ago, the Council is also becoming something unintended by many of those who fought to rework the city government: a strong voice for middle-class values, in which different minorities with often competing priorities may have less of a voice than before.
 
Different View on Cuts
 With the jury still out, the Council is in the spotlight on the most pressing civic question of the day: what to do about New York's deepest fiscal problems since the crisis of the mid-70's. And its leader, Speaker Peter F. Vallone, has vowed to challenge Mayor David N. Dinkins's proposals to help close a $3.5 billion budget deficit with a $1 billion tax increase and cuts in a wide range of services.
Invoking the values of middle-class New York, Mr. Vallone and the Council have called for reducing the tax increases by roughly half and looking harder at making cuts in some social services, while minimizing cuts in what they see as such basic services as schools, street-cleaning, parks and cultural programs that all New Yorkers depend on.
Because the Council now has the sole power to approve the budget -- a power that former Mayor Edward I. Koch says, with some hyperbole, makes it stronger than the mayoralty itself -- the positions it takes could make a difference to millions of taxpayers, thousands of city workers facing layoffs and a giant population of poor people, which endured the sharpest cuts during the 1975 fiscal crisis.
The Council is dominated by Mr. Vallone, a regular Democrat and part-time lawyer from the sidewalks of Astoria, Queens. He has used his control of committee chairmanships, which carry extra pay, to reward loyalists and punish dissenters. He has surrounded himself with a core of sophisticated aides making six-figure salaries comparable to those of commissioners and top mayoral aides. And he has more than doubled the Council's budget and tripled the central staff directly under his control.
As a result of these big-shouldered political maneuvers, Mr. Vallone has consolidated power in a 34-member majority, including the six black and three Hispanic members. A battle over drawing new districts to increase the Council to 51 seats from 35 in a special election this fall, as required by the Charter, may change the proportion of minority members from one in four to perhaps one in three. But, Mr. Vallone's closest aides say, the Council's political stance will probably not change at all, because its membership is likely to remain middle class.
"The goal for the 90's has to be a leaner more responsive efficient government that can still deliver the basic services as well as the services that make New York City unique," Mr. Vallone said last winter in a speech outlining his vision of the city. "The reality is that we have an extremely small taxpayer base and we can't drive out those who pay the freight."
The question is how far the Speaker, who has had a reputation for accommodation, will go in exerting the Council's new powers to press this philosophy.
"Right now, most people in the city don't know the Council exists," Mr. Vallone conceded. "It's going to take a long time to re-educate the public that we're as good a body as they are, and that's pretty good."
His critics are less charitable.
"I don't think Dinkins is going to have to have sleepless nights worrying about the Council as a serious competitor unless the Council works a lot harder than it does now," said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, a consumer and citizen advocacy group. "If they're going to be co-equal, they're going to have to write more laws, ask tougher questions and show up at oversight hearings with more than a second's worth of thought. At tops, a third of the Council members are doing the job they were elected to do. We know. We talk to them."
 
Stuck With Early Image Of 'Trained Seals'
 From the creation of the modern city of five boroughs at the turn of the century, the Council was overshadowed by the Board of Estimate, a hybrid of the mayor, comptroller, council president and borough presidents that controlled zoning and contracts and shared power on the budget.
The early Council was derided as "the 40 Thieves" for its corruption. Years later, Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia dismissed its members as "trained seals" who took their orders from their county political bosses.
But in 1989, the Board of Estimate was declared unconstitutional because each of the borough presidents had one vote while representing populations that varied widely in size. The new Charter abolished the board and gave the Council broad new powers. Not only will it continue to approve local laws and hold hearings, it now has final say over the budget and can review all land-use decisions.
Several members have won praise from civic groups for diligence and seriousness. But more than anything, the Council may be held back by many of its other members, a quaint and unabashedly ordinary collection which includes a former orchestra leader, a former livery-cab driver, a part-time soap opera actor and 10 lawyers, some of whom earn $100,000 a year in fees while practicing from their district offices.
In twice-monthly meetings in their dusky Victorian chamber on the second floor of City Hall, they drift in and out while mayoral aides, reporters and lobbyists mill about amid droning recitations of bills and resolutions.
The members are paid $55,000 a year, but most earn considerably more. "Lulus" for chairing committees and subcommittees range from $2,500 to $22,500, with only some full committees required to meet even once a month. The members each control $187,687 to spend on staffs and district offices, without oversight by the Council leadership.
The Council's growing flashes of aggressiveness contrast with its continuing lassitude. In the last year, one of its committees (on committees) did nothing except hold a buffet luncheon, and another, a subcommittee on pensions, never met publicly, though changes in the pension investment policy have been a major bone of contention in the city's current fiscal problems. Meanwhile, a panel on medical alternatives held repeated hearings on the merits of acupuncture and the chairman of the Economic Development Committee, Jerome X. O'Donovan of Staten Island, went on a trade mission to Romania.
Several committees violate the rule that they must meet at least once a month. The Committee on Civil Service and Labor held 11 meetings last year, and its chairman, Rafael Castaneira Colon, earned $10,000 for heading it. Two of the meetings were organizational and two were part of group hearings with other committees on the budget; none involved the municipal labor issues that have dominated the current fiscal crisis.
When Arthur J. Katzman of Queens, who once suggested that black and Hispanic children had "no liking for learning," retired as chairman of the Education Committee, he was replaced by Priscilla Wooten, a former bus matron from Brooklyn and a Vallone loyalist. Ms. Wooten once suggested that the city should permanently keep recruits in its Police Academy, whether it had the money to hire them or not, ignoring that the recruits must be paid.
Mr. Vallone also drew much criticism for naming his good friend and supporter, Jerry L. Crispino of the Bronx, to lead the all-important Land Use Committee. Mr. Crispino went around proclaiming his ignorance of land use so often that Council aides urged him to stop lest he be believed.
Eric Lane, who was counsel to the Charter Revision Commission, which drafted the new Charter, said it was unfair to focus too much on the foibles of individual members.
"Legislatures are supposed to be typical of their constituencies, and no consitituency will elect a person that's too dissimilar," he said. "It's the greatest means of accountability."
 
The New Priorities: Not Just Street Names
 For generations, perhaps the classic measure of the Council's limited stature was its fondness for changing street names. Of the 84 bills passed last year, 35 did just that. But now, the Council passes a handful of important laws each year, instead of one or two every few years.
In the last year, the Council passed bills cracking down on illegal social clubs, restricting minors' access to cigarettes and tightening restrictions on doing business with companies that have ties to South Africa. It outflanked Mr. Dinkins by passing a law setting deadlines to close large shelters for the homeless (which he had long opposed) faster than the Mayor believed possible.
The Council's laws also reflect its middle-class priorities, like one to let homeowners do construction work on weekends. On the hottest issues of the day, the Council still often finds itself following public debate.
It held a hearing and issued a report that harshly criticized Mr. Dinkins's handling of a black-led boycott of two Korean-owned groceries in Brooklyn, but only after the dispute had run for months and the Mayor's approach had been widely condemned. Mr. Vallone cited this as one of the biggest achievements of the year.
"If I were a commissioner, I wouldn't take the Council seriously because we're not prepared half the time," said Sal F. Albanese, a Councilman from Brooklyn.
One of the most important new powers the Council received under the new Charter, control over land use, has yet to be fully tested because the recession has slowed development to a trickle. It is in the area of its most significant power, the authority to remold and approve the budget, that the Council has made perhaps its greatest strides.
To lead his finance staff, Mr. Vallone hired Marc V. Shaw, a veteran of the State Senate Republican staff in Albany. The Council has asserted its prerogatives over spending at almost every turn, jockeying over its institutional role with the Mayor, though its bedrock priorities have changed little.
The Council has long stood for neighborhood interests, while mayors have always had to appeal to a citywide constituency. But the budget debate underlines the central paradox of the new Council, created to reflect growing ethnic and racial diversity: To Mr. Vallone and the Council leadership, the new balance of power between the Mayor and the Council is what diversity is all about.
All government tends toward the middle, and Mr. Dinkins has struck many of the same themes as the Council, for example, in building up the police force to the dismay of some liberals who elected him. But on matters involving millions of dollars, thousands of jobs and critical services, a battle is takingshape.
The Council has called for cutting Mr. Dinkins's proposal for $1 billion in higher taxes nearly in half, sparing proposed cuts in schools, parks and libraries and making cuts in social services. It has also proposed such maneuvers as consolidating other agencies.
The Council has just six weeks to dicker with the budget before the new fiscal year begins, and the depth of the city's fiscal problems will tie its hands somewhat. But in other ways, it has the tactical advantage. To win help from municipal unions and the state, Mr. Dinkins proposed cuts not only in programs that he knew the Council would fight to restore, but in some of his own pet programs, like health services for the poor, that the Council might be only too happy to let stand and blame him for.
The Council has more room to maneuver because it outfinessed Mr. Dinkins last year on hiring police officers, which was often the old Council's first and last budget goal. Last summer even before a spate of highly publicized crimes put Mr. Dinkins on the defensive, the Council had proposed hiring thousands of new officers by using a surcharge on state lottery tickets. That eventually led the Mayor to respond with a far more costly plan, which both sides finally agreed to finance.
 
The Gorgeous Mosaic Vs. the Melting Pot
 Mr. Shaw of Mr. Vallone's finance staff said that much of the struggling so far has been institutional, rather than philosophical, with the Council seeking to be taken seriously by the west wing of City Hall.
But a philosophical fight is looming on whether New York can afford to maintain such a vast government and system of social services. In that debate Mr. Vallone has staked his turf, growing passionate over broken traffic lights and bus-stop shelters.
"I really do believe that we're spending, we're wasting a lot of money in H.R.A. It's up to $7 billion now," he said, referring to the city Human Resources Administration. Of the city's public hospitals, he said, "I really do believe that health services are absolutely essential, but the City of New York should not be paying for them." The Federal and state governments should pay, he said.
Mr. Vallone's approach is widely shared by his Council colleagues, including the minority members.
Archie Spigner of Queens, one of the Council's senior black members, said: "I don't see a radical shift in the makeup of the Council. You just look at the black members of the Council," pointing to a group that supported Mr. Koch for much of his tenure when others in the black community complained that he was insensitive to their needs. "Unless strong measures are taken to keep the middle class, black and white, we're going to be in real trouble."
But David R. Jones, executive director of the Community Service Society, a nonprofit social-service group, said Mr. Vallone and his members did not adequately address the needs of dispossessed constituencies whose distress could divide the city.
"If he wants to take the leadership position," Mr. Jones said, "he's going to have to start not only crying out for his narrow constituency, but for all the people of New York, a majority of whom happen to be either poor or nonwhite."
Mr. Vallone wants to be seen as aware of the demands upon him, and often speaks of his and the Council's concern for the homeless. But he hews to a more assimilationist vision. He says all groups should strive for representation, but rejects the notion that they must be represented by someone from the same ethnic or racial group.
Unlike the Mayor, who wanted to craft a top staff reflective of what he calls New York's "gorgeous mosaic," Mr. Vallone, saying his only criteria was picking the best person for the job, recruited a core staff that basically reflects pre-war New York.
"Forget this mosaic," he said. "I like the melting pot." Because there are talented members of all races and ethnic groups, he added, the staff will balance out over time.
What Mr. Vallone will ultimately do with his power, and how long he can keep it, remains to be seen.
"If there is real power in the City Council, people will throw out representatives who don't produce," said Richard D. Emery, the civil rights lawyer who brought the lawsuit that led to the Council's ascendancy.
"If that dynamic doesn't work," he said, "it means that the voters don't care at all and any form of democracy is meaningless."

The Economy
The S.E.C. is expected to take a big step today toward 24-hour stock trading, approving the New York Stock Exchange's request to extend trading beyond the closing bell at 4 P.M. [Page D1.] 
 The Department of Energy is spending nearly $2 billion a year, a fifth of its nuclear weapons budget, on plants, projects and contracts attacked by its own inspector general and leading members of Congress as wasteful or simply unnecessary. [A1.]
As many as 500 credit unions are expected to convert from private insurance to Federal deposit insurance by Sept. 30, according to officials at the National Credit Union Administration. [D4.]
John Garamendi is the point man in trying to solve what may be the nation's worst insurance crisis. The California regulator's handling of the situation will help to determine whether policyholders will escape potentially devastating losses. [D1.]
 
Companies
The Empire State Building is for sale, and for a mere $50 million. But there's a catch that is 84 1/2 years long. Until the year 2075, the 102-story building is tied up in a complex leasing arrangement that will prevent its new owner from taking control. [D1.]
Unsecured creditors of Eastern Air Lines find themselves fighting with the airline's retirees over who will get about $125 million expected from Eastern's liquidation. [D4.]
A former stockbroker has sued Prudential for $15 million, accusing it of forcing him from his job because he threatened to divulge information about what he says was a fraud by the firm. [D4.]
Lotus will include computer font technology developed by Adobe in a version of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet program that it is developing for Microsoft's Windows software. [D2.] Parties in a closely watched copyright suit filed by Apple against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard have discussed settling. But the companies say there are "no foreseeable prospects" for a settlement. [D8.]
 
International
France's Prime Minister has come across, in her first few days in office, like a Joan of Arc seeking to save French industry. For Edith Cresson, the enemy is not the British but the Japanese. [D2.]
An Iraqi missile penetrated U.S. air defenses during the gulf war, and slammed into a military barracks in Saudi Arabia, because a computer failure shut down the American missile system designed to counter it, two Army investigations concluded. [A6.]
 
The Media Business
Fox Broadcasting turned momentum into money last year. Now the young and restless network has lost ground in the ratings even as it expanded its program base. [D1.]
Marketing experts wonder who will replace Bo Jackson as advertising's best pitchman. Some think the next superstar endorser will be David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs. Ad Scene. [D10.]
A flashy tabloid called Super hit Berlin newsstands this month, starting a fierce price war at the low end of eastern Germany's rumbling newspaper market. [D11.]
Penguin U.S.A. has embarked on a three-year promotion to persuade booksellers to carry more of the Penguin Classics -- presumably at the expense of competitors. [D10.]
Agencies are changing ads as F.D.A. scrutiny forces their clients to change labels. What responsibility does the ad industry have in the case of misleading assertions about products? Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D12.] A leader of advertising's creative revolution of the 60's is off to seek a second revolution. Ronald M. Rosenfeld has left Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss. [D12.]

HEADLINE: The Primary for Mayor Is Leaving Many in Philadelphia Befuddled

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 19

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of yet another bribery scandal in City Hall, a resurgent fiscal crisis and the likelihood of more municipal chaos, a sales tax increase and severe service reductions this year, seven candidates are vying to become Philadelphia's 127th mayor in Tuesday's primary election.
There are so many candidates saying similar things that voters have become more and more confused in four months of campaigning. "I'm so undecided, it's a sin," said Naomi Lingham, a 73-year-old from North Philadelphia. In polls, the ranks of the undecided have swollen in the last month and now include almost one of three Democrats and one of six Republicans.
 
Two Are Given an Edge
 Experts say this trend foreshadows a low turnout for the primary, giving a significant edge to the Republican Party's endorsed candidate, Ronald D. Castille, and the Democratic front-runner, Edward G. Rendell. Both are white, 47-year-old former district attorneys who pledge to put city spending on a crash diet and squeeze millions from Washington and Harrisburg. 
 Mayor W. Wilson Goode, a Democrat and the city's first black mayor, is finishing his second four-year term and is prevented from running for a third. His administration, scarred by the worsening fiscal crisis and the death and destruction caused by his 1985 decision to bomb the fortified home of the radical black group called Move, has led to a pent-up demand for sweeping change.
The Republicans see this as their best opportunity in 40 years for capturing the mayor's office. Democrats, who outnumber Republicans by a 5-to-2 ratio, are talking about saving money by reducing city workers' health benefits and hiring private contractors to collect the trash and perform other city services. Some Republicans say the same things.
The fiscal crisis has permitted candidates to be candid about their plans for rescuing the city, said Paul Seidenstat, an associate professor of economics at Temple University. "They are more open and have a more coherent point of view than candidates ever did in the past," he said.
 
Diverse Field of Candidates
 The times have spawned an unusually diverse field of candidates, including the two former district attorneys; Lucien E. Blackwell and George R. Burrell Jr., two black Democrats who have been relatively inactive as members of the City Council, and Peter Hearn, a former chancellor of the Philadelphia Bar Association who is running as an outsider and reformer but has drawn very little support.
There are also two Democrats-turned-Republicans, Sam Katz, a municipal finance expert who has become a serious contender, and former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo who is, for the fifth time in 20 years, bearing the standard of law and order here in what he calls "Dodge City." Mr. Rizzo, who lost the last election to Mayor Goode by only 17,000 votes, has said he would find the money to hire 1,500 more police officers by doing things like eliminating programs for AIDS victims and the homeless.
In each party's primary, the candidate with the most votes wins. The two primary winners will face off in the general election on Nov. 5.
In a city where blacks represent 40 percent of the population of 1.5 million people and nearly 60 percent of the 650,000 registered Democrats, this campaign has been remarkably free of racial tension. Political analysts say it signals a growing acceptance by whites and a political maturity on the part of blacks, who now hold many positions of power.
The two black candidates, Mr. Burrell, a former safety with the Denver Broncos of the National Football League, and Mr. Blackwell, a former longshoreman and boxer, have traded charges all through the campaign.
 
Majority Whip Joins Fray
 Joining the fray last week was United States Representative William H. Gray 3d, the House's majority whip and the most powerful black Democrat in Philadelphia. Mr. Gray, who is sponsoring the candidacy of Mr. Burrell,charged that Mr. Blackwell had accepted a $1,000 campaign contribution from his brother, who the Pennsylvania Crime Commission has said runs a numbers racket in the city.
Mr. Blackwell vehemently denied the charge, saying that the contribution came from his cousin, and not from his brother. Both share the same name, Junious Blackwell Jr. "The bum made a mistake," the candidate said of Mr. Gray.
The Democratic candidates debated on television Tuesday, the same day that a Federal grand jury indicted a veteran City Councilman, James J. Tayoun, on charges of bribery and racketeering. With that indictment in the background, the candidates traded charges of wrongdoing involving gas bills, loan defaults and parking tickets.
Dr. Sandra Featherman, director of the Center for Public Policy at Temple University, who occasionally gives a speech entitled "Why Philadelphians Elect Felons and Corpses to Public Office," said the mayoral candidates were guilty of "pecadillos" compared to the norm. "One of the depressing problems in Philadelphia is how willing Philadelphians are to tolerate improper behavior by their politicians," Dr. Featherman said.
The Republicans' televised debate on May 8 was more civilized, in part because the debate's inflexible structure provided no interaction between candidates. The 70-year-old Mr. Rizzo was uncharacteristically mild in the debate.
Mr. Rizzo, trailing in the polls and embittered at losing the endorsement of party bosses, had repeatedly lashed out at Mr. Castille, the front-runner, calling him a "mental case," a "drunk." Mr. Castille complained about some charges to the Fellowship Commission.
The commission, an independent committee that tries to clean up local elections, examined Mr. Rizzo's charges and determined that the drinking charge was unfounded. But it waffled on the other charge, stating: "Reasonable people might debate what the terminology 'mental case' suggests."

HEADLINE: 83 Brand-New Condos and a Harbor View: What Am I Bid?

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Battery Park City was a real-estate developer's dream: an opportunity to build apartments with unobstructed views of the Statue of Liberty and New York Harbor, which would attract the up-and-comers of Wall Street working in the gleaming skyscrapers just steps away.
But while the buildings went up on the narrow strip of filled land that is the World Trade Center's backyard, the stock market plummeted, dragging New York's economy and the real-estate market down with it. 
 So the low-key sales pitch intended to attract the well-heeled Wall Streeters has instead emerged as the burbling patter of the auctioneer, as a developer, Goodstein Properties, yesterday auctioned off 83 brand-new condominiums in the Cove Club, one of the latest luxury developments in Battery Park City.
The auction, at the Marriott Marquis in midtown, was also testament to New Yorkers' uncanny ability to mine silver in every dark cloud. More than 700 prospective buyers registered to bid on the apartments, and several found bargains, if not outright steals, on condominiums with the latest amenities and unparalleled views.
"You can look at this as an end of one era or the beginning of another," said Luk Sun Wong, who works for another real-estate company and hoped to pick up a couple of apartments for himself as an investment. "It's a chance to bring real-estate prices back down to earth and give normal people a chance to live in New York." Many of those who attended yesterday already live in Battery Park City, and like it. Edward and Alison Simioni, who have rented there for the last three years, say they like the esplanade just steps away from their front door, the quiet, clean streets and the tastefully landscaped parks and courtyards.
"We've been watching buildings go up and this just seemed like it might be a good opportunity," Mr. Simioni said.
The Simionis had their eye on three apartments in the Cove Club, corner units with wraparound views of the New Jersey shoreline and the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. They bid on the first one and got it for $332,000 -- less than the $350,000 they were prepared to pay and a bargain compared with the $411,000 asking price. But Mr. Simioni was still nervous.
"You never know -- the other two could go for even less," he said as he was whisked into another room to make the financing arrangements for his new home.
The auction itself seemed to flummox some bidders new to the process. The bid ding, conducted by ruddy men with names like Rocky and Mel, moved rapidly, taking broad leaps of $10,000 and even $25,000 when an apartment was initially placed on the block and then little skips of $2,500 or $1,000 at the end, until the chief auctioneer yelled, "Sold!" into the microphone.
"This sure isn't Sotheby's," said Richard Milbank, poking his Hewlett-Packard to calculate how much of a bargain had just transpired.
For Mr. Milbank and many others, the auction was less a chance to buy than a chance to witness what until recently would have been a rare curiosity -- a New York City real-estate transaction that seemed to favor the buyer instead of the seller.
They did not abandon their skepticism, however. "Deals? Who's talking about deals?" asked Virginia Young, the high bidder on a 552-square-foot penthouse studio with a view of a sliver of the estuary. "Nothing is a good deal."
Mrs. Young, her husband, Yoon, and their son, William, will use the apartment as a pied-a-terre where they can escape the tranquillity of their home on two acres in Croton, N.Y. They bid $150,000 for their slice of city life, 16 percent less than the $179,000 original asking price.
"I like the view. I like the garden," Mrs. Young said. "I like the garden and I don't have to work to enjoy it."
The Youngs got less of a discount than other bidders, who bought for as little as 53 percent of the original offering prices during the first 90 minutes of the auction. A town house with two terraces, three bathrooms and a view of Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, listed at $648,000, went for $383,000. A large one-bedroom with a balcony sold for $192,000, 29 percent less than the $272,000 offering price.
 
'Expedited Marketing Approach'
 Some of those views may be worth a bit less in coming years, since ground is being broken adjacent to the Cove Club for a new tower.
Andrew Goodstein, the president of Goodstein Properties, said that although his company would take some losses in the auction, there were advantages as well.
"This is an expedited marketing approach," he said. "It allows us to sell 50 percent of the units quickly, saving us money, and it creates interest that will be useful in the future."
The Cove Club was the first new condominium in New York City to open with the bang of a gavel, although groups of apartments in several older co-ops have been auctioned off. Mr. Goodstein said he expected the event to increase awareness of the property and attract buyers for the other 80 units in the building.
David A. Emil, the president and chief executive of the Battery Park City Authority, said that although he had had misgivings about the auction, the sale prices yesterday were a pleasant surprise. The first 42 apartments to go on the block had all sold, he said.
"I think although auctions generally have tended to indicate a real distressed situation, the prices that were bid there today show there's still a good market for Battery Park City residential property," he said.
For Mr. Goodstein, the auction was also a way to quickly sell the minimum 15 percent of the project that state law requires for a condominium plan to become effective. The rest of the apartments and town houses in the Cove Club will probably be rented at first and sold after the market has picked up, Mr. Goodstein said.
Although he said his company may take a loss on this development, Mr. Goodstein did not rule out future projects in Battery Park City. The Goodstein family were also partners in Liberty House, Liberty Terrace and Liberty Court, three other developments in Battery Park City.
"The area has come a long way -- it will go a long way," he said.

HEADLINE: Soviets Cooperating on Military Books in the West

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
With the change in East-West relations, the Soviet Union is now cooperating with Western publishers on books about the Soviet military, providing the sort of facts, figures and even photographs that spies had for decades risked life and limb to obtain.
"If the Soviets knew you'd had this kind of material five or six years ago, they'd have come after you with their agents," said Moise Feder, the editor of the Military Book Club. "Now they're helping make it available to us in the West." 
 The books are remarkable for detailing everything from Soviet military training methods to specification of the most modern Soviet submarines and airplanes, and publishers are gambling that American readers will be sufficiently intrigued by the revelations of what was once classified information to make the books big sellers.
Some of the information in the books has come from unofficial Soviet sources and some from ranking military and intelligence sources in Eastern Europe. But most was supplied by Soviet officials who, for political and economic reasons, have been willing to provide Western publishers with facts, figures and photographs that were formerly kept secret.
 
Soviets Are More Open
 "We're now at the end of the cold war, we hope, and the Soviets are much more open at every level," said John W. R. Taylor, who for 30 years was editor of "Jane's All the World's Aircraft," one of the series of authoritative military reference books published in London.
Mr. Taylor is also the editor of "Soviet Wings: Modern Soviet Military Aircraft," just published by Presidio Press in Novato, Calif. and simultaneously by publishers in England, Canada, France, Japan, Yugoslavia, Italy and Germany. The book consists of 141 color photographs never before published in the West, including some featuring the latest Soviet combat aircraft. All the photos are by Aleksandr M. Dzhus, a Soviet aerial photographer.
Soviet aircraft have sometimes participated in air shows in the West, but Mr. Taylor and others said those planes were usually photographed sitting on runways, their weapons covered up. But "Soviet Wings" shows them taking off from carrier decks, shows their armament and electronic jamming equipment and has detailed specifications.
"We had so few good pictures of Soviet aircraft that the joke in aviation and intelligence circles was that they built only blurred aircraft," said Lionel Leventhal, the head of Greenhill Books in London, a leading publisher of military books. Mr. Leventhal acquired the photographs for "Soviet Wings" from a Moscow publisher and arranged for the book's simultaneous publication on three continents (but not in the Soviet Union).
The book is a main selection of the Military Book Club. "It's something of a gamble for us," Mr. Feder said, "because it's an expensive book." (It retails for $50, and the club price is $30.) "But some of those planes haven't been seen before, and most of the photographs compare well to those of American aviation photographers."
 
A Year With the Soviet Military
 Next month, AbbevillePress will publish "Inside the Soviet Military" by Carey Schofield, a British journalist, with photographs by Leonid Yakutin, a Soviet naval officer and military photographer. They spent a year with the Soviet military, visiting a naval base at Vladivostok, covering parachute training at Ryazan, watching the winter maneuvers of Warsaw Pact troops and visiting many other bases, units and warships.
In his foreword to the book, Christopher Donnelly, Sovietologist in residence for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, wrote that never before had a Western observer been allowed to see and report on the Soviet armed forces from the inside, and never had such unrestricted access to military installations and personnel been granted.
"That it was granted at all is amazing," Mr. Donnelly said. "That it has been granted so completely and free from official restraint is one of the most heartening signs for the development of that dialogue essential to a permanent improvement of relations between the U.S.S.R. and the West."
The reasons for such cooperation are not always clear, although the authors and publishers of those books attribute it to the new Soviet policies of openness. But there may be other motivations as well. Asked what inspired the Soviet authorities to make available the revealing photographs of Soviet planes, Mr. Leventhal replied: "Money. I'm paying them in Western currency." He declined to say how much.
 
Airplanes and Submarines
 Norman Polmar, a naval analyst and a consultant to the Department of Defense, said: "The Soviets for years have wanted to sell commercial airplanes, and 'Soviet Wings' is a reflection of that goal. But they're not as open about their submarine fleet, because they're not trying to sell submarines."
Nevertheless, Mr. Polmar received greater cooperation from Soviet officials than he expected while writing "Submarines of the Russian and Soviet Navies, 1718-1990." Just published by the Naval Institute Press , the detailed book is co-authored with Jurrien Noot, a research analyst on the staff of the Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic.
Mr. Polmar said his requests for photographs and certain specifications were honored sometimes and disregarded at other times with no discernable pattern. Nevertheless, he said he had noticed big differences in Soviet attitudes about its military.
"I sat down with the new Soviet naval attache a few weeks ago," he said, "and at that first meeting he told me he was a Soviet nuclear submariner. Ten years ago when you met a Soviet attache, they would always say there are in headquarters, or on staff work, or served on surface ships. They just didn't talk about who they were and what they did."
The Soviet Union is not forthcoming about everything pertaining to its military, said Milan Vego, a former Yugoslav naval officer who teaches at the Defense Intelligence College and is a consultant at the Center for Naval Analyses.
"They have opened up some archives, and it's possible to subscribe to Soviet magazines that were formerly forbidden, so for the first time you can consult originals on military subjects," Mr. Vego said. "But the Soviets still are not forthcoming about tactics; those you have to pursue in East European magazines."
Despite such detours, publishers say they expect the openness to continue. Aristide D. Caratzas, which publishes books in the humanities and modern history, is planning a range of books from the Soviet Union, including geographical handbooks. And Presidio Press has contracts with high-ranking Soviet military officers for four books, including one on the Afghan war told from the Soviet perspective, and another describing Soviet military aid to North Korea and North Vietnam, and to Egypt and Syria in their wars against Israel.

HEADLINE: Protect Deposits -- and the Economy

 BODY:
A House banking subcommittee last week rejected two White House proposals to cut back Federal deposit insurance. That might seem odd at a time when the fund that insures depositors is low and sinking. But the subcommittee showed shrewd judgment. There's a much sounder way to fix up bank insurance:
Give regulators more authority to close failing banks -- long before the insurance fund, and taxpayers, are threatened. 
 Once that is done, there will be no need to reduce insurance or punish depositors, actions that would only destabilize banks and threaten the economy.
 One of the Administration's proposals rejected by the subcommittee would limit insurance for an individual to a single non-retirement account of up to $100,000 per bank. The subcommittee also voted to permit healthy banks to issue insured deposits through brokerage firms, a practice the Bush Administration wants to end. These decisions might appear to do little more than protect fat cats. But the truth is more complicated.
Many middle-income workers receive large lump-sum payments at retirement and anxiously seek safe havens for the money. Nonprofit institutions are not fat cats either, but many hold large uninsured deposits, as was sadly demonstrated last year in the collapse of Freedom National Bank of Harlem.
Protecting these and ordinary savers is reason enough to preserve widespread Federal deposit insurance. But there's another, more compelling reason: to stabilize the banking system.
In times of crisis, panicky withdrawals by uninsured depositors can close an otherwise solvent bank. That, in turn, can trip withdrawals from neighboring banks. And large banks typically hold uninsured deposits from smaller banks, which would be threatened by the large bank's collapse. By exposing more depositors to losses, Congress would jeopardize a regulatory system that has for half a century brilliantly insulated the economy against ruinous panics.
The reason for preserving insured brokered deposits is more subtle. Some large brokerage firms allow their clients to withdraw their money early without the usual penalty. To do this, the brokerage firms hold inventories of certificates, giving them a vested interest in dealing only with creditworthy banks. In effect, brokered deposits turn private institutions into financial overseers of banks -- a useful protection.
Taxpayers are justifiably angry that, once again, they are threatened by collapse of financial institutions. That anger impels politicians to lash out at attractive targets like rich depositors and brokerage firms. But when they are targeted unjustly, such action is demagogic and dangerous.
Final House and Senate votes will not come until summer, and not every subcommittee vote has been wise. But last week's votes are an optimistic sign that Congress can resist destructive temptation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SCENE;
Outsiders' Role In Mexico Pact

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FOREIGN-OWNED factories in the United States, a spreading phenomenon in the 1980's, left many Americans wondering if the nation's industrial power had been diluted. Now the proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico is renewing debate over that concern.
The Mexican agreement is to come on top of a similar pact already in force between the United States and Canada. The goal is to remove all the barriers to trade and investment among the three countries. A company that makes auto engines or shirts in, say, Monterrey will enjoy the same easy access to American customers as companies that make those products in Cleveland or Toronto. Mexico, in effect, would become an industrial zone within the United States. 
 But should an "outsider" -- a German or a Japanese company, for example, with a factory in Mexico -- gain the same free access to the huge United States market as do companies owned by the "insiders," Americans, Mexicans and Canadians? The answer will probably be yes, but only if the "outsiders" agree to rules intended to make them look like "insiders."
"This will be one of the critical issues in the negotiations," said Roger Wallace, a Deputy Under Secretary of Commerce. "We will have to define what constitutes a North American product."
The definition will probably be that a forklift, for example, assembled in Mexico, is "North American" if most of the parts are made in Mexico, the United States or Canada. Caterpillar Inc. makes such forklifts today near Monterrey. But a forklift assembled by a German or Japanese company from parts brought mostly from Europe and Asia would not qualify. More than 50 percent of the parts or the work done on the forklift would probably have to originate within the new free-trade region, says Julius Katz, a deputy in the United States trade representative's office.
So far, most foreign manufacturing companies in Mexico are American-owned. But once a North American common market is in place, "outsider" investment is likely to mushroom, over the objections of some who say that "outsiders" should not have easy access to United States markets, even if they comply with stiff local-origin requirements.
Put another way, should Germany's Volkswagen, which closed an auto factory in Pennsylvania in 1988 as unprofitable, be encouraged to expand its Mexican operation and re-enter the American market through unrestricted exports from that plant? Or, should a Taiwan shirt maker be allowed to get around United States import quotas for apparel and textiles by relocating to Mexico, where a chief requirement for unlimited access would be shirts made mostly from fabrics purchased in Mexico or the Carolinas? The Bush Administration seems to say yes, as long as local-origin rules are observed. The Mexicans apparently are not so sure. In a recent speech, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, Mexico's President, appealed to Asians to build high-technology factories in Mexico, arguing that his country was becoming a platform for penetrating the United States market. He did not dwell on local-origin rules.
Mexico has a highly skilled but low-paid work force. The combination has already prompted American companies, particularly auto manufacturers, to put state-of-the-art factories in Mexico. Mr. Salinas has accelerated the process by reducing trade barriers with the United States, even in advance of a free-trade agreement.
Once one is securely in place, a European or a Japanese company planning to put a factory in Chicago might put it in Monterrey instead to save on wages, depriving Americans of jobs, argues Mark Anderson, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. economist.
Others maintain that local-origin rules are not an impediment. Japanese auto makers, already investing in Mexico, will be able to ignore them. The only penalty would be payment of the standard United States tariff, which is 2.5 percent for autos. A proposed solution would be to levy higher penalty tariffs for violating the local-origin rules.
Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, takes solutions a step further. He would require "outsider" car manufacturers, for example, to export one car to another part of the world for every car sold within the region. And "outsiders" would have to buy their factory machinery from North American companies.
Mr. Prestowitz's approach is intended to give United States-owned companies a competitive advantage in their own low-wage backyard. But that runs counter to Administration policy, which favors tariff-free trade for everyone everywhere in the world. The compromise is likely to be stiff rules of local origin. Other forms of special treatment would be unconscionable, Mr. Katz says.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fare Wars Start Anew At Airlines

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 20

 BODY:
Domestic airlines cut their summer ticket prices today by as much as 20 percent, and said children could come along for half-price.
Northwest Airlines started the fare promotion over the weekend. American, Continental, Delta Air Lines, United and USAir matched it today. 
 "We're trying to stimulate travel as much as we can for the summer period," said Doug Miller, a Northwest spokesman. "As we were looking out at our advanced bookings for summer, they were just slightly below where we hoped they would be."
 
New York to Chicago: $278
 Under the promotion, a round-trip ticket from New York to Chicago would cost $278 during peak hours and $238 during off-peak hours. A child could accompany an adult for $168 or $118, respectively.
Off-peak travel generally is defined as noon on Monday through noon on Thursday. Peak travel is noon on Thursday through noon on Monday.
The offer extends through May 31 for travel through Sept. 8. The nonrefundable fares apply to round-trip flights with reservations made at least seven days before travel.
Children 17 and under must be accompanied by an adult for the half-off fare. A Saturday night stay is generally required.
The offer is aimed at families trying to decide between driving and flying for summer vacations, or whether to make a trip at all, Mr. Miller said.
Domestic airlines are trying to lure more passengers to raise revenues and return to profitability. The industry lost nearly $4 billion last year, a record, as carriers were assaulted by the recession, higher jet-fuel prices and a loss of passengers stemming from the Persian Gulf war.
 
America West Starts Round
 Two weeks ago, America West Airlines lowered all of its fares, some by as much as 40 percent, in a promotion aimed at business travelers. But the cuts did not catch on in an industry where airlines often scurry to keep up with the competition.
Nor did the carriers match Southwest Airlines when it announced a summertime promotion two weeks ago in which children would fly free. The offer expires on Wednesday.
Jackie Pate, a Delta spokeswoman, said the airline was surprised by the newest round of price-cutting. "Our bookings for the summer are very strong," she said.
But she added: "In the airline business, you must remain competitive. If the competitors are offering a lower fare, you have to match it."

HEADLINE: Banks Avoid Some F.D.I.C. Fees

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
As the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation prepares to increase insurance premiums charged on bank deposits, a handful of banks are taking advantage of a financing technique that allows them to borrow funds in a way that does not require payment for deposit insurance.
Following the rules of the F.D.I.C., banks may issue notes that are a general obligation, like a deposit, but are not called deposits and are not insured by the Government. The notes are sold in multimillion-dollar minimums to institutions like money market mutual funds, whose investments are so large that in theory they benefit little from the $100,000 of Government insurance per account, which would apply to large certificates of deposit. 
 Bankers are eager to sell notes to such large investors because the notes usually carry a lower interest rate than would be required for notes issued by a bank's parent holding company and the notes do not require payment of deposit insurance premiums. Annual deposit insurance premiums are scheduled to increase to $2,300 per $1 million on July 1, up from $1,950 currently, and nearly three times as high as the $830 premium charged until the end of 1989.
"We have had inquiries from many other banks who are considering notes because they do not like to pay the F.D.I.C. insurance premium," said Edward Z. Emmer, a banking analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation. S.& P. already rates bank notes of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the Republic National Bank and the American Express Centurion Bank, all of New York, and the U.S. National Bank of Washington, a Seattle-based subsidiary of U.S. Bancorp of Portland, Ore.
Morgan Guaranty, with about $600 million of notes outstanding at the end of 1990, has issued the most notes, and analysts noted that its top-notch credit rating had attracted many investors. The American Express Centurion Bank has plans to issue notes, but has not yet done so.
Securities dealers who asked not to be identified said that an additional half-dozen banks had sold uninsured notes occasionally. The perception that weakness in the banking industry is not fatal, as reflected in higher prices for bank stocks, has strengthened demand for the bank notes.
 
Many Banks Unsure
 "But there are lots of banks sitting on the sidelines right now because they are unsure about the banking legislation in Washington," an investment banker said. "Their fear is that the laws will change so that insurance premiums are charged on a broader base of assets or liabilities."
Bruce Mauger, senior vice president at U.S. Bancorp, which has issued about $230 million of the notes in the last month, said the bank planned to issue as much as $1 billion as it replaced its maturing certificates of deposit with the lower-cost notes.
"The absence of F.D.I.C. insurance premiums is the driving force behind the note sales," Mr. Mauger said. He added that the instititional investors who buy the notes "are relying on the quality of the bank, not the presence of deposit insurance."
Mr. Mauger said the notes had been sold recently with an interest rate that is only five-hundredths of a percentage point greater than certificates of deposit. The extra interest cost is more than offset, he noted, by avoiding payment of the deposit insurance premium of 23-hundredths of a percentage point on certificates of deposit.
 
More Options for Banks
 Richard Kendrick, an expert on bank securities at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said many investors were wary of buying notes issued by a bank's holding company "but are quite interested in notes issued by banks." The issuance of notes, which he expects will increase, "helps open up the market for banks, and gives them more options," he said.
Analysts said that for many banks, the interest rates on the notes due in about two years were only about three-tenths of a percentage point higher than Treasury notes of similar maturity, while two-year notes issued by the holding company could carry rates that were a percentage point or more above Treasury notes.
The growing bank interest in the notes comes at a time when the F.D.I.C.'s financial condition has been so weakened by bank failures that Congress is considering ways of strengthening its finances by allowing it to borrow from the Treasury or the Federal Reserve.
Roger Hood, a lawyer and deposit insurance expert at the F.D.I.C., said the agency was not considering any measures to limit the sale of bank notes. But he said the possibility of imposing limits was discussed a few years ago "and if the practice becomes prevalent, we will take a look at it."

HEADLINE: New Study of Older Workers Finds They Can Become Good Investments

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Dan Young of Atlanta came out of an unwanted retirement four years ago, took a job booking hotel rooms and now at the age of 74 helps supervise hundreds of reservation agents.
Christine Shelley, a widow who was retired, became restless and went back to work. She learned to use a computer and earned six annual pay increases. Now 73 years old, she advises other older workers, "Never be afraid to accept a challenge." 
 Their experiences illustrate the findings of a new study of two American corporations and a British retail chain. It concluded that older workers can be retrained in new technologies, have lower absenteeism and are often better salespeople than younger workers.
"The biggest single barrier for employers to hire older workers was the lack of any verifiable evidence that it made good sense economically to do so," said Thomas W. Moloney, senior vice president of the Commonwealth Fund, which commissioned the study.
 
'Hard-Nose Economic Analysis'
 "We have here the first systematic, hard-nosed economic analysis showing older workers are good investments," he said of the study made by ICF, a Washington consulting concern specializing in labor market studies.
Earlier studies made for the Commonwealth Fund, a private foundation based in New York, estimate that six million unemployed Americans over the age of 55 are ready and able to work. They would join 13.5 million others over 55 who are already in the work force.
The Census Bureau said nearly 50.5 million Americans, or 20.3 percent of the nation's population, were over 55 in 1989, the latest such figures available.
"With each passing year there will be more and more upper-age Americans interested, able and desirous of working," said Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the Eisenhower Center for the Conservation of Human Resources at Columbia University. "Unless the country wants to pay additional taxes to support a lot of elderly people, it makes more sense to offer them the opportunity to work and earn an income."
 
The Recession as an Excuse
 Dr. Ginzberg, who is 80 and completing his 56th year of teaching, added, "One can always find an excuse, such as the current recession, to justify a prejudice about hiring policies."
The studies were conducted at the Atlanta headquarters of Days Inns of America Inc., the hotel chain; the Travelers Corporation of Hartford, a holding company and subsidiary of the Travelers Companies, and B&Q, Britain's largest chain of do-it-yourself hardware stores.
All three concerns were chosen for the study because of their long-term experience in hiring workers 50 and over and their willingness to permit analysts to examine their business records. Days Inns, in particular, had been experiencing high staff turnover and was looking for workers more likely to stay on the job.
"Three years ago we were out there beating the bushes to get other companies to learn from our experience," said Carol Bivins, a vice president at Days Inns who began in 1986 to organize job fairs where business representatives and older people could meet.
 
Some Changing Demographics
 The first event attracted 50 businesses. Last Saturday, 85 Days Inns hotels in 31 states threw open their conference rooms for job-seekers, attracting more than 1,700 concerns,
At the Atlanta job fair, which drew 200 job-seekers and representatives of 30 companies, Jerry Mabe, vice president of a temporary personnel service in Atlanta, said the demographics of the older work force were changing. Older men laid off or forced into early retirement by the recession now represent a larger portion of the older work force, he said.
Virtually all of the employers at the job fair said older workers were more reliable. "Older workers have a better work ethic, a lower rate of absenteeism and more dedication to the job," said Janice L. Moran of Spiegel Inc.
The Travelers, which employs 10,000 workers, adopted hiring practices that include affirmative action for older workers because demographic projections showed a diminishing number of young people applying for jobs.
"We had to find a labor source other than college and high school graduates," said Peter Libassi, the company's senior vice president.
So Travelers started a job bank project, recruiting its retired employees to return to part-time or, in some cases, full-time employment. When Travelers had more job opportunities than workers, it opened the program up to former employees of other companies in Hartford.
"On any day, there are 250 former retirees showing up for work," said Mr. Libassi. "We didn't do it just to make our retirees happy. We did it first and foremost because it was in the best interests of the company to hire, train or retrain older workers."
At Days Inns, both Mr. Young and Mrs. Shelley are part of a work force that operates a nationwide computerized reservation service from the concern's Atlanta headquarters.
Mr. Young, a former Air Force captain, said he was stunned when, at the age of 69, he was told he no longer had a job. He said he heard about Days Inns seeking older workers, applied for a job and, after three days' training, joined the pool of agents who make hotel reservations.
 
A Higher Success Rate
 The analysis of employees' productivity, made by ICF, measured how quickly agents worked, their success rate in making reservations, absentee and job-turnover rates, said Michael C. Barth, senior vice president of ICF and director of the Commonwealth Fund's study.
Analysts found, for example, that at Days Inns older workers might take a minute longer talking with callers, but they had a higher rate of success in making reservations. And older workers tended to stay on the job longer.
In Britain, the B&Q company found an additional benefit: older workers tended to be homeowners and were therefore more familiar than younger workers with the houseware and construction products sold by the chain.
To prove the capabilities of older workers to their skeptical store managers, the company staffed a new store entirely with workers over 50. The study found the store was 18 percent more profitable than five other B&Q outlets. It also found that the turnover rate was six times lower and that older workers were absent 39 percent less often than in the other stores.
B&Q was so impressed that another store employing workers over 50 was opened, and the company set a goal of 10 percent employment of older workers by the end of the year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Last Saturday, 85 Days Inns hotels in 31 states opened their conference rooms for job-seekers over the age of 55. About 200 job-seekers showed up in Atlanta to meet with representatives of 30 companies. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers began to prepare for a huge supply of new short-term securities.
This week the Treasury will sell $37.5 billion worth of new two-year and five-year notes as well as a 335-day cash management bill. 
 Those auctions follow yesterday's weekly sale of three-month and six-month bills.
At the bill auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.50 percent, unchanged from a week ago.
Bids on six-month bills produced an average rate of 5.66 percent, up slightly from the 5.63 percent average rate at last week's sale.
In advance of the note auctions, which will be held tomorrow and Thursday, traders said rates on the new securities to be sold look attractive. But they added that the sheer weight of the issues might force up yields even higher to attract demand.
"Distribution is everything," one Government securities trader said. "When everybody already owns securities and there is no business, the market tends to sag."
In lat trading, the new two-year notes, which will be sold tomorrow, were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.87 percent. The new five-year notes, which will be sold on Thursday, were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.76 percent.
Indeed, some portfolio managers said that at this point it is difficult to justify committing large amounts of additional capital to the market.
"In the United States, along with a lot of other major markets, you won't get hurt a whole lot," said Robert Sinche, a fixed-income portfolio manager at Alliance Capital. "but you won't make a lot of money in them either."
Mr. Sinche said it would take a "convincing" change in the fundamental outlook to alter his view.
"Evidence of a relapse in the economy or signs that inflation is not going to moderate" would push interest rates out of their current range, he said.
 
Economy Still in Recession
 Despite some evidence that has suggested the economy may be turning, Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, told reporters in Washington yesterday that the economy was still in recession, and that the credit crunch had not abated.
Mr. Greenspan's comments stand in marked contrast to those made on Sunday by Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
In a television interview, Mr. Darman said that economic recovery had already begun.
Mr. Greenspan's comments did not provoke much of a reaction in the credit markets.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 98 10/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.27 percent, the same level as late Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 15/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.07 percent. And the 7 percent three-year notes were offered at 99 19/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.15 percent.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was very slow, traders said.
Prices of most issues in both markets were essentially unchanged on the day.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Two Big California Utilities Plan to Cut CO<2> Emissions

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Southern California Edison Company and the municipal utility that serves Los Angeles said yesterday that they would cut their emissions of carbon dioxide, which is believed to cause climate change, by 20 percent in the next 20 years.
The companies, the first American utilities to make such a promise, said the reductions would be achieved primarily through improving the efficiency with which electricity is used in lighting, cooling, heating and other uses. Other reductions would come by rebuilding plants that now burn oil and natural gas at low efficiency to burning gas at high efficiency and by buying more power made from wind, solar energy and geothermal heat. 
 Most of the steps would be required anyway, to reduce smog and keep electric rates as low as possible, the companies said. But environmentalists said the announcement showed the potential for utilities around the country to cut the emission of "greenhouse gases" at low cost.
At the Natural Resources Defense Council, a nonprofit environmental group based in Washington, Daniel A. Lashof, the group's senior climate scientist, said, "It's something that all utilities could achieve."
The United States will have to be prominent in any effort to control greenhouse gases, Mr. Lashof said, adding that Southern California Edison, with a population area of 10 million, and the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, with 3.5 million people in its service territory, now emit more carbon dioxide than Portugal, Ireland or New Zealand emit from all sources.
The European Community has promised to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions in 2000 at 1990 levels, and some countries, especially Germany, have promised to go further. In international negotiations, the Bush Administration has refused to commit the United States to reducing carbon dioxide emissions, which would essentially mean reducing the use of fuel, especially coal.
The Administration has said, however, that it expects American emissions of all greenhouse gases to stabilize by 2000, as chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, are phased out. CFC's are greenhouse gases that also destroy the ozone and that are being eliminated by treaty.
At the Environmental Protection Agency, Dennis A. Tirpak, director of the global climate change division, said that the ability of utilities to cut their carbon dioxide emissions would differ from company to company, but that the two California companies "certainly would be serving as an example for what other uiltiies might want to look at."
Southern California Edison, the nation's second-largest utility after the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, and the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, the largest municipal company, said that with no action, rapid growth of population and demand in their service areas would cause their emissions of carbon dioxide to grow rapidly.
Scientists disagree about how fast or how much the climate will change because of the man-made change in the concentration of carbon dixoide and other atmospheric gases. But John E. Bryson, the chairman and chief executive of Southern California Edison, said at a news conference in New York yesterday, "Taking prudent, reasonably economical steps to reduce carbon dioxide is warranted by the current state of knowledge."
The reductions, he said, were based on a "no regrets policy," meaning that most of the steps made sense for other reasons as well. Encouraging more efficient use of electricity is generally cheaper than building new power plants, he continued.
And state and local regulations in California will require the companies to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides about 75 percent in coming years, he said. Nitrogen oxides react with other gases in sunlight to form smog.
But the promise announced yesterday will require the companies to go further than other factors would push them. Vern Pruitt, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, estimated that his department would spend about $12 million a year, entailing rate increases of one-tenth of 1 percent, to pay for the program.
Mr. Bryson said that the additional cost for his company would be small, that he was not able to say how much it would be, but that the company would seek a rate increase.
 
Efforts Already Being Made
 Southern California Edison, a holding of SCEcorp, is already paying bonuses to home builders who construct energy-efficient houses, subsidizing customers who buy energy-efficient fluorescent light bulbs and adding "renewable energy" -- mostly solar, wind or geothermal, produced by small companies. Last month the company, with Texas Instruments Inc., announced a breakthrough in photovoltaic cells that convert sunlight directly into electricity.
While no American utilities have been ordered to cut carbon dioxide emissions, many expect carbon dioxide to be added to the list of pollutants they must minimize. Mr. Pruitt of the Department of Water and Power said his department would rather cut emissions itself than wait to be told to act.
"If you wait for the voters to begin a ballot initiative, you've waited too long," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Two Chains Post Mixed Results

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 7.3 percent in the first quarter, but profits fell nearly a third at Toys "R" Us Inc.
K Mart attributed its gains to new business from bargain-hunting consumers in the recession and to a shift in its merchandising strategy. 
 K Mart, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and several other discount retailers have thrived recently while others have lost sales because of the recession.
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
K Mart
The retailer, based in Troy, Mich., said its earnings in the quarter that ended on May 1 totaled $107.5 million, or 53 cents a share, compared with $100.1 million, or 50 cents a share.
Overall sales rose 8.5 percent, to $7.64 billion from $7.04 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year, which are considered the best barometer of a retailer's performance, rose 4.3 percent, a strong showing during difficult times for the industry.
Some retailing analysts said K Mart's earnings exceeded their predictions and showed the strength of discounters during the economic slump.
Daniel Barry of Kidder, Peabody & Company said K Mart had also made several moves that were helping its sales, including the conversion to scanning checkout counters and the lowering of prices on household products.
K Mart operates more than 4,000 retail outlets in the United States, Puerto Rico and Canada. That consists of 2,337 K Mart stores, as well as the company's Pay Less Drug Stores, Builders Square, Waldenbooks, Pace Membership Warehouse and Sports Authority stores.
K Mart's stock rose $1.375 yesterday, to $41.25 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
 
 
Toys 'R' Us
 Toys "R" Us, based in Rochelle Park, N.J., said it earned $22.3 million, or 8 cents a share, in the quarter that ended on May 4, down 32 percent from $33.2 million, or 11 cents a share.
The company said its overall sales rose to $1.03 billion from $944.8 million. Those from stores open at least a year fell 4.7 percent.
Toys "R" Us gave no reason for the earnings decline, but like other retailers, it has been hit hard as consumers scale back their spending. Although consumers were not expected to scrimp on purchases for their children, Toys "R" Us and other toy retailers saw their sales slump during the Persian Gulf crisis and remain depressed after the end of the war in early March.
The company's shares fell 12.5 cents each, to $27.625, yesterday on the Big Board.
The retailer operates 451 toy stores in the United States, 97 overseas, as well as 180 Kids "R" Us clothing stores.
