HEADLINE: On My Mind;
If I Were a Rich Man

BYLINE: A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
When I was about 17 years old, I used to daydream about earning some money beyond what I needed for carfare and lunches in the college cafeteria. I mean real money, something like thirty or forty dollars.
In my reverie, I would go straight down to Macy's book department, whose stock I knew by heart from hours of wandering cashless along the shelves. 
 There I would spend my dream money, selecting Poe and O'Neill in the satisfyingly hefty Modern Library Giants edition, that three-volume Shakespeare for $4.95, or a book of India travels for a dollar, careful not to go over my lavish budget, enjoying every moment while I strolled, enjoying it even in retrospect when I shook myself into reality and got off at the City College subway stop.
Now, somewhat older, I daydream in larger terms, about what I would do if the Government showed up at my office one day and asked me how to spend bigger money -- say $2.5 billion for foreign aid, or even $150 billion.
We are told that the United States must lend at least $2.5 billion to the Soviet Union this year for agricultural products -- $1 billion already provided and an additional $1.5 billion the Bush Administration seems determined to give to Moscow. Various governments and economists say it would cost the West about $30 billion a year for at least five years to bolster the Soviet economy, and they tell us it is a bargain.
I don't know about that. Loans guaranteed by the U.S. -- low rate, long term and non-collateralized -- to a bankrupt country with hidden assets are tax-paid foreign aid. So part of that money is mine and yours, which should concentrate our minds on how it is spent. Let's start small, with a dream stake of that $2.5 billion in agricultural credits.
Nobody wants Soviet citizens to go hungry. But if hunger-relief is the goal, the Soviet Union does not seem in worse condition than Ethiopia, the Sudan or Bangladesh.
If the goal is economic assistance to shore up countries emerging from the disaster of Communism I would pick from the shelf those that have already emerged. How about more for Poland? The Poles are not only jumping fully into the rough currents of free enterprise but were the victims of the Soviet Union, where Mr. Gorbachev still has not dipped a toe into the water. And though the Soviet Parliament passed a law allowing free emigration, it won't take effect until 1993.
If the goal is to help countries that have overthrown dictatorship, here's an idea. How about Haiti, Nicaragua and Panama? It would certainly be nice if for once the U.S. devoted enough money and continuous attention to making economic showcases out of impoverished neighbors who fought for political freedom.
The heart of the issue, of course, is whether money spent now for Mr. Gorbachev's Government will solve or perpetuate the Soviet crisis. The problem is that Mr. Gorbachev's Government cannot get food from the Soviet field to the Soviet stomach any better than could Stalin's. It is not just money credit but political credit Mr. Gorbachev wants -- economic help now against economic change tomorrow.
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has asked the President to look into the realities of the Soviet system that cause the problem. How much is lost to waste, corruption, and policies that make the black markets and shortages inevitable? Is the centralized system being used to coerce the republics, by holding back food from certain maverick regions? (Yes.) Here's a question from Soviet dissidents: How many officials and ex-officials of the Communist bureaucracy are selling contracts to the West and battening on food profits?
And what about collateral? If the Gorbachev Government needs food supplies, it has plenty of resources it could put up -- billions in gold bullion and diamonds, for instance. It could avoid need for credits if it just stopped spending billions for arms to the Afghan Government and for Castro-propping.
Answers received, Americans can decide on the urgency of additional Soviet agricultural credits.
But after that we should wait until Mr. Gorbachev or his successor make fundamental changes in the Soviet economic system, which of course would make it totally un-Soviet. Until then, we should take that $150 billion in hand and spend a little time strolling in our minds, dreaming of how it could be spent, and for whom.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: After Mexico, the Main Event

 BODY:
Fast-track trade legislation, committing Congress to voting on trade agreements promptly and without amendment, is scheduled for vote early this week. Without such protection, foreign governments won't negotiate trade pacts, fearing that hard-fought deals could then be picked apart by special interests. That's why opponents of the Administration's free-trade pact with Mexico have targeted fast-track for attack.
The economic benefits of the Mexican agreement will be small on both sides of the border. Thus a no vote on fast-track might seem unimportant. But that view would be myopic: Mexican trade is a sideshow to what's really at stake, the five-year Uruguay Round of international trade talks scheduled to be completed this year. It will slash tariffs and other trade barriers, thereby adding trillions to the world's economies by the end of the decade. Few, if any, government policies in the U.S. or anywhere else will do more for economic growth. 
 The Uruguay Round has been stalled over Europe's refusal to scale back policies that lock out food imports. But once this roadblock is overcome, the benefits will be enormous. Third-world countries will gain access to developed countries for exports of food and textiles; in turn, industrialized countries will gain important protections for exports of services and intellectual property.
After the Uruguay agreement knocks down barriers everywhere, free trade with Mexico will pale in significance. Indeed, the case for the Mexican pact is mainly political. Mexico has launched brave market reforms the U.S. can now reward.
Organized labor has objected to the pact because, it argues, factories will flee to take advantage of low Mexican wages and poor working conditions. But most studies show that free trade will increase U.S. jobs. Some industries, like textiles and autos, will suffer. But the Administration has offered the right answer: generous retraining and re-employment services for dislocated workers.
Mr. Bush has also reassured environmentalists that free trade won't compromise high U.S. standards and has granted them a role in negotiating the pact. The National Wildlife Foundation cited these assurances last week as the basis for its endorsement of fast-track.
Finally, there is the charge that fast-track is undemocratic because at the end of the process Congress is given an all-or-nothing package. But that accusation ignores the rest of the process -- one of constant consultation between trade negotiators and Congressional committees.
Freer trade is Congress's golden opportunity to boost productivity and growth. But before that can happen, it needs to approve fast-track. Mr. Bush has addressed legitimate objections; the ones that remain are nakedly protectionist.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Square Deals Will Sell American Cars

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is with great sadness that I read about the $2 billion loss suffered by Ford and G.M. in the last quarter (Business Day, May 1) and the economic woes that the United States suffers as a result. American car makers claim that they are victims of our economic malaise and foreign competition, but that is only part of the problem. The American people are shunning not just the big three auto makers but their dealers' methods of selling cars. 
 For years automobile dealers have been perceived as greedy rip-off artists who rarely deal openly with their customers about their fat profit margins over factory invoice or about the numerous hidden costs that are associated with buying accessories. The American people are fed up and have turned to foreigners for value at a fair cost.
It is time for a new way of thinking. Instead of discounting to dealers, who try not to pass the savings along, United States car makers should give the discounts directly to the customers by cutting sticker prices. Dealers should be forced by car makers to be upfront about the true cost of a car and its options and add only a 3 percent commission. Let's get the scam out of the deal!
Replacing the car dealers' book of tricks with a fair transaction on each automobile will prompt the American consumer to start buying American again. At the expense only of unscrupulous dealers, U.S. car makers will be able to return to profitability, increase production, rehire laid-off workers, help decrease the foreign debt and perhaps singlehandedly pull America out of the recession. Americans want to buy from Detroit, not Tokyo. Detroit ought to help them do it!
 
ROB BELL
Flemington, N.J., May 2, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Fleet/Norstar Fills Massachusetts Post

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Leo R. Breitman worked at the Bank of New England in its heydey and he was around for its demise. Now, at age 50, he is the most senior official to be offered a job by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, which acquired the Boston-based bank last month.
Mr. Breitman will be chief executive of Fleet/Norstar's $7 billion Massachusetts banking unit, which consists primarily of the old Bank of New England business plus a small Fleet/ Norstar operation. After nearly 20 years at the Bank of New England, Mr. Breitman has the knowledge of an insider but has not been tainted with the real estate lending mistakes that led the Bank of New England to insolvency. 
 Starting as a specialist in leasing and other kinds of secured lending in 1971, Mr. Breitman was a leading player in the development during the 1970's and 1980's of the Bank of New England's strong connections with small- and medium-sized businesses in New England. Even today, he said, in the midst of a recession, "the middle-market lending activity has held up very well." The problems with bad loans "are clearly within acceptable standards," he added.
After leaving the Bank of New England in 1985 to become president of the Patriot Bank in Boston, Mr. Breitman found himself back home in 1987 after the Bank of New England acquired the Conifer Group, which owned Patriot.
Shortly after his return, Mr. Breitman emerged as a trouble-shooter, spending time at the company's troubled Connecticut bank unit. Since June 1990, he has served as the company's senior credit policy officer with responsiblity for improving and managing the loan-approval process.
In his new position as head of the Massachusetts bank unit of Fleet/ Norstar, Mr. Breitman said his top priority would be to create more stability for employees and customers.
"We have suffered attrition of people who were worried about their careers, and I can't say to those remaining, 'Don't worry, you won't be fired,' " Mr. Beitman said. "But because I know the people and the contributions they have made and their capacity, I can make the necessary changes in a thoughtful and high-quality way."
Customers of the Bank of New England will soon notice a difference, Mr. Breitman said, because the financial strength that results from the acquisition by Fleet means the bank will have more money to lend.
Mr. Breitman says he enjoys playing golf, but he has enough of a competive streak to be coy about admitting to a 16-stroke handicap. Opportunities to play have become scarce enough, he said, "that my handicap could be 20 by the next time I play."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: BUSINESS PEOPLE (TIMES COLUMN)

HEADLINE: OSLO JOURNAL;
Who's in Charge Here? Chances Are It's a Woman

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSLO

 BODY:
The Prime Minister of Norway is a woman, and half her Cabinet are women. So are the leaders of two of the main opposition political parties. So are the two candidates running next fall for Mayor of Oslo. And so are 59 of the 165 members of the Norwegian Parliament.
"Sometimes I meet some men who think that women have too much influence," said Astrid Noeklebye Heiberg, a professor of psychiatry at Oslo University and the Conservative Party nominee for Mayor. "But I remind the men they should not be too fearful. They still have two-thirds of the Parliament." 
 In no other country do women play such a large and highly visible role in both national politics and government as Norway. In Britain, for example, only 7 percent of the Members of Parliament are women, and in Washington, fewer than 6 percent of the lawmakers in Congress are women -- 29 of 435 members in the House of Representatives and 2 of 100 Senators.
 
Premier Is the Inspiration
 Gro Harlem Brundtland, a 52-year-old Harvard-trained physician who is serving as Norway's Prime Minister for the third time, is both the inspiration and the symbol of the growing influence of women in public life here, a trend that she attributes to her nation's deeply held democratic beliefs and longtime commitment to social reform.
"If you look at the 70's, in the U.S. and in other European countries, feminism was a kind of high-level intellectual and cultural debate, focused through novels, through speeches," she said. "It never came deep into reality."
But in Norway there is broad agreement with the idea that women must take part fully and equally in politics. To that end, Dr. Brundtland's Labor Party adopted a rule in 1983 requiring that no fewer than 40 percent and no more than 60 percent of its nominees must be women. Soon other parties followed.
Such questions are probably more easily addressed in a small, prosperous and racially homogenous country like Norway, where civil rights mostly revolve around questions of age and sex.
Even so, there are those who believe that feminism alone cannot explain what has happened. Four years ago a Norwegian research institute commissioned a study called Scenario 2000, in which a group of scholars, business executives and politicians suggested that one reason that women were becoming more prominent in public life was that men had conceded them the field.
As Norway's economy became more internationalized, the theory goes, real power was no longer confined within the nation's borders. That meant, in turn, that the brightest men were deliberately avoiding public service and choosing to move into higher-paying, higher-status jobs in the private sector.
The report concluded, "Women may be moving from a marginal minority to a marginal majority."
Dr. Brundtland acknowledges that women have made few gains in Norway's private sector, but says women have come to power as Government influence is expanding.
"During the 1970's and the 1980's, there was an increase in public expenditures, an increase in the number of new Government programs and new reforms," she said. "If you want to use the power discussion, this certainly was not a phase in Norwegian postwar history where political questions were uninteresting, or where there was no growth."
She also argues that women have made a difference in reshaping Norway's national agenda. With more women in politics, she says, there has been a much stronger emphasis on issues like child care, education and family life.
 
Equality Issue Wanes
 Dr. Brundtland herself is the mother of four. Kaci Kullman Five, who is the head of the rival Conservative Party, has two children, and Anne Inger Lahnstein of the rural Center Party has three. Their parties attract 70 percent of the national electorate.
Although some critics say the changes are mostly symbolic and merely an extension of Norway's traditional emphasis on social welfare, there are broader discussions in Government now about expanding day care programs for the children of working parents, and lengthening the number of hours that children are in school.
Bernt Aardal, a political researcher at the Institute for Social Research, says the number of women means that there is virtually no political debate anymore over questions of sexual equality. Referring to a televised debate on whether Norway should seek membership in the European Community, in which Dr. Brundtland appeared on a panel with Mrs. Lahnstein and Mrs. Five, he said: "You no longer think: These are three women talking. Where are the men?"
On second thought, Mr. Aardal said, there was one thing. "You notice that they all call each other by the first names," he said. "The men would never have been so informal."
But Dr. Brundtland's opponents find her an increasingly difficult target. In the last election, for example, the Conservatives tried to profit from the fact that her husband, Arne Olav, had once been a longtime member of their party.
"Do as Gro did," a campaign slogan went. "Choose a Conservative." Dr. Brundtland was quick with her riposte: "Do as Arne Olav did," she said. "Choose Gro."

HEADLINE: Bush Tells Belgrade That U.S. May Consider Restoring Aid

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Bush has informed the Government of Yugoslavia that he would consider lifting suspension of all United States economic assistance to that country, a White House spokesman said today.
The aid cutoff began automatically on May 6 as a result of legislation enacted in November decreeing that unless Yugoslavia and its constituent republics ceased systematic human rights violations American aid would be terminated in six months. The law stipulates that unless the Secretary of State certified that Yugoslavia had met this test, the suspension would automatically go into effect. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d allowed the deadline to pass without comment. 
 The legislation in question is the Nickles amendment to the Foreign Operations Appropriations Act for the 1991 fiscal year and is named for its principal author, Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma.
Although the legislation did not single out any part of Yugoslavia on the human rights issue, its main supporters made clear that their target was the Republic of Serbia because of Serbian maltreatment of its large minority of ethnic Albanians.
On Monday, Mr. Bush telephoned Yugoslavia's federal Prime Minister, Ante Markovic, to assure him that the Administration still supports him, his economic reform program and the unity of Yugoslavia.
 
'No Decision One Way or Other'
 Explaining Mr. Bush's stance on the Nickles amendment and his message to Mr. Markovic, Roman Popadiuk, a White House spokesman, said: "We made no decision one way or the other, so that put the Nickles amendment into effect. What the President was saying is that we're going to take a look at our decision, which was basically no decision, and see if we can certify if they are complying or not."
In Belgrade today, the chief American delegate, Warren Zimmerman, told Tanyug, the Yugoslav press agency, that the Bush Administration would be more favorably disposed to restoring economic aid if Yugoslavia resolved its constitutional crisis, which has left the country without a head of state.
Referring to an impasse over the installation of Stipe Mesic of Croatia as the head of the federal presidency, Mr. Zimmerman said, "A softening of the consequences of the Nickles amendment will depend partly on whether Mr. Mesic will be allowed to take over the post of President." Serbia is leading the effort in the eight-member federal presidency that has prevented Mr. Mesic from assuming the post.
While only $5 million in American aid has been halted by the suspension and no other programs are under consideration, Yugoslavia could run into grave problems when it seeks a $1.1 billion standby loan from the International Monetary Fund later this year. The suspension calls on the Administration to oppose loans for Yugoslavia in the I.M.F.
Mr. Baker conferred today on the aid suspension issue with senior aides, including Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a former Ambassador to Yugoslavia, but apparently without immediate result.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Retreat; Gold Little Changed in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower yesterday in quiet, uneventful trading following reports of central bank intervention in Europe.
Gold prices were little changed after rising overseas. 
 On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $357.20 an ounce, off 20 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $356.50 an ounce, unchanged.
The dollar started out lower in Asia, then continued to fall in Europe after some reported dollar selling by the German Bundesbank and Sweden's Riksbank.
 
Central Banks Intervention
 The central banks had intervened to keep the dollar in check after Sweden's announcement last week that it would link the krona with the European Currency Unit. The dollar had soared on the expectation that Swedish banks would have to buy dollars to adjust their foreign exchange holdings.
Traders said the dollar has since settled down domestically after the Swedish commotion.
"I think the Swedish situation is finally out of the market, and people are trying to assess the U.S. economy," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Mr. Johnson said there was "not a strong incentive to buy or sell the dollar right now" in the absence of fresh economic data and as the Memorial Day holiday neared.
Traders predicted the dollar would trade in a fairly stable range in the near term.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell 0.65 yen to close at 138.15 yen. It was quoted at 137.40 yen in London, and 137.30 yen in New York, down from 138.50 Monday.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound compared with late Monday. Sterling bought $1.7365 in London, up from $1.7195, and $1.7370 in New York, up from $1.7170.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.7128 West German marks, down from 1.7320; 1.4485 Swiss francs, down from 1.4615; 5.8140 French francs, down from 5.8690; 1,272 Italian lire, down from 1,285, and 1.14895 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14925.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $356.80 a troy ounce, from $355.50 late Monday. In Zurich, gold closed at $356.45 an ounce, up from $355.10.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.37 to close at a bid $357.13 an ounce.
Silver prices headed higher. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.035 a troy ounce, up from $4.02 Monday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Increase

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices moved higher and long-term interest rates fell a bit yesterday, as investors seeking higher yields purchased long-term securities. Shorter-term note prices, by contrast, posted more modest gains.
"We have seen some real buying in the long end," one trader in government securities said. "A large part, if not all, of the bonds sold at the refunding have been distributed." 
 Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank North America, said "the last couple of sets of price data should engender the thinking that inflation is coming down," a favorable development for bonds.
 
'A Bit Less Nervous'
 "Also, the market seems a bit less nervous about the supply of bonds" left over from the Treasury's quarterly refunding, he added.
While the near-term outlook for bonds seems favorable, traders were less confident about the effect that the coming auctions of two-year and five-year notes might have on short-term rates. "There is the potential for a minor setback," one trader said. "But by the middle of next week we should be set up for a decent rally. After these auctions, we aren't going to have any supply of coupon-bearing securities for a month. These days, that is about as long as you get."
An auction yesterday of $16 billion worth of new 335-day cash management bills went fairly well, traders said, given the issue's enormous size. The new bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.89 percent.
 
Two- and Five-Year Notes
 Today the Treasury will sell $12.25 billion of new two-year notes. That auction will be followed tomorrow by the sale of $9.25 billion of new five-year notes.
In when-issued trading yesterday the new two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.83 percent, down from 6.87 percent late Monday. The five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.70 percent late yesterday, compared to 7.76 percent on Monday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 98 21/32 late yesterday, up 10/32, to yield 8.24 percent, down from 8.27 percent on Monday.
 
Narrow Yield Differential
 For much of the year, to lock in higher yields "many investors have been buying corporate or mortgage-backed securities," rather than Treasury bonds, said James Kochan, chief of fixed-income money management at R. W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "Now the yield differential between those securities and governments is so narrow that investors are beginning to sense that the government market is cheap," he added.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 99 23/32, up a quarter of a point, to yield 8.04 percent. And the 7 percent three-year notes were offered at 99 22/32, up 2/32, to yield 7.11 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.47 percent, down one basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.65 percent.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by close to $1 billion in new offerings. Underwriters said that for the most part the deals were well received.
Meanwhile, prices of the most widely quoted issues in the secondary market for municipal securities were unchanged, dealers said.
 
Ryder Systems Notes
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Ryder Systems Inc. priced $100 million worth of 10-year notes through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 1/4 percent notes, which mature May 15, 2001, were priced at 99.15 to yield 9.382 percent, 1.33 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by an eighth of a point to a quarter of a point in active trading.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks to Avoid Gorbachev Talks

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Bush has decided that the idea of inviting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to a seven-nation summit meeting in London in July is "a non-starter" and is trying to scuttle the plan without embarrassing the Soviet leader, Administration officials said today.
Although Soviet-American relations are going through a smoother period now than they were late last year, as Mr. Gorbachev appears to be steering his Government back toward political and economic change, the officials said the prospects were also becoming dimmer for holding the next superpower summit conference in Moscow in late June, as envisioned by an agreement reached earlier this year. 
 Lingering problems in arms control and unsettled questions about the extent to which the United States will be able to help the Soviet Union financially make it increasingly likely that the meeting will not be held until later in the summer, officials said.
"There is a strong predisposition on the President's part to go to Moscow, but the final hurdles have not been passed," an official said.
 
Talk With Soviet General
 The United States has been holding back from setting a date for the summit meeting in hopes of putting pressure on the Soviet Union to compromise in a dispute over the carrying out of a treaty reducing conventional armed forces in Europe.
Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, Chief of the Soviet General Staff, talked for about 15 minutes today with Mr. Bush in the office of his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. Mr. Scowcroft and General Moiseyev talked alone for about 15 minutes as well, the White House said.
Earlier, the general met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Administration officials said the first round of discussions, on Monday, had been disappointing and there were no reports of any major progress after today's talks either.
 
Gorbachev Trip to London
 With the timing of his next summit meeting with Mr. Bush unsettled, Mr. Gorbachev has raised the idea of going to London in July to attend the annual meeting of the seven most powerful industrial democracies, whose help he is seeking as he tries to save his country's foundering economy.
After meeting in the White House on Monday, Mr. Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany appeared to leave the door open for such a trip. But American officials said today that the United States did not support the idea and that Mr. Kohl had not made a strong pitch for it either.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush was eager to help the Soviet Union financially but was still not certain how far he could go and feared that having Mr. Gorbachev in London could force his hand.
"We don't foresee a meeting in London," an official said. "It's a non-starter from our perspective because of a number of concerns, the most important of which is that having him come to a meeting like that puts him in the grandstand position of asking for money and puts pressure on us to respond."
 
Economic Issues in Forefront
 The official continued: "There are also political concerns about other countries in Eastern Europe that might more obviously warrant inclusion in a meeting like the London summit. We can't come out and say 'No,' because the British are the hosts and because the President doesn't want it to appear to be a slap in the face at Gorbachev. But basically, we're going to make sure everyone is on board and then we're going to make this not happen."
As the ideological and military confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union have become less important, Administration officials said economic issues have started to move to the forefront of the way Washington views its ties with the Soviet Union and are increasingly dominating the Soviet-American relationship.
One clear sign of that, they said, was the recent appointment of Edward Hewett, an expert on the Soviet economy, as the chief Soviet adviser on the staff of the National Security Council. Mr. Hewett's predecessor, Condoleezza Rice, was a specialist in arms control, the Soviet military and Kremlinology.
But one official said the more traditional Soviet-American problems had not disappeared and that was one reason that Mr. Bush was still wary of becoming more deeply engaged with the Soviet Union economically.
"If arms control doesn't work out, then the whole relationship could be dominated by that issue once again and there won't be any question of Congress approving moves to give more financial aid to the Soviet Union," an official said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Cummins Lowers Dividend 50

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ind., May 21

 BODY:
The Cummins Engine Company, suffering under continued losses and a bleak outlook for North American heavy-duty truck sales, said today that it was sharply cutting its quarterly dividend from 55 cents a share, to 5 cents.
The Columbus-based diesel engine maker, which had maintained its dividends in the face of a string of operating losses, also said it expected to post a loss for the second quarter that would be less than its $34.3 million first-quarter loss. Cummins had a $119 million loss for the fourth quarter of 1990. 
 Henry B. Schacht, chairman of Cummins, said the company's board had delayed cutting the dividend until a special meeting on Monday because it was hoping to get a clearer picture on when its business might improve.
"We see nothing to indicate that a recovery is in sight," Mr. Schacht said. "As a result, the board determined that it would be prudent to reduce the dividend to a level more consistent with existing business conditions."
Cummins said last month that the market for North American heavy-duty trucks had declined 45 percent over the last two years and that it expected the market to drop more during the current quarter.
"It continues to be our objective to move to break-even levels later in the year," Mr. Schacht said. "At the same time, continued economic uncertainty and soft demand for the company's heavy-duty truck engines make it difficult to forecast financial results."
The 5-cent dividend is payable June 14 to stockholders of record on May 31. Cummins stock lost $1.625 a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $36.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Many Readers, Few Ads for Bauer

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
As the recession in the magazine industry worsens, the battle to grab readers at supermarket checkout counters has intensified. And no company has been more aggressive at expanding its American operations than the German publisher of Woman's World and First for Women.
Both magazines have attracted millions of readers but the Bauer Publishing Group has yet to woo the advertisers it needs to make a profit. 
 Bauer, based in Hamburg, Germany, is one of Europe's largest magazine publishers, with titles like TV Horen und Sehen and Auf Einen Blick, which are family and women's magazines combined with TV guides. Its troubles in the United States, American magazine executives say, illustrate how a foreign company, in a rush to become global, refused to take the time to learn all the rules of the American market -- and suffered financially as a result.
 
Acknowledges Mistakes
 They assert that Bauer disregarded the way Americans do business. Bauer executives acknowledge the company's troubles but attribute them to naivete rather than arrogance and maintain that its problems are behind them. In fact, the first magazine it started in the United States, Woman's World, has been a success without much advertising.
Two years ago, Bauer started the supermarket weekly First for Women, filled with tips on dieting, money management, shopping and housework aimed at women in their early 30's. First for Women competes almost directly with Woman's Day, a Hachette publication, and Family Circle, published by The New York Times Company.
Bauer, which is privately held, does not disclose financial data, but rivals estimate that the company spent $75 million to get First for Women to the American shopping public. Hubert Bohle, a Bauer executive vice president, said the figure was much too high but would not be specific.
First for Women has built a circulation of 2.6 million, according to the most recent audit statements, and Mr. Bohle called it "the only new magazine launch that has been as successful as People," which was an instant hit with readers and advertisers.
That claim might startle almost any American magazine publisher accustomed to the difficulties of attracting regular readers. While First for Women's circulation is impressive, its early moves, particularly in setting ad rates, hurt ad sales and undermined its credibility with some executives at major ad agencies.
As a result, First for Women is probably a big money loser, though Bauer executives refuse to talk about that. Several publishing executives said Bauer might have lost $60 million or more since it was begun. After some missteps, the company seems to be adjusting to the American way of courting advertisers. But it still has a long way to go. Even if First for Women makes it, the question is how much more money it will lose.
Part of the problem may have been that Bauer was not well versed in how to approach American advertisers.
"In Germany we run mass circulation magazines that depend on circulation much more than advertising," Mr. Bohle said in an interview. "Perhaps we were naive about the advertising side of the business. The American publisher defines a target group in the way the advertiser sees it. He would try via subscriptions to obtain those readers to sell to advertisers."
 
'Start With the Readers'
 In Germany, "We start with the readers," he continued. "We say: 'We have a concept. How many readers are there for that concept?' "
Woman's World, Bauer's first American publication, worked fine using that approach. A weekly tabloid with a circulation of 1.5 million readers, it is now believed to produce operating profits of about $15 million annually.
It takes in a maximum of five pages of advertising an issue, but, like Bauer's German publications, sales of individual copies at $1.10 each account for most of the profit. Moreover, the product is different. Instead of the magazine format of its competitors, Woman's World mixes entertainment and advice for women, especially housewives, in its tabloid form.
But First for Women, which is edited by Jackie Highe, was hardly a new idea. Woman's Day, with a circulation of 4.8 million and Family Circle, with 5.4 million, have long since built strong followings at the checkout counter. All three are service publications aimed at helping a woman with home and family.
 
Paid for Rack Space
 Bauer used its financial muscle for some big moves to insure that First for Women reached its intended target. The company paid millions for supermarket rack space, raising the cost of rack space for the whole industry. Then it offered eight million copies of the inaugural issue at 25 cents each to get shoppers to try the magazine.
The start-up was accompanied by an extensive promotional advertising campaign, estimated at $20 million. For the second issue, the magazine raised its price to $1 and the magazine sold about four million copies.
Bauer, which had initially guaranteed advertisers that First for Women would deliver two million readers, was so encouraged by early sales that it suddenly raised that guarantee to four million.
But sales dropped to 2.7 million copies, below the company's expectations. Even at the end of 1990, it was charging advertisers for a circulation of three million when actually its circulation was 2.6 million. It has since lowered its rate base and Bauer soon realized it needed more emphasis on advertising to make money from the new magazine.
 
Hired British Company
 "They are charging $1.50 a copy," said one magazine executive of First for Women. "They keep about 90 cents of that. If they sell 2.6 million copies, that is $2.3 million at the newstands."
And every company prints more copies than it sells. First for Women may print 3.4 million copies. At 50 cents a copy, that is $1.7 million. Then there are charges for rack space, wholesalers and other fees. Clearly circulation revenue is not enough.
To increase advertising pages, Bauer hired a British company, the Magazine Consultancy, which had represented Bauer in Britain. The Consultancy's first attempt to sell advertising here was a disaster, the company acknowledged. Its major mistake was to offer advertising agencies a discount available to all clients.
"Naturally, large advertisers were furious that the smaller ones were getting the same benefits," said an agency executive, who asked not to be named. "
 
Worked Well in London
 Craig Vander Ploeg, vice president of the Consultancy, who is in charge of advertising sales for Bauer, acknowledged that the plan was a poor one and had to be scrapped very quickly. "Our London office uses that strategy and it works very well there," he said. "But it didn't work here at all."
Mr. Vander Ploeg is using more traditional sales strategies now, offering volume discounts and other incentives.
What First for Women does have in its favor is that it delivers the younger readers many advertisers desire, because their buying patterns are not yet set. Family Circle and Woman's Day do not attract that market as successfully. But even after Bauer changed its advertising sales approach, advertising has been slow to follow.
The most recent issue carried 37.5 pages of advertising, down from 38 pages in the comparable issue a year ago. But Mr. Bohle said that many of the 1990 pages were part of deals given to advertisers, and on a dollar basis the company was getting more money a page this year.
The company is planning to start a third magazine for the American checkout counter sometime in the next two years, though it is typically secretive about what kind of publication it will be.

HEADLINE: Health Crisis Said to Grip Iraq In Wake of War's Destruction

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Public health in Iraq is rapidly deteriorating under the strain of postwar epidemics, power disruptions, shortages of doctors, nurses and medicines and the closing of many overloaded hospitals and clinics, according to a Harvard University medical team that conducted a survey in major cities this month.
"Throughout Iraq gastroenteritis, cholera and typhoid are now epidemic," the study said. "Contrary to the statement of both the Iraqi Government and Western journalists that the health situation is stable and will continue to improve, the study team finds that the state of medical care is desperate and -- unless conditions change substantially -- will continue to deteriorate in every region and at nearly every provider level."
 
Rise in Infectious Disease
 Child mortality soared in the first four months of the year, the study said. It calculated that 55,000 more children died than in the comparable period the previous year. 
 While the dean of the Harvard School of Public Health, Dr. Harvey V. Fineberg, who was not a member of the study team but reviewed its findings, said in an interview that he could not confirm mortality projections, because "specific figures are speculative," the medical team concluded that the child mortality figure was likely to increase to at least 170,000 additional deaths by the end of the year. The figures were based on data collected in four major Iraqi hospitals.
But Dr. Fineberg added that "in the aftermath of the disruption of war, the conditions have fostered an increase in epidemic infectious disease and other threats to health that have substantially increased the loss of life."
"My reading of the evidence," he continued, "is that there will be a substantial increase in infant mortality in Iraq, and the severity of the conditions speaks to a real crisis."
The "main message" of the study, Dr. Fineberg said, "is that the consequences of war are not fully realized during the time of active conflict, and the aftermath carries with it a very real burden of death and disability."
The medical team's report raises new questions about whether the Bush Administration's postwar strategy of continued economic sanctions against Iraq will lead to rising mortality rates in the nation of 18 million, where health problems, disease and malnutrition are reported to be growing out of control.
Senior Bush Administration officials have said in the past that they will not allow Iraqi civilians to starve as Washington calibrates a postwar pressure campaign to keep tight trade sanctions on Iraq to force President Saddam Hussein from power. But the Harvard study suggests that a combination of disease, food shortages and high prices is already causing thousands of deaths.
The 10-member Harvard team of doctors, lawyers and public health specialists was sponsored by the MacArthur Foundation and seven other private groups.
Their report, which was distributed to news organizations this week, said there was a direct correlation between the allied decision to bomb most of Iraq's electrical generating plants and the subsequent breakdown in public health and medical care.
"Without electricity," the report said, "hospitals cannot function, perishable medicines spoil, water cannot be purified and raw sewage cannot be processed."
By all indications, Bush Administration officials did not foresee that their bombing strategy would lead to a public health crisis among Iraqi civilians. In a briefing on Jan. 30, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander in the Persian Gulf, said: "We never had any intention of destroying 100 percent of all the Iraqi electrical power. Because of our interest in making sure that civilians did not suffer unduly, we felt that we have to leave some of the electrical power in effect."
The new findings call into question the ability of the military and its targeting analysts to make judgments about how a percentage reduction of electrical generating capacity will affect a civilian population.
The Harvard team conducted the most thorough survey to date of bomb damage to power plants in Iraq and found that in the first days of the war, 13 of Iraq's 20 generating plants were incapacitated or destroyed and by the end of the fighting, Iraq was generating only 4 percent of its prewar capacity.
Nearly three months later, the country's electrical output still is barely 22 percent of the prewar level, and without a lifting of the trade sanctions, electrical output is not expect to grow further, thus complicating the public health situation with the approach of searing summer heat.
The team members said they could move freely and were barred only from one infectious disease hospital where they suspected Iraqi officials were diverting many cholera cases in an effort to cover up their loss of control over the health crisis.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Spotlight Is on Software at Show

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 21

 BODY:
With manufacturers of small computers continuing to report bad news this week, software publishers took the spotlight here as the personal computer industry convened for the spring version of the semiannual computer show, Comdex.
Although the number of exhibitors is the same as last year, there are 70 percent more software publishers among the 900 computer companies showing wares to 60,000 people at the four-day show ending on Thursday. 
 Several leading personal computer companies that had skipped this convention in previous years -- I.B.M., Microsoft and Lotus Development -- returned with business software products designed to take advantage of faster, more powerful hardware.
On Monday, Microsoft introduced a new version of its Basic computer language designed to exploit its graphical user interface, Windows. A separate section of Comdex was opened this year for some 200 companies offering software that operates with Windows.
"For the last few years, the hardware -- the computers, printers, networks -- have had the focus of this show," said Cheryl C. Currid, a former computer executive at the Coca-Cola Company who now has her own consulting firm.
"The software companies are playing leapfrog now that they've had the chance to exploit the new hardware," she said. "The software people are finally getting a chance to play."
Hardware makers, by contrast, were taking a beating. On Monday, Apple Computer announced a restructuring that the company said would result in a 10 percent staff reduction. Last week, Compaq Computer said second-quarter earnings would be about 25 cents a share, down from $1.18 a share a year earlier, and the stock plunged.
"There are still going to be innovations in hardware, but the innovations which drive the industry aren't going to be merely in bigger, faster computers," said Gene R. Talsky, president of Promark, a Huntington Beach, Calif., computer consulting service. "Most people who own personal computers today can't take full advantage of them."
Sheldon Adelson, chairman of the Interface Group, the show's sponsor, said: "It's always been difficult for software to keep up with the changes in hardware. Now that they've caught up, the mission is to rise above the clutter of their competitors. That's what is bringing them here."
Mr. Adelson noted that there were 5 percent fewer manufacturers of printers and other computer peripheral products at the show. There have been similar reductions in the number of computer makers and suppliers of computer services. But software publishers, who accounted for 18 percent of the computer vendors at the 1990 show, account for 31 percent of all products this year.
Nevertheless, Mr. Adelson said the pessimism of the financial community about computer makers was unwarranted. "No one has ever said we would see negative growth in the computer industry," he said. "Even when there was a recession in the computer market in 1985-86, it only meant that growth dropped from 50 percent per year to 20 percent."
Computer makers were cheered by news today that the East European computer market might expand more rapidly than first thought. During a session focusing on European trade, Andrzej Dabkowski, managing director of a Polish trading company, said privatization of Eastern European companies was moving more quickly than had been expected.
"Six months ago, I was saying that probably 50 companies a month would go private in Poland," he said. "Today, it's closer to 200 per month. When companies adopt Western-style financial structures, they need Western computers and software to make it work."

HEADLINE: Business Tax Breaks Are Hurting Schools, Educators Complain

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Many American companies in recent years have made a crusade of trying to rescue the nation's deteriorating public schools, casting themselves as white knights whose donations help the cause.
But at the same time, many of these companies are extracting as many sizable tax breaks as they can from their communities, cutting off money needed to finance public education. 
 Now educators are fighting back, trying to make businesses pay their full share of taxes. In Washington State, corporate loopholes were a major issues, along with pay increases and benefits, in a statewide teachers' strike this spring. In Kansas, Texas, Minnesota, Ohio and other states, legislation and lawsuits are being used to try to eliminate corporate tax exemptions.
"Companies are caught in a contradictory situation," said Michael W. Apple, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin at Madison who wrote several books on the financing of public education. "They want more spent on education but preferring that it not come out of their own pockets."
Tax exemptions take many forms, but the most common concession reduces or eliminates property taxes for long periods, and in most areas the bulk of property tax revenue goes to support public schools. Such concessions must end, educators say, not only because the recession is squeezing public budgets, but also because the extra revenue is needed to pay for the many improvements mandated by school reform legislation. Such measures are often backed by businesses.
But many municipalities say that ending corporate tax exemptions will provoke businesses to relocate, leaving the public treasuries even poorer.
For their part, businesses defend the exemptions as necessary for many reasons, including remaining competitive with foreign firms. "It would be ridiculous to expect companies not to negotiate for exemptions," said William H. Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business. "Economic development has always been a quid pro quo. Cities want these developments."
 
Experiences in States
 While there are no reliable national statistics on corporate contributions to public schools or corporate tax breaks, a survey of several school systems and states suggest that educators may have a point.
*In Corpus Christi, Tex., the local school system estimated it received $250,000 in the last school year from local companies in money, equipment and donated time from employees, but said it also lost $900,000 in tax revenue for the district because of exemptions.
*The Wichita, Kan., public schools said local businesses this school year contributed $1.1 million in a variety of areas. But the district also said that businesses did not pay $1.6 million in school taxes because of concessions.
*In Florida, $32 million has been given to public education this school year, the state Department of Education said. But that amount is dwarfed by roughly $500 million in tax concessions this year, including breaks on sales taxes, machinery and fuel costs, according to an analysis by the state Department of Revenue.
 
Issue Under Scrutiny
 The issue has so concerned the National Governors' Association that it plans an October meeting on the matter, and the National Association of School Boards two months ago formed a committee to investigate the effects of corporate exemptions on public school finances.
For their part, businesses defend their exemptions as necessary to remain competitive, and maintain that their contributions are helpful to the national effort to improve schools.
But some educators contend that such contributions are usually targeted for a specific program and are not entirely altruistic.
"They can turn contributions off and on and use it to leverage things they want done," said Chris Pipho, director of state relations for the Education Commission of the States, a Denver research and policy organization.
Although tax breaks are not new, their use has drastically grown over the last two decades, as more states, counties and cities compete for businesses. They assemble packages that include the elimination or reduction of sales or property taxes or both, exemptions on new equipment, tax breaks for training new employees and reductions on taxes for school improvements. Some states, like Florida, even award companies tax breaks for fuel use.
"Companies are saying, 'Look, this is a competition we basically didn't create,' " said Jay Kayne, director of policy studies for the National Governors' Association. "In a sense they are right."
 
Accountability and Revenue
 Nonetheless, educators assert that if they are to be held more accountable for school performance, then they need a stronger revenue base to pay for things like improved academic programs, building new schools or replacing aging buildings. A lawsuit filed in January by the Cleveland Public Schools helps illustrate the growing national debate.
The complaint filed in state court maintains that the Cleveland Public Schools system, currently facing a $34 million deficit for the 1991-92 school year, has been significantly hurt by the tax breaks granted to businesses and others in the name of economic development.
In one example cited by Timothy J. Armstrong, a Cleveland lawyer representing the school system, the city's new Society Center, a multiuse development that includes a hotel and a bank, would pay a 2.1 percent tax rate, or $8 million, on the development's $400 million value. But Mr. Armstrong said the entire $8 million in tax proceeds was abated, or eliminated, by the city as an incentive for the developer. Of that $8 million, 60 percent would have gone to the school system, he said.
"Our City Council hasn't seen a tax abatement that it didn't like," said Mr. Armstrong, adding that school systems in the state are routinely excluded from participating in city or county decisions on tax exemptions for economic development.
But the city responded that the abatement was necessary to get the hotel built. Cleveland does not have enough hotels for conventions, a shortage that has caused the city to lose several gatherings in the past, said Craig S. Miller, the city's law director. He said the shrinking pool of Federal money for city development projects had forced a heavier reliance by Cleveland, as well as other cities, on tax concessions to prod development.
The issue of corporate exemptions reached such a boil two months ago in Washington State that teachers included a protest against corporate tax breaks in the list of grievances when they walked off their jobs.
Legislation proposed by the Washington Education Association, the teachers' union and Washington Citizen Action, a citizens' consumer group, would end several business exemptions and would raise more than $700 million over two years for education spending.
"Businesses are demanding everything from the system, but they are not willing to put anything back in," said Karin Goodro, a fifth-grade teacher in Tacoma who walked off her job.
The Boeing Company took the brunt of the criticism because it is the state's largest employer and because of the tax concessions it receives. Although the company has said that it does not maintain records on the extent of its sales tax exemption, the Washington Citizen Action group analyzed state Department of Revenue records filed by the company and asserted that in the 1989-1991 period the company was exempted from more than $900 million in sales taxes on its products, including commercial and military aircraft.
 
Boeing Response to Critics
 Boeing defended its contributions and exemptions, and contended that without accountability in school performance, real improvements would remain elusive.
"First they say, 'Give us more money,' " said Forrest Coffey, corporate vice president for government affairs at Boeing. "Why should I give you more money? What do I get?"
One reason business has come under increasing scrutiny over exemptions is their vocal criticism of schools and their public displays of gift-giving to schools that have soured some educators. Last year, Minnesota closed a loophole through which potential school funds were drained.
Under a widely used state development program, cities were luring companies into blighted areas with low-interest bonds. But the resulting increase in property values and taxes paid only went to pay off the bonds, with no funds going to help schools. In 1988, the last year for which statistics are available, $60 million in potential school funds was lost, said State Representative Ann H. Rest, who successfully sponsored legislation forcing the cities to reimburse school systems for revenue lost as a result of the practice.
"There is a myth that has been perpetrated, and it's a fallout from the Reagan Administration," said Thomas A. Shannon, executive director of the National Association of School Boards. "And that is: 'You can't fix education by throwing money at it.' It's a crock."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Advice to Patriots: Save, Don't Spend

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SUPPOSE there were Americans so patriotic as to decide to ignore their own material well-being and to deploy their money with the sole aim of benefiting the national economy.
Are these self-sacrificing citizens best advised to go out and buy, say, new cars or wardrobes, in hopes that the extra spending will help shorten what has recently been declared the nation's ninth postwar recession? Or, given Alan Greenspan's warning that the country's biggest domestic problem is a lack of savings, is it better to put the money aside, as the increasingly quaint phrase goes, "for a rainy day"? 
 The answer, not unusual in economics, is not clear. It depends on how long the economic patriots stick with their choices and how many others might join them.
It is, however, widely agreed that the long-held Keynesian focus on insuring adequate buying power, thereby stimulating the necessary production, is largely discredited as inflation-prone and thus cannot serve as a policy prescription.
On the other hand, the Ben Franklin assumption that thrift is always a good thing is also erroneous, particularly in a recession when higher savings tends to depress economic activity further. According to a textbook staple known as the paradox of thrift, if too many people try to save more money, the result is likely to be less total savings, not more.
According to "Economics," Paul A. Samuelson's classic text, "the individuals who save cut down on their consumption. They pass on less purchasing power than before; therefore, someone else's income is reduced, since one person's outgo is another person's income."
So what should the patriot do? An informal sampling of economists found broad support for the idea that virtue -- the savings paradox notwithstanding -- lies in socking the money away rather than visiting car dealers or clothing stores.
"I think he should save -- invest in an active way," said Herbert Stein, a longtime Washington policy maker. Buy stocks, bonds, even a house "to induce a larger flow of investments for the future," he added.
Charls E. Walker, a lobbyist and sometime academic as well as a former Treasury official, agreed. "I would pick out a strongly investing corporation and buy stock in it," he said. Newly issued stock would be best because the company would probably use the capital to expand its -- and the nation's -- productive base.
This recommendation implies not only considerable pain for retailers and producers of consumer goods but also a longer and more severe recession than otherwise. But the potential benefits over time -- and the savings versus spending issue is best viewed as a trade-off between the short term and the long term -- are immense if the nation can forgo some current consumption and shift these resources into investment.
"Inadequate domestic savings is impairing our economic prospects for the long run," Mr. Greenspan told a Senate panel considering a new type of individual retirement account last week. "By choosing to consume more now and to save less, we are limiting our ability to expand and upgrade our stock of capital." This, together with technology and the labor force, ultimately determines a country's standard of living, he added.
Compared with almost any other developed country -- and even with a considerable chunk of America's history -- today's 4 1/2 percent rate of personal savings is puny. The overall savings rate is even less because the Federal and other governments, running deficits, are "dissavers."
Policy makers regularly despair of the world's richest country needing to import huge amounts of capital but they see little hope of inducing Americans to save more. One reason for low savings, of course, is a relatively generous Social Security system for retirement and disability. Without it people would no doubt take greater financial precautions.
There is no proof, in fact, that making contributions to I.R.A.'s fully deductible for half the 1980's raised savings rates at all. Perhaps they induced people only to shift money from one account to another. It is known, however, that savings are notoriously unresponsive to interest rates. Income counts for much more.
Alan C. Lerner, an analyst for the Bankers Trust Company, suggests a middle ground for economic patriots: Buy a car now but promise to save increasing amounts as business activity revives.
Not everyone will be able, financially or psychologically, to become such a contracyclical economic force. But most people could help the country by saving more.

HEADLINE: Trenton Treasurer Finds Bigger Budget Shortfall

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 21

 BODY:
Blaming a weak economy, the State Treasurer said today that New Jersey was facing an additional budget shortfall of $768 million for the fiscal year that begins July 1.
The Treasurer, Douglas C. Berman, said that disappointing revenues from sales, income and other taxes would make it more difficult than expected to balance the $14.3 billion budget for the next fiscal year that Gov. Jim Florio had proposed in January. 
 In addition, Mr. Berman said the falloff in tax revenues is expected to enlarge the shortfall for the current fiscal year to $773 million from the $600 million estimated by the Governor in January.
"Our problems are real but manageable," Mr. Berman told a joint meeting of the Assembly and Senate finance committees. "We will eliminate our shortfall without raising taxes or reducing the property tax relief we promised New Jersey residents last year."
 
Harsh Choice for Unions
 Although the growing budget gap here is considerably smaller than those facing New York City, New York State or Connecticut, Mr. Florio is more limited in his options than leaders in other states. After angering the public with $2.8 billion in new taxes last year, Mr. Florio has promised to balance the budget, as required by the State Constitution, without raising more taxes.
In a related move, the Florio administration this week presented unions representing state workers with a harsh choice: either agree to take $40 million worth of unpaid furloughs starting July 1 or face up to 10,000 layoffs.
The union representing the largest number of the state's 70,000 employees, the Communication Workers of America, is asking its members this week to vote to authorize a strike, which the union threatens to use unless the Florio administration becomes more conciliatory.
The estimate of exactly how much money the state needs to have a balanced budget is, in fact, a highly political decision that depends on what revenues are counted and what are not, and which accounting techniques an official decides to use.
In his testimony today, Mr. Berman assumed the state would realize close to $800 million in savings and new revenues as a result of two strategies that Mr. Florio proposed in his budget announcement in January.
 
$181 Million Drop in Revenue
 At that time Mr. Florio suggested that the state raise $400 million by selling a public highway to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. He also said the state would require public employee unions to give up $370 million in raises and benefits already agreed to in current contracts. If either of those strategies fails, the state's shortfall would probably top $1 billion.
In addition, Mr. Berman estimated that falloffs in tax revenues had created an additional shortfall for the current fiscal year of $181 milllion. But he said that gap could be addressed by a number of measures, including the current hiring freeze, changing the date of state contributions to a police and firemen's fund, and using $43 million from a capital expense account for operating expenses.
But Republican legislators today questioned whether the Florio administration's estimates were accurate and accused Mr. Berman and his staff of incompetence in making fiscal projections.
"Why not submit a balanced budget?" Assemblyman C. Richard Kamin, a Republican from Franklin Lakes, asked Mr. Berman. "We are going through the same scenario again of overstating revenues."
Another Republican, Senator Henry P. McNamara of Franklin Lakes, criticized Mr. Berman for taking money from funds dedicated to purposes like hazardous waste cleanups and capital expansion to pay for the state's operating expenses.

HEADLINE: Yields Fall For C.D.'s

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts, down for the last three months, fell again for the one-week period ended yesterday.
Dennis R. Kosovac, a senior vice president in the consumer banking group of Chemical Bank, said that many depositors had been buying certificates with maturities as long as 60 months whose yields are about 300 basis points higher than the very-liquid savings, or passbook, rates. He said rational depositors were taking some cash and giving up a little liquidity for the higher yields, or stacking accounts to take advantage of higher-tier yields. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 He expects the Fed may still lower rates at least a couple of times more to help the economy, but the lower short-term rates will have an impact on bank rates, he added.
 
Treasury Weekly Auction
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction Monday, the average discount rates were only slightly different from a week ago, but still at their lowest levels in three years. The results of these bill auctions often indicate what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The three-month bill was unchanged at 5.50 percent for the third consecutive week, while the six-month bill increased a few basis points, to 5.66 percent.
The largest yield changes in the New York area this week were recorded at the Howard Savings Bank in New Jersey, which cut 52 basis points off its money market account, to 5.13 percent. Connecticut Bank and Trust reduced the yield on its three-month certificate by 16 basis points, to 6 percent, while Marine Midland Bank reduced its six-month certificate by 22 basis points, to 5.65 percent.
Commercial banks cut back deposit yields only slightly less than savings institutions. Money market accounts were lowered by an average of 2 basis points, to 5.235 percent, while three-month certificates were lowered by 4 basis points, to 5.62 percent, and six-month certificate were lowered by 5 basis points, to 5.74 percent.
Savings institutions lowered the yield on money market accounts an average of 9 basis points, to 5.63 percent, while cutting 4 basis points off the yield on a three-month certificate, to 5.95 percent. The average cut on a six-month certificate yield was 6 basis points, to 6.17 percent.

HEADLINE: History Suggests Bush's Popularity Will Ebb

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
President Bush's high approval ratings, increased by the Persian Gulf war, are not likely to last for long, if the experiences of his nine immediate predecessors are a reliable guide, according to a new study by researchers at the Gallup Organization.
Mr. Bush's historic peak of 89 percent approval in a Gallup poll in early March, just after the fighting ended in the gulf region, has already begun to fade, standing at 77 percent in the latest Gallup poll. Taken by telephone with 1,002 adults nationwide from May 16 to 19, the poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. 
 According to the new Gallup historical study, Mr. Bush's rating can be expected to continue to decline over the next several months until it reverts to the mid-60 percent range, his level before the gulf crisis began.
Still, Mr. Bush's surge in popularity in mid-January, when the air war began, was one of the largest rises in the 50-year history of polling and has already lasted longer than the average rise experienced by his nine predecessors, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Ronald Reagan.
 
Five Decades of Polling
 In the new study, " 'Rally Events' and Presidential Approval," Larry Hugick, vice president of the Gallup Organization, and Alec M. Gallup, co-chairman, analyzed hundreds of Gallup polls from more than five decades -- beginning in 1938 during Roosevelt's second term -- to measure the impact of international crises, diplomatic events and military operations on Presidential popularity.
Past studies, like the book "War, Presidents and Public Opinion" (John Wiley & Sons; 1973), by John Mueller of the University of Rochester, have identified the tendency of the public to rally round their flag, troops and President during many foreign crises. Though the magnitude of such surges have been documented, the new study is the first to look closely at their duration, and it finds they do not last long.
The findings, reported at the annual meeting of the American Association for Public Opinion Research that ended on Sunday in Phoenix, showed that each of the last 10 Presidents experienced at least one such rally of opinion over a foreign event. The 42 rallies studied have occurred on average every 1.2 years.
Increases in support for previous Presidents from these events averaged eight percentage points. The smallest examined by the researchers was three percentage points, while the largest was 19 percentage points.
 
10 Weeks of Higher Favor
 Mr. Bush's 18-percentage-point surge, registered in mid-January as the air war on Iraq began, was one of the three largest rises in Presidential popularity ever recorded by Gallup. Jimmy Carter saw a 19-percentage-point increase when American hostages were seized in Iran in November 1979, and Richard M. Nixon saw a 16-percentage point lift at the time of the Vietnam peace agreements in January 1973.
Rallies in support for previous Presidents lasted an average of 10 weeks. The briefest were over in a week, while the longest disappeared after about seven months. Mr. Bush's surge has persisted for four months, well beyond the average.
 
Holding Goodwill Till '92
 The most long-lived increases in public favor were the 30 weeks for Franklin D. Roosevelt after Pearl Harbor in 1941, the 31 weeks for John F. Kennedy after the 1962 Cuban missile crisis and the 30 weeks for Jimmy Carter after the American hostages were seized in Iran in 1979.
Mr. Hugick and Mr. Gallup concluded: "Based on our analysis of rally events throughout polling history, the effects of the Persian Gulf war on George Bush's approval seem likely to be sustained for several more months. It is highly unlikely, however, that the approval boost resulting from the gulf war will carry over into election year 1992."
But some other analysts believe Mr. Bush's increase in favor from the gulf war may prove more long-lived, similar to that resulting from the 1982 Falklands war. "In the British General Election of 1983, a year after the Falklands war, British voters rewarded its successful outcome" by returning the incumbent party, said Helmut Norpoth, professor of political science at the State University of New York, Stony Brook.
George C. Edwards 3d, director of the Center for Presidential Studies at Texas A&M University, said: "The key to the whole thing is what topics are salient in 1992. The gulf victory may be sustained by multiple homecomings, but won't remain salient throughout the Presidential campaign. We can't have ticker tape parades forever."

HEADLINE: Hartford Plan Would Raise New Funds The Old Way

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 21

 BODY:
Legislators leading the charge against Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s income tax plan released a package today to resolve the state's fiscal crisis through expanded sales and business taxes, deeper cuts in spending and a system of spending limits written into the State Constitution.
Leaders of both parties expressed confidence that the package would pass, based on headcounts conducted in closed-door meetings this afternoon and evening, and they said they planned to bring it to a vote in the Senate on Thursday as one all-inclusive bill that includes both the tax increases and the long-term spending changes. The House would not get the plan until next week at the earliest. 
 The bill would raise $960 million in new revenue -- putting it in roughly the same orbit as Mr. Weicker's plan as one of the largest one-year tax increases in state history.
But unlike the sharp departure that Mr. Weicker proposed in February, when he urged cutting most state taxes, especially the 8 percent sales tax, and substituting instead a long-avoided tax on wages, the legislative plan would essentially give Connecticut residents more of the same of what they have -- much more.
 
Assortment of New Taxes
 The 8 percent sales tax, already the highest statewide rate in the nation, would be kept at its current rate but expanded to include everything from house and car repairs to newspapers and magazine subscriptions, haircuts, inexpensive clothing and nonpresecription drugs. A new assortment of fees and special taxes would also be introduced, including a mortgage tax on homes costing over $150,000, a 12 percent occupancy tax for people who use campgrounds and a 5.75 percent sales tax on gasoline.
The Weicker administration immediately denounced the plan as laden with gimmicks and short-term solutions that could chase employers from the state and cripple Connecticut's recovery from the recession.
 
Support for General Idea
 A critique of the plan issued by the state's Office of Policy and Management also said that lawmakers had included "make-believe cuts" in spending that would give Connecticut a shortfall of $896 million for the year that begins on July 1. If the state took no action at all, it would face a projected shortfall of more than $2.7 billion over the next 13 months in a preliminary budget of $8.6 billion.
The legislative plan, which was drafted by a coalition led by Republicans in both chambers of the General Assembly and Democrats in the Senate, received increasing support over the last week from many lawmakers who are opposed to the income tax. But those voices of support had also, until today, been pledged to a fairly general framework of ideas. Lawmakers and special interest groups who support Mr. Weicker's budget package said the hard reality of what is involved in avoiding an income tax could jar some people into rethinking their positions. The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, declined to speculate on the alternative plan's chances, though he said earlier this week that "the votes just aren't there" for an income tax in either chamber. Mr. Balducci has said he supports the concept of an income tax but refused to say how he would vote on the alternative plan.
The alternative plan includes a projected $842 million in revenue from new taxes for the general fund -- led by the sales tax changes -- and $118 million in new taxes for the transportation fund, led by raising the per-gallon tax on gasoline to 25 cents from 23 and an increase in the annual motor vehicle registration fee to $90 from $62.
The 2-cent gasoline tax increase would be in addition to the 5.75 percent gasoline sales for the general fund.
Coalition leaders, who presented the plan to other legislators in closed meetings this afternoon and into the evening, framed their package as essentially a spending control plan, according to budget documents obtained from lawmakers.
The centerpiece would be a cap on state spending, written into the State Constitution, which would prohibit growth in the general fund from exceeding the rate of growth in personal income or inflation. A constitutional amendment would require voter approval and passage by a 75 percent majority in both the House and Senate.
The plan would also require the governor to present a two-year spending plan to try to control spending growth and would create a nonpartisan revenue forecasting board composed of budget officials from the administration and the legislature.
"For too long, budgets have been approved with the state's immediate future in mind, containing no vision toward years to come," the budget document proclaims. "That nightmare is now over."
Income-tax advocates charged instead that the plan would bring new nightmares of its own.
"This plan is bad for business, bad for consumers, bad for the elderly, and bad for Connecticut's poor, working- and middle-class families," said Ethan Rome, political director of the Connecticut Citizen Action Group, a liberal lobbying group.
Mr. Weicker's supporters might rally around the proposal's approach to business taxes. Mr. Weicker proposed reducing the corporate profits tax to 11.5 percent from 13.8 percent and reducing the sales tax -- about 40 percent of which is paid by business -- to 4.25 percent. The legislative plan would keep the corporate tax structure intact and would raise $66 million in additional revenue by applying the tax more broadly.
