HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Caterpillar Sees Bleaker Outlook

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., May 21

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. warned investors that it could lose money for a second consecutive quarter because the weak world economy had depressed sales. The maker of construction equipment lost $32 million in the first quarter, and it has revised its earnings outlook downward twice in two months.
"This doesn't say we definitely will have a loss," said a spokesman, Dick Stober. "It just means we've seen enough weakness in sales and felt we need to get out a revised outlook statement." The company said it did not have immediate plans for layoffs.

HEADLINE: REVIEW/FILM;
Where the Streets Are Mean and People Are Even Meaner

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Matty Rich's "Straight Out of Brooklyn" portrays the downfall of a black working-class family from the Red Hook section of Brooklyn in a style that used to be called kitchen-sink realism. At times gawky and plodding, the film, which represents the producing, directing and screen writing debut of the 19-year-old Mr. Rich, also has an affecting earnestness as it explores the social and economic pressures that drive the Browns, a family of four, to self-destruct.
Ray Brown (George T. Odom), the head of the household, is an embittered gas station attendant heading into middle age. He despairs of ever doing better. Although he loves his family, his passion curdles into violence when he drinks. He stormsthrough the family's tidy little apartment, beating up his wife, Frankie (Ann D. Sanders), smashing dishes and angrily soliloquizing to an invisible white oppressor. 
 Frankie, who works part time as a cleaning woman, accepts his beatings with a remarkable equanimity. Even when unable to find employment because of the bruises and welts on her face, she refuses to utter a word of criticism about her husband.
Quivering in their beds during these drunken rages are the couple's two adolescent children, Dennis (Lawrence Gilliard Jr.) and his younger sister, Carolyn (Barbara Sanon). Ray's violence stimulates fantasies of patricide in the young man, who longs to escape from the neighborhood and live in Manhattan with his girlfriend, Shirley (Reana E. Drummond).
Determined to make some quick money, the son engages his two best friends, Larry (Mr. Rich) and Kevin (Mark Malone), in a scheme to rob a low-level neighborhood drug dealer. The robbery has repercussions that go far beyond anything the young men could have imagined.
"Straight Out of Brooklyn," which opens today at the Plaza and Village East Cinemas, has a contemporary setting, but the literalness of its dialogue and its careful cinematography give it the feeling of a 1950's problem play adapted for the screen and moved up to the present. It is the kind of film in which a conversation about working-class expectations and the American dream takes place on a rooftop with the Statue of Liberty shown plainly in the background.
The Browns are portrayed as decent people who are stretched to the breaking point by forces outside their control. But beyond being sympathetic victims of hard times, racism and the plagues of inner-city life, their characters remain unclear.
Ray is the most fully drawn, but even he is defined almost entirely by his rage. Frankie is the sort of long-suffering martyr and fortress of goodness satirized in the playwright George C. Wolfe's sketch "The Last Mama-on-the-Couch Play" from "The Colored Museum." The two children are effervescent but vague.
But if the situation is familiar almost to the point of cliche, Mr. Rich is able to squeeze some emotional juice from it. At moments, Mr. Odom's performance assumes a towering intensity. The late-night speeches he delivers to a blank wall about racism and oppression may have a clunky oratorical ring, but the actor infuses them with an angry passion that stirs the heart. Ms. Sanders's Frankie, who seems poised on the brink of tears most of the time, is entirely sympathetic. Mr. Gilliard's Dennis seems a bit too bland and callow for an inner-city youth about to pull his first robbery, but the scenes in which he goofs around with his pals have a engaging, easygoing energy. In a movie that primarily deals with society's rebuke to black male self-esteem, the daughter, Carolyn, is a strictly marginal figure.
"Straight Out of Brooklyn" is a promising film-making debut, but it is also an odd one. Where first-time directors tend to explode their feelings onto the screen nowadays, Mr. Rich's film echoes the formal, socially responsible dramas from an earlier and more emotionally temperate era of American film making.
"Straight Out of Brooklyn" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes strong language and some nudity.
 
Straight Out of Brooklyn
 
Written, directed and produced by Matty Rich; director of photography, John Rosnell; edited by Jack Haigis; music by Harold Wheeler; released by the Samuel Goldwyn Company.

HEADLINE: New York Has One True Barbecue And Here Are All Eight of Them

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
FOR those who live by barbecue, Kansas City brisket and "burnt ends" sound one siren's call, the ribs and shredded pork of Memphis another. From the pits of Greensboro, N.C., vinegar-basted pork issues a hickory-scented invitation. Lubbock, Tex., where the fuel is mesquite or oak and the meat is brisket of beef, has an allure of a different aroma.
New York City, on the other hand, lacks barbecue mystique. Among connoisseurs, the term "New York barbecue" is more likely to elicit a guffaw than an anticipatory licking of the chops. 
 This lack of respect appalls the maestros of the city's terrace-based grills and sidewalk smokers; it is downright loathsome to the pioneers who have bravely brought a barbecue mosaic to the restaurants in this urban frontier.
Enough, already! A New York barbecue summit was called. Representatives of eight disparate schools of barbecue recently gathered in a midtown apartment to address the politics and public image of their hometown barbecue.
Sylvia Woods, the 65-year-old grande dame of South Carolina-style oven barbecue and doyenne of the Harlem restaurant that bears her given name, delegated her daughter, Bedelia Woods. She arrived wearing a red silk blouse that nicely complemented the sauce on the 20 pounds of ribs she carried.
Rusty Staub, the former New York Met who owns Rusty's on the Upper East Side and Rusty's on Fifth in midtown, represented a Louisiana-style oven barbecue. He wore the sort of chalk-striped gray suit that one sees a lot at Hall of Fame dinners and exuded a pregame "We're gonna win this one, guys," attitude.
Robert Pearson, the owner of Stick to Your Ribs, a restaurant in Stratford, Conn., that caters barbecue in New York, was the Texas-style cool-smoke delegate, and he wore acid-washed jeans with a white cowboy-cut shirt.
Simon Oren, an owner of Brother's Bar-B-Q on Houston Street, was the deputy of a Kentucky-style smoked barbecue and a prototype of downtown fashion.
Martin Yerdon and Eileen Weinberg, the owners of Carolina restaurant in midtown, represented the North Carolina style, though the brisket they brought was a cut of meat more commonly barbecued in Texas. They acknowledged that the meat had been cooked in a closed, rather than open, pit, using post oak and apple wood that are indigenous to New York, rather than the hickory used in the low country. This revelation brought a slight lift of the collective brow, but Mr. Yerdon waved it aside.
"We have to address the issue of modifications and the limits of the urban setting," he said in the tone of a Presidential adviser acquiescing in the full disclosure of classified material. With furrowed brow, the group nodded.
"But look at this," Mr. Yerdon said, waving to the group and toward the platters of barbecue crowding the summit table. "How can anybody say that we can't barbecue! This city has more transplanted sons and daughters of Dixie than the entire city of Atlanta!"
Mr. Oren, who grew up in Israel, shifted slightly in his T-shirt and loose linen jacket. His reaction was mitigated by the arrival of Yon Suk Choi, who owns the Woo Chon Korean restaurants in Manhattan and Queens and who looked like an exotic travel poster come to life in her Korean ceremonial dress. "Famous Barbecue Beef," she said, offering a platter of her specialty. She also brought an interpreter.
Michael Tong, who owns Shun Lee Palace, Shun Lee West and Shun Lee Cafe, followed. He wore a well-tailored business suit and, although empty-handed, assured the crowd that he would "call and have some barbecue ribs and duck delivered."
"We, uh, have gotten the delivery thing down," he said.
While Mr. Tong called his restaurant, Allan Vernon entered. He wore a blue blazer and a baseball cap that read "Vernon's: Number One Jerk in the U.S.A." and carried 20 pounds of Jamaican barbecue.
The demographics of the assembled delegates were emblematic of a basic pathos of New York barbecue. The city's repertory is so diverse that it lacks a single identifying flavor. Barbecue fanatics tend toward monolithic passions and are therefore confounded by New York. In addition, what one master reverently calls barbecue another calls burned meat. In the past, this has limited conversations between New York barbecue experts. It was no coincidence that the first items on the summit agenda emphasized commonality.
"We all live outside the barbecue belts," Mr. Pearson said. A former hairdresser, the British-born 44-year-old was reborn a " 'cue master" after studying the craft from the Carolinas to Texas.
Like most aficionados, when Mr. Pearson looks at a map, he sees one great barbecue belt that stretches from the Carolinas and the Southeast to Kentucky and Tennessee and features marinated pork cooked slowly in an open pit. The other barbecue belt stretches from Texas and the Southwest through Kansas and most of the Midwest and features beef cooked slowly in an open pit and basted with myriad dry and wet "mops," or tenderizing sauces.
Those two vast barbecue regions are credited with taking "barbacoa," the Spanish barbecue, and turning it into an all-American art form -- and eventually all-American fanaticism. Barbecue freaks won't be swayed by anything other than the precise form they were raised on and resist all attempts at expanding their definition of barbecue.
That is bad news for New Yorkers, who live and 'cue in the epicenter of innovation and cross-cultural culinary exchange. Despite their varying approaches, the delegates felt united.
"I call this barbecue," Mr. Staub said, sinking his teeth into one of the Chinese barbecued ribs that Mr. Tong had supplied. Mr. Tong said his ribs, like Yon Suk Choi's sliced beef, are cooked over a slow fire (or grilled) rather than surrounded by slow smoke (as in traditional barbecuing). Mr. Staub paused, appeared to gulp, and then continued. "Good meat-to-bone ratio," he said approvingly.
Secretly, the traditional camps of American barbecue wouldn't go so far as to use rice wine, hoisin sauce or sesame oil in their sauces, but they have an abiding empathy for nontraditional flavor enhancers. "Traditionally, it was the flavor of your fuel that permeated your 'cue," Mr. Yerdon said. "Not many people in this city are set up to cook a hunk of meat for 12 hours over a load of oak."
The barbecue delegates agreed that open-pit options are limited in New York City, though Mr. Vernon did refer to one particular pothole on Park Avenue South and Mr. Oren nodded enthusiastically. "I could do a whole pig in that one," he said.
Others expounded on their attempts to simulate pit cooking. Mr. Yerdon and Ms. Weinberg began experimenting with barbecue in the winter of 1982, using a grill on the terrace of their East Side apartment. "We had flare-ups and the thing caught on fire so I ended up serving 35 firemen," recalled Mr. Yerdon, who later spent $18,000 to built his first steel and brick smoker at Carolina. "It burned down, too," he said. "I rebuilt in '83."
The other delegates shook their heads sympathetically. "Flare-ups are a real problem," said Mr. Pearson, who places a pan of water on the floor of his smoker-type oven to catch the combustible dripping grease. It's not the fires he minds so much; it's the charring of the meat or -- quelle horreur -- "raising the internal meat temperature above 210 degrees and boiling the juice in the meat." Long, slow, moist heat breaks down the fat and the tough membranes in the inexpensive cuts typically barbecued.
Slow smoking can be simulated in a backyard (or terrace or sidewalk) grill by waiting until the coals turn white, placing the meat on the grill and placing the lid over the grill with the vents open to promote a flow of smoke. The fire should be fed gradually so the cooking temperature never goes above 200 degrees. "Then you just have to allow sufficient time to achieve desired results," Mr. Pearson said. "Say, 15 hours for briskets, 10 hours for pork shoulders, 5 hours for pork ribs, chicken and beef ribs."
"That's about right," said Mr. Oren, who uses electric smokers at Brother's Barbecue. Along with the other 'cue masters, he acknowledged that taking 15 hours to cook a brisket is somewhat at odds with the spirit of a town where that cut of meat is usually cured and called corned beef.
Just as the outside world doesn't understand the effect of New York City on barbecue, the city doesn't fully appreciate what the finer points of the craft require of a New Yorker. In addition to building Rube Goldberg smokers and having the patience to stoke them, skilled labor is a problem. "A good pitman is about as easy to find as an unemployed sheepherder in this town," Mr. Yerdon said.
Which may be why some local 'cue masters turned from the pit to the oven. "My daddy used half a tin drum in the backyard and I get the same result in the oven," said Mr. Staub, who grew up in New Orleans. He said careful marinating and saucing and long slow braising can perform magic on meat, though it is no less time-consuming. Ms. Woods of Sylvia's said the magic is in the marination: "We hire people just to massage the meat every night before we cook it. That's the only way you can get that falling-off-the-bone effect."
"I can get that with peppers, baby," said Mr. Vernon, adjusting the bill of his cap. "The philosophy of jerk is to use your jerk sauce to tenderize the meat and then just add a little smoke at the end," he said, noting that after marination, he oven-braises and finishes his meat, chicken or fish on a low grill.
Both Michael Tong and Yon Suk Choi use similar methods. "We don't have much of a history of open-pit cooking in China," he said. "Waste of fuel," she said through her interpreter. She held one of Mr. Staub's baby back ribs at arm's length and, in an effort to save her costume a splatter, leaned forward for a nibble. "Ummm," she said.
The other delegates followed suit. Flushed with sampling more than 100 pounds of barbecue and comforted by the smoking grill on the terrace near the conference table, they began sharing cooking techniques and pondering the quandary of 'cue. It was a brotherhood of barbecue. A rare moment. The beginning, said each delegate loudly, of building a positive local barbecue image.
Quietly, however, they said other things. "Look at the gristle on his ribs," whispered one. "He uses liquid smoke," hissed another. You can take barbecue out of the country, but you can't take a Hatfield and McCoy tone away from the pursuit of barbecue perfection.
Walking away from the table, two delegates noted that another had not been particularly forthcoming on his cooking technique. "I bet he uses a hair dryer," said one. "Ummm," said the other, wiping his barbecue-slathered hands on his silk ascot. "Gives a good flavor, doesn't it?"
 
FOR THOSE WHO'D RATHER LICK A FINGER THAN LIFT ONE
 FOR those who don't want to spend 15 hours preparing their own, these are some of the best spots for barbecue in the New York region:
BIG WONG, 67 Mott Street, near Canal Street; (212) 964-0540. Chinese ribs and duck.
BROTHER'S BAR-B-Q, 228 Houston Street, near Avenue of the Americas; (212) 727-2775. Smoked pork butt and pork ribs.
CAROLINA, 355 West 46th Street; (212) 245-0058. Smoked brisket and ribs.
COPELAND'S, 547 West 145th Street, near Broadway; (212) 234-2356. Barbecued ribs in a fancy Harlem setting.
HARRY'S TX BARBECUE & AZ GRILL, 934 Hope Street, near Camp Avenue, Stamford, Conn., (203) 348-7427, and 76 River Street, at Hudson Place, Hoboken, N.J.; (201) 420-0304. Ribs, brisket, chicken, sausage and chopped beef.
RUSTY'S, 1271 Third Avenue, at 73d Street; (212) 861-4518. Baby back ribs.
SHUN LEE CAFE, 43 West 65th Street; (212) 595-8895. Chinese ribs and duck.
STICK TO YOUR RIBS, 1785 Stratford Avenue, near Honeyspot Road, Stratford, Conn. (203) 377-1752. Sensational smoky ribs, brisket and chopped chicken.
SYLVIA'S RESTAURANT, 328 Lenox Avenue, near 126th Street; (212) 996-0660. Pork ribs
VERNON'S JERK PARADISE, 254 West 29th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues; (212) 268-7020. Jamaican-style jerked meat, fish and chicken.
 
OF A FIRE IN THE BACKYARD
 FOR most barbecue, a kettle-style grill with a cover is the best model for backyard attempts.
Stack the coals evenly in the bottom of the grill and light them. When the coals are white and powdery, the grill is generally around 200 degrees. At that point, a drip pan can be placed directly on the coals if the recipe calls for one.
Next, place the rack three to four inches from the highest coal and put the meat, chicken or fish directly on it. Cover the grill and open the vents in the cover slightly, to pull the smoke through.
During the cooking, the temperature should never go above 200 degrees; so replenish the coals slowly, adding several new pieces every 45 minutes. Keep a spray bottle of water handy and if there is a flare-up, mist the coals to extinguish it.
 
THE FIRST STEP IS TO KNOW THE SMOKE FROM THE SAUCE

 
Smoky Brisket (Adapted from Martin Yerdon)
 
Total time: 15 hours 30 minutes
 
For the dry mop:
 
 1/2 cup paprika
 2 tablespoons freshly ground black pepper
 3 tablespoons salt
 
For the wet mop:
 
 1 1/2 tablespoons instant coffee
 2/3 cup water
 2 cups ketchup
 3/4 cup Worcestershire sauce
 8 tablespoons butter
 
For the meat:
 
 1 brisket (4 pounds)
 
For the barbecue sauce:
 
 1 medium-size onion, pureed
 1/4 cup olive oil
 1 35-ounce can tomato puree
 2 cups water
 3/4 cup dark-brown sugar
 2 bay leaves
 2 beef bouillon cubes
 3 tablespoons hot sauce
 2 tablespoons chili powder
 1 tablespoon cayenne pepper
 1 tablespoon lemon juice
 3/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1/3 cup cider vinegar.
1. To prepare the dry mop, combine the paprika, pepper and salt in a small bowl. To prepare the wet mop, dissolve the coffee in the water in a medium-size saucepan; then add the ketchup and Worcestershire. Bring to a boil, reduce heat and simmer 20 minutes. Remove from heat and whisk in butter.
2. Rub the dry mop all over the brisket, and set brisket aside.
3. Prepare the grill (one with a cover works best). After the coals turn a powdery gray-red, put a pan of water on top of the coals to catch the grease. Put the brisket on the grill over the water, and cover. Baste brisket with wet mop every half-hour for first 2 hours and once an hour after that. The longer you cook it the better the texture. At Carolina it is cooked for 24 hours; it needs at least 15 hours. Replenish charcoal and water regularly. The brisket is cooked when the meat registers 150 degrees on a meat thermometer.
4. While meat cooks, make the sauce. In a large heavy skillet over medium heat cook onion in olive oil until translucent. Add remaining ingredients except vinegar and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer 20 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in vinegar. When brisket is cooked, slice it thin and serve with sauce.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Spareribs (Adapted from Brother's Bar-B-Q)
 
Total time: 5 1/2 hours, plus 2 hours for marinating
 
For the pig sauce:
 
 1 quart white vinegar
 2 tablespoons crushed red pepper
 2 tablespoons freshly ground black pepper
 2 tablespoons salt
 2 garlic cloves, chopped
 
For the meat:
 
 1 slab, 2 1/2 to 3 pounds, pork spareribs
 
For the bluegrass bourbon sauce:
 
 3/4 cup barbecue sauce
 2 tablespoons marmalade or other fruit preserves
 1 tablespoon bourbon.
1. To prepare the pig sauce, combine all ingredients in a medium-size bowl. Marinate ribs for 2 hours in a shallow glass, ceramic or stainless-steel pan. Remove ribs from sauce and let drain.
2. To prepare the bourbon sauce, mix together the barbecue sauce, marmalade and bourbon in a small bowl.
3. Prepare grill (or ideally a smoker, at 170 degrees). Place spareribs on the rack. Cover and cook 3 to 3 1/2 hours, until tender. Smother with bluegrass bourbon sauce and serve.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Barbecued Chopped Chicken (Adapted from Robert Pearson)
 
Total time: 2 hours
 
For the sauce:
 
 6 tablespoons butter
 6 tablespoons oil
 3 medium-size onions, diced
 Juice and rinds of 1 1/2 lemons
 6 cups ketchup
 1 1/2 cups red-wine vinegar
 9 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce
 3/4 cup brown sugar
 1 1/2 teaspoons cayenne pepper
 2 tablespoons salt
 2 tablespoons dry mustard
 
For the chicken:
 
 5 pounds chicken pieces
 2 1/2 quarts barbecue sauce (see Step 1)
 1 medium-size onion, peeled and quartered
 2 tablespoons corn oil
 1/4 cup cider vinegar
 1 tablespoon salt
 1 tablespoon freshly ground black pepper
 1 tablespoon chili powder.
1. To prepare the sauce, melt the butter with the oil in a straight-side skillet over medium heat. Add onions and cook until lightly browned. Stir in remaining ingredients, including lemon rinds, and simmer 20 minutes. Remove from heat and discard rinds. For a very smooth sauce, puree in blender or food processor.
2. Prepare grill.
3. In a large bowl combine chicken and 1 quart of the barbecue sauce. Rub sauce all over chicken, coating well.
4. Grill 15 minutes on each side. Remove to a platter and set aside until cool enough to handle. Pull chicken from bones in bite-size pieces. Discard bones. (Skin may be saved if you want a very rich sauce. Set it aside.)
5. In a food processor or blender, puree the onion. (If you want to use the chicken skin, puree with the onion.) Warm a large straight-side skillet over medium heat, add the oil, and when hot, add the onion. Cook, stirring frequently, until translucent. Add vinegar, salt, pepper, chili powder and the remaining 1 1/2 quarts of barbecue sauce. Stir well; add the cooked chicken and simmer on low heat 30 minutes.
Yield: 4 to 6 servings.
 
Barbecued Ribs (Adapted from Sylvia's)
 
Total time: 2 hours 15 minutes, plus 8 hours for marinating
 
For the ribs:
 
 1 tablespoon salt
 1 tablespoon freshly ground black pepper
 2 slabs pork spareribs (about 6 pounds)
 1 tablespoon crushed red pepper
 2 cups distilled white vinegar
 
For the sauce:
 
 2 large lemons
 1 rib celery, chopped fine
 1 medium-size green pepper, chopped fine
 1/2 large onion, chopped fine
 1 cup hot sauce, preferably Red Devil
 2 cups tomato puree
 1 1/2 cups sugar.
1. To prepare the ribs, mix salt and black pepper in a small bowl. Rub all over ribs; repeat with red pepper. Place ribs in a baking pan, add vinegar and let sit in refrigerator overnight.
2. Preheat oven to 375 degrees.
3. Roast ribs in oven 1 1/2 hours. Remove from oven, and transfer ribs from roasting pan to a cookie sheet, turning them in the process. Increase oven heat to 400 degrees. Return to oven for 30 minutes more.
4. Meanwhile, make the sauce. Squeeze the lemons and slice the rinds; set aside juice and rinds. In a blender puree the celery, green pepper and onion. In a saucepan over low heat, combine all ingredients, including lemon juice and rinds. Simmer 15 to 20 minutes. Do not let sauce boil. Serve ribs with sauce.
Yield: 8 to 10 servings.
 
Jerk Fish (Adapted from Allan Vernon)
 
Total time: 1 hour, plus 2 hours for marinating
 
 3/4 cup Jamaican jerk sauce (see note)
 2 cups water
 1 medium-size onion, peeled and coarsely chopped
 1 sprig thyme
 1 scallion, trimmed
 1 Scotch bonnet pepper, stem removed
 1 cup sherry, optional
 4 baby red snappers, 3/4 to 1 pound each, cleaned, scaled, rinsed and patted dry.
1. In a blender or food processor combine jerk sauce, water, onion, thyme, scallion, pepper and sherry, if desired, and puree until smooth. Pour the mixture into a glass or ceramic baking dish. Place fish in the marinade and coat well. Refrigerate for 2 hours.
3. Prepare grill. Remove fish from marinade and pat dry. Grill 5 to 8 minutes on each side, until fish flakes easily with a fork. Serve with rice and additional jerk sauce, to taste.
Yield: 4 servings.
NOTE: Some specialty markets carry jerk sauce. Vernon's can be ordered by calling (800) 660-JERK [(800) 660-5375] in New York State, or (212) 268-7020.
 
Barbecued Pork (Adapted from Shun Lee West)
 
Total time: 2 hours, plus 3 hours for marinating
 
 2 1/2 tablespoons sugar
 2 tablespoons honey
 2 tablespoons rice wine or sherry
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1 pound pork tenderloin.
1. In a small, shallow bowl mix sugar, honey, rice wine and salt. Place tenderloin in a shallow stainless-steel or ceramic bowl and brush sauce over meat. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate 3 hours.
2. Prepare grill. Cover the rack with aluminum foil. Grill the meat over medium-low heat, covered, for 1 1/2 hours, turning occasionally.
3. Remove meat from grill and carefully peel foil from grill; then replace pork on grill. Cook just until meat becomes sizzling brown, about 5 minutes. Remove from grill, cut into 1/4-inch slices and serve.
Yield: 2 servings.
 
Famous Beef Barbecue (Adapted from Yon Suk Choi)
 
Total time: 1 hour 10 minutes, plus 8 hours for soaking
 
 2 short ribs beef with bone (14 ounces each) or 2 9-ounce rib-eye steaks, sliced into very thin strips
 1 4-ounce piece ginger
 1 medium-size papaya, peeled and pureed
 1 tablespoon clear honey
 3 tablespoons soy sauce
 2 tablespoons minced pear
 2 tablespoons minced pineapple
 1/4 medium-size onion, chopped
 1 tablespoon rice wine (sake)
 1 teaspoon minced garlic
 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 2 scallions, trimmed and halved
 1/2 teaspoon sugar, or to taste (optional)
 1/2 teaspoon sesame seeds
 2 tablespoons sesame oil.
1. In a large bowl or pot, soak the meat in cold water to cover and refrigerate overnight. Remove meat from water, wipe clean and set aside. Strain soaking water and reserve 1/3 cup.
2. Peel ginger and grate against the finest side of the grater, keeping a bowl beneath to catch juices. Measure out 1 tablespoon of ginger juice. In a small saucepan, combine the 1/3 cup reserved water, papaya puree, ginger juice, honey and soy sauce. Cook over very low heat 10 minutes; do not let boil. Remove and allow to cool slightly.
3. In a blender, combine 6 tablespoons of the cooked sauce, pear, pineapple, onion, rice wine, garlic, pepper, scallions and sugar. Puree until smooth. Stir in sesame seeds. Pour into small saucepan and cook over low heat 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
4. Place beef on a plate. Pour 6 tablespoons of the marinade onto plate and rub into beef. Rub sesame oil into beef. Set aside 10 minutes.
5. Prepare grill. Grill meat 2 minutes on each side, or until brown on outside, for medium beef.
Yield: 2 servings.

HEADLINE: University Research Depends on 'Overhead'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
My research is supported by a grant from the United States Department of Energy. My colleagues and I often grumble about the fraction of our grants that go to "overhead," since the indirect charges paid to the university reduce the amount of money we have for our research. But the indirect charges are crucial in that they support the infrastructure -- offices, laboratories, libraries, etc. -- without which our research universities would cease to function. 
 Certainly these charges must be assessed fairly, and perhaps this system is in need of major overhaul, but in the frenzy of the moment let's not throw the baby out with the bath water. Our research universities are vital to the nation and worthy of both our pride and support. They are imitated throughout the world, and undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and senior researchers from virtually every country -- including our staunchest economic competitors, Japan and Germany -- pay our institutions of higher learning the highest compliment each year by seeking to study or work at them.
 
MICHAEL S. TURNER
Prof. of Physics, U. of Chicago
Chicago, May 5, 1991

HEADLINE: Eximbank Helps U.S. Exporters Compete

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Corporate America has recovered from its sinking spell and is re-emerging as the world's pre-eminent industrial nation. This is due almost entirely to producers' renewed emphasis on quality, productivity and design. While there is still enormous room for improvement, these changes have transformed the United States into an export-driven economy for the first time in history.
The challenge remains for those of us in the financial sector to insure that our exporters have access to the competitive financing needed to get their products overseas. 
 Unfortunately, many of our commercial banks are hesitant to participate in trade financing, although there are some encouraging signs this is changing. But exporters should know that a source of financing is available to them. The Eximbank's mission is to facilitate the export of U.S. goods and services. Last year it helped finance nearly $10 billion in exports that otherwise would have not occurred. It provided short-, medium- and long-term financing and insurance. More important, the bank also leveraged its resources by guaranteeing commercial bank lending. These guarantees eliminate commercial and political risks for private lenders and increase the pool of funds available to exporters.
Guarantees get local institutions involved that can better service local exporters. The local lender profits from servicing the loan and the exporter benefits from the lower cost of the transaction. The Eximbank also gains. Its costs are reduced by dealing with financial institutions that know its export support programs.
I agree with the view that foreign trade is likely to power the economy for years to come. But I believe further that exports almost by definition must be the engine of future growth.
We have no choice. The world's economies are growing faster than ours. About 75 percent of the world's gross national product lies outside our border. Most important, there is hardly an American-made product that doesn't face foreign competition both here and abroad. Any U.S. producer that cannot compete overseas will soon find that it cannot compete at home.
 
JOHN MACOMBER
Chairman, U.S. Export-Import Bank
Washington, May 8, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: A Creative Council Reaps an Array of Benefits

SERIES: Playing for Power: The Council's Bid for Influence -- Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB with DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
Respect has never come easily to the New York City Council. And even as the revised City Charter has given it vast new responsibilities, power has remained in short supply for all but a handful of its members.
Nonetheless, this most demeaned of public offices does have its attractions. 
 By blurring the lines of their personal, political and official lives, the 35 Council members can wind up with hundreds of thousands of dollars a year in public and private money at their disposal. With little oversight, the members can use much of this to buy items from microwaves to cars, hire political cronies, and wine and dine constituents and contributors.
Each Council member receives a $55,000 salary for what is officially a part-time job. But this is just the beginning. Including perks and office-expense allocations, the most restrained Council member controls nearly $250,000 a year in government money.
And with the Council's new power has come new cash: the Council and its members have joined a high-stakes political money game financed by big businesses, labor unions and other interests courting their influence.
Six years ago, Council members raised a total of $1.2 million for their re-election campaigns. In 1989, as the Council was about to assume greater responsibility on budget and land-use issues, its members raised more than $2 million, much of it through a new political action committee. That figure promises to be dwarfed this year.
Noach Dear, a Democrat from the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, may have used his various funds more expansively than any other member. He has disbursed campaign donations to buy and insure a car; to contribute to his favorite charities; to take frequent trips to Israel and the Soviet Union, and to cover tens of thousands of dollars in American Express and Visa bills that have been paid without an itemization of individual charges.
But while few, if any, members have been as skillful as Mr. Dear, many have used their part-time jobs to enhance their life styles by mastering a handful of simple devices.
 
No. 1: The Lulu
 Essential to the financial enhancement of Council members is a simple rule: be kind to Peter F. Vallone, the all-powerful Speaker of the Council. The most direct way for Mr. Vallone to show his appreciation for loyalty is through the "lulu."
Twenty-nine of the 35 Council members receive these annual lulus -- payments in lieu of expenses -- of between $2,500 and $22,500, for taking on such added responsibilities as running committees, some of which rarely meet. Mr. Vallone did not invent these bonuses, but his first order of business upon assuming the title of Speaker last year was to increase their total value by more $113,000. Mr. Vallone, who himself gets a $35,000 lulu, decides who gets lulus and who doesn't.
Since early last year, two of his biggest critics, Michael DeMarco of the Bronx and Sal Albanese of Brooklyn, lost lulus worth $20,000 and $6,000, respectively.
Mr. Vallone says he expects loyalty from his committee chairmen on crucial issues because they are members of his leadership team. He staunchly defends the competence of his appointees.
Perhaps the most easily earned bonus belongs to Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, Republican of Staten Island, who gets $20,000 a year, plus a car and driver, to serve as council minority leader. As the only non-Democrat on the Council, Mr. Cerullo constitutes the entire Council minority.
 
'I Don't Abuse It'
 Mr. Cerullo, 29 years old, a lawyer and part-time soap opera actor, said his bonus was a longstanding, built-in part of the minority leader's pay. Of his car -- one of 12 assigned to the Council, up from 4 three years ago -- he said: "If that is a privilege of the office, I'm concerned about relinquishing that. But I don't abuse it in any way."
Councilman Jose Rivera of the Bronx gets $2,500 a year for running the subcommittee on pensions. Often the member with the worst attendance record, Mr. Rivera maintains that he has been getting better, and said, "You will see that I've always been present when there has been a committee meeting." Reminded that records show that his committee has never met, he said that it did meet, but not in public. "The pension committee always meets internally," he said. "You cannot blame me for the past tradition of meeting internally."
 
2. The Gold Apple
 Among the desks, computers, picture frames and plane tickets for which Council members bill the city, no single item symbolizes the petty extravagances better than the gold apple lapel pin, the unofficial mark of a member. At least a dozen members have invested in thousands of these items, at about 75 cents each, which are handed out to passers-by everywhere from the streets of New York to Puerto Rico and Israel.
"We always focus on the negatives of the city of New York," said Councilman Victor L. Robles of Brooklyn. "These little apples say that whatever you read, whatever you see, the city of New York is the best place to be."
Mr. Robles's goodwill gestures go beyond apples; he has also spent more than $1,000 of city money on birthday cards. He said his staff maintains a computer printout of the birthdays of every constituent approaching 65.
"It was my way of keeping in contact with those who reach their golden years, as I call them," he explained. "Every time a senior returns my card, I can look at the letter and tell they've been crying."
 
Goodwill Trips
 Sometime the goodwill gestures are more expensive.
Mr. Rivera has spent the most public money on trips. Council records show that since September he has spent at least $2,400 on flights to Puerto Rico, Washington and other destinations. "Yes, I have made a couple of goodwill trips to Puerto Rico," he said, including one after Hurricane Hugo.
Mr. Robles and other Council members also used their district office funds to buy video and still cameras. Mr. Robles said he uses his to record community events.
A major chunk of a Council member's expense money is used for personnel, and with this money members have hired business associates, campaign aides, losing candidates whom they supported, and relatives of political backers.
Councilman Jerry Crispino, for example, pays $38,263 to Sandra Prosnitz, a lawyer who is an associate in his firm. Martin Lasher, the father of Assemblyman Howard Lasher, receives $6,000 as a part-time aide to Councilman Sam Horwitz. Assemblyman Lasher and Councilman Horwitz share office space. Councilman Joseph Lisa hired Frank Sansivieri, a losing candidate for the state Senate and former district leader, to work for him part time. Councilman Morton Povman employs Bruce Eiber, son of an appellate division justice, a former Assembly candidate and a tennis partner of Mayor David N. Dinkins. And so on.
 
3. The Witching Hour
 If there is a witching hour for Council members, it is midnight on the last day of a fiscal year. Council members know that whatever expense money they have not spent by July 1 goes back to the city treasury. Last year, they went through $140,094 during the last week of the fiscal year, spending $107,782 on the last day, June 29, alone.
Among the big-ticket items were $21,603 in computers, copiers, software and printers; Mr. Cerullo spent $13,344 and Abraham G. Gerges $6,438.
 There was also a spate of spending on office supplies -- $5,055, with Councilman Robert Dryfoos absorbing more than $2,000 of it himself.
But for many members, the imagination runs out before the budget line. The standard response: buy stamps. In the last week of the year, 18 council members bought a total of $34,888 worth of postage stamps. Several members said they used the stamps to mail newsletters to constituents.
Mr. Cerullo said that he could hardly be blamed for spending money on office equipment since he had just assumed his Council post that month after winning a special election. Mr. Gerges, who bought his elaborate computer set-up half a year before leaving office to take a seat on the state Supreme Court, said he shopped around for the best price and eschewed such purchases as greeting cards and apple pins to save up for it.
 
4. Generous Supporters
 Campaign funds have historically been a source of largely unmonitored income for Council members, but they are now easier to come by and more plentiful than ever. The $2 million raised in 1989 went toward campaigns that with two or three exceptions attracted no serious opposition, leading to healthy surpluses that many members used for purposes other than campaign needs.
A three-year-old political action committee controlled by Mr. Vallone amassed more than $500,000, mostly from builders, unions, contractors, lawyers and lobbyists with continuing interests before the Council. Mr. Vallone disbursed much of this money to Council incumbents and to enhance the reputation of the institution he controls.
 
Major Contributions
 Nearly one-fifth of the money raised by the Council Political Action Committee, known as C-PAC, came from real-estate developers, including Donald J. Trump, who gave $5,000. More than $87,000 came from unions.
Roughly $15,000 of C-PAC's money came from powerful government lobbyists and advisers like Howard Rubenstein, the longtime adviser to a succession of mayors, who gave $4,000. Another $31,000 came from lawyers, including such government-oriented firms as Shea & Gould and Davidoff & Malito, each of which contributed $4,000.
The giving is not limited to C-PAC. Records show that, as in most legislative bodies, chairmen and members of Council committees often receive sizable contributions from the interests they are supposed to monitor.
For example, Rafael Castaneira Colon, chairman of the Civil Service Committee -- a job for which he receives a $10,000 lulu -- raised $29,705 of his $92,210 fund from municipal unions. Jerome X. O'Donovan, chairman of the Economic Development Committee, received $1,760 from the Political Action Committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, $2,000 from the Building Industry of New York, $1,000 from another real-estate group, the Neighborhood Preservation PAC, and $1,000 from the General Contractors Association.
Councilman Sheldon Leffler, who received more than $10,000 from real-estate interests in his last campaign, said he got the contributions because of contacts he made as the swing man on a 4-to-3 vote in the Economic Development Committee that killed a proposal for commercial rent control. "I think they felt I was somebody who was not an anti-landlord demagogue, who understands development in the city," he said.
Because of his leadership of C-PAC, Mr. Vallone did not actively raise money on his own behalf after 1987 and took in only $4,224 during the 1989 campaign year. Of this, $1,500 was from the General Contractors Association, which recently lobbied the Council fiercely to stop construction of a municipal asphalt plant, and $2,000 from the union local representing school paraprofessionals.
 
Broad Range of Expenditures
 This union, Local 372 of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, is a longtime supporter of Priscilla Wooten, whose recent appointment as chairwoman of the Education Committee brings her a $10,000 lulu. The local was her largest contributor at $4,500.
Councilwoman Wooten said she would not be compromised by the strong union backing.
As Council members know, the campaign funds can be spent on far more than campaigns. It has been used, legally, to pay for car phones, dinners, and contributions to other candidates and to charities.
Until recently, virtually none of these funds were audited. State election law permits wide discretion in their use, prohibiting only the most purely personal expenses.
In 1989, Councilman Dryfoos used his campaign fund, which includes contributions from some of Manhattan's wealthiest developers and businessmen, to pay himself at least $13,716 in salary, and $2,100 for unspecified travel expenses. A spokesman for Mr. Dryfoos said the payments were to reimburse the Councilman for salaries he advanced to campaign staff.
 
5. Merging Interests
 Regulations also permit members to maintain outside businesses. Many of the dozen lawyers on the Council not only continue to practice, but do so out of the same premises as their Council district offices.
The convergence is perhaps best symbolized by a sign on Westchester Square, in the Bronx, advertising, "Office of Councilman Michael DeMarco, Esq."
Council members who are lawyers are prohibited from representing clients against the city. The city's Department of Investigations three years ago began examining accusations that Mr. DeMarco had pressured city agencies into taking actions that would benefit one of his clients in the waste-hauling business. Mr. DeMarco denies that the company was a client. The investigation has not reached a conclusion.
Mr. DeMarco said his joint office is a legacy of the days when Council members received small expense accounts and he could not afford to run separate offices.
For others, like Mr. DeMarco's Bronx neighbor, Mr. Crispino, the lines between legal work and Council work can become obscure, indeed. Mr. Crispino has served as lawyer for the family that owns the Naclerio Construction Company, whose principals have contributed thousands to his campaigns over 15 years. As a Council member, Mr. Crispino sponsored legislation renaming a street in the Bronx "Salvatore Naclerio Place," for the company's founder.
 
'Westchester Office'
 The Naclerio company was barred from doing new business with the city after it was caught submitting phony invoices. More recently, the company has been mired in controversy over the botched reconstruction of Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn.
Mr. Crispino said he stopped representing the Naclerio family three years ago. There is no evidence that Mr. Crispino represented the company on any of its city contracts.
Unlike Mr. DeMarco, Mr. Crispino does not practice law from his Council office, but from his home. He lives in a leafy neighborhood on the border between the Bronx and Westchester County, which has led opponents to assert that he barely lives in his district. Indeed, on his law firm letterhead, Mr. Crispino lists his home address as his "Westchester Office."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 24, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the perquisites of membership on the New York City Council misidentified a councilman who used district office funds to buy camera equipment. He was Jose Rivera, not Victor Robles.

HEADLINE: Ethiopia's Dictator Flees; Officials Seeking U.S. Help

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 21

 BODY:
Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, who ruled Ethiopia with an iron hand for 14 years, resigned today and fled the country. Officials of his Government then called on the United States to try to arrange a settlement with Ethiopian rebels who were reported advancing on the capital.
Shortly after Colonel Mengistu's departure at 9:30 A.M. on an Ethiopian Airlines plane bound for Zimbabwe, Prime Minister Tesfaye Dinka telephoned the charge d'affaires at the the United States Embassy here, Robert G. Houdek, to request that Washington relay a request to the guerrillas for an immediate cease-fire. Later in the day, airport officials in Harare, Zimbabwe's capital, said Colonel Mengistu had arrived there. 
 American officials, who have played a growing role in seeking a negotiated solution to the civil war in recent months, agreed to pass on the message, but a representative of the rebels refused to call a halt to the offensive.
 
Control to Vice President
 Before he left, Colonel Mengistu, who held the title of President, handed control of the Addis Ababa Government to his Vice President, Lieut. Gen. Tesfaye Gebre-Kidan. But the departure of Colonel Mengistu appeared to herald the end of Africa's hardest-line Marxist government, one held responsible for the deaths of thousands of Ethiopians in political purges and for the forced relocation of hundreds of thousands of peasants to Government-founded cooperatives and state farms.
In the last year the Government moved to loosen restraints over the nation's politics and economy, but the animosity it had created among a diverse collection of rural ethnic groups was too much to overcome.
Like the hard-line Communist leaders of Eastern Europe, Colonel Mengistu was undermined by sharp reductions in Soviet military and economic aid in the last two years. A nearly complete cutoff of Soviet assistance since December eroded army morale, and one unit after another collapsed when confronted by a rebel offensive begun in February.
The rebels are reported to be within 50 miles of the capital and still advancing. The Second and Third Revolutionary Armies, Ethiopia's best, appear to have taken flight.
United States officials in recent weeks had quietly suggested that Colonel Mengistu resign to achieve peace. Last month, Colonel Mengistu told former Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a special envoy of President Bush, that he would leave his post if it was the only way to keep Ethiopia united.
Senior Government officials said the Ethiopian President and his closest advisers decided Monday night that he should resign after concluding that it was the only way to avert the disintegration of the country.
"Everything is coming to an end because we have reached a stage where our military can't do anything to stop the guerrillas," said a senior Government official, who spoke on condition that he remain anonymous. "This is not the beginning of the end. It is the end of the end."
The Mengistu Government faced two major rebel groups: the Eritrean People's Liberation Front and the Tigre People's Liberation Front.
 
Fighting for 31 Years
 For 31 years, the Eritrean group has been fighting for the independence of the northern province, which borders the Red Sea and includes the critical port of Massawa. Massawa has been in rebel hands for more than a year and rebel forces are besieging the province capital, Asmara. During the 1970's, the Eritrean group had a strongly Marxist ideology, but in recent years has softened its line.
The Tigre rebels, based in that province south of Eritrea, are fighting to overthrow the Mengistu Government. Active since the mid-1970's, it won military control of Tigre several years ago. The Tigre group has a harder Marxist line than the the Eritreans.
In the last several months, the two groups have formed the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front, but have kept their separate identities and long-term goals.
The Government announced Colonel Mengistu's departure in a brief radio broadcast at noon.
"In order to control the shedding of blood and return the nation to peace and progress, several individuals came to the understanding that the President should relinquish his power," it said. "Therefore, he has relinquished his power to Vice President Lieut. Gen. Tesfaye Gebre-Kidan and left the country."
 
Would Work in Transition
 The statement went on to suggest that the Government would "work for the formation of a transitional government."
Senior officials in the Government said General Tesfaye, who only took office as Vice President last month, would be little more than a figurehead. They said Prime Minister Tesfaye, who is no relation to the general, would effectively run the Government and attempt to negotiate a settlement with the guerrillas.
General Tesfaye was military administrator for Eritrea province until he was appointed Vice President. He was described by diplomats as a non-ideological officer with a decent record on human rights. He is reportedly popular with most groups in the army.
Prime Minister Tesfaye is an economist and former Foreign Minister who has developed a good relationship with officials in the Bush Administration and Western Europe.
The immediate popular reaction to Colonel Mengistu's departure appeared to be one more of surprise than relief. No demonstrations were reported in the capital or around the country, and the omnipresent signs and banners with Colonel Mengistu's picture were left untouched.
"Mengistu is gone and that is a relief for us," said Mugeta Tesfaye, a 39-year-old bank clerk, "but we will be lucky if we get a peaceful resolution."
"How could this be good?" asked Abeb Tesfaye, an accountant. "Just as we are threatened, he leaves us."
After Colonel Mengistu fled, rumors spread through the capital that the rebels were about to descend on the capital and kill everyone associated with the Government. Army troops patrolled the streets in open-bed trucks and jeeps with their assault rifles at the ready. During the day, citizens formed long lines at banks to withdraw their money and at local stores to hoard food. Schools and Government office buildings closed early, and the Government announced that the normal midnight-to-5 A.M. curfew would begin at 9 P.M.
Colonel Mengistu, whose age is placed between 46 and 53 in various references, was a member of a council of officers that overthrew Emperor Haile Selassie in a bloodless coup in 1974. He took sole control in 1977, when he personally killed several members of the junta at a meeting in the capital.
After making a tactical alliance with the Soviet Union and Cuba to repulse an attack by neighboring Somalia in the late 1970's, he formed a Marxist-Leninist ruling party and set out to create a Communist system.
 
No Respite for Government
 But separatist guerrillas in Eritrea bled his Government with their persistent attacks. Then war, failed economic policies and a devastating drought in the mid-1980's led to mass-scale hunger that left hundreds of thousands of people dead.
Critics charged that Colonel Mengistu worsened the famine by denying food to areas most opposed to his agrarian programs, which included fixed prices and forced crop and labor contributions by peasants.
His rule unraveled quickly since the guerrillas began coordinated attacks Thursday to the west, north and northeast of the capital. Today, Tigrean rebels accomplished their goal of cutting off the capital from Assab, the last port under Government control, by taking the northern highway town of Mille. As other Tigrean forces marched only 50 miles west of the capital, Eritrean rebels threatened to overwhelm Government troops in Asmara, the Eritrean capital.
Dawit Yohannes, a member of the rebels' supreme council, said in a telephone interview from Washington that he welcomed Colonel Mengistu's departure. But he added that the President's resignation did not go far enough because it did not signify an end to the Government.
He said the rebels were ready to discuss entering into a coalition government with officials in the present Government at peace talks sponsored by the United States and scheduled to be held in London next week. "We have no intention of attacking the capital," he added.
But Eritrean rebel leaders said they would only join a coalition government if a referendum is set for their province to decide on outright independence. The present Government has refused to consider any condition that would threaten the unity of Ethiopia.
 
'What Will Impress Them?'
 Kassa Kebede, foreign policy chief of the ruling Ethiopian Workers' Party, said he was disappointed by the guerrilla response. "If the stepping down of the President doesn't mean much to them, what will impress them?"
A Western diplomat predicted that the Government and guerrillas would attend the London talks, and that Addis Ababa "would have little left to bargain with."
Colonel Mengistu apparently made his final decision to depart after President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe sent an envoy here on Monday to repeat his invitation that the Ethiopian leader move to Zimbabwe, where his family had already gone.
Colonel Mengistu reportedly invited many of his longest supporters to his palace for a farewell party on Monday night. He left for the airport this morning, unceremoniously, in a caravan of four vans surrounded by motorcycles.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mengistu Haile Mariam (Associated Press) (pg. A1); A catastrophic milestone in the rule of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam was the famine that horrified the world in 1984. Bodies of famine victims were prepared for burial at a relief center in Korem. (Sebastiao Salgado/Magnum) (pg. A13)
 
Chart: "Ethiopia: At a Glance"
 
Government
Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam had led a single-party Marxist-Leninist government based on the Soviet model since 1977.
 
Geography
Bordered by the Red Sea, Sudan, Kenya and Somalia, the country of 472,000 square mles is about the size of Texas, Oklahoma and New Mexico combined. The terrain largely consists of high plateaus, mountains and dry lowland plains.
 
Economy
The country, one of the least developed nations in the world, has an economy based on agriculture. Two-thirds of the arable land is under cultivation and nearly 90 percent of the people depend on farming for subsistence. Coffee is the country's most important cash crop. But guerrilla insurgencies and famine caused by recurring drought have caused major disruptions in economic activity.
 
History
A nation of 48 million people, modern Ethiopia dates to 1896, when Emperor Menelik II repelled an Italian invasion from Eritrea and consolidated the country. His cousin, Ras Tafari Makonnen, became regent for his daughter at Menelik's death, and when the Empress died in 1930, proclaimed himself Emperor Haile Selassie. Mussolini's invaders forced him to flee the country in 1935, but he returned in 1941 after the Italians were defeated by British troops. The former Italian colony of Eritrea was merged with Ethiopia in 1952.
In 1974, the Emperor was deposed in a military coup by leftist officers. One of them, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, consolidated control in 1977, killing remaining rivals for power. Authoritarian rule in the following decade -- along with the miseries of drought, famine and long-running guerrilla strife in Tigre and Eritrea -- left the country hobble. Until recently Colonel Mengistu had received billions of dollars in Soviet military and economic aid.
 
People
The dominant Ethiopian people are the Oromo, who make up 40 percent of the population. But there are 40 other ethnic groups in the country. The next largest are the Amhara (25 percent), the Tigre (12 percent) and the Sidama (9 percent). About 40 percent of the population is Muslim, about 40 percent is Ethiopian Orthodox Christian. (pg. A13)

HEADLINE: Weicker Says He'll Veto No-Income-Tax Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 22

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he would veto the no-income-tax budget plan unveiled by legislators on Tuesday. His announcement, one day before the Senate is expected to begin debate on the plan, raised the stakes further in the battle of wills between the administration and the General Assembly.
The budget plan was developed by leaders in both parties as a way to avoid the tax on wages that Mr. Weicker has argued is the only way for Connecticut to resolve its fiscal crisis. 
 Instead of an income tax, it would raise business taxes and apply the state's 8 percent sales tax to hundreds of millions of additional transactions. In the process, Mr. Weicker argues, it would also cripple the state's ability to pull itself out of recession.
Connecticut is one of only a handful of states that does not tax wages, although it does tax income from dividends, interest and capital gains.
 
A Much Smaller Margin
 "This is disastrous," he told reporters as he was entering the Capitol this morning. "If I didn't veto this, I should not be governor of the State of Connecticut."
Mr. Weicker had attacked the plan before as the particulars were still in negotiation, but had reserved a formal veto promise until all the details were in. Sponsors of the plan said today that since Mr. Weicker's views were well-known, he had added nothing new today, and they again expressed confidence that they had the votes to pass their plan in the Senate, as well as in the House, though there by a much smaller margin.
Other lawmakers said that Mr. Weicker, having now "guaranteed," as he put it, that the plan would not survive past his desk, had added another wrinkle in the complex political game that is going on as lawmakers look both to what their constituents want and do not want, and how the wrenching choices to be made this year may affect the legislative elections in 1992.
The thinking works like this: with a veto certain, lawmakers now know well in advance of their vote that a simple majority in both chambers for the no-income-tax budget will not be enough to insure passage; a two-thirds majority is needed to override a veto.
 
Even More Complicated
 Mr. Weicker's announcement sends a message to lawmakers who might agree that an income tax is needed, but who feel trapped by the public's apparent antipathy toward it.
Knowing where Mr. Weicker stands, they can safely vote for the legislative plan, knowing it will not become law, and then change their minds after his veto.
But some income-tax supporters say the equation is even more complicated. So many unpopular taxes had to be raised or added to make up for the lack of an income tax, they say, that the legislative package may no longer be a safe vote either. The plan would raise total taxes by $960 million, almost as much as Mr. Weicker's plan.

HEADLINE: On Philippine Treaty, Gap Is Said to Narrow

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
American and Philippine officials are expressing optimism that they can work out a new treaty permitting American forces to remain at two large military bases in the Philippines after the current lease expires in September.
Officials on both sides caution, however, that they are still without an agreement on the duration of the proposed treaty and the amount of compensation due to Manila. 
 The Philippines has offered to allow American forces to remain at Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay Naval Station and four smaller installations for up to seven years in exchange for $825 million a year in cash and other benefits.
The United States has demanded a treaty of at least 10 years and, according to Philippine negotiators, has offered an annual compensation package of about $400 million. American officials have refused to confirm the $400 million figure.
Clark and Subic are among the largest and oldest American military installations abroad, home to more than 10,000 American troops.
While the Defense Department no longer considers them vital to national security in light of a diminished Soviet threat in the Pacific, the Bush Administration hopes to hold on to the bases, arguing that it would be impossible to establish similar, mammoth military installations elsewhere in the region.
Newspapers in Manila reported this week that American and Philippine negotiators were hurrying to complete the agreement so that Vice President Dan Quayle could sign a treaty during his current trip to Asia.
American officials said today that a Quayle visit to Manila had been considered but was now unlikely. "We had hoped that the agreement might be ready this week," a State Department official said. "But it wasn't." President Corazon C. Aquino has intervened personally in the base negotiations in recent days, summoning the United States Ambassador, Nicholas Platt, to the presidential palace in Manila last Saturday for three hours of talks.
American negotiators said they were heartened by Mrs. Aquino's move. "Anytime the Ambassador gets the opportunity to visit with the president of the republic, I think it's pretty clear that she wants to bring the process to closure in a friendly way," a State Department official said. "I think it's fair to say she's anxious to get an agreement."
Mrs. Aquino is thought to be anxious to sign a new bases treaty if only to protect Philippine economic ties to the United States, the Philippines' largest trading partner.
 The Philippines is among the largest recipients of American foreign aid and enjoys a variety of trade concessions with the United States that, American officials have suggested, would be threatened if the base negotiations collapse.
Under Philippine law, a new treaty would have to be ratified by the nation's 23-member Senate, and American officials say Mrs. Aquino will have to lobby vigorously if the agreement is to win approval from Philippine lawmakers.
Although opinion pools show that the Philippine public wants to keep the bases, there has been strong opposition within the Senate. Many of the senators describe the American bases as a violation of national sovereignty and an ugly reminder of the Philippines' colonial past.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Post Mixed Yields for the Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week that ended yesterday.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's say short-term interest rates are still coming down, but if economic indicators show that the recession is near its end, expect money market yields to settle near their present levels since the Federal Reserve may not lower interest rates further. 
 Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, noted that today's durable-goods report for April could be critical. If the numbers are bad, an indication of weakness in the manufacturing sector, further interest-rate cuts could be in order, and that would push yields on Treasury bills and money market funds even lower.
Tax-exempt money fund yields declined for the week, with the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios down a day, to 43. The assets of tax-exempt funds increased by $715 million, to a total of $88.9 billion.
For the seven-day period that ended yesterday, the average tax-exempt compounded yield fell by 8 basis points, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 4.15 percent, with the seven-day simple yield down by 7 basis points, to 4.07 percent. The 30-day compounded average yield fell by 2 basis points, to 4.29 percent, with the 30-day simple falling a similar amount, to 4.20 percent.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield was 5.76 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket was 6.01 percent.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee, had the best return for the second straight week, at an unchanged 5.19 percent.
 
Taxable Assets Up
 The assets of taxable funds increased by $3.4 billion for the week, to a total of $460.7 billion, with those of institutional funds up by $1 billion, to a total of $117.5 billion. But only $600 million of the gain represented sales, while the rest came from the addition of new funds. Consumer assets increased by $2.4 billion, to a total of $343.2 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield was unchanged at 5.74 percent, while the 30-day compounded yield fell by 5 basis points, to 5.81 percent. The seven-day simple yield remained unchanged, at 5.58 percent, while the 30-day simple yield was down by 5 basis points, to 5.65 percent.
Including capital gains, the taxable fund with the best return was the Prudential Government Securities/ U.S. Treasuries, with a yield of 8.57 percent, but the more conventional return was by the American Performance Cash Management Fund, distributed by the Winsbury Company in Columbus, Ohio, with a yield of 6.82 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Some Gains In Extremely Slow Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose on technical factors in extremely quiet trading yesterday.
Gold fell 90 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York to close at $356.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $355.50, off $1. 
 Analysts said there was no news to sway the currency market. Ronald Holzer, chief foreign exchange dealer with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, described the dollar's movements as a "technical retracement" after losses on Tuesday.
Traders were adjusting their positions ahead of today's scheduled release of data on April orders for durable goods and the weekly state unemployment claims. The markets were also beginning to wind down before the three-day Memorial Day holiday weekend.
The dollar gained against the Japanese yen in New York, trading on speculation that the Bank of Japan might lower its discount rate. A lowering of rates in a country generally tends to cause its currency to drop in value.
The dollar closed at 137.80 yen in New York, up from 137.30 late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the United States currency fell 0.70 yen, to a closing 137.45 yen, but it was quoted higher in London at 138.00 yen.
The British pound slipped against the dollar. Sterling fell to $1.7280 in New York, from $1.7370 on Tuesday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.7270 from $1.7365.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.7227 German marks, up from 1.7128; 1.4602 Swiss francs, up from 1.4485; 5.8455 French francs, up from 5.8140; 1,279.00 Italian lire, up from 1,272.00, and 1.14975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14895.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.7210 German marks, up from 1.7125; 1.4598 Swiss francs, up from 1.4480; 5.8425 French francs, up from 5.8100; 1.9390 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9290; 1,277.50 Italian lire, up from 1,271.25, and 1.1490 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1488.
Silver fell 0.3 cent on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.032 an ounce. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.03, from $4.05 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Recovery Expected to Be Weak

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Ask a White House official, a member of Congress or a Federal Reserve policy maker what might happen when the recession ends, and they give this answer: Growth will be slow and sluggish. The bursts of activity that came immediately after other post-World War II recessions will not materialize this time.
That view showed up repeatedly in nearly a dozen recent interviews with Government officials. They accept the view of many economists that the American economy will probably expand by less than 3 percent in the first year of recovery, or roughly one-third the average growth rate after the eight previous postwar recessions. 
 The Government's reluctance to provide special stimulus has two aspects. One is a belief that the economy lacks the capacity to grow robustly without reigniting inflation. The other reflects a decision, shared by Democrats and Republicans, not to violate the October budget agreement, which chips away at the deficit over five years. The agreement rules out -- for the first time since World War II -- the combination of tax cuts and new spending that made the economy boom in the past.
"I am not attending meetings where we talk about how to get out of the recession and insure a strong recovery," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana.
Did such meetings to discuss emergency spending programs like highway construction or job training take place in the 1981-82 recession? "Sure they did," Mr. Hamilton said. "We talked about many programs, but we have lost confidence in what Congress can do to pump up the economy in the short term."
Beyond politics, the various engines of growth -- exports, home construction, auto sales and household incomes -- are not likely to be strong enough to power a brisk recovery, economists say. What's more, Corporate America is no longer willing to engage in the rapid stockpiling of goods in anticipation of rising sales, a practice that inflated growth in the aftermath of past recessions.
"The real story of this recession, and probably the early recovery period, is that there is no area of strength, not in exports, or rising personal income or Government spending or manufacturing," said Henry J. Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution.
The recession is not over yet. The gross national product is still shrinking, which means that the quantity of goods and services produced in each quarter since last October has declined. The Administration says the decline will end by July, and that is also the consensus view of 50 private forecasters surveyed each month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators.
Assuming that a turning point is near, the Blue Chip consensus forecast in May predicted G.N.P. growth of 2.2 percent in the recovery's first year. After the eight other postwar ecessions, the average first-year growth rate was 6.5 percent.
"We could drift along for some months," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office.
An anemic first-year recovery would make companies reluctant to rehire laid-off workers. Raises for those who do have jobs might be small and scarce, reflecting recent trends. And consumers will probably remain cautious shoppers until a stronger economy makes them feel more secure in their jobs.
 
What Fed Is Doing
 The Federal Reserve, which also has the power to step on the economic gas, favors a mild recovery. According to Fed policy makers, mild growth is all that the economy can achieve without increasing the inflation rate. Their concern is that the nation's businesses are not productive enough to supply all the needs of an economy growing at an annual rate of more than 2.5 percent to 3 percent. Beyond that level, people simply bid up the prices of a limited supply of goods and services and inflation rises. From 1983 through 1989, the G.N.P. grew at annual rates ranging from 2.5 percent (in 1989) to 6.8 percent (in 1984).
Such concerns about the nation's capacity for growth contributed to the Fed's decision to keep interest rates relatively high before the recession began last July. The decision played a key role in reducing the nation's economic growth to an annual rate of less than 2 percent, starting in the spring of 1989.
The Federal Reserve, which termed this approach a "soft landing," wants to maintain the policy after the recession ends, Fed officials suggest. The Fed would lower interest rates another notch (and thereby encourage the borrowing that stimulates economic activity) only if it saw clear evidence that the recession was continuing. That strategy was adopted at the Fed's policy making meetings on March 26 and again last Tuesday, according to the minutes of the March meeting and the reports of Government officials.
"I would say that in their heart of hearts, Fed policy makers want a very slow recovery that maintains the economy below its potential for growth," said Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science, who believes the Fed has been too cautious.
The last recovery got help from the Federal Government. President Reagan provided a huge fiscal stimulus, the nation's last big one, when he pushed through his 1981 package of tax cuts and investment incentives in the early months of the recession. The robust recovery that began in November 1982 resulted in part from the big Reagan tax cut, many economists contend.
Today Administration officials and Republicans in Congress maintain that tax cuts and spending programs are no remedy because they would bear fruit too late. They say that steps to authorize public works projects and other job-creating programs would not produce jobs until next year, after a recovery was already under way.
 
Inflation in 70's Recalled
 They argue that similar legislation in the recessionary mid-1970's contributed to the high inflation rates late in the decade. These included a public works bill, a job-training program, Federal housing assistance, higher levels of Federal financing for state and local governments than exist today, and broader unemployment insurance coverage. "
"Fiscal stimulus has tended to add to inflationary pressures in the postwar period," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "By and large, the spending came into effect only after recoveries had started, and long after anyone advocating the policy deemed it desirable."
Reflecting the White House view, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said the current recession had been mild and was ending without special help from extra Government spending. Mr. Darman acknowledged that economic growth, in the first year of recovery, will probably be weaker than in the aftermath of past recessions. But the more important issue, he said, is achieving sustainable, noninflationary growth over a longer term.
Below-par economic growth is likely to endure well into the 1992 election campaign, but studies by political scientists show that voters will not necessarily be alienated, Mr. Darman said. "It is the direction, not the magnitude, that counts," he said.
The Democrats do not openly challenge the view that fiscal stimulus is not needed and in the past came too late. As Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said, "The miraculous thing is that no one is pushing for job programs and other major spending."
Nevertheless, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, says public works projects now on hold at the state and municipal level -- for lack of financing -- could get under way immediately, if Congress provided the necessary funds. That would hasten a recovery, he said.
The fiscal stimulus proposed to date is small scale. Senator Sarbanes, Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, and a few others want to extend unemployment insurance payments to 52 weeks, as they were in the last recession. They currently are a maximum of 26 weeks in nearly every state, a result of rule changes in the 80's that tightened eligibility.
The spending increase to extend jobless pay -- nearly $5 billion a year, according to the Congressional Budget Office -- would require under the budget agreement an offsetting tax increase or an immediate reduction in some other spending program. That can happen only if Congress passes an emergency authorization to extend unemployment insurance, and President Bush gives his endorsement.
Democratic leaders in Congress say they would have sought the emergency authorization if the unemployment rate had risen in April beyond the March level of 6.8 percent. Instead, the rate fell to 6.6 percent for reasons that the Labor Department says might be reversed in May.
