HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Georgia Pacific May Laugh Last

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
THE Georgia Pacific Corporation may be poised for the last laugh at the naysayers who said a year ago that it was taking on far too great a burden in its $3.8 billion acquisition of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, which made it the nation's largest forest-products concern.
Many analysts and industry executives said the acquisition would be particularly challenging amid predictions of an economic downturn and said its earnings would suffer profoundly. Indeed, last month the company reported a first-quarter loss of $7 million, its first quarterly loss since 1982. 
 One reason for the loss is the nation's recession. Lower industrial output has translated into fewer items being shipped in boxes, and sagging corporate profits and layoffs have meant less paperwork is being performed. But in addition to the negative economic forces affecting the entire paper industry, Georgia Pacific has been saddled with huge interest payments from the Great Northern acquisition.
Nevertheless, there are widespread forecasts of remarkably smoother sailing in the industry after the end of next year, and, analysts now say, Georgia Pacific's competitive position will be considerably stronger as a result of its acquisition.
"Over time, the acquisition of Great Northern will prove to be one of the smartest decisions made by any paper company," said Mark S. Rogers, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "Of course, right now we are seeing the negative side of the acquisition. The good news is that the cash flow of the company is strong, and the debt is working its way down. As we see general business conditions improve, the addition of Great Northern will prove to be valuable."
One reason for this optimistic outlook is that Georgia Pacific, like most other paper companies in the United States, is a relatively low-cost producer, compared with overseas competitors. Also, capacity in the United States is growing at much the same rate as growth in demand, Furthermore, as the nation recovers from recession, demand for paper products like business papers and shipping cartons will pick up, they reason.
Also, Georgia Pacific has worked feverishly to whittle down its debt. The company has undertaken an asset sale program, raising $1 billion from the sale of two linerboard mills, more than 30 box plants and timberlands in the Pacific Northwest. Also, an aggressive capital spending program is slowing down as more projects are completed.
"They are on their way to their target, which is to reduce their debt to the 40 percent to 45 percent range," said Michael L. Bowyer, a paper analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. The company's debt-to-capital ratio soared from 47 percent at the end of 1989, to nearly 70 percent after the acquisition.
Moreover, the acquisition of Great Northern Nekoosa has bolstered the company's presence in the paper products sector of the business, reducing its exposure to the highly cyclical building products sector, which tends to be dependent on the housing industry. "They have a stronger product mix as a result of the acquisition," Mr. Bowyer said.
"When all is said and done, I guess one can say that Georgia Pacific plotted all the strategies very well," said Sherman Chao, a paper analyst with Salomon Brothers. "They have planned for and anticipated everything that has come about -- except for the wood-products business suffering from the credit crunch that has affected the housing sector. But, other than that, they have planned well."
Mr. Rogers expects the company will report a loss for this year, but he estimates that Georgia Pacific will earn $2.90 a share next year. That will be lower than the $3.99 a share earned last year and the $7.42 a share Georgia Pacific earned in 1989. Still, he predicts that the economy will be more robust and the company's debt will be down so dramatically that Georgia Pacific will earn about $12 a share within three to four years.
Mr. Chao also predicts a loss this year, but forecasts earnings of $2.50 a share for Georgia Pacific next year. He declines to estimate earnings beyond that. Mr. Bowyer of Duff & Phelps is more optimistic, forecasting earnings of $1.85 this year and $3.50 for 1992.
Investors also seem bullish. The company's stock, which traded at $44 at the time of the acquisition, closed up 12.5 cents yesterday at $47 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Demand for Notes Spurs Bond Selloff

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An auction of $12.25 billion in new two-year Treasury notes went well yesterday, but after the results of the sale were announced, traders responded by selling longer-term notes and bonds.
The new notes were sold at an average yield of 6.81 percent, the lowest level in more than four years and well below the 7 percent average rate at the last two-year note sale on April 24. 
 Demand for the new securities was strong, but when the results of the auction were announced, bond prices fell. Traders said people were selling bonds to buy the shorter maturities, betting that the Federal Reserve Board might yet again move to lower short-term interest rates.
 
Volume Is Light
 Moreover, market participants said trading was so light that any selling of bonds had a disproportionately large effect on prices.
"It was a very unusual auction," said John P. Costas, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation.
"This issue is doing very well," he said. "There is an isolated source of demand for securities with maturities of two years or less. But the litmus test for the market will be the five-year auction on Thursday, not these two-year securities. And I think the market will need to see rates back up a bit in order to take on the five-year."
Demand for the new two-year notes remained strong after the auction, and by late yesterday the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.78 percent.
Meanwhile, the five-year notes scheduled to be auctioned today were offered in when-issued trading late yesterday at a price to yield 7.69 percent, down from 7.70 percent late on Tuesday.
The sense that yields on the new five-year notes will have to move higher to attract demand is based on recent performance of such notes, the analysts said.
"Since the inauguration of the monthly five-year note auctions in January, much of the steepening in the yield curve has been between two-year notes and five-year notes," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J., that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. The differential between the yield on two-year notes and the 30-year bond is the greatest in five years, but two-thirds of that, Mr. McCarthy said, represents the difference between yields on the two-year notes and the five-year notes.
"But yields in the five-year sector are pretty good right now," Mr. McCarthy added. " There is not a lot of reward to extend out beyond five years. But there is a lot of reward to go out to five years."
 
30-Year Bonds at 8.27%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 98 3/8 late yesterday, down by 9/32, to yield 8.27 percent, up from 8.24 percent late on Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 19/ 32, down by an eighth of a point, to yield 8.06 percent.
But the prices of shorter-term notes firmed slightly.
In late trading, for example, the 7 percent three-year notes were offered at 99 25/32, up by 2/32, to yield 7.08 percent.
Treasury bill rates finished mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.44 percent late yesterday, down by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late-offered rate of 5.62 percent.
In other developments, the heavy issuance of new tax-exempt municipal bond offerings continued.
 
Massachusetts Financing
 Foremost among issuers yesterday was the financially beleaguered Commonwealth of Massachusetts, which tapped the municipal bond market for the first time this year.
Investor demand for the new securities was so strong that the size of the negotiated sale was increased to $508.8 million, from the $475 million that was initially anticipated.
The issue consists of serial and term bonds with maturities to 2011.
The maximum yield on the securities offered was 7.83 percent on term bonds maturing in 2010.
Even with the increased size of the issue, market participants said the deal was oversubscribed.
"Reception of this transaction shows that investors have confidence in the plan of the Governor, the Treasurer and the legislative leadership" to balance the state's budget, said Eric Turner, the Massachusetts deputy treasurer for debt management.
Paul Williams, the manager of corporate planning and research at John Nuveen & Company, said, "There are some buyers who feel that perhaps Massachusetts's problems have ebbed."
 
Sound Yields Seen
 Another reason for the offering's success, Mr. Williams added, is that "there are not a lot of high-yield offerings out there." He went on, "And depending on an individual's tax bracket, the yield on these securities could translate into a taxable coupon of 10.5 percent to 11 percent."
The First Boston Corporation acted as the lead manager for the Massachusetts financing. The securities are rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was very spotty, traders said. The prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged on the day.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds also reported that trading was very light, and that prices of most issues were unchanged.

HEADLINE: GORBACHEV PLEADS FOR $100 BILLION IN AID FROM WEST

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 22

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pleaded today for $100 billion in economic aid from the democratic world, asserting that it would be well worth it to the West to bolster global security by priming a Soviet recovery.
The Soviet leader put his own print on what has been an unofficial and far from successful Kremlin lobbying campaign of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies for a voice at their summit gathering and for considerable cash aid for the staggering Soviet economy. 
 It was also the first time he had cited a specific figure. But it was unclear if the $100 billion was a well-thought-out request or was only suggestive. He did not say over how many years he envisaged such aid, but Soviet economists have been talking of $30 billion a year, much of it in outright grants, not loans. If it were loaned, $100 billion would instantly vault the Soviet Union into second place on the list of governments with the heaviest debt to foreign creditors.
 
Opposition From the White House
 "I have optimism on this issue," Mr. Gorbachev said at a news conference.
Mr. Gorbachev chose to move publicly with the ambitious economic initiative despite an oblique rebuff from White House officials, who said on Tuesday that his idea of formal inclusion at the seven-nation economic summit meeting in London in July is "a non-starter."
Announcing progress on a Soviet-American arms-control treaty today, President Bush held open the possibility of Mr. Gorbachev's attending the Group of Seven meeting, but did not endorse the idea. [Page A10.] But the idea of Mr. Gorbachev's coming to London was backed by Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, who shared the platform with Mr. Gorbachev today.
Mr. Gorbachev argued that the fate of Soviet economic and political change was as important to the stability of the world outside as to the future of his troubled nation.
It deserved closer attention and support from the Group of Seven, he argued, because the Soviet Union has become "one of the solid, reliable pillars of today's world."
"If that pillar disappears," he continued, "we should consider all the possible consequences."
 
Summit Meeting's Prospects
 Mr. Gorbachev also confirmed that there would probably be no summit meeting here with Mr. Bush by the end of June, as originally planned, because preparatory details on disarmament issues remained unsettled.
"We cannot fix the exact date in advance," he said, but stressed that he and Mr. Bush continue to enjoy a good relationship and look forward to the meeting being held eventually.
Mr. Gorbachev, appearing jointly at the Foreign Ministry with Mr. Andreotti, seemed intent on declaring the extent of his hopes rather than in pondering the political risks of an initiative that thus far has received no encouragement from the White House.
"If I don't go, I'll still say what I want to say," he declared, smiling jauntily in discussing his need to be heard in some fashion at the economic summit meeting.
He demonstrated his point by even specifying the sort of economic aid he thinks it would be wise for the economic superpowers to extend to the Soviet Union as he and Soviet republic leaders attempt to fashion a workable plan for warding off economic collapse.
"If we are able to find $100 billion to resolve the crisis," he said, "the question of cooperation with the Soviet Union for the benefit of perestroika, for perestroika to go ahead and for the country, as a result of radical reforms, to turn to the individual and to open up to the world -- I think that is worth the candle."
He also spoke of the aid question as a "very important" one for an exchange of views with President Bush "if the summit takes place" in Moscow.
Until today, Mr. Gorbachev had remained one step removed from fully embracing the Kremlin initiative to seek a hearing and some aid at the annual economic gathering of the United States, Canada, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Japan.
 
Economic Strategist's Return
 The idea mainly was being pursued in his behalf by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a free-market economic strategist with some credibility in the West. He had quietly rejoined the Kremlin planning team lately, after Mr. Gorbachev signalled his own retreat from attempting hard-line management of the crisis.
In making his case to be heard at the economic summit, Mr. Gorbachev said that it now was "quite natural" that international relations evolve further each year.
"Now there is really a necessity for the Soviet Union to have the possibility to express its views and considerations at the session of the seven," he said.
Mr. Andreotti reacted diplomatically to Mr. Gorbachev's statements, avoiding a direct endorsement of a Soviet presence at the London meeting while saying that "we postively evaluate" the idea of strengthening contacts with the Soviet Union.
 
'There Are Many Obstacles'
 Speaking of the United States, Mr. Gorbachev said that while relations had been getting stronger, "there are many obstacles in the way of economic cooperation."
"In my opinion not everything has been done to normalize relations," he said in referring to current disarmament differences.

HEADLINE: Memo Says Reagan Trade Policy on Iraq Helped Hussein

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
A State Department memorandum released today by a Congressman said that Reagan Administration policy in the late 1980's, while barring most arms exports to Iraq, allowed the export of military equipment intended to protect President Saddam Hussein.
A Government official confirmed today that there were shipments of equipment for the protection of Mr. Hussein but that they were probably limited to military radios for his bodyguards. Congressional officials, however, said some weapons might also have been involved. All the officials spoke on the condition that they not be named. 
 The unclassified memo, dated Dec. 6, 1988, said there was no reason to change the policy on the shipments of military equipment. "U.S. policy permits sale of Munitions, List articles to Iraq only when they are to be utilized for protection of the Head of State," it stated. "Congress's view toward Iraq has toughened as a result of Iraq's use of gas against the Kurds, and sanctions could be forthcoming."
The memo was released by Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, whose aides declined to indicate how he had obtained it. It provides another chapter in what is becoming a lengthy and increasingly partisan investigation by seven House and five Senate committees. The committees are examining the Administration's handling of relations with Iraq in the months preceding Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
Agreement, but No Action
 The memo was displayed by Mr. Levine at a hearing of the House Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade. The panel is looking into why the Administration did not limit exports to Iraq of civilian goods that could be used by the military after Iraqi forces gassed several thousand Kurds in 1988 or after Mr. Hussein threatened early last year to attack Israel.
A senior State Department official told the panel today that in April and May 1990, several months before the invasion, Administration officials agreed that controls on exports to Iraq should be tightened.
But the official, Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said he could not recall any specific action being taken as a result of what he described as a "general agreement" at two meetings of top deputies to the nation's most senior national security officials.
Mr. Kimmitt's account of the two meetings was less detailed and differed somewhat from Congressional testimony provided on April 8 by Dennis E. Kloske, who was then the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration. After Mr. Kloske gave his testimony, he was reportedly urged by the Administration to accelerate his planned resignation, reports the Administration has denied. Mr. Kloske left on May 1.
Mr. Kimmitt told the panel today that the Administration had begun pursuing a policy of prodding foreign governments to tighten their controls on exports to Iraq in April last year. "I wanted to find a way to deal efficiently with Iraq and other countries of export concern," he said. The best way to do this, he added, was to encourage countries with more lax export controls than the United States to tighten them, rather than through further tightening of American controls.
Mr. Kloske told the same House panel that at the meetings he had advocated a ban on exports of some high-technology products to Iraq, but that the State Department had opposed that view, saying it could affect existing relations with Iraq.
Mr. Kimmitt, who represented the State Department at both meetings, testified that he had advocated tightening export controls against a number of countries, particularly Iraq.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Soviets Near Settling Arms Pact Dispute

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Minn., May 22

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union today moved toward agreement on resolving differences over a treaty cutting non-nuclear armed forces in Europe.
The disagreements have prevented the pact from taking effect and have blocked the scheduling of the next superpower summit. 
 In St. Paul to promote his education program, President Bush expressed hope that the differences over the treaty could be ironed out this week. And in Washington, the chief of the Soviet general staff suggested that he had accepted a compromise plan offered by the United States.
 
'It Went Very Well'
 "We don't have all the results yet," said Mr. Bush, adding, "As far as I'm concerned, it went very well."
Mr. Bush spent 15 minutes at the White House on Tuesday with Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, the Soviet officer. General Moiseyev, who met with other senior American officials on Monday and Tuesday, had been seen by Washington as the leader of hard-line military officers who opposed the terms of the conventional arms treaty. But he indicated in a statement to reporters that the Soviet Union had agreed to abide by the overall limits set by the treaty, which was signed in Paris last year but not ratified.
American charges that the Soviet Union has reneged on some of its commitments under the treaty have stalled efforts to conclude another agreement, which would reduce long-range nuclear weapons. That in turn has prevented the final scheduling of a Soviet-American summit meeting that is supposed to be held in Moscow this year.
The Soviet Union had been insisting that its naval infantry units and coastal defense forces should not be counted toward the treaty's ceilings, while the United States had suggested that Moscow keep those units intact if it so desired but eliminate a corresponding number of other ground forces so that the overall ceiling set by the pact would not be violated.
 
Accord Possible This Week
 "The naval infantry armaments and the armaments of the coastal defense will be counted against those overall ceilings," General Moiseyev said in Washington.
He said it was "quite possible" that a final agreement on the treaty could be reached this week. "What is left is not of great importance," he said.
Although the general's comments were not definitive, David Shorr, associate director of the British American Security Council, a group that closely monitors conventional arms reduction, said: "Moiseyev seems to be ready to meet the concerns that the U.S. has been expressing. He seems ready to count everything we want counted under the limits."
Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One en route to St. Paul, Mr. Bush called "totally erroneous" a report in The New York Times and some other newspapers today that he opposed inviting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to London in July for a meeting of the leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies.
Mr. Bush said, "No decisions have been taken on that," but he declined to say whether he indeed favored inviting Mr. Gorbachev to the meeting in London. "If his coming there could help with the reform, genuinely help reform, that would be a very, very important matter," he said.
Administration officials who had said on Tuesday that Mr. Bush did not want Mr. Gorbachev invited to London said today that while no formal answer had been sent to Mr. Gorbachev, the United States did not want to include him in the meeting this year because the extent and nature of economic assistance that Washington is ready to offer the Soviet Union remains unsettled.
They said Mr. Bush was irked that discussions about the meeting had appeared in news reports before a diplomatic accommodation had been reached and a final decision announced. The articles also came as General Moiseyev was in town for delicate discussions in which the Bush Administration has a large stake.
Moreover, in his dealings with Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush tries to strike a careful, diplomatic tone that does not embarrass the Soviet leader publicly. Administration officials said today that it was still possible that some face-saving convention might be found in place of Mr. Gorbachev attending the London conference, for instance having Moscow send a lower-level delegation to consult with officials of the countries meeting there.
Administration officials have been placing great importance on General Moiseyev's visit to the United States because he had been perceived in Washington as a leading figure among conservative military officers who thought the conventional arms treaty cut too deeply into Soviet military strength in Europe.
Mr. Bush's comments today seemed to be a signal that the Administraation has concluded that the military, or at least General Moiseyev, was no longer blocking final agreement.
"One thing I came away with is that they genuinely want to resolve both these matters," he said. "There was some question as to whether the Soviets wanted a deal, or whether we did. The answer is that we both do."
General Moiseyev said: "The ceiling for the Soviet Union which is envisaged by the treaty signed in Paris will remain the same for the Soviet Union. It will not be exceeded."
But Mr. Bush declined to provide any details of the discussions. "We're at the stage where we need confidential discussions going on," he said.

HEADLINE: Man Convicted in Rabbi's Death

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
A jury convicted an unemployed house painter yesterday in the killing last year of Rabbi Chaskel Werzberger, a leader of the Satmar Hasidic community in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.
The 37-year-old defendant, David Ranta of Brooklyn, could face 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced on June 10 by Justice Francis X. Egitto, who conducted the trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
 
Botched Robbery
 Rabbi Werzberger, 58, was a sexton, or chief assistant, to the grand rabbi at Congregation Yetev Lev D'Satmar. The rabbi, a native of Hungary and a survivor of the Auschwitz death camp, came to the United States after World War II. 
 He was shot about 5:45 A.M. on Feb. 8, 1990, in front of his apartment in Williamsburg. His assailant fired one shot through the passenger side of the car, opened the door, shoved the rabbi's body onto the street and then sped off in the rabbi's 1985 Oldsmobile Cutless.
The prosecutors, Barry Schreiber and Suzanne Mondo, charged that Mr. Ranta killed Rabbi Werzberger to steal his car while making a getaway after botching the robbery of a jewelry courier.
The defense lawyer, Michael Baum, contended that Mr. Ranta, who was arrested in August, was the wrong man and was charged with the crime to quiet the anger of the Hasidic community over the slaying of the rabbi.
A witnesses for the prosecution, Alan Bloom, testified that he and Mr. Ranta tried to rob Chaim Weinberger, a jewelry courier, who thwarted the robbery by speeding away in his car. He said Mr. Ranta shot the rabbi while making a getaway.
 
Appeal Is Planned
 On the second day of deliberations in the three-week trial, the jury convicted Mr. Ranta of attempted robbery, robbery and murder in the commission of a robbery, while acquitting him of an intentional murder charge.
"We think the verdict was just and we are satisfied that justice was done," Mr. Schreiber, said.
Mr. Baum called the verdict unjust and said he would appeal it.

HEADLINE: Credit-Card Rules Urged

 BODY:
Legislation to require that consumers be given at least 30 days to repay credit-card debts before the interest rate could be increased was proposed yesterday by Representative Charles Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat.
The proposal would protect consumers whose banks sell credit-card businesses to other banks, which then may raise the interest rate. In the past, banks were required to provide 15-days notice of a rate increase. 
 Increases in card rates have become more common in the last few years as the largest credit-card banks, whose standard rate is 19.8 percent, have bought the businesses of smaller banks with lower rates.
Mr. Schumer also proposed that on the front of any envelope with an application or solicitation for a credit-card account, banks be required to display information about the interest rate and other fees.
The same information would also be required in advertisements, including those on television or in print, under the Schumer proposal.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan Give Out Economic 'Report Cards'

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 22

 BODY:
Like two schoolteachers relishing the chance to grade one another, Japan and the United States concluded a novel round of trade talks here today with modest praise for the progress each had made in economic self-improvement over the last year but harsh criticism for continued shortcomings.
In an atmosphere that alternated between warmth and coolness, the United States found that Japan had taken steps to increase public investment, to make it easier to open large retail stores and to ease regulations on foreign investment in Japan, but had failed to establish new rules for effectively breaking up cartels and other anti-competitive groupings. 
 Japan, on the other hand, acknowledged that the United States had taken important steps to improve education and training, but took Washington to task for failing to tame the growing Federal budget deficit and for permitting companies to overpay their executives and focus on short-term profits, rather than long-term results.
 
Basic Viewpoints Unchanged
 After a year of this experimental approach to trade negotiations, it was evident that Japanese officials still regard the United States as profligate and unable to curb its excesses, and that the United States sees Japan as a closed society that excludes outsiders to benefit its own economy unfairly.
At a news conference today, a Japanese negotiator attacked an unidentified American auto company, which was taken to be the Chrysler Corporation, for paying what he said were exhorbitant sums to its top executives.
An American official was just as strong in assailing Japan's lack of antitrust prosecutions, saying that it was all but impossible for a person in Japan to file an antitrust suit and that the Government had not filed a criminal antitrust case in 17 years.
After three days of talks during a week of tough trade negotiations, Japan and the United States were assessing how well each had lived up to pledges made a year ago to remove barriers that were believed to be inhibiting open trade and investment.
The two had agreed to this novel method as an addition to the traditional method of negotiating product by product, market by market. In more traditional talks, negotiations are under way this week on opening Japan's market for semiconductors and construction projects.
The outline of what each side expected of the other was issued a year ago. This week's meeting constituted a report card.
 
Assigning Percentages
 A senior Japanese official had judged that Japan had lived up to 65 percent of its pledges in what is known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, while he graded the United States at 20 percent.
S. Linn Williams, the deputy United States trade representative, called this "a bum rap." He and John B. Taylor, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that even though the Federal deficit had expanded, the budget process had been changed in a way that would begin to narrow the deficit.
Mr. Williams called the Japanese criticism "just an attempt by some to avoid focus" on the issue of monopolies in Japan.

HEADLINE: Sony Is Reportedly Near Deal To Lease A.T.&T. Skyscraper

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
In what is shaping up as one of the biggest real estate deals in New York City this year, A.T.& T. has tentatively agreed to lease its headquarters building, one of Manhattan's architectural highlights, to the Sony Corporation, real estate executives said yesterday.
A proposed 20-year lease with an option to buy the eight-year-old tower would consolidate Sony USA's corporate presence in New York. The 35-story building, sheathed in rosy granite, is sometimes called the Chippendale skyscraper for its pediment resembling the top of an 18th-century highboy, 
 Sony, the Japanese consumer electronics giant that has spent about $5 billion acquiring CBS Records and Columbia Pictures in the last four years, was searching for a corporate home in New York that would reflect its presence and prestige.
 
No Comment by Either Side
 Neither Sony nor the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would comment yesterday on whether they were negotiating a lease on the property on Madison Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets.
"We are not going to comment on discussions we've had or are having with prospective tenants," said Walter Murphy, the vice president for corporate communication at A.T.& T.
Robert Zito, a vice president of Sony USA, said, "We continue to look at options, and beyond that we have no comment."
But several real estate executives in New York said an agreement was all but complet, although they added that negotiations were continuing on some important points, like the terms of the purchase option and whether to name the skyscraper the Sony Building. The building's purchase price would be about $320 million, some executives said.
The leasing of the building, which has received about $39 million in property tax breaks from the city since 1978, is something of an epilogue to the dismemberment of the old Bell telephone network.
The tower, with its grand four-story lobby housing the company's longtime symbol, a 24-foot-high winged statue known as "Golden Boy," was completed just months before the telephone monopoly was broken up by the Federal courts and the seven regional telephone companies were spun off. It cost $200 million to build and is now too expensive for the much smaller A.T.& T. to maintain.
Few buildings have achieved the rapid fame for architectural distinction that was lavished on the building. The structure, built between 1978 and 1983, was designed by Philip Johnson and John Burgee on a grand and opulent scale that was clearly intended to merge the pleasing aspects of classical architecture with modern office tower design.
If the proposed deal between Sony and A.T.& T. is finally sealed, A.T& T. would have to give back to the city about $13 million in tax breaks it received for putting up the building and keeping about 1,200 of its employees in New York. In addition, A.T.& T. would forgo another $3 million in tax abatements it could get between now and 1994 under a pact with the city signed in 1987.
 
Promises About Employees
Executives of A.T.& T. said yesterday that the company would scrupulously fulfill both "the letter and the spirit" of its agreement with the city, and that even if the building is leased none of the 1,200 employees would be moved out of the city.
"It's important to us that it be clearly understood that if we do arrange a lease, the A.T.& T. employees that are in that building will be moved to other locations in the city," Mr. Murphy said.
The agreement's tentative terms reportedly would allow Sony to begin moving into the building by January and there would be no rent charged for one year on most of the 670,000 square feet of office space. Sony would relocate about 2,500 employees from various operations now scattered around the city. Most of the employees, about 2,000, work for Sony Music Entertainment, the former CBS Records. The others work for Sony USA, its main corporate subsidiary in this country, and a few other divisions.
In looking for a building that would announce its presence in New York, Sony considered joining in the planned development of Columbus Circle with Mortimer Zuckerman and it considered renting or buying other existing buildings. But even with the high vacancy rate in Manhattan, few buildings could provide the more than 600,000 square feet of prime office space Sony wanted.
For its first five or so years in the A.T.&. T. building, Sony would pay about $20 a square foot a year in net rent, which takes landlord services and the break for the first year into account. That would rise to about $23 a square foot net rent for the next five years. Over the remaining 10 years the net rent would be increased periodically until it reached $30 to $35 a square foot.
The option to buy the building and the price are apparently still being negotiated. It remained unclear whether it would be an option that would expire if not exercised or whether Sony could renew it.
 
Concerns About Politics
 One real estate executive said a principal reason Sony could not make an outright purchase of the building now was that with the city in financial trouble, A.T.& T. is concerned about the political fallout from breaking the deal it signed with the city.
The deal with the city requires A.T.& T. to maintain the building as its headquarters site and keep its employees in the building, said Michael Schlein, chief of staff for Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. But Mr. Schlein said A.T.& T. had repeatedly assured the city it would keep its employees here and would honor the agreement.
"A.T.& T. has been very responsible in the way they are handling this," Mr. Schlein said. "They think they can save some money with this, and our concern is about the jobs and keeping them in New York City."
Mr. Schlein said the city would work with A.T.& T. as long as the company remained committed to keeping the jobs in the city.
Anthony J. Mannarino, the executive vice president for the New York City Public Development Corporation, the city's agent for commercial and industrial development, said the city's main concern was that A.T.& T. adhere to the contract. He said the possibility of selling the building had been broached with the city.
"They have suggested that they might lease or sell a portion," Mr. Mannarino said yesterday.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 970 words

HEADLINE: Democrats Block G.O.P. Attack on Campaign Bill

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Senate Democrats rejected a Republican effort today to remove the most important provisions of their campaign finance bill. But the action, in a replay of past clashes, may turn out to be little more than symbolic.
President Bush has threatened to veto the package, and a crucial vote showed that proponents of the measure do not have the strength to override. 
 Today's action allowed lawmakers in both parties to claim credit for trying to improve a system, even if the measure, the most significant change in campaign finance law since the Watergate era, is never enacted.
 
Democrats Refuse to Back Down
 Democrats refused to back off from a proposed system that involved voluntary spending limits in exchange for some taxpayer-financed incentives, and Republicans insisted that the remedy was not cutting spending but curbing the special interest political action committees that make contributions.
Although the Senate is expected to approve a campaign finance measure, a version has yet to be introduced in the House. Backers brushed aside the President's veto threat and insisted that in light of recent ethics scandals there was more momentum in both parties to do something about the campaign finance system.
The strongest challenge to the Democratic proposal came in an amendment by Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, that would have stripped the measure of its key provision: partial public fiancing for candidates who adhere to spending limits, It was rejected in a party-line vote of 56 to 42, after George J. Mitchell, the Senate Democratic leader, warned that the amendment "will kill campaign finance reform."
But after the vote, Mr. McConnell asserted that efforts to overhaul the finance system were as good as dead. He read aloud passages from a letter he received today from President Bush, who renewed his pledge "to veto any campaign finance 'reform' legislation which features spending limits or taxpayer financing of Congressional campaigns."
Although it rejected the McConnell proposal, the Senate was unwilling to go further than the leadership bill, rejecting an amendment by calling for the Government to subsidize nearly all of the general election costs for candidates who adhere to spending limits.
The amendment, sponsored by Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, was defeated in a vote of 58 to 39, with supporters picking up only one vote from last year, when an nearly identical proposal was offered.
As the Senate moved closer to a final vote on a Democratic-sponsored bill, lawmakers spent the day trading stories about how they struggled to raise money for their own campaigns and how the race for contributions should be halted.
 
Discounts on Television Time
 The Democratic bill would offer incentives, such as discounts on television time, for candidates who adhere to a spending ceiling on campaigns that would range from $950,000 to $5.5 million, depending on a state's voting age population. The bill would also prohibit political action committees from donating to Congressional campaigns. Under present law, there is no system of voluntary spending limits, and political action committees continue to increasingly donate to Congressional campaigns.
Republicans offered a barrage of amendments today that, while attacking the Democratic bill less directly, would still have made it too unpalatable to pass.
One amendment that drew extensive debate before it was rejected dealt with the sensitive issue of term limitations: Senators would be prohibited from serving more than two consecutive terms if they agreed to limit their spending and accept public funds.
Senator Hank Brown, a Colorado Republican who sponsored the amendment said, "It will create legislators who will be more likely to take firm stands on controversial issues and less likely to cater to special interests."
But Senator Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat, characterized the amendment as nothing less than an assault on the Democratic bill. Supporters of term limits, he declared, have "misdirected their venom, their hostility and their contempt" and instead ought to support changing the campaign finance system.
 
Notice on Campaign Ads
 Another Republican sponsored amendment that was defeated would have required a notice on campaign advertisements that they were "paid for with taxpayer funds."
In addition, the Senate rejected an amendment that would allow challengers to spend 50 percent more than incumbents on their campaigns.
The Senate did approve, by a voice vote, an amendment by Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat, that reduces to $25,000 from $250,000 the amount candidates are allowed to contribute personally or loan their own campaigns. On Tuesday, the Senate also passed an amendment that would prohibit members from supplementing their income with outside speaking fees.
In seeking to unhinge the Democratic bill, Mr. McConnell said his goal had been to insure that "we are not going to fleece the taxpayers to pay for our campaigns at a time when the budget deficit continues to grow, taxes continue to increase, the bill for Desert Storm must be paid and the recessionary economy is cutting into private paychecks."
 
Curbing the Cost of Campaigns
 But Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat and chief sponsor of the Democratic bill, said Mr. McConnell's proposal sought "to penalize people who accept spending limits." He said it was well worth the public expense to reduce the influence of special interests and curb the total cost of campaigns.
Mr. Boren said he was not discouraged by the President's veto threat, saying, "The President himself has also placed this matter on his personal agenda. He clearly understands that the status quo isn't working and something needs to be done."
